fields.headline: Yardstick
fields.trailText: In praising metric, Dr Fookes (Letters, April 20) overlooks the advantages of a system established for peoples' everyday use, over one based on an obscure measurement of the earth. Just compare the ease in pacing out a distance in yards, to the unnatural gait required when using metres.
fields.body:
In praising metric, Dr Fookes (Letters, April 20) overlooks the advantages of a system established for peoples' everyday use, over one based on an obscure measurement of the earth. Just compare the ease in pacing out a distance in yards, to the unnatural gait required when using metres.

Imperial weights and measures allow the expression of any quantity in terms of a reasonably sized number and an easily pronounced unit. People can comprehend the small numbers in 11 stone and six feet better than 70 kilograms or 180 centimetres. For typical purposes, imperial has an appropriate unit, while metric has a mouthful within around a hundredth of the amount desired.

Alex Dicks
Winchester
alex.dicks@chch.ox.ac.uk

webTitle: The poor can bank on us

fields.headline: The poor can bank on us
fields.trailText: It is simply false to claim that the World Bank is further impoverishing people in Zambia and depriving its girls of education (To keep them destitute and starving, April 13). The bank finances 13 projects in Zambia, for a combined sum of close to $500m, with the aim of reducing poverty through investment, lending and aid coordination.
fields.body:
It is simply false to claim that the World Bank is further impoverishing people in Zambia and depriving its girls of education (To keep them destitute and starving, April 13). The bank finances 13 projects in Zambia, for a combined sum of close to $500m, with the aim of reducing poverty through investment, lending and aid coordination. The bank last year loaned over $7bn for health, education, nutrition and social protection around the world, far from the picture George Monbiot seeks to paint. The share of such lending in the bank's overall portfolio has gone up from 5% to 25% since 1980.

According to our recent study Voices of the Poor, which contains the personal views of 60,000 poor men and women in 60 countries on what poverty means for them, people themselves say education is the escape route out of poverty. World Bank president Jim Wolfensohn will be involved in the global Education For All conference in Senegal next week to push harder for greater support and progress in this vital area. The bank will commit itself, along with other partners, to seeing that no country with a viable education strategy will be unable to carry it out for lack of the right help.

In the last couple of years we have been working in Indonesia to provide over 6m scholarships to get children to school; in Mali we have helped create over 300 new community health centres, and in Nicaragua we have supported over 1,200 projects to help rebuild communities after Hurricane Mitch. This is the kind of work we do, day in day out.

Poor countries have to make ends meet. The whole thrust of the bank's comprehensive development approach is to achieve a more effective strategy against poverty, for economic growth and social justice. The World Bank wants to debate how we bolster the fight against poverty. But on the basis of fact, not fiction.

Mats Karlsson
Vice-president, World Bank

fields.headline: Street values
fields.trailText: Your article (Police braced for violence at 'hard core' protests, April 20) contained several errors.
fields.body:
Your article (Police braced for violence at 'hard core' protests, April 20) contained several errors:

1) Guerrilla gardening is not a protest.

2) "Anarchists Federation" should be "Anarchist Federation".

3) May Day is next weekend, not "this weekend".

4) I object to the way you are already linking May Day to violence.

Thomas Buniak
London May Day 2000 Group
www.mayday2000.org.uk

fields.headline: It was murder most foul
fields.trailText: Living in Texas, where any intruder is highly likely to be carrying a gun, Michael W Johnson (Letters, April 21) can be forgiven for overestimating the danger which Tony Martin faced.
fields.body:
Living in Texas, where any intruder is highly likely to be carrying a gun, Michael W Johnson (Letters, April 21) can be forgiven for overestimating the danger which Tony Martin faced. In America, the immediate use of lethal force may be reasonable. Tony Martin could have shouted a warning at the intruders. He could have threatened them with the gun and either detained them until the police arrived or herded them off his property. He could have fired a warning shot. Had he done any of these things and they did not either flee or obey his commands, then he would have been justified in shooting them as he did.

The law is now, as it always has been, that you can use any reasonable force including lethal force to defend your property or yourself. What you cannot do is proceed straight to lethal force for the purposes of punishment rather than self-defence.

Richard Miller
Whitstable, Kent

 Mr Martin was not, in spite of Mr Johnson's fantasies, about to have a non-existent wife, children or family pet attacked. He was simply being robbed. This was frightening and distressing and he was clearly entitled to use reasonable force and, no doubt, when people were still hanged for theft, his actions would have been reasonable.

He was armed with a deadly weapon, the thieves were not. Since it is difficult to use a shotgun with the intention of wounding, it is difficult to avoid the conclusion that the intention was to kill. It is sad Mr Martin was, reportedly, driven to the levels of fear and paranoia that he was, and as a former victim of burglary I can sympathise with his anger, but his actions were out of all proportion to the crime being committed.

Mike Healey
Bradford
mike@atbman.freeserve.co.uk

 I suppose that Michael W Johnson regarded the assassination of President Kennedy and the murder of his alleged assassin before any trial could take place in that law-abiding city of Houston as par for the course.

John Sheeran
Cheltenham

 I find myself equally as shocked and amazed as Mr Johnson, due to the fact that someone can hold his belief in the right to defend property by force of arms, whilst living in a country that suffers one appalling gun tragedy after another (Death mocks Columbine memorial, April 21). School children, in one case as young as six, day traders who happened to have backed losers and lately, senior citizens in sheltered dwellings all going on the rampage with guns and leaving behind dozens of victims and families to pick up the pieces of a constitutional right, gone mad. Only the law can be allowed to punish the criminal actions of others, or we have descended to the criminal's level.

Stephen Durkin
Grimsby, Lincs
sdurkin@breathemail.net

 Michael Johnson provides the perfect illustration of the reasons why I choose to live in the UK rather than Texas.

Kath Checkland
Stockport
kath.checkland@dial.pipex.com

 As a man of similar age to the gentleman in this case, I look forward to further column inches explaining how I might use minimum force when confronted in the dead of night by three younger men who, by their very presence, demonstrate that they have scant respect for any laws that might protect me.

Chris Brown
Shenfield, Essex

 I have a friend who lives in an isolated place in the country. She has been burgled six times. She is 81. She replaces the inevitable broken glass herself, cleans up the mess, and gets on with her busy life.

A Wilks
Whitstable, Kent

fields.headline: Britain, beer and Bollinger Bolsheviks
fields.trailText: In praising the new design of the National Portrait Gallery, Jonathan Glancey (G2, April 17) delights in the removal of the mahogany revolving doors saying that I designed the doors "some 20 years ago - to highlight the building's heavy-handed Victorian design". I removed the original glass revolving doors, because they were out of character with the good Victorian architecture, 10 years ago in the gallery's careful refurbishment.
fields.body:
In praising the new design of the National Portrait Gallery Jonathan Glancey (G2, April 17) delights in the removal of the mahogany revolving doors saying that I designed the doors "some 20 years ago - to highlight the building's heavy-handed Victorian design". I removed the original glass revolving doors, because they were out of character with the good Victorian architecture, 10 years ago in the gallery's careful refurbishment. The museum is listed Grade 1 - clearly the historians did not find the building to be by an obscure architect or "heavy handed". I designed mahogany doors more in keeping with the building. These doors, now ripped out, were probably the last large wooden revolving doors ever made, since the workshops of the specialists who made them were burned down and all their records and equipment destroyed.

However, these historical considerations do not concern any of our museum curators. They, like philistine shopkeepers and brewers, are only concerned in destroying their buildings to keep up with what they believe are the latest fashions.

Roderick Gradidge
London

 Francis Wheen is spot-on (G2, April 19). The concept of hair-shirt socialism is a peculiarly British one. Try telling a French, Italian or Spanish socialist it is unacceptable to drink wine or champagne and they would know your brain had been addled by drink. But there is one aspect of this heresy which, as a paid-up Bollinger Bolshevik, always puzzles me. Why is it that otherwise sensible members of the left accuse me of selling out by drinking wine, even from a co-operative, but are happy to pour beer down their throats and money into the coffers of the breweries, those well known defenders of socialism?

Liz Turner
London

 How absurd it is to suggest there is any conflict between the Institute of Directors and Business for Sterling on the euro (Directors split over euro, April 20). Neither have said that we should rule out membership forever. Both represent the majority business view on this issue which is that, for the foreseeable future, joining the euro would be against our economic interests because the costs outweigh the benefits. When both the chambers of commerce and CBI have decided to stop campaigning for the euro, it would be ridiculous for the IoD to take their place - particularly given the concerns about economic divergence.

James Staughton
Managing director, St Austell Brewery

 Wasn't Michael Caine reported to be a fan of Mrs T (Caine mutiny, April 14)? If he wants to be appreciated, why does he not sponsor a few drama scholarships? Perhaps he is ignored in Britain because he has ignored and shown little love of Britain.

B Varley
Keighley

fields.headline: Dennis Cambell
fields.standfirst: The sailor who invented the modern aircraft carrier flight deck
fields.trailText: In 1951, Rear-Admiral Dennis Cambell, who has died aged 92, came up with one of those many British inventions that had to be taken up abroad before their value was appreciated at home. It was the angled flight-deck on aircraft carriers, which saved many lives and millions of pounds.
fields.body:
In 1951, Rear-Admiral Dennis Cambell, who has died aged 92, came up with one of those many British inventions that had to be taken up abroad before their value was appreciated at home. It was the angled flight-deck on aircraft carriers, which saved many lives and millions of pounds.

At that time Cambell was in an administrative backwater at the Ministry of Supply, as a naval air liaison officer. Previously, carriers had to launch and land aircraft with catapults and arrester wires, while other planes waited at the end of the only deck. The damage when an aircraft failed to take off or land properly, as often happened, and ploughed into waiting planes, was very high. The Admiralty ignored him until US Navy officers showed keen interest in 1952. The first British experiments were made, with painted white lines, on the carrier HMS Triumph. But it was the Americans who fitted the first real angled deck on their carrier, USS Antietam, which, in 1955, let British Fleet Air Arm pilots have a go after three years of completely successful trials. The Royal Navy eventually took up the idea, which gave aircraft a clear run for take-off and landing. An incoming plane could abort a bad landing and go round again without endangering aircraft drawn up on deck. Only the British Harrier jump-jet, with its ability to land vertically, made it possible to dispense with the angled deck on the three Invincible-class carriers now in Royal Navy service.

Britain consistently led the way in carrier innovations, starting with the first flat-top in 1918, but a measure of the country's fateful lack of interest in naval aviation was the fact that Cambell had to pay for his first private flying lessons with money borrowed from his father, before unfashionably volunteering for official training with the Royal Air Force, getting his wings in 1931. At this time relatively elderly American naval officers as senior as captains (and future fleet admirals) - Ernest J King and William F Halsey - were lining up for pilot-training to qualify for command of carriers.

Cambell left Westminster School at 18, and then joined the Navy as a late entrant in 1925. Three years later, when his ship was refitting, he took his first flying lessons while on leave. He served in biplane fighters on Furious and Glorious, both of which had been designed as super-cruisers and converted to carriers.

Six months before the second world war broke out in 1939, he rose to command a squadron aboard the new carrier Ark Royal. In September, before the war was a fortnight old, he led two other pilots into an attack on Fritz Lemp's submarine U30, which had sunk the liner Athenia on the first day of hostilities and had then been sighted shelling another ship in the North Sea. But these were early days in airborne anti-submarine warfare (ASW).

Cambell's colleagues were forced to ditch when their tailplanes were blown off by the premature blast from their own bombs. The unscathed U-boat took them prisoner as Cambell escaped.

He won the DSC in 1940 for his work with Ark Royal (sunk in 1941), but had to stop flying because of arthritis, mysteriously cured when his appendix had to be removed in 1941. He served successfully as a test pilot until made Commander (Air) aboard HMS Argus, the oldest British carrier, heavily escorted while ferrying fighters to besieged Malta in 1942.

But only a few months later, he was reassigned as a test pilot after two others had died on trials of the experimental Blackburn Firebrand carrier fighter. He managed to fly one from HMS Illustrious, but the design was abandoned.

Cambell's career continued ashore with a posting to Washington as naval representative on the British Air Commission in the US, acquiring American planes for British service. It was only after two post-war years at the Admiralty that Cambell went back to sea as commander (air) on the carrier Glory in the Far East. This was followed by a very different sea-going job, commanding a corvette used for ASW training in home waters, and then came the Ministry of Supply.

After more than five years in various staff posts, Cambell was delighted in 1955 to take command of the brand-new carrier Ark Royal, 50,000 tons and with angled deck, the climax of 35 years in the Navy. Yet, after only 18 months, Cambell returned to the Admiralty, first as director of naval air warfare and, finally, as flag officer, flying training. When he retired in 1960, he was appointed Companion of the Order of the Bath - and also received the American Legion of Merit for his simple, but revolutionary, idea of the angled flight deck.

In retirement, Admiral Cambell worked as a director in helicopter sales before starting a travel agency for holidays in Turkey. He is survived by his wife Dorothy, whom he married in 1933, and their two daughters.

 Rear-Admiral Dennis Royle Farquharson Cambell, sailor, born November 13 1907; died April 6 2000

fields.headline: Bill Dean
fields.standfirst: From Kes to Brookside Close: a late-starting actor with a gift for projecting the simple truth
fields.trailText: Brookside's champion griper, Harry Cross, played by the actor Bill Dean, who has died aged 78, elevated neighbourly nosiness into an art form. From 1983 to 1990, Harry's flat but penetrating tones, projected from beneath the heaviest pair of specs on television, brought to life the ultimate whinger without whom no close could be complete. Bill Dean was an acting late-starter, but he took an attitude to life that was second nature to him and made it into a dramatic force in many television and film roles.
fields.body:
Brookside's champion griper, Harry Cross, played by the actor Bill Dean, who has died aged 78, elevated neighbourly nosiness into an art form. From 1983 to 1990, Harry's flat but penetrating tones, projected from beneath the heaviest pair of specs on television, brought to life the ultimate whinger without whom no close could be complete. Bill Dean was an acting late-starter, but he took an attitude to life that was second nature to him and made it into a dramatic force in many television and film roles.

Born in Everton, Dean worked variously as a tram driver, pipe fitter, insurance agent, ship's steward and docker by day, while playing the clubs as a stand-up comic at night. War service in the RAF from 1940 took him all over the Middle East, and by the time of his big dramatic break, in 1969, he was a local government officer in Liverpool. He gave up the day job when Ken Loach cast him in Neville Smith's BBC play, The Golden Vision.

Smith came to him again for his crime comedy film Gumshoe (1972), with Albert Finney and Billie Whitelaw; Whitelaw and Dean also appeared in the mystery Night Watch (1973), with Elizabeth Taylor. Dean thoroughly approved of Taylor for being "good at get ting a round in": that counted a lot for a man who in real life, as Brookside's Sinbad, actor Mickey Starke, put it, was "always happy as long as he had a scotch. He'd ring me up at two or three o'clock in the morning from some pub to tell me a joke. He always wanted to be first with the jokes."

Dean's other television credits included The Liver Birds, Dixon of Dock Green, Z Cars, Coronation Street, The Sweeney and When The Boat Comes In.

His wife predeceased him, but he is survived by his sons Peter and David, and by his daughter Diane.

Ken Loach writes:

Neville Smith's The Golden Vision followed an unusual format for a TV play - it was a documentary about Everton football club and its star player Alex Young, combined with a fictional account of a group of supporters - and we wanted to find new actors to match the novelty of the style. So Ernie Mack, a booking agent for social and working men's clubs, introduced us to a whole group of performers including Billy Dean (as he was always known to me), and it was immediately clear that he was ideal for a leading comic role.

Later that year, Billy was a grumpy fish and chip shop man in Kes, and in 1971 another television film by Smith, After A Lifetime, gave Billy scope to develop the lugubrious, deadpan manner which endeared him to audiences. His exchanges with Johnny Gee exuded unsurprised exasperation, notably during an attempt by the pair of them to manoeuvre a carpet across a road in order to lend greater respectability to a family funeral.

In 1972, his playing of routine domestic misery gave way to a deeply realised sense of failure in David Mercer's Family Life. As a man who has married above himself socially and fathered a schizophrenic daughter, Billy gave a moving performance of great sincerity, leaving generations of Continental film students puzzled as to why they had not encountered the actor elsewhere. They recognise the integrity and authenticity of an actor whom I always found to be rock-solid, unfailingly reliable, and possessed of a straightness that made you smile when he looked at you, simply because he made you recognise the truth.

Mark Lawson writes:

The characterisation in soap operas is often rather broad, and Harry Cross advertised in his surname the main quality he was supposed to represent. It was his job to be cross. His situation in Brookside Close - sharing a house with a male lodger -was fairly shamelessly taken from The Odd Couple, and Bill Dean was charged with being a Scouse Walter Matthau. A third element to the casting was that Brookside - created for the innovatory Channel 4 Four - had the youngest cast of any British soap. Dean was one of a small number of veterans who were cast to provide the sense of past (and geriatric comedy) which had been accumulated slowly in Coronation Street.

Essentially, except in the sequences about his wife's death and his brief return to the Close last year with Alzheimer's, Cross was comic relief, the pedantic fist-shaker whose love of gossip gave the scriptwriters a useful way of introducing the intrigues which became more sensational later in the series.

It was greatly to Dean's credit that he brought depth to this stock role. He carried a real sense of Liverpool's past. Loach favoured actors from real life rather than drama school, and Dean had that knack of acting that seemed like merely being. The gift was still there in Brookside.

Bill Dean was an acting late-starter, but he took an attitude to life that was second nature to him and made it into a dramatic force in many television and film roles. Born in Everton, Dean worked variously as a tram driver, pipe fitter, insurance agent, ship's steward and docker by day, while playing the clubs as a stand-up comic at night. War service in the RAF from 1940 took him all over the Middle East, and by the time of his big dramatic break, in 1969, he was a local government officer in Liverpool. He gave up the day job when Ken Loach cast him in Neville Smith's BBC play, The Golden Vision. Smith came to him again for his crime comedy film Gumshoe (1972), with Albert Finney and Billie Whitelaw; Whitelaw and Dean also appeared in the mystery Night Watch (1973), with Elizabeth Taylor. Dean thoroughly approved of Taylor for being "good at get ting a round in": that counted a lot for a man who in real life, as Brookside's Sinbad, actor Mickey Starke, put it, was "always happy as long as he had a scotch. He'd ring me up at two or three o'clock in the morning from some pub to tell me a joke. He always wanted to be first with the jokes." Dean's other television credits included The Liver Birds, Dixon of Dock Green, Z Cars, Coronation Street, The Sweeney and When The Boat Comes In. Later that year, Billy was a grumpy fish and chip shop man in Kes, and in 1971 another television film by Smith, After A Lifetime, gave Billy scope to develop the lugubrious, deadpan manner which endeared him to audiences. His exchanges with Johnny Gee exuded unsurprised exasperation, notably during an attempt by the pair of them to manoeuvre a carpet across a road in order to lend greater respectability to a family funeral. In 1972, his playing of routine domestic misery gave way to a deeply realised sense of failure in David Mercer's Family Life. As a man who has married above himself socially and fathered a schizophrenic daughter, Billy gave a moving performance of great sincerity, leaving generations of Continental film students puzzled as to why they had not encountered the actor elsewhere. They recognise the integrity and authenticity of an actor whom I always found to be rock-solid, unfailingly reliable, and possessed of a straightness that made you smile when he looked at you, simply because he made you recognise the truth. fields.headline: Terminal decline
fields.standfirst:
It is not just the Tories but activism as well

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Three years into a Labour government, the troops are not there and nor is the money. The Times claimed yesterday that the party's membership has fallen to around 325,000 - 25,000 less than when William Hague became leader.
fields.body:
In the dying days of the Major era a senior Tory was asked if he knew how his party, afflicted with an ageing and dwindling membership, might be saved. "Yes I do," he replied. "Don't quote me, but it's called a Labour government." The calculation was simple: subjection to life under Labour would rally the troops and get the party's traditional benefactors investing once more in the hope of escape. But none of it happened. Three years into a Labour government, the troops are not there and nor is the money. The Times claimed yesterday that the party's membership has fallen to around 325,000 - 25,000 less than when William Hague became leader. Whatever the truth, one thing is clear: the recovery has been nowhere near as robust as the senior Tory predicted and has fallen even more calamitously short of Mr Hague's prediction when he took over that he would soon have it up to the million mark.

In circumstances like these the party leader inevitably gets saddled with most of the blame. In some senses that is unfair. From the start, rightly concluding that people today are unlikely to stay in a party which treats them as subservient lackeys, he tried to alleviate some of the traditional impotence of Conservative rank and file members. But what he has utterly failed to do is to instil in its old campaigners the sense that it is worth going on, and to create for potential adherents the happy expectation of a worthwhile adventure, with glory, and possibly jobs, at the end of the road. The million mark has a special significance for Conservatives: it is what the party achieved in the heyday of Margaret Thatcher. Like her or not, she had a project and left no one in doubt about where the party was going. Mr Hague has done nothing like that.

Yet simply comparing today with the party's great yesterdays misses a crucial dimension. The old spirit of fixed allegiance is flaking away. In our shop-around society, the notion of investing near-permanent trust in a single party is dying; and with it, the kind of commitment which active party membership must entail. Labour, once the euphoria of May 1997 began to fade, started losing members too. If Tony Blair, the nearest thing to a miracle worker in the politics of our era, cannot keep his supporters in good heart, what hope is there for a far less charismatic figure like Hague? And that is not to suggest that installing Michael Portillo would get the juices going again. The days when party politics engaged the attention year after year of anything more than a small minority are over. Mr Hague's blunder has been not so much the performance as the reckless promise he made at the outset.

fields.headline: Pay better teachers more
fields.standfirst:
Skills-linked pay does not erode teamwork

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The best text for the opening day of the biggest teaching union's conference is the closing speech by the leader of the third biggest union on Thursday. Peter Smith warned his members of the danger of them being left in the wings "while the real drama of policy-making occurs somewhere else".
fields.body:
The best text for the opening day of the biggest teaching union's conference is the closing speech by the leader of the third biggest union on Thursday. Peter Smith warned his members of the danger of them being left in the wings "while the real drama of policy-making occurs somewhere else". He spoke of his "persistent concern that teacher organisations are busy writing themselves out of the script". There was a need for all six teacher unions to find more effective ways of tapping the true feelings of all their members, rather than just the activists. How was the profession going to attract the new blood that it needed if every Easter, in a succession of teacher conferences extensively covered by the media, all that emerged was a negative picture of whinge and protest?

What applies to Mr Smith's more moderate Association of Teachers and Lecturers (ATL), has even more relevance for the much more militant National Union of Teachers (NUT) meeting in Harrogate today. The ATL's main concern was resisting "fast track" promotion for bright graduate recruits, but the NUT is bent on opposing performance pay. Absurdly, it will be debating a variety of industrial actions - including one-day strikes - which it wants to apply against the extra £2,000 a year which ministers will begin paying some of its members from September.

Teachers are right to emphasise the importance of cooperation and collaboration in creating a constructive school ethos. A staff room in which the emphasis is on support and partnership provides a healthy counter-culture to the sharp-elbowed me-first competitive working environment advocated by some. But they are wrong to believe that performance pay erodes team work. There are plenty of differentials in me dia, sport, medicine and finance, where team work remains essential. Performance pay has not hurt Manchester United or the media. Moreover, what the opponents of performance-related pay ignore, is the resentment which its absence can generate. What is fair about a dedicated and exceptionally gifted teacher receiving the same pay - or even less if the teacher is young - than a clapped-out, clock-watching, uncreative time-server?

Ministers were right to modernise pay. It is wrong that the current ceiling for classroom teachers stops at £24,000. About 200,000 of the 450,000 teachers in England and Wales are stuck there. At least half are ultimately expected to get the £2,000 rise and a new pay scale climbing to £30,000. Sensibly, other unions are seeking ways of improving the assessment procedure, rather than resisting it. The NUT seems intent on ending up "in a losing clinch with a disappearing past". The union was right, 100 years ago, to fight the Victorian payment-by-results scheme, but the new plan could not be more different. Ministers are not talking about docking pay, but dramatically increasing it.

Similarly, the "fast track" for bright new recruits is needed if teaching is to fill the vacancies which are going to occur. Over half the profession is over 45. Within 15 years they will have left teaching. New recruits will be needed for middle and senior management jobs. New young blood should bring a fresh vigour to teaching and end the rule of the gerontocracy. Old NUT and ATL dinosaurs may dislike this, but changing the culture is vital. There has been a disastrous drop in applications for postgraduate teaching courses this year. Performance pay and fast track hold the key to reversing this dangerous new trend.

fields.headline: Clinton questioned over funding abuse
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: President Clinton came face to face with federal inquisitors yet again in a Good Friday evidence-giving session in the oval office, the White House revealed last night.
fields.body:
President Clinton came face to face with federal inquisitors yet again in a Good Friday evidence-giving session in the oval office, the White House revealed last night.

Mr Clinton was questioned about continuing suspicions that he broke campaign fundraising laws during the 1996 presidential contest, allegations which he has been unable to shake off since they surfaced in the months after his re-election.

Vice-President Al Gore also agreed to be interviewed about his part in the inquiry, the White House said. Mr Gore was questioned earlier this week, though the fact only became known yesterday. "The president and the vice-president cooperated fully with the taskforce and voluntarily agreed to be interviewed this week," the White House said.

The federal investigation of possible fundraising abuses in the Clinton-Gore campaign was set up by the attorney general, Janet Reno. A succession of investigations has taken place into various aspects of the allegations, but no charges have been brought against either of the men.

The fact that the issue will not go away is potentially more damaging for Mr Gore than for the president, in view of this year's presidential contest. Mr Gore has been unable to shake off charges that he raised illegal donations during a visit to a Buddhist temple in Los Angeles in 1996.

A former adviser to Mr Gore was found guilty of breaches of campaign law arising from the visit to the temple earlier this year.

fields.headline: Patients and players link
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
www.planetmedica.com
fields.trailText: Planet Medica aims to become the Healtheon-Web MD of Europe.
fields.body:
Planet Medica aims to become the Healtheon-Web MD of Europe.

Founder Eric Souetre, a qualified commercial airline pilot and psychiatrist with an MBA and a PhD in neuroscience, says he is building a European "infomediary for patients, payers and providers".

GPs are at the centre of the business model because their clinical decisions affect 80% of costs, he says.

Planet Medica's portal plans to electronically link providers such as hospitals, labs and specialists with patients and doctors.

Mr Souetre claims it will help connect a fragmented market comprising thousands of buyers and sellers.

Multiple revenue streams have been identified from sources including transaction fees, commissions and advertising. The company forecasts revenues of euro 1m - euro 2m this year, rising to euro 30m (£17.8m) by 2002, when the company is expected to break even. A euro 25m second round of fundraising is planned.

Planet Medica is based in Belgium with offices in Britain, France and Germany and plans to expand into Italy, Spain and the Netherlands by the end of the year. Partnerships are planned with the major internet service providers and pharmaceutical companies.

Its target customers are typically women aged 25-55. Competitors include NetDoctor.co.uk and the Nutrition & Health Company.

"We have to be pan-European to gain economies of scale," Mr Souetre said.

"We can replicate our websites country by country. Speed to market and quality of execution are more important than ever."

fields.headline: Digital explosion
fields.standfirst: Telephone number telephone numbers
fields.trailText: Millions of telephone subscribers find themselves today with a wholly unwanted Easter present: a brand new number. Unrest is probably greatest in London, where people remember being told by the authorities when 0171 and 0181 codes were introduced that this system would stick for the foreseeable future.
fields.body:
Millions of telephone subscribers find themselves today with a wholly unwanted Easter present: a brand new number. Unrest is probably greatest in London, where people remember being told by the authorities when 0171 and 0181 codes were introduced that this system would stick for the foreseeable future. But now Londoners have to memorise eight digits to follow the initial drum roll of 020, a much more taxing process than trying to remember seven. The rest of the country, much of which has been struggling with eight-digit numbers or more for ages, will regard such complaints as a characteristic example of metropolitan moaning, while those with mobile phones will also have had ample practice in dealing with interminable numbers. None of which will make the chorus of complaint any less plangent.

As Matthew Engel recalled in the Guardian on Tuesday, it used to be so much easier. A London telephonic address consisted of a four-digit number preceded by three letters derived from some tasteful local association: a hero born in the neighbourhood, perhaps, or a poet who wrote some notable work in one of its coppices. But here, perhaps, is a useful way out for those who cannot remember their numbers. Letters are creeping back on to the faces of phones. With a little ingenuity, you may be able to shape a mnemonic out of your numbers. The Guardian's London number, for instance, becomes 020-7278 2332. If people choose to memorise 7278 as, for instance, Rapt, which is how we hope our readers may be when they think of us, or even Sapt, the name of the honest colonel who serves his king so faithfully in that stirring epic, The Prisoner of Zenda, we shall have no complaint.

fields.headline: UK tourist murdered in Cyprus
fields.trailText: A 41-year-old British tourist has been murdered while on holiday in Cyprus.
fields.body:
A 41-year-old British tourist has been murdered while on holiday in Cyprus.

Graham Mills, a chartered accountant from Tring, Hertfordshire, was found dead outside a bar in the coastal resort of Limassol in the early hours of Thursday morning. Relatives yesterday flew to the Mediterranean island to identify the body.

Cypriot police said Mr Mills had died as a result of multiple head injuries, which they believe were caused by a crowbar or similar blunt instrument. The weapon has not been found.

A murder inquiry has been launched and police are reportedly looking for two men who were seen drinking with Mr Mills on the evening before he was killed.

Police have not established a motive for the murder, but have ruled out robbery as Mr Mills was found to be wearing jewellery and carrying money in his pockets.

The victim was only identified after police combed hotels in Limassol. He had been reported missing on Wednesday afternoon.

A spokesman for the Foreign Office stressed that such incidents were rare.

He said British officials on the island would give every assistance to the Cypriot police in their hunt for the killers.

The Foreign Office is arranging for Mr Mills's body to be flown back to Britain. Martin Deacon

webTitle: Hell is other people at 30,000 feet

fields.headline: Hell is other people at 30,000 feet
fields.trailText: When Irish jokes should be French
fields.body:
I had a nine-hour flight back from the US, on a packed 747. It wasn't bad; the food was almost edible, one of the 11 TV channels in my economy seatback showed the excellent Being John Malkovich, and I find that if you speak to the stewards firmly but politely, you can be awash with booze from an early stage.

The problem was my fellow-passengers. I was behind the world's tallest Dad, who I knew would tip his seat back as far and as fast as it would go, which of course he did, almost spilling Bloody Mary, red wine and chicken in salsa on to my lap.

He was accompanied by the world's tallest mum, a woman who spent much of the flight shouting at her children in an upper-class English rasp, waking me up at one point with the cry: "Oh, do you want your fleece or your gilet, Daisy? And no you can't have Larry, please don't be so stupid!"

On my right was an American working a laptop so massive that, for him to use the mouse, it had to overhang the tray table by a foot or so. He was evidently using the time between Denver and Gatwick to design a baseball stadium. The temptation to lean an inch over and say: "That looks an interesting key, mind if I press it?" was great but resisted.

The nice Scottish woman on my left could apparently only get to sleep by listening to very loud rock CDs on her Walkman. So she snoozed happily through the Chucka-choo-choo, chucka-choo-choo" while I squirmed with repressed rage, especially when she actually woke up to put a new CD in.

None of these people were thoughtless yobs. I'm sure that if I'd met any of them at a party I'd have liked them, with the exception of the shouting mum.

They probably loathed me for the way I glowered at them, and left my reading light on throughout most of the night.

My only consolation was that, the first time I crossed the Atlantic by myself, in 1973, the return air ticket cost six weeks' wages. Through shopping around early, my ticket to Denver cost less than two days' pay.

 While I was waiting to speak in Colorado at one of the ferocious panels on Ireland which I mentioned last week, there was a short delay and I thought I'd fill in with one or two of the jokes I'd heard at a dinner the previous night. The dinner is hosted each year by Roger Ebert - probably the best-known American film critic these days - and traditionally ends with the telling at length of dirty jokes to the mixed company.

As I launched into the only one I could possibly re-tell, I realised with horror that it was an Irish joke. So I rapidly flipped the nationalities round. A Frenchman, an Irishman and an Englishman are boasting about which country is the best to drink in.

The Frenchman says he knows a cafe where if you buy a glass of wine, you get a second glass free.

"That's nothing," says the Irishman, "I know a bar where if you buy a pint of Guinness, you get two pints free."

"My dear chaps." says the Englishman, "I know a pub where you get your first drink free, your second free and your third drink free. Then you get laid."

"Zut!" says the Frenchman. "And 'ave you been to thees place?" "No," says the Englishman, "but my sister has."

Doesn't quite work, does it? In fact Irish people tell Kerryman jokes, just as the French tell Belgian jokes, Indians tell Parsee jokes, and Mancunians tell scouser jokes. Now an article by Frank Buttle, analysing Irish idioms in the work of Frank McCourt, and reported in Prospect magazine, suggests that the Irish reputation for stupidity may derive from the structure of their language.

"If you translate Irish into English but retain the Irish word order, you often end up with a question rather than a statement... asked by an English boss where his shovel is, the Irish speaker might have pointed to the object and said 'Is it there?' giving the impression that he wasn't sure what a shovel was."

 I heartily recommend Cor, Blimey (ITV Monday night). It's the story of the affair between Barbara Windsor and Sid James, acted out against the background of various Carry On films. The actors are spookily like the other actors they're playing, so much so that you know instantly which is which. Oddly enough, the script doesn't include a line I heard from Barbara Windsor on the only, brief, occasion I had met her. Sid James had been pursuing her for months without success, until one day they went for lunch. "I dreamed about you last night," he said. "Did yer?" she asked. "Nah, you wouldn't let me." She was so tickled by this quip that she slept with him that day.

I only met Kenneth Williams once, too, at a TV celebration of Round the Horne. He told a story about going with Maggie Smith for an after-theatre supper with Princess Margaret and her then beau, Roddy Llewellyn. At one point someone mentioned a famous female novelist.

There was a long and difficult silence, broken by Llewellyn saying in a grave and sonorous voice: "Her Royal Highness does not like her. She called Her Royal Highness 'a stupid cow'."

Williams's description of the two actors desperately trying to contain their laughter was almost as funny as the line itself, and I laughed immoderately myself.

 More than a year ago I wrote about the pompous work Sir Vidia's Shadow, in which Paul Theroux complains about how horrid his old friend VS Naipaul had been to him, as if the rest of us cared. fields.headline: Underside
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Richard Handover, chief executive of WH Smith, has watched his group's share price halve in the past 12 months as the City's hottest analysts have decided the nation's favourite purveyor of pens and student pads is not a swinging dot.com stock but merely, er, WH Smith. Does he care? Not a jot, even though the fall has slashed his potential personal fortune by leaving many of his share options underwater. The reason for this positively hippy-ish detachment from the, like, material world? "I was in the Paddington train crash," he explained. "And when I was lying in a heap of rubble on the floor I looked up and saw the sky and just thought I would never worry about our share price again." One of the grateful non-dead.
fields.body:
Richard Handover, chief executive of WH Smith, has watched his group's share price halve in the past 12 months as the City's hottest analysts have decided the nation's favourite purveyor of pens and student pads is not a swinging dot.com stock but merely, er, WH Smith. Does he care? Not a jot, even though the fall has slashed his potential personal fortune by leaving many of his share options underwater. The reason for this positively hippy-ish detachment from the, like, material world? "I was in the Paddington train crash," he explained. "And when I was lying in a heap of rubble on the floor I looked up and saw the sky and just thought I would never worry about our share price again." One of the grateful non-dead.

 On the theme of long-ago rock bands, Bank of England deputy governor Mervyn King spoke recently in Wolverhampton to bosses of Britain's hard-hit metal-bashing industries. Attempting to reach out and feel their pain, he told them he too was a boy from the West Midlands, and quoted Noddy Holder: "You can take the boy out of the Black Country but you can't take the Black Country out of the boy." Challenged on this topic on his flight back from the IMF meeting in Washington this week, our friend Mervyn admitted he had dropped all attribution to the Slade vocalist from his remarks, chiefly because he reckoned none of the suits present would have heard of him (Noddy, that is, not Mervyn). So does the Bank-man listen to the Banks's-drinking Mercian bluesmen from yesteryear? "I listen to them between the Mozart and the Beethoven." Mama, we're all evasive now.

 Elsewhere in the Washington pow-wow, Gordon Brown was, unwittingly, sitting at the base of a pyramid of crazed gambling at the Washington summit. First off, the British economics correspondents arranged a $5-a-pop sweep on how many times the second lord of the Treasury would use the word "stability" during his post-G7 press conference on Saturday night. The winner must remain anonymous, to comply with strict US gaming regulations, despite being Robert Miller, economics editor of the Express. But, as the man from Blackfriars Bridge pocketed his 45 bucks, the Treasury's hit squad was paying out the winner of its own little wager, that on which word the newsmen would pick for their Brown bet. The champ, we understand, was the chancellor's special adviser, Shriti Vadera. Anyone have Sergeant Bilko's mobile number?

 Back home, Fred Goodwin, nicknamed "Fred the Shred" and chief executive of Royal Bank of Scotland, has big problems on his mind now he has bought NatWest. Improving the coffee at the Lothbury headquarters of NatWest for one (see previous Undersides on the conspicuously vile machine-vended hot drinks on offer inside the bank as it sought in vain to persuade investors how lean and mean it was). He has also to work out what to do with NatWest's art collection when the door closes on the Lothbury headquarters in June. He wants to put it on display. But where, given that cost-cutting means there will be fewer and fewer walls with enough space? Selling off Lothbury means he has also to decide what to do with NatWest's wine cellar; it appears that Sir David Rowland, the former NatWest chairman, failed to drink it all as he promised. No wonder he lost the bid battle.

 Finally, Matt Barrett, the millionaire "bargain" chief of big bad Barclays bank, was - as predicted here - mauled by the Treasury select committee of MPs this week. Surrounded by a bodyguard of PR advisers and journalists, Mr Barrett put on a brave face after his recent PR disasters but kept his warmest welcome for fellow Canadian Bill Dalton, also there to give evidence in his capacity as chief executive of HSBC's UK bank, formerly Midland. He jumped up from his seat outside the committee room and shook Mr Dalton by two hands, à la mode Premier Major. Strangely, neither stayed to press the flesh with Don Cruickshank, their tormentor turned last (we bet) boss of the bourse, who was also present. Funny that.

fields.headline: Pensioned off
fields.standfirst: The old are no less concerned about the environment, globalisation, education and other contemporary issues than the young
fields.trailText: The old are no less concerned about the environment, globalisation, education and other contemporary issues than the young
fields.body:
I don't think the government will want to put me down yet. Although I am embarking on my seventh decade of life, I am still in pretty good health and churning out stuff for the newspapers. If I happen to get ill and go to hospital, there should still be a sporting chance that I won't be designated "not for resuscitation" - a phrase which, according to Age Concern (an organisation with which I increasingly empathise), the National Health Service has been writing on the hospital notes of a number of elderly patients lately.

But it is unfortunate that reports of such callousness in the NHS should have appeared in the media on the same day as reports that the government has written off pensioners as not worth cultivating politically because they tend to be Conservative and "racist". One begins to tremble slightly. The likelihood of being labelled "not for resuscitation" must surely increase if the government doesn't consider one to be of any value as electoral fodder. If we all promise to vote for New Labour at the next election, do you think we may be spared?

According to the Sunday Times, New Labour's disillusionment with the old stems from the fact that they didn't play their part in the party's landslide victory of 1997. In fact, only 34% of pensioners voted Labour in that election, while 44% voted Tory. This was hardly an improvement on the 1992 election, when the equivalent figures were 36% Labour and 47% Tory. Pensioners either didn't notice, didn't care about, or didn't like the Labour Party's efforts to re-invent itself as a party dedicated to free-market principles.

The view that pensioners are "predominantly Conservative" and "often racist" was attributed by the Sunday Times to Clive Soley, the chairman of the Parliamentary Labour Party, though he has subsequently "clarified" the remark. Peter Mandelson has also denied saying at an election strategy meeting that there was "no mileage" to be had from pensioners, and that Labour instead should be targeting "aspirational" voters. But the impression remains that Labour considers pensioners a bit of a lost cause - people who whine about their pensions, blame the government for giving money to asylum seekers instead of them, and resolutely refuse to be grateful for all the help they are given.

But how can 10 million people possibly be stereotyped in this way? Everybody has just one seamless life that cannot be split into segments. Most people are much the same at the end of their lives as they were at the beginning. Their characters may change with experience, but usually not much. Most idealists in youth remain idealists until they die. Most cynics remain cynics. If some people who used to vote Labour have stopped doing so in old age, this is as likely to be because the party has changed as because they have.

When New Labour talks about "aspirational" voters, it doesn't mean people with higher aspirations for their country or for the good of the world, but people young enough to have higher aspirations for themselves - to become dot.com millionaires, for example. The old, in my experience, are no less concerned about the environment, genetically-modified foods, globalisation, education and other contemporary issues than the young are, and they are probably (though in this case for selfish reasons) much more concerned about health care. If Tony Blair cannot get them to vote for his party, it is probably because they don't think he is doing enough about these things.

My mother-in-law, at 85, is no less a campaigner on the environment, and especially against nuclear power, than she ever was. Her elder sister is still campaigning against the export of live animals to Europe. My late mother was in her 90s before she stopped writing letters to General Pinochet asking him to stop killing and torturing people.

Of course, some people become bitter in old age, usually because they resent being old. But others remain "aspirational" until they die. Obviously, the culture of youth is not very appealing to pensioners because it is specifically designed to exclude them. One wonders, for example, what older readers of the Daily Telegraph will have thought when they opened their paper this week to find an entire page devoted to a "boob job", a detailed personal account of a breast-implant operation. They must have felt that it was their paper, not they, that had changed.

But it is also an error to stereotype the young by assuming that they all share the same values and are interested in the same things. There are, alas, plenty of racists among the young. There are also plenty of young people who reject trendiness. The 8,000 Christian evangelists who gave a rapturous reception to William Hague last Sunday when he spoke about family values at their "Spring Harvest" festival included few pensioners. Young, old, and middle-aged, we are all as varied as can be.

fields.headline: 'Dire staff shortage' at Heathrow control
fields.trailText: Political uncertainty over the part-privatisation of air traffic control intensified yesterday with disclosures of a "dire" situation at Heathrow.
fields.body:
Political uncertainty over the part-privatisation of air traffic control intensified yesterday with disclosures of a "dire" situation at Heathrow.

They come from controllers at the London airport, who say their tower is badly understaffed, resulting "in tremendous problems in congestion across northern Europe". The shortage has led to a drastic amendment to flow rates of inbound aircraft.

The controllers' chairman, Angus McCormick, said Heathrow required 66 staff but had been down to 52; on some watches only three of five operational positions in the tower had been been staffed. Writing in Log, the journal of the airline pilots' union, Mr McCormick blamed management for "taking commercial risks with staffing because of the commercial pressures they are under".

Government whips are concerned that a revolt by Labour MPs during the report stage of the transport bill in the Commons next month could damage the privatisation.

Mr McCormick said it took between eight and 14 months live training to qualify at Heathrow. "This has increased significantly over recent years due to the vastly increasing traffic complexity. Staffing is not something that can be changed overnight."

He said controllers felt that training new staff was "virtually impossible because it was too busy".

Mr McCormick stressed that the shortages were due to preparations to open the air traffic control centre at Swanwick in Hampshire. It should have opened two years ago, but because of computer problems its opening had been retimed for the winter of 2002.

A spokesman for the national air traffic service accepted there were staff shortages at Heathrow, but said safety of passengers and staff was never put at risk. Controllers always limited the aircraft allowed in air space if they faced temporary problems of understaffing.

webTitle: If you're seeking safety,  look here

fields.headline: If you're seeking safety,  look here
fields.trailText: Got your fingers burned over the past few weeks? Thinking that maybe the stock market is not for you after all? Before you abandon ship and start putting your savings in shoe boxes under the bed, consider protected funds.
fields.body:
Got your fingers burned over the past few weeks? Thinking that maybe the stock market is not for you after all? Before you abandon ship and start putting your savings in shoe boxes under the bed, consider protected funds.

By capping the amount by which your investment can fall and rise, these funds provide a way of profiting from the stock market when it's up and not losing too much when it's down.

Consider, for example, HSBC Asset Management's protected technology fund Safety.net, launched last week. HSBC guarantees that if you invest in the fund, which is linked to 20 leading global technology stocks, and the market falls, 90% of your capital will be protected. So £100 in the fund will never fall beyond £90, no matter how much shares plummet.

If shares rise, your investment will also rise, but only by the average amount of the share rise over a quarter - not the full amount.

The downside, then, is that if shares soar, you will not reap all the rewards. But the upside is that, no matter how far they fall, you will get at least 90% of your investment back. The funds have various restrictions. To invest in HSBC's Safety.net - which can be done through a Maxi Isa - you would need to make a minimum deposit of £3,000 before June 1 and, ideally, leave the money in the fund for its three-year life. Quarterly returns on the portfolio will be averaged at the end of the three years to calculate a final return.

You can take your money out before the three years are up, but you would lose your 90% protection -so it wouldn't be advisable to do this if your investment had fallen below that mark.

On the other hand, Scottish Life International's (SLI) newly launched fund, protected.com, has quite different criteria. The fund, which participates in the technology-weighted Nasdaq-100, gives you 95% capital protection and locks investment gains in each quarter.

Every three months, SLI will take a small proportion of your money, around 7%, and use it to buy options on the Nasdaq 100 Options Market. Options are complex contracts which give you the right to buy or sell stock at a future date if the price is right.

They are very risky, but can provide the potential for big returns. This quarter, for example, the options are providing a return and the fund is giving investors 61.1% of any growth in the Nasdaq-100 index.

The biggest downside of this particular fund is its minimum investment requirement of £15,000.

On the charges front, HSBC's fund has an initial charge of 5.25% and an annual charge of 0.5%.

But what if you think that share prices are not going to rise but are set to collapse, can you still make money? The answer is to "short" a stock, whereby you borrow shares, sell them, buy them back once the price has fallen again and pocket the difference before giving them back to their owner.

But it is not for the fainthearted. Roddy Kohn, managing director of Kohn Cougar say: "Shorting is scary. It's really no more than a gamble and should only be attempted by people who really know what they are doing. The private investor would probably have more luck on the horses at Newmarket."

webTitle: Tokyo backs plans to set up Asian IMF

fields.headline: Tokyo backs plans to set up Asian IMF
fields.trailText: Japan is backing a plan by Asian governments to set up a multibillion-dollar emergency fund to defend their currencies from speculative attacks of the kind which triggered the global financial crisis in 1997.
fields.body:
Japan is backing a plan by Asian governments to set up a multibillion-dollar emergency fund to defend their currencies from speculative attacks of the kind which triggered the global financial crisis in 1997.

A Japanese newspaper reported yesterday that Tokyo has thrown its weight behind the fund, which was approved in principle last month by finance ministers from the Association of South East Asian Nations, Asean.

Under an existing $200m (£126m) currency stabilisation arrangement, Asean central banks can draw on credit lines with each other to prop up their currencies when speculators attack. But with trillions traded daily on the world's foreign exchanges, the existing fund is too small to take on the might of the markets when they target a currency.

The new fund could mobilise ten of billions of dollars, according to a report yesterday in the Tokyo-based Sankei Shimbun newspaper.

Japan, China and South Korea, which are not Asean members, have been invited to join, to beef up the kitty.

Policymakers hope it will prevent a repeat of the spectacular currency crashes which swept through the region in the summer of 1997.

Speculators trained their sights first on the Thai baht, which lost half its value in a few weeks, and then the Philippine peso, the Malaysian ringgit, the Indonesian rupiah and the Korean won which all plunged to record lows.

The currency swap facility was set up after the crisis after plans for a fully fledged Asian Monetary Fund to bail out stricken economies ran into opposition from the West. The US, other western nations and the International Monetary Fund fear an AMF - first mooted by Japan - would undermine the IMF's role as the world's emergency lender.

The beefed-up emergency fund is intended to compliment the fund's role by helping countries stabilise their currencies in advance of IMF programmes. But Washington is likely to renew its objections on the grounds that a rival mechanism will devalue the IMF.

fields.headline: SoftBank tries to rebuild
fields.standfirst:
Global dot.com leader goes on offensive to stop debt doubts eroding share price

E-finance: special report
www.softbank.com
fields.trailText: The world's biggest dot.com investment company, SoftBank, yesterday went on the offensive against the recent savaging of its share price which has destroyed its president's chances of becoming the world's richest man.
fields.body:
The world's biggest dot.com investment company, SoftBank, yesterday went on the offensive against the recent savaging of its share price which has destroyed its president's chances of becoming the world's richest man.

The Japanese group's chief financial officer, Yoshitaka Kitao, declared that SoftBank's stock was "too cheap" and poured cold water on claims that its debt levels were excessive. He also pointed to the company's range of investments to highlight its earnings potential.

His comments sent SoftBank's shares surging 6% after two months of steep decline.

The company has more than 300 hi-tech investments and claims to own 7% of internet stocks worldwide.

The recent bear market has caused a plunge in the personal wealth of SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son, who was worth more than $40bn in February.

At one stage, Mr Son looked likely to topple Microsoft founder Bill Gates from the head of the world's rich list. Mr Gates has assets of over $70bn.

However, the gap between them has widened as Mr Gates has been only modestly affected by the internet sell-off.

When asked about SoftBank's borrowing, Mr Kitao said: "Our debt itself is a very small amount, only $1.7bn or $1.8bn, which is very small, particularly taking into account our huge unrealised gains. So our current debt position is quite normal."

He cited SoftBank's 51% stake in the internet portal Yahoo Japan as an example of its solid portfolio of investments: "I think our stock prices are definitely too cheap, taking account of our huge hidden assets, companies like Yahoo."

SoftBank's shares rose ¥3,000 to ¥52,300 (£327) - the maximum daily increase allowed under the rules of the Tokyo stock market. However, they remain well adrift of their ¥198,000 peak.

Mr Son is famous for his powerful connections. He is a friend of Mr Gates and is credited with helping to convert Rupert Murdoch, the global media mogul, to the joys of the internet.

SoftBank has substantial stakes in some of the largest internet operators, including GeoCities and E*Trade.

However, the group has attracted criticism for helping to over-inflate the internet bub ble. Many of its investments are in private companies, which are difficult for analysts to value.

SoftBank's fall from grace was hastened by a profits warning earlier this month, revealing that it would make a Y55bn year-end loss, partly due to the effect of exchange rate fluctuations on its yen-denominated debts.

The group yesterday bought 10% of a Malaysian holding company, Dijaya Enterprise, in a move aimed at creating a "mini-SoftBank" in Malaysia.

SoftBank started life in 1981 as a hardware and software distribution business.

Last month, the company began an assault on the British market through a tie-up with Mr Murdoch's News Corp and Vivendi, the French media and utilities group.

The three groups have created a vehicle called SoftBank Europe Ventures which will spend $450m over the next two years backing start-ups and new business concepts in Britain. The venture will invest a further $550m in mainland Europe.

SoftBank is also collaborating with the World Bank in a $500m plan to invest in the digital economies of developing countries.

webTitle: Putting heart and soul into your working life

fields.headline: Putting heart and soul into your working life
fields.standfirst:
There is a growing sense of spirituality in the workplace and this will become increasingly important to all of us, argues David Pride
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: There is a growing sense of spirituality in the workplace and this will become increasingly important to all of us, argues David Pride.
fields.body:
You might think that no one ever uses phrases like "Bless you" or "Godspeed" any more, but I believe an increasing incidence of these, and other, more spiritual forms of greeting are being used in working life.

As a consultant I spend time with many organisations each year and this is a theme I find repeated around the world. It is not always a Christian message and one of my clients even wishes: "May the force be with you". Whilst this might seem comic it is intended quite seriously.

I have come to the conclusion that what I am witnessing is a growing sense of spirituality in the workplace. People are finding, and making known, that there is more to their day jobs than simply getting on with the work.

In our consultancy practice we work very hard to raise people's consciousness about the place of the spirit in work. As part of a more holistic view of work we believe that it is critical that each person is not only able to meet his or her needs for earnings, an interesting job and agreeable colleagues, but also to nourish a deeper, more meaningful part of his or her being, which I choose to call the spirit.

Let me declare that I am not pursuing any religious doctrine, nor seeking to convert people to any faith. Rather I am portraying what I see people need in the workplace: colleagues who respect them as human beings; work that nourishes as well as rewards them and an opportunity to build their self-esteem and grow with dignity in what they do.

This form of spirituality shows itself in many ways. In one organisation it is based clearly around colleagues sharing a Christian belief and here the messages relate to that belief system.

In another organisation the phrases are much more those of the humanist psychologist and here people are more likely to say: "I really appreciated that"; "well done"; "real teamwork"; things that generally build a person's morale, boost his or her self-esteem and generally reinforce their feeling of belonging and support.

This need to express spirituality in the workplace seems to be a natural need, brought out more into the open as people confront an increasingly demanding and unpredictable work environment.

By embracing the human need and working in ways that support the individual, communities at work are quickly built. Such communities unite in a common purpose, energise themselves to accomplish their tasks and celebrate success when they do.

Celebration is an important part of this process too, and many organisations are still woefully ignorant about how to organise this on any kind of regular basis - without it becoming purely a monetary thing. What we are looking for is the ability of people to spontaneously give recognition to one another, selflessly and for the sole purpose of promoting harmony, self-esteem and a conscious acknowledgement of worth.

This will become increasingly important as we seek to measure performance, put the spotlight even more on the individual and set targets that are stretching where pay is impacted by the quantity and quality of attainment.

What I would expect to see would be: language that affirms a person's contribution, in that it does not rubbish or in any way discount a person or his or her contribution through inappropriate behaviour such as put-down humour or swearing; a large measure of self-determination about how a person does his/her job as well as around the contractual aspects relating particularly to time-keeping, where work is done and so on.

Here are some suggestions for how to achieve this:

team-based work, where appropriate, which allows for the growth of each person's competence and contribution.

team-based rewards so that where teams really excel they are recognised and attract benefit.

colleagues who are frank with one another and say what they think in ways that respect each other and build self-esteem.

quality work that ensures that routine and drudgery are kept to a minimum.

leaders who work in a holistic way, bringing about outcomes that enrich individuals as well as the organisation.

It is high time that we worked out how to achieve. If we deny that humanity is the foundation of our culture, our communities and our organisations then we are truly starving both the individual and collective spirit. The outcome would be a destiny of forever being on a treadmill of work because we have to: rather than because it affirms our very being.

 David Pride is the chief executive of the Centre for Enabling Leadership (UK) Ltd, Goring on Thames, Oxfordshire, tel: 01491 873232 or go to www.centell.org

fields.headline: Don't tax your brains
fields.standfirst: The Revenue's guide to filling in your return is bigger than ever. But, writes David Brodie, there are ways of simplifying the situation
fields.trailText: The Revenue's guide to filling in your return is bigger than ever. But, writes David Brodie, there are ways of simplifying the situation.
fields.body:
Sometimes you can't help feeling sorry for the taxman! He has just received a barrage of criticism for the latest tax return pack which, on careful examination, is actually a huge improvement.

The tax return form and explanatory notes are virtually unchanged, but critics have complained that the tax calculation guide has swollen from 11 to 27 pages. This was, in fact, a direct response to previous gripes that the guide was incomprehensible as it seemed to be written for the benefit of computer programmers. While the new booklet is long, it is at least possible to understand.

Nonetheless, it is madness that so many trees must be sacrificed just so that we can comprehend our fiscal responsibilities. But the fault lies with successive governments, which have tinkered with the tax system without regard to its increasing complexity, and not with the Revenue.

In any event, you are free to ignore the tax calculation guide. Provided your return is submitted by September 30, your tax office will compute your tax for you.

If you are reluctant to trust this job to the taxman - and official figures concede that 6% of Revenue calculations contain mistakes because of processing errors - you may ask for a free CD-Rom which prints out your return and does the calculation automatically.

This is available to anyone whose income is covered by the main eight-page return and employment and self-employment pages (see page 4 of the tax return guide).

And the more adventurous may try internet filing, for which there is a £10 incentive on offer (see www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk). Some 7.2 million tax returns have just been issued, mostly to the self-employed, company directors, higher paid employees, and others with untaxed income such as rents from property. The number is lower than before, as the Revenue has removed 400,000 people with relatively simple affairs, including 200,000 pensioners, from self-assessment.

Until last year, employees and pensioners with more than £500 of income received untaxed - such as National Savings interest or rental income - were automatically sent a tax return. From this year, returns should not be issued where untaxed income is below £2,500, if the Revenue can collect the tax through PAYE instead.

If you are in this group, but have been sent a tax return which you find difficult, contact your tax office as you may be able to persuade them to dispense with the form.

Following last year's introduction of a 10% tax band, there are many more pensioners and others on low incomes who are overpaying tax because they have bank or building society savings earning interest from which 20% is deducted at source.

For example, Sally is 63 years old and in 1999/2000 received the basic state pension of £3,471 and building society interest of £2,000, giving her total income of £5,471. The first £4,335 of her total income fell within her personal allowance, and the balance of £1,136 should be taxed at 10%, giving a tax bill of £113.60. However, the building society will have deducted £400 tax from her interest (£2,000 at 20%), and so she is entitled to a refund of £286.40.

You can obtain a tax reclaim form (R40) from any tax office. It is fairly straightforward and should be sent to one of five reclaim offices listed in Revenue booklet IR 110 - A Guide For People With Savings. Refunds should be made within about four weeks, although things can take a bit longer at this time of year.

For those who must file the full-blown tax return, my immediate advice is not to panic. You still have more than five months to file and it may help to set yourself the immediate target of checking that you have the right supplementary pages (see page 2 of the form) and collecting the information you will need.

Income from employment is reported on form P60, which your employer should give you by May 19, while any taxable benefits in kind and expenses payments are on form P11D which you should receive by July 6. Most banks and building societies send an annual certificate of interest paid on your savings; if not you are entitled to one free upon request.

 David Brodie is director of TaxAid, the charity which provides free tax advice to people who cannot afford professional fees. Phone 020 7624 3768 between 10 am and 12 noon, Mondays to Thursdays.

fields.headline: Dropping off at Barclaycard
fields.standfirst: Ignoring letters and making misleading statements about legal rights raise concerns, says Richard Colbey
fields.trailText: It may not quite compare with closing 170 rural branches or paying the chief executive Matthew Barrett a possible £30m, but a reader's run-in with Barclaycard will reinforce the view of many, that the only decent thing Barclays' customers can now do is vote with their feet.
fields.body:
It may not quite compare with closing 170 rural branches or paying the chief executive Matthew Barrett a possible £30m, but a reader's run-in with Barclaycard will reinforce the view of many, that the only decent thing Barclays' customers can now do is vote with their feet.

The owner of the Wrought Iron Bed Factory went bankrupt last year, leaving more than 4,000 customers out of pocket; they had paid for goods which were never delivered.

Those who paid more than £100 with a credit card were, though, entitled to claim against the card company. Unfortunately for Barclays, among those in that position was an experienced solicitor who had ordered himself a £215 table from the business, using his Barclaycard.

His first two letters to the bank seeking the refund he was, beyond argument, entitled to were simply ignored. He then wrote to the chief executive. By this stage he had decided he not only wanted the £215 back but also the £235 extra he had had to pay for a similar table from another supplier.

It would probably not occur to many customers to ask for this, but where someone breaks a contract the victim is entitled to be put in the same position as if the contract had been performed.

In a case like this, that can mean more than getting a refund. Barclays was clearly as liable as the retailer would have been for the extra he had paid. Rather more questionably, he also demanded £100 for "inconvenience, disappointment and distress".

Three weeks later the solicitor did get a reply containing what he regarded as the rather surprising claim that "customer satisfaction is of paramount importance to Barclaycard". Barclays, who had been able to get the £215 from the Bed Factory's bank, were prepared to give him that sum back. However, it asserted that: "Regarding your claim for additional costs for a replacement item, I regret Barclaycard are unable to assist you with regards this request."

No reason was given for this, and the solicitor wrote again, spelling out his claim in even clearer terms. This time a reply was sent by a more senior manager saying that as the replacement table was not identical to the one originally ordered, Barclays would not pay. Again this statement, as Barclays was later to accept, was legally wrong.

The letter also provided an explanation, of sorts, for the failure to reply to earlier letters: "Due to an increase in correspondence caused by recent marketing initiatives, we have not been able to deal with customers' queries as quickly as we would like."

This, the solicitor described as "disgraceful". It seemed to amount to an admission that Barclays, rather than honour its existing obligations, would give priority to increasing profits by attracting new customers. However, Barclays' spokesman said this referred to the complaints that arose out of its attempts last year to offer cheap mobile phones to cardholders.

The solicitor then threatened to sue or deduct the amount he was entitled to from the amount he owed the bank on the account. In just over a week there was a complete capitulation from the same manager, who now claimed to have taken advice from the legal services department. Interestingly, that department did not seem to have advised the manager that he might take issue with the claim for £100 for inconvenience.

Barclays' spokesman ad mitted: "We have fallen short of our usual standards on this occasion. We would expect our staff to advise customers of their rights. We normally send out a leaflet setting out the position under the Consumer Credit Act."

A copy of the leaflet was produced, but it contained nothing that suggested people were entitled to claim for consequential loss. The spokesman said consideration would be given to altering it.

Here, as in most battles between consumers and banks, it was determination that won the day. It is cheaper for a bank to pay the odd extra £100 to the customer who does not give up, than to evaluate each claim individually.

However, for every person who takes a claim as far as this reader did, there may be a dozen who accept a bank's misleading statements about its legal liability at face value.

One can't say whether Barclays has been guilty of anything worse than gross inefficiency, but customers' passivity undoubtedly contributes to the profits that enable the Matthew Barretts of this world the chance to award themselves £30m.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister
