The owner of the Wrought Iron Bed Factory went bankrupt last year, leaving more than 4,000 customers out of pocket; they had paid for goods which were never delivered. Those who paid more than £100 with a credit card were, though, entitled to claim against the card company. Unfortunately for Barclays, among those in that position was an experienced solicitor who had ordered himself a £215 table from the business, using his Barclaycard. His first two letters to the bank seeking the refund he was, beyond argument, entitled to were simply ignored. He then wrote to the chief executive. By this stage he had decided he not only wanted the £215 back but also the £235 extra he had had to pay for a similar table from another supplier. It would probably not occur to many customers to ask for this, but where someone breaks a contract the victim is entitled to be put in the same position as if the contract had been performed. In a case like this, that can mean more than getting a refund. Barclays was clearly as liable as the retailer would have been for the extra he had paid. fields.headline: Less than loopy
fields.trailText: Super Furry Animals Scala, London***
fields.body:
Super Furry Animals Scala, London***

In the five years since Fuzzy Logic was released, Super Furry Animals have consistently rejected the suggestion that they're weird. They reckon it's just that other bands are conventional. The quintet are right: they're not that strange.

Certainly not at this show. Like most bands would, they tease those listening to the gig's broadcast on Radio 1 by fibbing "We're dressed as giant razorfish and there's an amazing laser show". Ironically, though, these are exactly the things you usually do see when SFA play live. On record, most of their supposed loopiness stems from Cian Ciaran's frolicking with electronic equipment during golden pop numbers. Here his scrawls and squirls are barely audible, coming into their own only when the guitars are toned down during The Doors to This House Remain Open and Gwreiddiau Dwfn/Mawrth Oer Ar Y Blaned Neifion.

Then there's the Welsh question: the fact that their forthcoming album Mwng is sung entirely in their first language will no doubt strike some as barmy, but the new songs are actually some of SFA's simplest and sweetest, and the live versions are blissful. Gruff Rhys's sinewy voice has a startling purity as he clambers over a scale for the reeling chorus of Ymaelodi A'r Ymylon. Pan Ddaw'r Wawr, a gurgling folk tune, sounds deliciously like the closing theme song to Monkey.

There's a lovely story that a New York audience watching Jacques Brel cheered loudest when the staunchly French-speaking singer pointed out that they didn't understand him. Something of the same spirit infuses SFA's devoted fans, who receive the new songs as delightedly as a hilariously disjointed, buzzsaw rendition of Nightvision and a seductive take on The Turning Tide, both from last year's Guerrilla. Whether the songs are in Welsh or English, SFA's exuberant pop melodies and playful electronica are so straightforwardly enjoyable, it's hard to see why people find them bizarre.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Unemployed disabled people get a helping hand

fields.headline: Unemployed disabled people get a helping hand
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: More than 120 companies from the north-west of England congregated in Manchester this week for the Workability Forum for Business as part of a national drive to raise awareness of unemployment amongst disabled people.
fields.body:
More than 120 companies from the north-west of England congregated in Manchester this week for the Workability Forum for Business as part of a national drive to raise awareness of unemployment amongst disabled people.

The Forum, organised by Leonard Cheshire and Microsoft UK, is one of a series of events around the UK that aims to make employers aware of their legal obligations under the Disability Discrimination Act (DDA), highlight recent research into the business benefits of employing disabled people and increase awareness of Workability.

This is a national project that aims to equip disabled people with the skills to assist them in the search for jobs by providing free computer equipment and internet-linked training and take positive steps towards providing training and employment or further education opportunities.

Meanwhile the employment rights of more than 3m disabled workers will be significantly strengthened after the launch earlier this week of the Disability Rights Commission with similar powers to the Equal Opportunities Commission and the Commission for Racial Equality.

A TUC poll conducted by BMRB International shows strong public support for the equal treatment of gay and lesbian workers - 75% of the people questioned say that it is immoral to sack or treat gay and lesbian staff any differently from their straight counterparts. The TUC is using the findings of its study - Straight Up! Why the law should protect lesbian and gay workers - to argue for new legislation that would safeguard lesbians and gay men from discrimination at work. For a copy of the report, call the TUC on 020 7636 4030.

Management consultant Nora Doherty and her partners at Professional Mediation Resolutions (PMR) have designed a new conflict resolution programme. Ms Doherty runs specially tailored courses to train managers in peacemaking techniques for effective conflict management. PMR is running a one-day seminar on May 11. Details on 01926-339744 or e-mail: mediation@cwcom.net

webTitle: Lloyds ups stakes in the plastic card game

fields.headline: Lloyds ups stakes in the plastic card game
fields.standfirst:
The big bank broke ranks this week over charging for use of cash machines. Tony Levene and Rupert Jones report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The row over cash machine charges turned into a high-stakes poker game this week, with Lloyds TSB attempting to up the ante by announcing a 50p charge on non-customers for using its machines - half the £1 Barclays proposal.
fields.byline: Tony Levene and Rupert Jones report
fields.body:
The row over cash machine charges turned into a high-stakes poker game this week, with Lloyds TSB attempting to up the ante by announcing a 50p charge on non-customers for using its machines - half the £1 Barclays proposal.

And for those excluded from mainstream banking and other financial services, there was also some hope. A number of leading charities banded together to launch a new campaign "Debt on our doorstep" - one of whose objectives is to throw light on the huge interest rates paid on loans by the least well off.

On the cash machine front, Tesco piled further pressure on Britain's most unpopular bank by saying it will remove 74 Barclays cash machines from stores in protest at the bank's charging plans, adding that it may ditch a further 125 if Barclays refuses to budge.

Some observers say Lloyds TSB's move could spark an ATM charges price war and may force Barclays to cut substantially its proposed fee.

It's the latest twist in a long-running, bad-tempered saga. Last month banks and building societies belonging to the Link cash machine network voted to outlaw double charging for cash machine withdrawals - someone using another bank's ATM won't face both a disloyalty charge from their own bank and a surcharge from the institution owning the machine.

Giving evidence before a committee of MPs this week, Lloyds TSB chief executive Peter Ellwood finally laid bare the truth about the cost of ATM withdrawals cost when he said the figure was around 38p. He added that from January 1, 2001, his bank will abolish the current £1.50 disloyalty charge and instead charge 50p a time for non-customers who use its machines. Mr Ellwood said this charge would allow it to make a "very small profit" on withdrawals.

The Co-operative Bank, which does not intend charging fees, warned against "falling into the trap of thinking 50p is good news". It says if the charge was adopted by all banks then customers would pay £500m a year.

Debt on our Doorstep, a campaign aiming to prevent low income household from a lifetime of high interest debt points out that it is 29 years since a government committee on consumer credit concluded there was a level of credit costs "above which it becomes socially harmful to make loans available."

Debt on our Doorstep says that as banks have moved out of poorer areas, the door to door lenders - both legal and illegal - have moved in.

Someone borrowing £100 from Provident Financial or Cattles - the two biggest companies in the door to door loan market with combined stockmarket value approaching £2bn would typically pay back £140 in 26 weekly instalments. This is equal to an annual percentage rate (APR) well into three figures.

Aloan of the same amount from Direct Line on a credit card would cost £16.98 a month for six months at the card's 6.9% introductory rate - a total of £101.88 - or £17.37 a month at the standard 15.9% level, totalling £104.22.

A £500 loan to be paid back over 18 months would cost £11.28 a week with Provident Financial which would be paid back a total £884.80 - a 76% interest rate.

The same loan with Direct Line would be repaid in just 11 months with a typical credit charge of around £38.

Damon Gibbons, of the Money Advice Association calculates that these two compa nies alone - and there are many more - take out around £100m a year from the poorest areas. And estimates from brokers Merrill Lynch suggest that both companies will increase profits by around 50% by 2001.

The campaign estimates that more than 3m people are forced to borrow from door to door lenders for essentials such as children's clothing and basic furniture.

For those in this position, any extra cost is a calamity. A High Wycombe family which had to borrow from Provident at 76% to pay off rent arrears got further into debt and is now paying off a £1,000 loan from Provident. This family was hit when the cooker collapsed and they had to buy a new one , and again when an unpaid £20 parking fine turned into £290 after bailiffs added on their costs.

The retreat of banks from poorer areas removes the chance of many of leaving the areas of the cash economy and high cost loans, campaigners say. But amid the bad news on bank closures - Barclays says it is likely to shut even more - Lloyds TSB says it will now not close a branch where it is "the last bank in town" reprieving 18 branches due to close in May or June.

fields.headline: Stuck on stripping
fields.trailText: Ricochet Dance Company Queen Elizabeth Hall, London***
fields.body:
Ricochet Dance Company Queen Elizabeth Hall, London***

Ricochet Dance Company has always seemed an exemplary ensemble, a loyal band of dancers who have subjected their egos to the demands of all the choreographers with whom they've worked. But this season the group's five members get to hog the limelight, each performing an eight-minute solo created by the choreographer of their choice.

In the four shown here (one was cancelled due to injury), the most striking feature was the eagerness with which the company's two men get off their kit. Two male strippers in one show is more than coincidence. Their styles, however, were very different. Phelim McDermott's solo for Ben Wright was a strip in reverse, beginning with a pair of pants and embroidering the act of dressing with a series of sweet- natured, if slight, comic routines.

David Waring, in Gary Carter's fan dance, waggled his sequinned jock strap far more aggressively in our faces. As he artfully wielded a pair of ostrich plumes Waring ran the whole gamut of sexual tease - from coy Swan Princess to bump-and-grind male stripper. The timing was brilliant and the gestures so sharply observed that Waring's performance never toppled into indulgence. Its mordant eroticism was, however, familiar dance-theatre territory, unlike La Ribot's bizarre little number for Anna Williams.

This opened on a stage littered with random objects and it transpired that Williams's task was to get all of them stuck on her flesh. Some were pre-glued, so that she had to press her exquisitely articulate limbs into contortions that allowed parts of her body to make contact with them. Bulkier objects she had to bind with sticky tape. The more encumbered Williams became, the harder her task and the more strangely she had to move. Given her skills as a dancer, it was a curiously beautiful process to watch - a wacky comment on the nature of virtuosity.

Kate Gowar, another fine performer, was less flattered in Neil Greenberg's solo, which looked as if it wanted to launch into flights of dance but was embarrassed to do so. Ironically Gowar found a much better showcase in the group work, Russell Maliphant's Cut. Maliphant's style is inward and thoughtful, but it has a singing clarity of line that makes the dancers look like virtuosos even when they're performing simple moves (particularly in the burnished atmosphere of Michael Hull's lighting). But the tick-tock pulse of Matteo Fargion's music for Cut also inspires Maliphant to a series of tiny, complex interactions, so that the stage becomes a kind of sculpture garden - an intriguing showcase of sensuous lines, statuesque forms and grown-up clockwork toys.

Spring Loaded continues until June 4. Details: 020-7387 0031.

webTitle: Time for hi-tech to hit the road?

fields.headline: Time for hi-tech to hit the road?
fields.standfirst:
Investors in the dot.com boom are being urged to get out fast. But, says Patrick Collinson, it could pay dividends to hold firm in this crisis
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Investors in the dot.com boom are being urged to get out fast. But, says Patrick Collinson, it could pay dividends to hold firm in this crisis.
fields.body:
Any tips? inquired a fresh-faced new investor on an internet bulletin board this week. Within seconds came the reply from a trader bombed out by this week's dot.com collapse. "Er... get out as soon as possible."

The love affair with hi-tech investment is over. Despite furious spinning by the tech fund groups, repeatedly telling investors this week to "sit tight", there is evidence that investors are beginning to dump the funds, cancelling cheques and redeeming their units. Aberdeen Technology admits that 200 of its investors have cancelled their cheques, and SocGen Technology adds that 0.5% of its unitholders quit this week.

Ominously, even the tech fund managers predict further slumps in share prices. In a note to investors that went out after the market panic on Monday, SocGen warned that "the Nasdaq 100 still looks vulnerable to a further fall of up to 10%."

The investment performance figures make grim reading for anyone who joined the hi-tech share bandwagon too late - and most people did. Hundreds of millions of pounds poured into tech funds in the February and March "Isa season" - £300m into Aberdeen Technology, £200m into Jupiter's new fund, and more than £100m into the most dot.com led fund, Framlington NetNet.

The smell of burnt fingers is strong. If someone put the maximum Isa allowance of £7,000 into the NetNet fund on March 10 and wants to cash in today, it will only be worth £4,042. Close Brother's Techmark fund, which took in around £65m from investors during February and March, now stands at around 151p from its 258p peak, taking a £7,000 investment to £4,097.

The technology funds, which are more broadly based and include stocks such as Microsoft, Cisco Systems and Dell rather than the dot.coms, are down by around 30% from their peaks.

But it would be wrong to suggest that all investors have lost their shirts. The boom in tech shares that took off in October last year was so strong that even after the fall back in recent weeks, early investors are still ahead.

Amelia Koutsavakis, a 25-year-old trainee surveyor based in Chatham, Kent bought the Close Techmark fund shortly after it was launched in November, and invested her full £7,000 Isa allowance. In the heady days of the boom she saw her investment nearly double and by early March it was worth around £13,000. By this week it had fallen in value to £8,500 - but that still leaves her with a profit of £1,500 so far.

She remains a firm believer in the new hi-tech revolution and is not going to quit the fund because of the sell-off. "I think it's fine, I'm pretty sure I'm not going to lose out in the long run. Things will steady from here on and eventually the fund will start improving again."

Ms Koutsavakis uses email to share investment tips with her friends and colleagues (although she encouraged her boss to jump in a month ago, only to see his investment slide in value by a third) and also owns a few individual shares. "A lot of my friends have got tech shares and most of them have lost a lot of money over the last week. Some have bowed out, but most are holding on."

She even dipped back into the market this week with her most speculative investment so far - shares in a Kazakhstan oil exploration company, Atlantic Caspian. It is a classic penny stock (currently at around 7p-8p), and she admits it is purely a punt rather than a long-term investment.

Ms Koutsavakis is part of the new wave of investors who spurn traditional and dull funds in favour of investments that will either spiral in value or collapse. All of her investment money is in tech stocks or penny shares. It's a trend that worries traditional investment advisers. Jason Hollands of Best Investments says: "The final months of the tax year saw huge demand for technology funds, driven by the repeated headlines about dot.com millionaires. While many brokers actively pushed their clients into such Isas, we warned investors to exercise restraint. Our message has been simple. Don't go overboard in your level of tech exposure."

Many of the tech fund managers are almost relieved that share prices have fallen back without sliding into a rout. "Clearly the question is whether the technology sector now represents good value and an interesting entry point. We believe it does. We are getting back to the trend line of growth... with many of the excesses removed," says SocGen's Chris Godding. But he cautions against an early bounce back in tech shares. "I think we are going to go sideways for a couple of months," he predicts.

Marc Gordon, managing director of Close Fund Management, is more upbeat. "The only thing that has changed is the perception about share valuations. webTitle: Pension rise to win grey voters

fields.headline: Pension rise to win grey voters
fields.standfirst:
Angry MPs force Brown into cash boost for elderly

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is planning to woo disaffected pensioners back to Labour by raising basic old age pensions by £2-3 a week - above the rate of inflation if necessary - before the next general election.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is planning to woo disaffected pensioners back to Labour by raising basic old age pensions by £2-3 a week - above the rate of inflation if necessary - before the next general election.

The chancellor, who now regrets not raising pensions above what backbench critics regard as a niggardly 75p this month, has seen a succession of angry MPs in recent weeks whose postbags have filled with complaints from elderly constituents.

To the Treasury's dismay, the inflation-based rise has provoked pensioner anger since it was first paid on April 1. The government, sensitive to "grey" voting power, is keen to get back on course.

To further ease the plight - and resentment - of those pensioners whose careful provision for retirement has given them incomes just above the level of extra state help, Mr Brown is now engaged in a secret review, MPs told the Guardian yesterday.

It is expected to result in what officials call "an occupational pension disregard". That jargon means that the first and crucial £10-15 a week of an occupational pension would not count against help provided by Labour's top-up scheme, the minimum income guarantee.

Next week the chancellor will also make a joint statement with the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, drawing attention to moves to help pensioners - including the Budget's £150 winter fuel allowance and the free £104 television licence for the over-75s.

But MPs say many of Britain's 10m pensioners regard such moves as "a hand-out". One said: "They've worked all their lives and feel they're entitled.

Another complained: "It's like a poor employer who robs his workers every week, then gives them a turkey for Christmas.

Unlike this month's pension calculation, based on last September's 1.1% inflation rate, the Treasury is banking on an increase next April of about 2.5%. This would yield around £2 a week on a single pensioner's £67.50, and £3 on a married couple's £107.90.

It would be paid on April 1 2001, possibly just weeks before the expected election. Even if inflation in September is lower than expected, colleagues believe the chancellor is now locked into a £2-3 rise.

Mr Brown also promised some visiting MPs last week that he will consider restoring the link between state pensions and earnings, severed in favour of inflation-proofing only by Margaret Thatcher.

However, it is more likely Mr Brown will instead press on with his current approach of mixing universal and targeted improvements.

Ministers say there are sound reasons for mixing universal payments - such as the basic pension increase and the winter fuel allowance - with those such as the minimum income guarantee which are targeted on the poor.

But the fact that minimum income guarantee payments are linked to average pay - not inflation - makes it politically unsustainable in the long-term, MPs say. Ironically, Mr Brown's mixed approach has cost the frugal chancellor £840m more over three years than restoration of the earnings link would have done.

Tony Blair, who also met unhappy MPs last week, claims that the trouble with increasing basic pensions is that relatively well-off people like his father, a retired lawyer, benefit along with poor pensioners.

In one meeting with MPs preparing for the run-up to local elections on May 4, the chancellor issued some figures to help them respond to mounting criticism that pensioners are being ignored by the government.

The figures said average pensioner income was now £132 for a single person and £258 for a couple. The median figure was between £90 and £100.

fields.headline: Naive consumers don't shop around
fields.standfirst: Worrying new research highlights the need for everyone to learn about financial products and services at school, argues Tony Levene
fields.trailText: Financial consumers fail to shop around, have difficulty understanding the information they get, and often find it hard to identify products to match their needs, according to a new report from the Financial Services Authority published today.
fields.body:
Financial consumers fail to shop around, have difficulty understanding the information they get, and often find it hard to identify products to match their needs, according to a new report from the Financial Services Authority published today.

The watchdog found that three out of 10 failed to shop around - with the highest and lowest social classes the most likely to ignore this basic step in financial self-defence. Oddly enough, the retired are less likely to comparison shop than those in full-time employment.

And independent advice does not rate highly either. A greater number are likely to look at products from companies where they were already customers, than the number of people who would consider going to an Independent Financial Adviser (IFA) or other companies put together.

The research has worried the FSA and could have an effect on how companies present information to prospective customers.

"Many consumers do not know they have information needs," says Victoria Raffe, the FSA head of consumer policy and research. "It is all too easy to make sweeping generalisations which assume a customer level of understanding that does not exist for most people buying financial services."

After 12 years of financial services regulation, the FSA concludes that many potential customers do not know what products are available or appropriate for their needs; are overwhelmed with information and do not know which leaflets to read; are surprised or shocked by the small print when they find out what it means; and are unaware of how to access comparative information.

As consumer advocates including Jobs & Money have long argued, merely producing information which complies with regulatory requirements is of little help to customers with no legal, investment or actuarial knowledge - and that is most people.

One solution, says the FSA, is to teach financial matters at school. Primary school materials will be sent out for September with secondary resources published a year after that.

More immediately, the FSA plans to publicise its local call rate helpline (0845-606-1234) which has not yet been promoted. It currently attracts just 10,000 calls a month. There is also an e-mail facility at consumerhelp@fsa.gov.uk The FSA also publishes a number of consumer guides ranging from financial advice in general to how to make a complaint. The advice is mostly generic - the planned league tables which name individual companies have still to see the light of day.

Meanwhile with world equity markets looking shakier than at any time since the Russian crisis two years ago, a new free web-based education service on shares was opened this week by the Lord Mayor of London. Equity Education - www.equityeducation.com - is aimed at those who want to try to make some money, but don't want to take the risks of giving up their job and taking on the day trader task. But while there are risk and wealth warnings, do not expect to see alternatives to equities receiving a major billing.

The course is backed by the City Corporation, the London Stock Exchange, Merrill Lynch, Halifax, which has a stockbroking arm, NatWest Stockbrokers and Share people.com. And most of these have a commercial interest in increasing private investor numbers.

The no cost service aims to take beginners and more experienced investors through a course in the basics of stocks and shares, from what a share is through using a broker to managing a portfolio of shares.

There will be three levels on the course - beginners, intermediate and advanced. Only the beginners course has so far been posted on the net - the intermediate work should come later this year with an advanced level early next year.

Each step is backed up by an exam which you cannot take until you have perused the material in the section.

The course consists of basic information - there is little on the dangers of taking big positions in volatile stocks.

fields.headline: Parallel turns
fields.trailText: The Comedy of Errors Royal Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon***
fields.body:
The Comedy of Errors Royal Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon***

Two options confront the director of this masterpiece about separated twins. You can treat it as a seriously mysterious comedy, as Tim Supple did in the last RSC revival. Or you can view it as madcap farcical romp, as Lynne Parker does in her spirited Stratford debut. With its nods towards Harold Lloyd, Keaton and Laurel and Hardy, Parker's production is a palpable crowd-pleaser. What you lose is something of the play's emotional reality.

To be fair, Parker treats the plight of the execution-awaiting Egeon with due gravity: incarcerated in a grimly contemporary Turkish jail, Paul Greenwood delivers his opening speeches with riveting stillness. But once we enter the world of the twin Antipholuses and Dromios, language takes second place to escalating comic business. We get joke suitcases, shadow monsters, stand-up routines and funny merchants, all leading towards a frenzied Keystone Cops-style chase in which the permutated twins and their creditors are joined, for no apparent reason, by a knight in clanking armour and a lumbering dromedary.

It's all very jolly but Parker underplays both the Syracusan twins' bewilderment at finding themselves in a dream-like Ephesus where they are constantly recognised, and the emotional dilemma of the luckless Luciana, wooed by the man she takes to be her brother-in-law. What you get instead is a considerable display of physical skill. David Tennant's Antipholus of Syracuse at one point does a slide down a staircase-rail and across the stage that Barrault might have envied. And both Ian Hughes and Tom Smith as the Dromios possess an impeccable, poker-faced physical precision. It just seems a pity that Hughes's virtuosic description of a gargantuan kitchen wench is gradually turned into an applause- begging vaudeville routine.

There is a vital distinction between delighting an audience and pandering to it; Parker's production sometimes leans towards the latter. But it would be churlish to deny that it is executed with great elan and, at the end, as the reunited twins gaze at their other selves with a curious wonderment, the inherent magic of Shakespeare's play triumphantly re-asserts itself.

In rep until October 7. Box office: 01789 403403

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: The new cricket: one for all and none for Lewis

fields.headline: The new cricket: one for all and none for Lewis
fields.standfirst: Cronjegate: full background
fields.trailText: English cricket has finally offered up its first victim in the squalid world of match-fixing. A scandal that has engulfed half the cricketing world was bound to arrive here eventually. The only problem is that England is conniving in the destruction of a seemingly innocent man.
fields.body:
English cricket has finally offered up its first victim in the squalid world of match-fixing. A scandal that has engulfed half the cricketing world was bound to arrive here eventually. The only problem is that England is conniving in the destruction of a seemingly innocent man.

When Chris Lewis was allegedly exhorted by an Indian businessman last summer to bribe England players to rig the test series against New Zealand, no one suggested that he did not behave impeccably, rejecting the approach and informing both the police and the cricket authorities within a matter of hours.

But from the moment that Ashim Kheterpal, a sports promoter, allegedly implicated three England players as having accepted bribes, Lewis faced a predicament.

Had he chosen to remain silent, only for the affair to be later revealed as part of a wider conspiracy, he would have been widely pilloried for his dereliction of duty in failing to alert the game to a potential threat.

So he divulged the information, in strict accordance with England and Wales Cricket Board regulations, and has suffered for it. His is the unwelcome lone voice, threatening English cricket's pristine reputation. He is being depicted as the purveyor of cheap gossip, tainting the reputation of every honest soul ever to have pulled on the England sweater. He is the outcast that a complacent media are content to destroy.

No one has produced a shred of evidence to suggest that Lewis did not respond with the utmost integrity. In an earlier age, had he been a white former public school boy, even now Lord's would be erecting his statue outside the Grace Gates: A Virtuous Man Who Did His Duty To The Noble Game.

But Lewis is something of a maverick. Cricket feels distinctly uncomfortable with his non-conformity. During his time at Nottinghamshire, if they were not deriding the fact that he did not drink, they were taking exception to his Calvin Klein underwear. They looked critically upon his dubious fitness record and pinned his salary slip to the dressing-room wall.

It cannot be denied Lewis can be his own worst enemy. Along with Mark Ramprakash, he is the great unfulfilled English talent of the past decade. One, Ramprakash, is presented as over-committed; the other, Lewis, held to be not committed enough.

In the West Indies in 1993 he shaved his head and missed a game through sunstroke. He once turned up late for a one-day international, pleading a puncture but omitting to warn England in advance that he would be delayed. He has been temperamental, a highly strung talent whom many have wished to see highly strung.

None of that remotely justifies his treatment. In Lewis's latest discussions with the ECB the implication was that he was being "hauled in" on a disrepute charge, not that there was the glimmer of a chance that he possesses vital evidence in combating the greatest outrage in cricket's history.

For all his faults, he has not been as culpable as much of the English media. Lewis has never once claimed that he has direct evidence against any of the three England players involved but the media have repeatedly declared that he has and then slated him for doing so.

Neither, it seems, has he proved as pusillanimous as the board. Lewis claims that, when he first offered the names of the three England players allegedly match-rigging, eight months ago, the ECB's international teams director, Simon Pack, refused to accept them on the grounds it was "hearsay".

If this claim is true, on whose authority was Pack acting and which members of the board were aware that he refused to accept the names? Why did the ECB change its mind and request the names this week? Surely not just because Lewis's decision to speak out to the News of the World had left it with no choice?

Lewis says that, when Kheterpal threatened a £150,000 legal action, the ECB told him he was on his own. But this is the board, under the chairmanship of Lord MacLaurin, that professes to be so set on stamping out match-fixing that it is the driving force behind next month's emergency meeting of the International Cricket Council.

If that is the case, can it provide a good reason why it apparently refused to accept its financial and legal obligations to protect an English cricketer who was assisting its inquiries, and instead showed more of a fixation with safeguarding its bank balance?

Pack, like many in English cricket's elite, had a distinguished military career. Officers accept that in every conflict there will be casualties and it looks as if Lewis has been universally judged as expendable in this one.

In Lewis's latest discussions with the ECB the implication was that he was being "hauled in" on a disrepute charge, not that there was the glimmer of a chance that he possesses vital evidence in combating the greatest outrage in cricket's history. For all his faults, he has not been as culpable as much of the English media. Lewis has never once claimed that he has direct evidence against any of the three England players involved but the media have repeatedly declared that he has and then slated him for doing so. Neither, it seems, has he proved as pusillanimous as the board. Lewis claims that, when he first offered the names of the three England players allegedly match-rigging, eight months ago, the ECB's international teams director, Simon Pack, refused to accept them on the grounds it was "hearsay". If this claim is true, on whose authority was Pack acting and which members of the board were aware that he refused to accept the names? Why did the ECB change its mind and request the names this week? Surely not just because Lewis's decision to speak out to the News of the World had left it with no choice? Lewis says that, when Kheterpal threatened a £150,000 legal action, the ECB told him he was on his own. But this is the board, under the chairmanship of Lord MacLaurin, that professes to be so set on stamping out match-fixing that it is the driving force behind next month's emergency meeting of the International Cricket Council. If that is the case, can it provide a good reason why it apparently refused to accept its financial and legal obligations to protect an English cricketer who was assisting its inquiries, and instead showed more of a fixation with safeguarding its bank balance? Pack, like many in English cricket's elite, had a distinguished military career. Officers accept that in every conflict there will be casualties and it looks as if Lewis has been universally judged as expendable in this one.

fields.headline: Henry keeps England in Europe
fields.standfirst:
Lens 1 Nouma 73
Arsenal 2 Henry 43, Kanu 86
Arsenal won 3-1 on aggregate
fields.trailText: English football put its faith in Arsenal last night - and were admirably repaid. These seasoned standard bearers in Europe reached next month's final in Copenhagen and few would bet against such a resilient and composed team bringing back the silverware.
fields.body:
English football put its faith in Arsenal last night - and were admirably repaid. These seasoned standard bearers in Europe reached next month's final in Copenhagen and few would bet against such a resilient and composed team bringing back the silverware.

Inevitably the talk will be of the French connection here last night as Arsène Wenger sent out a team that was to flourish once Thierry Henry, currently in irresistible mood, struck superbly in the 43rd minute to register his seventh goal of this competition.

But this was a night on which all those in the north Londoners' famous red and white redeemed England's flagging reputation.

Nwankwo Kanu's goal, coming five minutes from time after an interchange with his fellow substitute Marc Overmars, was no more than Arsenal deserved from a performance in which they grew in confidence to produce flowing football that silenced a passionate home crowd.

Apart from an uncomfortable 13 minutes after Pascal Nouma headed in a simple equaliser, effectively no more than a consolation goal, the prize of a third European final in seven seasons rarely looked like eluding Arsenal.

On May 17 Arsenal go back to the Copenhagen stadium where they won the Cup Winners' Cup in 1994.

Wenger may have been surprised to see Lens making two defensive changes, restoring the towering figure of the former Crystal Palace centre-back Valerien Ismael, after their long resistance at Highbury.

But Arsenal's manager was reassured by the lofty presence in his own rearguard of Tony Adams, despite continuing groin trouble. The captain was one of three changes from the first leg, the others seeing Henry return after suspension and Fredrik Ljungberg preferred to Marc Overmars.

Despite enjoying the bulk of possession in the first 20 minutes, Lens forced David Seaman into action only once when he dived to smother a low cross-cum-shot from Lamine Sakho.

Arsenal's goalkeeper had watched in alarm only seconds earlier, though, when the Senegalese striker, helped by Ray Parlour's loss of balance, strode on to Charles-Edouard Coridon's astute pass down the middle. But Sakho hesitated, enabling Martin Keown to clear the danger.

Henry's pace forced the game's first corner and the French striker produced his side's first shot after 21 minutes, when Parlour's persistence produced an opening on the right. But Henry's drive passed harmlessly wide of the far post.

The French team's initial confidence and neatness started to drain away as Arsenal imposed themselves. Yet another Parlour run saw the lunging Henry again fail to connect before Arsenal fashioned the best movement of the opening period, one carving through the Lens' ranks.

Silvinho found Henry with an intelligent pass down the left that was flicked instantly and cleverly into Dennis Bergkamp's path. The Dutchman strode through the middle and took aim but his deliberate 25-yard shot curled just wide of the far post.

The goal that Arsenal had been threatening arrived two minutes before the interval. Ljungberg and Silvinho were involved in an exchange on the left side of the penalty area before the Brazilian supplied Henry, who turned away from his marker, cleverly dragging the ball as he did so, before unleashing a superb right-foot blast into the far corner.

Arsenal came out after the interval to create, and miss, two glorious chances to make the tie safe. First Bergkamp, doggedly hunting down Franck Queudrue, forced the defender into error, the ball finding its way to Emmanuel Petit. Lens looked in vain for the offside flag but Petit was permitted to advance, only to deliberate about his shot and saw Jose Pierre-Fanfan clear.

Three minutes later, an incisive ball from Petit found Henry in space down the left. The striker, like Bergkamp before, bore down on goal before carefully curling his shot. This time it rebounded from the far post and Parlour, following up, was thwarted by Guillaume Warmuz's desperate save.

Lens (4-1-3-2): Warmuz; Sikora, Ismael, Pierre-Fanfan, Queudrue; Nyarko; Coridon, Dacourt, Brunel; Sakho, Nouma.

Arsenal (4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Keown, Adams, Silvinho; Parlour, Vieira, Petit, Ljungberg; Bergkamp, Henry.

Referee : J M Garcia-Aranda (Spain).

fields.headline: Anger flares at Leeds game
fields.trailText: Angry scenes marred the match between Leeds United and Galatasaray last night, with a missile smashing a window of one of the coaches carrying Turkish executives and journalists to the return leg of a tie that had seen two English supporters killed before the first game in Istanbul.
fields.body:
Angry scenes marred the match between Leeds United and Galatasaray last night, with a missile smashing a window of one of the coaches carrying Turkish executives and journalists to the return leg of a tie that had seen two English supporters killed before the first game in Istanbul.

Police outriders failed to stop the ambush between the city centre and Elland Road, Leeds' stadium, as an object was thrown at the front coach.

Coins were also thrown at the convoy as it turned into the stadium forecourt, where Galatasaray's team coach had arrived safely an hour earlier after a police decoy operation, before the Uefa Cup semi-final second leg.

The tie, won by the Turkish side last night, has been overshadowed by the murders of two Leeds fans in Istanbul two weeks ago on the eve of the first leg, which the Premiership side lost 2-0.

A police spokesman said a dozen arrests had been made, mainly for public order offences. The BBC said four of its journalists had been attacked by angry Leeds supporters.

Chants from hundreds of fans of "We are Leeds" turned to "Scum", with a few men drawing fingers across their throats in a threatening gesture, allegedly after a Turk on one of the buses made an obscene gesture. The throat-cutting gesture was similar to that given by Turkish fans towards United supporters in Istanbul.

The kick-off was delayed by 10 minutes as stewards and police searched every fan amid scuffles outside the ground. The Turkish players were applauded when they took bouquets of flowers and laid them round the pitch.

Galatasaray joined Leeds in wearing black armbands but then there was a muddled attempt at a minute's silence - in reality 20 seconds punctuated by shouts and shushes - as players and officials stood still to remember the murdered fans.

The centre of Leeds was very quiet as fans streamed the two miles to the club's ground, with mounted police stationed outside a number of pubs close to the main railway station but otherwise keeping a low profile.

fields.headline: Spain 8, England 3
fields.standfirst: The deluge finds Manchester United and Chelsea a level too low
fields.trailText: If one man is responsible for the swift disappearance of English interest in the Champions League on successive nights this week it is surely Albert Ferrer.
fields.body:
If one man is responsible for the swift disappearance of English interest in the Champions League on successive nights this week it is surely Albert Ferrer.

He is reported to have suggested that Chelsea wear the all-white strip of Real Madrid at the Nou Camp on Tuesday night, which brought out the beast in his old team, Barcelona, whose victory then raised Real's hackles at Old Trafford the following evening.

Nothing, of course, could be further from the truth. Our Albert remains that growing rarity in football, a full-back pure and simple with no Daedalus-like delusions about sprouting wings.

Chelsea and Manchester United were knocked out of the Champions League quarter-finals because, on their respective nights and in their different ways, they could not cope with attacking play that swept through their ranks like Spanish flu.

At the Nou Camp Gianluca Vialli's defenders were beaten so often in the air that, had Good Friday not been so close, one could have said that Chelsea were nailed on crosses. At Old Trafford Sir Alex Ferguson's centre-backs, Jaap Stam and Henning Berg, were outwitted on the ground not only by Raul and Fernando Morientes but by Steve McManaman floating, probing and prodding in the manner of a poor man's Eric Cantona.

Obviously Manchester United's was the greater fall. They had won the European Cup so theatrically in Barcelona a year earlier. Now they let it go with an equal sense of the dramatic, except that this time the mood was a mixture of black comedy and pantomime.

Chelsea did not play well at the Nou Camp but at least they were within seven minutes of going through despite the inspirational play of Rivaldo and Luis Figo, the latter offering an uncomfortable reminder of what England can expect in their opening European Championship fixture against Portugal in Eindhoven.

United's cause was all but lost once Raul had scored twice in three minutes early in the second half, helped by dreadful defending that saw Mikael Silvestre grant the striker shooting space for his stronger left foot and Fernando Redondo allowed to run half the length of the pitch to set Raul up for a simple tap-in.

It was a bad night, moreover, for Roy Keane to make more mistakes in one game than he normally does in a dozen. The well-meant but ill-judged lunge that turned an innocuous cross-shot from Michel Salgado into a calamitous own-goal left United to score twice to reach the semi-finals. Once Real had doubled that target, and with Iker Casillas, their 18-year-old goalkeeper, again in fine form, Old Trafford was looking for miracles.

Last season, for Ferguson's team, these were ten-a-penny: the brisk trading of goals with Barcelona and Bayern Munich in the group games, the 3-2 victory over Juventus after going 2-0 down, and the final triumph over Bayern with those stoppage-time goals from Teddy Sheringham and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer.

Manchester United did not win the European Cup because they were technically superior to the best the rest of Europe had to offer, far from it, but they combined their still excellent technique with a ferocious will to win, much as Real Madrid did on Wednesday.

Though United enjoyed periods when their passing and movement matched Real's and the performances of Ryan Giggs and David Beckham were well up to muster, there were too many flat spots, too many occasions when the margin for error was unacceptable at this level.

Beckham's outstanding goal, a reminder that he can dribble past defenders when the mood takes him, prompted a 25-minute assault on the Real goal that yielded nothing more than Paul Scholes's 88th-minute penalty.

At least Manchester United are assured of a presence in next season's Champions League and should complete their sixth Premiership championship in eight seasons over the Easter holiday. True their share price dropped a dozen points the morning after but they remain the world's richest football club and may now need to spend like one if they are to regain lost glory. Chelsea, struggling to make the top three in the Premiership, may have to be satisfied with the Uefa Cup next time and for some of their big names winning the FA Cup this season would be a minor compensation for missing out on the big one.

webTitle: Accies docked 15 points and go down

fields.headline: Accies docked 15 points and go down
fields.trailText: Hamilton Academical were yesterday docked 15 points and virtually relegated into the Third Division as the Scottish Football League handed out the most swingeing punishment in its history.
fields.body:
Hamilton Academical were yesterday docked 15 points and virtually relegated into the Third Division as the Scottish Football League handed out the most swingeing punishment in its history.

The sentence was imposed, without the right of appeal, after the club's players went on strike minutes before their match against Stenhousemuir on April 1, claiming that their wages had not been paid.

They had threatened to take industrial action before a previous match. The cheques were handed over days after the Stenhousemuir game was called off.

"I'm surprised, disappointed and still coming to terms with the decision", the club's chief executive Bill Sherry said last night. "There was a company on the phone selling outdoor equipment just now. I asked if they had any gallows.

"The club was willing and able to play the game but the players didn't. That has been ignored but we will see what the judgment says when it comes out. We were not at the hearing.

"This is not natural justice but it is the decision of the league. I really don't know what is going to happen to the club now."

Hamilton now have 19 points, 10 behind Queen of the South who had looked doomed with only one club going down from the Second Division because of league reorganisation. In addition, Hamilton will also have to pay Stenhousemuir's expenses for the postponed match - more than £2,000.

Aberdeen Supporters Association is threatening legal action against the SFA over its allocation of tickets for the Scottish Cup final at Hampden Park on May 27. Rangers have been told they will receive 24,549 while Aberdeen must make do with 17,600. The fans claim this breaks an earlier promise that finalists should gain equal numbers of tickets.

webTitle: Spurs splash out on Luton youngster

fields.headline: Spurs splash out on Luton youngster
fields.trailText: Tottenham Hotspur are set to sign the Irish youth and Under-21 international Gary Doherty from Luton Town for £1m plus increments depending on his progress.
fields.body:
Tottenham Hotspur are set to sign the Irish youth and Under-21 international Gary Doherty from Luton Town for £1m plus increments depending on his progress.

Doherty can play in attack or defence and has been tracked for several months by Tottenham's director of football David Pleat, a former Luton manager.

"The clubs have agreed on the deal," said the Luton manager Lennie Lawrence. "It will go through as soon as he passes a medical and agrees personal terms."

The Spurs manager George Graham is not expected to return to the club in time to take charge against Wimbledon on Saturday. He has been released from hospital and is back at home after tests on rheumatoid arthritis but must wait to see a specialist next week.

Doncaster Rovers of the Nationwide Conference have sacked their manager Ian Snodin, the former Everton and Leeds midfielder. The se nior players Dave Penney and Mark Atkins will take charge until the end of the season.

Thousands of Middlesbrough fans yesterday lined the route to the city's cathedral, where there was a requiem mass for their former player Wilf Mannion, who died last week aged 81. Middlesbrough's manager Bryan Robson attended along with his coaching staff and players.

The Tranmere manager John Aldridge has been fined a total of £750 for his clash with the Leicester midfielder Theo Zagorakis during the Worthington Cup final and for comments made to a match official during a game against Birmingham last November.

Aldridge has denied a third charge that followed comments he allegedly made to officials at Portsmouth.

Wimbledon's Robbie Earle is recovering after developing a blood clot in his stomach that required a blood transfusion.

fields.headline: Everton 0 - 0 Liverpool
fields.trailText:
Everton: Gerrard, Xavier, Weir, Dunne, Unsworth, Barmby, Collins, Pembridge, S. Hughes, M. Hughes, Hutchison.
Substitutes: Ball, Jeffers, Jevons, Ward, Simonsen.
fields.body:
Everton: Gerrard, Xavier, Weir, Dunne, Unsworth, Barmby, Collins, Pembridge, S. Hughes, M. Hughes, Hutchison.
Substitutes: Ball, Jeffers, Jevons, Ward, Simonsen.

Liverpool: Westerveld, Carragher, Henchoz, Hyypia, Matteo, Thompson, Hamann, Gerrard, Berger, Owen, Heskey.
Substitutes: Smicer, Fowler, Heggem, Murphy, Nielsen.

Referee: G Poll (Tring)

1 min Liverpool kick off at Goodison Park, historically a venue that has been a difficult place for the Reds to get a result. This Liverpool side has grown in confidence in recent months and will fancy their chances tonight.
2 David Thompson gets an elbow in the throat from Don Hutchison. Play continues and Thompson jogs down the touchline, rubbing his neck.
5 Heskey is the target for the ball over the top from the Liverpool midfield. For the third time in the first five minutes the long ball just reaches Gerrard in the Everton goal before the arrival of Emile.
6 Thompson is the first player to be booked as an over-enthusiastic tackle on Barmby leaves the Everton man poleaxed.
8 Mark Hughes feeds a great ball through the middle for Barmby to latch on to. His left-foot shot across the goal lacks pace and Westerveld makes the save with ease.
10 Mark Hughes penalised for backing into Henchoz. How many more times will that happen tonight?
12 Berger pounces on a loose clearance from Gerrard and plays in a delightful through-ball for Owen. The Liverpool striker advances on the Everton keeper, but Gerrard does everything right and makes the save to his right. Owen will rue not hitting it with his left foot, opting to scuff it in with his right.
13 Mark Hughes breaks upfield for the Toffees and tries his luck from 25 yards on the right. his effort is weak and straight at Westerveld.
15 Mark Hughes, with his back to goal (surprise) lays the ball back to his namesake Stephen. The former Arsenal man's rising shot is never going to trouble the Liverpool keeper, and sails harmlessly out of play. Goal kick. Early encouragement for Hughes and Everton.
18 Everton playing all of their creative attacking play through Mark Hughes. The Welsh firebrand feeds Stephen Hughes on the left. His snap shot skids across the face of the goal, and Unsworth cannot keep it in play.
21 A corner to Everton, from the left, taken deep to Mark Hughes at the far post. His scissor-kick/volley is ambitious even by his standards, and the ball balloons off his left foot for a goal kick.
24 Again, Gerrard has to sprint of his line as another slide-rule through-ball from Berger for Heskey to chase bisects the Everton defence. One of these is going to get through tonight.
26 It's all a bit scrappy as the soggy conditions underfoot make it difficult to set off on any long, mazy runs. Both sides swap possession in midfield four, five times and eventually it trickles out for a throw. The match needs some quality.
30 Chaos and mayhem in the Everton area as Heskey feeds a diagonal ball to Thompson on the right, who in turn feeds a first-time cross met by Owen at the far post. His shot is directed downwards and the bounce fools Gerrard, who spills the save. Heskey seems to hesitate as the ball falls to him, and Dunne has just enough time to clear. A great chance and Heskey will be kicking himself.
35 Liverpool continue to press during their best spell of the match so far. Berger is getting more of the ball, and that is reflecting in the increase the overall quality and imagination of the Liverpool attack.
39 Heskey injured as he challenges for an aerial ball. He lands awkwardly, twisting his back on impact, and is receiving lengthy treatment from the Liverpool physio.
40 Heskey back on the pitch, smiling away. Good news for Liverpool and England.
43 David Unsworth clatters into Thompson. X-rated Merseyside derby stuff - the pace of the game hasn't wavered during this frantic first half.
44 Hamann raises his boot into John Collins' face and is booked.
45 Heskey, on defensive duty, challenges Xavier on a cross at Westerveld's left-hand post. He immediately indicates to the Liverpool bench that his back is still bothering him, and again the physio works his magic. Anxious moments for Gerard Houllier.
47 Liverpool have a free kick on the left, 40 yards from goal. The cross is poorly directed and Everton can clear.
48 A high-octane half comes to an end. Hopefully there will be more quality on display in the second half.

45 Liverpool substitution: Robbie Fowler for Emile Heskey. A great striker joins the match.
47 Berger almost latches on to an excellent lofted through-ball from Hamann, but for once his first touch is poor and Gerrard can collect.
48 Gerard denied by Gerrard on the left. A good shooting chance from 15 yards and the Everton keeper does well to parry the effort away. Liverpool have started really brightly, buoyed by Fowler's return.
50 Nicky Barmby drives a low shot from the left to Westerveld's near post, after Mark Hughes' tenacity pays dividends on the left touchline. The Dutch keeper saves well - Everton's first chance of the half.
53 Michael Owen beats two Everton defenders with pace and change of direction on the left. His low, skidding shot beats Gerrard, but shaves the outside of the upright.
56 Liverpool substitution: Heggem for Thompson.
57 Mark Hughes, looking suspiciously offside, is deemed to be onside and breaks through the middle. Gerrard narrows the angle but Hughes' shot from the right slides across the Liverpool goal. Their best chance of the night goes begging and the veteran Welshman knows he should have done better.
59 Henchoz saves Liverpool's bacon with an athletic clearance just as Mark Hughes' lofted pass looked to be landing at Hutchison's feet with only Westerveld to beat.
62 The challenges are flying in thick and fast. Matteo on Collins, then Gerard on Xavier. The ref keeps his cards close to his chest.
64 Pembridge snatches at a chance on the right from 20 yards and misses the target. This is after Mark Hughes demolishes Dominic Matteo for a 50-50 ball. Matteo, somewhat understandably, is slow to rise to his feet.
66 John Collins makes space for a shot from the left, from 25 yards out. The rising drive is a powerful one, but straight at the Liverpool keeper.
68 It seems impossible, but the action seems to have gone up a gear. This frantic match is only pausing for fouls.
70 A cross from the right is cleared for an Everton corner. The centre is aimed at the near post, and is cleared easily. Another corner results, and another poor delivery follows. 80 Hamann almost finds Owen with a low cross-shot from the right that eludes everyone in the Everton box. Looks like one goal will decide this.

82 Everton substitution: Jeffers for Mark Hughes.
83 Patrik Berger screams a rising drive at Gerrard from 20 yards centre-right. The Everton keeper can only parry to shot, and Gerard cannot control the follow-up shot, which balloons out for a goal kick.
84 Jeffers his welcomed to the game by Henchoz, with a sliding tackle worth a booking, according to referee Poll.
85 Everton substitution: Ball for Pembridge.

webTitle: Middlesex on threshold of no-play progress

fields.headline: Middlesex on threshold of no-play progress
fields.trailText: Angus Fraser, itching to get cracking after a week of unscheduled thumb-twiddling, was far from distraught when yesterday's B&H Cup tie between Middlesex and Sussex at Lord's was abandoned without a coin being tossed. "If things had remained as they were on Wednesday, we could have qualified for the quarter-finals without bowling a ball," he said, smirking sheepishly.
fields.body:
Angus Fraser, itching to get cracking after a week of unscheduled thumb-twiddling, was far from distraught when yesterday's B&H Cup tie between Middlesex and Sussex at Lord's was abandoned without a coin being tossed. "If things had remained as they were on Wednesday, we could have qualified for the quarter-finals without bowling a ball," he said, smirking sheepishly.

The Middlesex and England seamer, who like his colleagues has yet to deliver a ball in earnest this season, may yet be proved correct. With the leading two teams in each of the three qualifying divisions progressing to next month's quarter-finals alongside the two third-placed sides boasting the best net run-rates, the Seaxes could still advance without muddying their boots.

Nor is it entirely beyond the realms of possibility that Middlesex's South Division rivals Kent, who suffered their third wash-out in four fixtures when their tilt with Hampshire was called off, could reach the knockout stages with the bare minimum of sweat and toil.

All of which, inevitably, calls into question the wisdom of beginning the season in the first week of April, earlier than ever before. Admittedly a fixture list bulging as never before renders an early start all but obligatory - all but, because the alternative, it seems, has not been seriously examined.

County cricket in October, of course, will be seen by many as sacrilegious. Yet one well-oiled argument, that football would overshadow the season's closing stages, simply does not stand up to scrutiny; it already overshadows all but a month or so of the flannelled tomfoolery.

Another, that dew would exert too great an influence, cannot be entirely discounted, although Sussex did discover before they hosted their first floodlit game a couple of years ago that the effect could be minimised by dragging a rope across the square and outfield.

A case could surely now be made for beginning each new term in mid-May - after most of the major football issues have been decided - and extending it into October. There is one proviso: that the final three weeks, say, are devoted exclusively to one-dayers under lights. A little bit more imagination, gentlemen, please.

 Simon Katich came good at Trent Bridge yesterday when Durham beat Nottinghamshire by two runs. The Western Australian left-hander ended his B&H trot of 1, 1 and 1 with Durham's top score of 50.

fields.headline: Dowman quick to settle
fields.standfirst:
Lancashire 218-6
Derbyshire 219-4
Derbyshire won by six wickets
fields.trailText: Derbyshire were distinctly unimpressed by the departure of almost half of last year's first-choice team, muttering darkly about the influence of their former player turned agent John Morris, but on this evidence they have wheeled and dealed effectively in county cricket's busiest-ever close season.
fields.body:
Derbyshire were distinctly unimpressed by the departure of almost half of last year's first-choice team, muttering darkly about the influence of their former player turned agent John Morris, but on this evidence they have wheeled and dealed effectively in county cricket's busiest-ever close season.

The former Warwickshire veteran Tim Munton put Lancashire on the back foot from the start, bowling his 10 overs straight through to claim two for 20. Mathew Dowman, a former youth international released by Nottinghamshire, scored an excellent 65 in addition to taking two important wickets to claim his first gold award. And Rob Bailey employed the know-how accumulated in 18 seasons with Northamptonshire in an unbeaten half-century which steered his new county to victory with an over to spare.

Derbyshire are now top of the North Division with five points from three matches, while Lancashire may be unable to reach the quarter-finals even if they win their remaining game. After dropping four catches yesterday, two of them straightforward and three in the tense closing stages, they have only themselves to blame.

The tall 34-year-old Munton had Mike Atherton lbw playing no shot and John Crawley caught behind, and Lancashire fell to 33 for three after Sourav Ganguly edged Paul Aldred to slip. But they recov ered as Neil Fairbrother and Andy Flintoff dug them out of trouble with an intelligent fourth-wicket stand.

Flintoff responded to his new coach Bob Simpson's twin demands that he bat more responsibly and play straighter, although the powerful England all-rounder still took only 75 balls to reach 70 with eight fours and a six off Dowman's first ball. But the medium-pacer stuck to his task and was rewarded when in consecutive balls Flintoff top-edged a pull and Fairbrother drove uppishly to mid-off.

Even then, thanks to Graham Lloyd and Joe Scuderi, Lancashire's new Italian-qualified Australian, the visitors were still able to post a total of 218 which should have been more than enough on a slow pitch. But Derbyshire shrugged off the early loss of their own new Australian, Michael di Venuto, with the left-handed Dowman striking 11 stylish boundaries in a second-wicket stand of 100 with Matthew Cassar.

They wobbled a little as Ian Austin tightened the screw and Flintoff delivered a wicket maiden in the 43rd over but Bailey was dropped once and Dominic Cork twice before reaching double figures - all the help the Staffordshire pair needed to see Derbyshire home.

 Lord's and the Zimbabwe board both confirmed yesterday that the Zimbabweans' two-test tour is going ahead despite the violence at home and that the squad is expected in London on Monday. The unrest is most worrying for Zimbabwe's fast bowler Heath Streak, whose father is a farmer.

Even then, thanks to Graham Lloyd and Joe Scuderi, Lancashire's new Italian-qualified Australian, the visitors were still able to post a total of 218 which should have been more than enough on a slow pitch. But Derbyshire shrugged off the early loss of their own new Australian, Michael di Venuto, with the left-handed Dowman striking 11 stylish boundaries in a second-wicket stand of 100 with Matthew Cassar. They wobbled a little as Ian Austin tightened the screw and Flintoff delivered a wicket maiden in the 43rd over but Bailey was dropped once and Dominic Cork twice before reaching double figures - all the help the Staffordshire pair needed to see Derbyshire home.  Lord's and the Zimbabwe board both confirmed yesterday that the Zimbabweans' two-test tour is going ahead despite the violence at home and that the squad is expected in London on Monday. The unrest is most worrying for Zimbabwe's fast bowler Heath Streak, whose father is a farmer.

fields.headline: Earth
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Mehta's engaging picture dramatises the real human cost of geopolitical decisions
fields.body: The insidious British imperial policy of partition was carried out in Ireland, Palestine, Cyprus and, as Deepa Mehta's engaging movie Earth reminds us, in India. It is set in 1947, when a newly independent India was split by Mountbatten to create the state of Pakistan, in such a way as to lead to the bloody, and indeed nuclear, confrontation that exists today. A reasonably peaceful, multi-ethnic society in Lahore is shattered by the new national boundaries, leading to tragedy for an urbane family of Parsees and their beautiful ayah Shanti (Nandita Das). Mehta's picture dramatises the real human cost of these geopolitical decisions and the concomitant "exchange of populations".

fields.headline: Nightmare on Wall Street
fields.standfirst: Bret Easton Ellis's showy novel becomes a film with a high IQ and a fine performance by Christian Bale
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A stylish, disquieting, unexpectedly witty piece of cinema... This is a clever, efficiently nasty film that hooks into the mind
fields.body:
In American Psycho, director Mary Harron has transformed Bret Easton Ellis's showy, explicitly violent novel into a stylish, disquieting, unexpectedly witty piece of cinema. And in doing so, has given us the first big star of the new decade: Christian Bale, an actor who gives a smart and sensuously physical performance.

He is Patrick Bateman, a smirking, self-important young man working for a Wall Street merchant bank in the 1980s. Grotesquely overpaid, he lounges in his hi-tech, spotlessly clean bachelor pad; he broods over the latest restaurants, the hippest clubs; he works out; he is casually, heartlessly unfaithful to Evelyn (Reese Witherspoon), his "supposed fiancée".

At the office, he competes ruthlessly with the other Ivy League fellows, and never seems to have to do any work - which is, incidentally, the one period error Harron commits: no financial institution, certainly no American institution of that time would let an employee get away with skiving in their office, listening to a chunky Sony Walkman. But there is something else about Bateman. He has a taste for slashingly, murdering violence - and the odd acte gratuit against tramps escalates into a raging secret addiction to killing, mainly women and prostitutes he lures to his apartment. Or is it all happening in his head?

Fans of the novel routinely claim the stomach-turning violence that once made it so controversial is a brilliant metaphor for the 1980s culture of consumerism and self-gratification. I am agnostic about these claims to moral seriousness, and that violence/materialism link has always looked a bit specious and glib.

But, either way, violence raises a distinctively generic problem in a commercial movie that it doesn't in a literary novel, and Harron adroitly solves this problem or, at any rate, bypasses it, by having most of the slicing and dicing happen off-camera. So it is saved from looking like a slasher movie with pretensions, or a sub-Joe Eszterhas chiller.

Harron and Guinevere Turner's adaptation is very funny when Bateman and his buddies compete for who has the most stylish business card, or when Bateman calls the smartest restaurant in Manhattan, asks them for a table for two at 8.30 that evening and is rewarded by the maitre d' simply laughing uncontrollably until Bateman is forced, disconsolately, to hang up.

When Bateman and one of his pseudo-friends have crowded into a night spot lavatory stall, and started arguing about something, someone pops their head over the top of the one next door and says: "Hey, will you keep the noise down, I'm trying to do drugs in here!" All the strange banality and gentility of upscale partying habits are summed up in the line.

Ellis's set-piece ruminations about 1980s recording giants Phil Collins, Genesis and Huey Lewis and the News are put into Bateman's mouth as supercilious speeches to the wary, resentful women who have entered his lair. These arias of drollness, juxtaposed as they are with the promise of imminent horror, are very funny, and it is at these moments you realise the script has a higher IQ than almost anything else around. But they are also replete with the inverted-commas, post-modern irony that was actually the last word in intellectual modishness in the 90s - and is now itself a bit dated.

Despite the notional 80s setting, Ronald Reagan on TV etc, everything looks and feels more or less contemporary, particularly the burnished chrome of Bateman's spiffy apartment. This is a digitally remastered, remixed 1980s, suitable for über-cool satire, without any of the low-comic tackiness or bad haircuts of, say, The Wedding Singer.

Bale is really excellent, and it is odd to think how close Leonardo DiCaprio came to being monumentally miscast in the part. Especially at the top of the film, performing his morning facial defoliation scrub routine, Bale is a massively threatening, preening, narcissistic figure, all abs and pecs. His large, impassive face attains the almost creepy handsomeness of a young Schwarzenegger. (It would be interesting to see Bale in a leading Shakespearian role of martial aggression - is anyone making Coriolanus?)

Harron defers the moments of horrid revelation until the end, and this restraint pays off as she lets rip with some really nasty Tobe Hooper unpleasantness, and then, with Bateman's final, hideous voice-over about his mission simply to perpetuate and spread pain for all eternity, a little of Abel Ferrara. This is a clever, efficiently nasty film that hooks into the mind.

webTitle: Lucasfilm sues rapper over sound clip

fields.headline: Lucasfilm sues rapper over sound clip
fields.trailText: Reports from the US suggest that American Rapper Dr Dre is being sued by George Lucas's Lucasfilm in one of the first cases of copyright infringement of a sound.
fields.body:
Reports from the US suggest that American Rapper Dr Dre is being sued by George Lucas's Lucasfilm in one of the first cases of copyright infringement of a sound.

The rap superstar is accused of using a sound called 'THX Deep Note', a sound Lucasfilm has trademarked - he claims the first sound ever to be trademarked - without the company's permission. The sound, described as a rumbling explosion, is used to accompany the THX logo before film screenings in cinemas with THX sound systems.

The sound is used over the opening of the Dr Dre 2001 album. MTV reports that Dre's lawyer claims not have received the suit, while a spokesperson for Interscope, Dre's record label would not comment.

webTitle: American Beauty's screen kiss is too hot for MTV

fields.headline: American Beauty's screen kiss is too hot for MTV
fields.trailText: Dreamworks, the studio behind Oscar-winning American Beauty has refused to let MTV use a clip of Kevin Spacey and Mena Suvari in a clinch for the network's ninth annual Movie Awards, despite the smooch snagging a viewers' nomination for best onscreen kiss.
fields.body:
Dreamworks, the studio behind Oscar-winning American Beauty has refused to let MTV use a clip of Kevin Spacey and Mena Suvari in a clinch for the network's ninth annual Movie Awards, despite the smooch snagging a viewers' nomination for best onscreen kiss.

Awards show producer Joel Gallen says the nomination was pulled because DreamWorks disapproved.

"They wouldn't clear it for us. It's a shame," Gallen says. "We generate nominees by viewer survey, and that came in the top five, but the only way it works is if we get the clips. Obviously, it was a very controversial kiss, and DreamWorks felt it was out of context without being part of the overall movie."

American Beauty's questionable kiss features Kevin Spacey's 40-something character realising his fantasies surrounding his teenage daughter's nubile best friend.

A DreamWorks spokesperson said the studio didn't want the scene glorified by MTV's light-hearted award for best onscreen kiss.

"It's inappropriate to celebrate a relationship between a 16-year-old girl and a 40-year-old man within the context of a 'Best Kiss' clip" a representative said. "Within the context of the entire movie, the relationship is made clear, and the kiss is seen as inappropriate."

fields.headline: Surprise hit sweeps Italy's awards
fields.trailText: Silvio Soldini's Bread And Tulips (Pane e Tulipani) took nine prizes at Italy's leading awards ceremony - the David di Donatellos - last night, including best film, best director and best screenplay for Soldini and Doriana Leondeff.
fields.body:
Silvio Soldini's Bread And Tulips (Pane e Tulipani) took nine prizes at Italy's leading awards ceremony - the David di Donatellos - last night, including best film, best director and best screenplay for Soldini and Doriana Leondeff.

The film also bagged awards for best actress, best actor, best supporting actress and best sound. Bread And Tulips is a surprise hit at the Italian box office, winning its audience and critical appeal strictly by word of mouth. The film has been released on only 39 screens and is the only Italian film currently in the country's box office top 10.

In what is becoming almost predictable, the best foreign film award went to Oscar winner Pedro Almodovar for All About My Mother.

webTitle: UK box office jumps 21% in first quarter of year

fields.headline: UK box office jumps 21% in first quarter of year
fields.trailText: Fuelled by the phenomenal success of Toy Story 2, box office revenue for the UK and Eire during the first three months of 2000 has risen by 21% compared to the same period last year. The £163m taken from January to March also exceeds the blockbusting period in 1998 when Titanic drove box-office levels to an all-time high of £160m.
fields.body:
Fuelled by the phenomenal success of Toy Story 2, box office revenue for the UK and Eire during the first three months of 2000 has risen by 21% compared to the same period last year. The £163m taken from January to March also exceeds the blockbusting period in 1998 when Titanic drove box-office levels to an all-time high of £160m.

Story 2 - which broke the record for the highest three-day gross in February with £7.6m - scooped the lion's share of revenue during the first quarter with £41.5m. February was one of the best months on record taking £78m - a 35% increase on the same month last year.

Admissions reflect this bonanza period at British cinemas but to a far lesser extent, emphasise the underlying rise in ticket prices over the last two years.

webTitle: Pearl Harbour veterans protest over Disney movie

fields.headline: Pearl Harbour veterans protest over Disney movie
fields.trailText: US war veterans have slammed plans to portray a famous American aircraft carrier as a Japanese warship in Disney's new blockbuster, Pearl Harbour, which currently in production starring Ben Affleck, Kate Beckinsdale and Cuba Gooding.
fields.body:
US war veterans have slammed plans to portray a famous American aircraft carrier as a Japanese warship in Disney's new blockbuster, Pearl Harbour, which currently in production starring Ben Affleck, Kate Beckinsdale and Cuba Gooding.

The BBC reports that the group of campaigners, based in Texas, say it would be an insult to the memory of the servicemen who lost their lives in the world war two battle.

The film's producers are keen to convert the USS Lexington - now a floating museum - into the Japanese carrier which launched dozens of bombers on the raid.

But 77-year-old Harry Ogg, of the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association, based in Corpus Christi - where the Lexington is anchored - said: "I think it's a disservice to the many men who lost their lives at Pearl Harbor, Corregidor and other battles.

"You can't have a Japanese war flag flying on a US warship."

Museum spokeswoman Sandi McNorton played down the controversy, pointing out that the Lexington had already portrayed a Japanese vessel in the 1976 film Midway, and would be used sparingly.

"The controversy is overstated," she said. "We believe it is an excellent movie and it makes sense for us to be a part of it."

fields.headline: Julia Roberts is box-office gold
fields.trailText: The actress's latest film passed the $100m mark on Tuesday, making it Robert's third movie in a row to do so, according to Universal Pictures
fields.body:
Eyebrows may have been raised over Julia Roberts's $20m fee for Erin Brockovich, but the money men have no cause for complaint now.

The actress's latest film passed the $100m mark on Tuesday, making it Robert's third movie in a row to do so, according to Universal Pictures.

It's her eighth film to earn more than $100m, one more than Tom Cruise. The milestone also positions her third all-time at the box office, behind Tom Hanks and Harrison Ford, who have 10 and nine $100 million-plus-earning films to their credits, respectively.

Julia's seven highest-grossing films: Pretty Woman, $178.4m

Runaway Bride, $152.1m

My Best Friend's Wedding, $126.8m

Hook, $119.6m

Notting Hill, $116m

Sleeping With the Enemy, $101.5m

The Pelican Brief, $100.6m
