fields.headline: Tails of the unexpected
fields.standfirst: A bunny isn't just for Easter: Playboy's is set to make a comeback.  Jess Cartner-Morley is all ears
fields.trailText: This bunny is more famous than the Easter bunny. The Playboy rabbit head is one of the most recognisable images of our time, instantly resonant of martini glasses and silk pyjamas, jacuzzis and curves. Vladimir Nabokov, a respected butterfly enthusiast in his spare time, was once moved to write to Hugh Hefner to point out how the carefully positioned wings and eyespot of a butterfly can be made to look like the Playboy bunny motif. As a pictorial logo, it is in the same league as Nike's seminal swoosh, but unlike the swoosh, the bunny has a distinctly retro flavour, firmly lodged in the 60s and 70s heyday of Hugh Hefner's empire. Nonetheless, this is one bunny that is about to come bouncing back.
fields.body:
This bunny is more famous than the Easter bunny. The Playboy rabbit head is one of the most recognisable images of our time, instantly resonant of martini glasses and silk pyjamas, jacuzzis and curves. Vladimir Nabokov, a respected butterfly enthusiast in his spare time, was once moved to write to Hugh Hefner to point out how the carefully positioned wings and eyespot of a butterfly can be made to look like the Playboy bunny motif. As a pictorial logo, it is in the same league as Nike's seminal swoosh, but unlike the swoosh, the bunny has a distinctly retro flavour, firmly lodged in the 60s and 70s heyday of Hugh Hefner's empire. Nonetheless, this is one bunny that is about to come bouncing back.

Eagle-eyed couch potatoes may have noticed Carrie Bradshaw, aka Sarah Jessica Parker, wearing a Playboy bunny pendant in the massively successful Sex In The City series. Which might not sound like very strong evidence, but bear in mind that the fashion-forward, urban-glamour Carrie Bradshaw "look" has whipped America's style press into a frenzy not seen since Jennifer Aniston spawned a million "Rachel" haircuts.

On this side of the Atlantic, Stella McCartney got into trouble when she included a sharp-toothed, skeletal version of the bunny in her spring/ summer 2000 collection for Chloe. (The designs were withdrawn when Playboy got wind of them, though Helen Isaacson, president of product marketing for Playboy Inc. in New York, told American Vogue: "No one is defining what is trendy, unique, or desirable for young people more than Stella McCartney. What she represents in the fashion world is exactly where we're going.") Meanwhile Gail Porter, best known as the bottom that lit up the Houses of Parliament, sported a bunny necklace on Top of the Pops and Pippa Brooks, the terrifyingly hip co-owner of fashion emporium Shop in London's Soho, wore a 70s gold Playboy bunny necklace when she was photographed for Jane, America's wittiest and most stylish women's magazine.

It was Brooks' soft spot for the bunny that caught Isaacson's attention and last year Playboy approached Brooks and her Shop partner Max Carie with a proposal to licence the bunny motif to their Shopgirl label. The result is a Playboy range within Shopgirl, including jewellery and bunny logo underwear, which will be launched at the Playboy building in New York in June and go on sale later in the summer.

There's no doubt the Playboy bunny has hopped back into fashion focus first and foremost because it fits with current trends (rule one: never underestimate the shallowness of the fashion world). Logos are this season's biggest story and the bunny is undeniably cuter than most monograms, after all. And on catwalks from Paris to New York, the message was: sex sells. Alongside skintight jeans and rhinestones, hotpants and lipgloss, the bunny fits right in. "It's quite Fiorucci," Carie muses. "Cute and sophisticated at the same time."

Cute it might be, but the question remains: why would a girl as cool as Brooks want to be associated with Playboy? Isn't the bunny a symbol of degrading, unequal gender relationships, better left to gather dust with the cottontails? The writer Joan Smith, who has interviewed former bunnies, sees the bunny as representing "a middle-aged man's sex fantasy, and not a very interesting one at that".

But somehow the Playboy image seems harmless in this day and age. Now that every other music video features gyrating G-stringed bottoms, the days when girls in full-cut pants and sturdy black tights were considered the height of erotic decadence seem almost charmingly naive.

Playboy bunnies look about as rude as Victorian ladies lifting their petticoats to show a glimpse of ankle. And it is even harder to see 74-year-old Hugh Hefner, looking increasingly infantile with his pyjamas and kid-in-a-sweetie-shop grin, surrounded by "special friends" Sandy, Mandy and Brande, as anything other than laughable. Even the renaissance of the Playboy Mansion as fantasy sex-Disneyland seems curiously harmless, with stories of security guards on hand to make sure no one gets drunk or takes drugs, and Hef's much-trumpeted new best friend being baby-faced prepubescent favourite Leonardo diCaprio.

"Women feel they are switching things round, wearing the bunny logo," Carie says. Playboy is a magazine for men: "But men can't wear the logo, only women can. Women are saying, I'm choosing to wear this."

To Smith, this is a phoney liberation. "It's like saying it's time we reclaimed footbinding. Certain things were tacky when they happened and they're still tacky. One can laugh at Hefner now, but there is still something vampiric about an old man's lust for young female flesh."

Smith believes the adoption of the bunny by a new generation of women shows how little has changed since the Playboy heyday. "It's still hard for women to find an authentic way to express themselves sexually; they are still searching for a way to be sexual. These organisations [like Playboy] enable women to express that in a way that's safe and socially acceptable. But it's sad women don't have the confidence to be sexual in another way."

Brooks sees it differently. "It's a gut thing with girls: as soon as they see the bunny T-shirts, they love them. Japanese girls especially are obsessed with the Playboy bunny in the same way they're obsessed with Hello Kitty. Girls have taken it over and it's become cute. Most have probably forgotten it comes from a porno magazine."

It was Brooks' soft spot for the bunny that caught Isaacson's attention and last year Playboy approached Brooks and her Shop partner Max Carie with a proposal to licence the bunny motif to their Shopgirl label. The result is a Playboy range within Shopgirl, including jewellery and bunny logo underwear, which will be launched at the Playboy building in New York in June and go on sale later in the summer. There's no doubt the Playboy bunny has hopped back into fashion focus first and foremost because it fits with current trends (rule one: never underestimate the shallowness of the fashion world). Logos are this season's biggest story and the bunny is undeniably cuter than most monograms, after all. And on catwalks from Paris to New York, the message was: sex sells. Alongside skintight jeans and rhinestones, hotpants and lipgloss, the bunny fits right in. "It's quite Fiorucci," Carie muses. "Cute and sophisticated at the same time." Cute it might be, but the question remains: why would a girl as cool as Brooks want to be associated with Playboy? Isn't the bunny a symbol of degrading, unequal gender relationships, better left to gather dust with the cottontails? The writer Joan Smith, who has interviewed former bunnies, sees the bunny as representing "a middle-aged man's sex fantasy, and not a very interesting one at that". But somehow the Playboy image seems harmless in this day and age. Now that every other music video features gyrating G-stringed bottoms, the days when girls in full-cut pants and sturdy black tights were considered the height of erotic decadence seem almost charmingly naive. Playboy bunnies look about as rude as Victorian ladies lifting their petticoats to show a glimpse of ankle. And it is even harder to see 74-year-old Hugh Hefner, looking increasingly infantile with his pyjamas and kid-in-a-sweetie-shop grin, surrounded by "special friends" Sandy, Mandy and Brande, as anything other than laughable. Even the renaissance of the Playboy Mansion as fantasy sex-Disneyland seems curiously harmless, with stories of security guards on hand to make sure no one gets drunk or takes drugs, and Hef's much-trumpeted new best friend being baby-faced prepubescent favourite Leonardo diCaprio. "Women feel they are switching things round, wearing the bunny logo," Carie says. Playboy is a magazine for men: "But men can't wear the logo, only women can. Women are saying, I'm choosing to wear this." To Smith, this is a phoney liberation. "It's like saying it's time we reclaimed footbinding. Certain things were tacky when they happened and they're still tacky. One can laugh at Hefner now, but there is still something vampiric about an old man's lust for young female flesh." Smith believes the adoption of the bunny by a new generation of women shows how little has changed since the Playboy heyday. "It's still hard for women to find an authentic way to express themselves sexually; they are still searching for a way to be sexual. These organisations [like Playboy] enable women to express that in a way that's safe and socially acceptable. But it's sad women don't have the confidence to be sexual in another way." Brooks sees it differently. "It's a gut thing with girls: as soon as they see the bunny T-shirts, they love them. Japanese girls especially are obsessed with the Playboy bunny in the same way they're obsessed with Hello Kitty. Girls have taken it over and it's become cute. Most have probably forgotten it comes from a porno magazine."

fields.headline: Most wanted:  Poole make-up
fields.trailText: Have you ever noticed that while glossy mags insist, "If you only buy one glitter mascara this month, it's got to be aubergine", real women's make-up bags are amazingly monotonous, with eye make-up in an electrifying range of shades from black to charcoal, lipsticks in a dizzying rainbow from pinky-brown to browny-pink. Jolly sensible, but wouldn't it be nice to look just a teeny bit different now and again? Which brings us neatly to Poole make-up, available exclusively at Harvey Nichols in London and Leeds, and the brainchild of Swiss-born graphic designer and girl-about-LA Louise Bonnet. Instead of individual items, you choose one of five kits, each fashionably modelled by Smashing Pumpkins bassist Melissa auf der Maur. Inside are all the colours you'll need, plus step-by-step instructions from professional make-up artists.

Which brings us neatly to Poole make-up, available exclusively at Harvey Nichols in London and Leeds, and the brainchild of Swiss-born graphic designer and girl-about-LA Louise Bonnet. Instead of individual items, you choose one of five kits, each fashionably modelled by Smashing Pumpkins bassist Melissa auf der Maur. Inside are all the colours you'll need, plus step-by-step instructions from professional make-up artists.

In the interests of research, I opted for the sunkissed-looking Afterglow kit: it was easy to follow, the products were good quality, but sadly the moody bronze hues, so stunning on Ms auf der Maur, made me look as if I were recovering from a pair of black eyes, which I'm guessing isn't the afterglow they were thinking of. The Bardot-esque Beach Ball kit, however, and the retro-sophisticated Delta of Venus looked a treat. My verdict? An excellent idea, but try before you buy (at £39.50 per kit, mistakes don't come cheap). Oh go on, you know you want to.

fields.headline: Goodness and greed
fields.standfirst:
However noisy the demonstrations against global capitalism, ethics in business are unenforceable

IMF and WTO protests: special report
fields.trailText: However noisy the demonstrations against global capitalism, ethics in business are unenforceable
fields.body:
"Smash capitalism", announced the banners of the protesters in the Washington streets last weekend. Global capitalism has a bad name these days, even when it takes the form of such innocuous British giants as Unilever, currently being reviled on American websites for buying Ben & Jerry's, makers of fashionable ice cream. So perhaps it is not surprising that more and more companies want to be seen to be good. They set up advisory committees on social responsibility; they write codes of corporate ethics; they appoint ethics officers; they talk of their duties to their stakeholders. Admirable though such efforts may appear, they are founded on a moral misunderstanding.

Companies that strive to behave ethically generally argue that they do so because, in the long run, it is good for business. Most of the time, they are right. Sometimes, indeed, they have little option, because ethical behaviour is what the law demands. In most countries, at least in the rich world, the law discourages companies from lying to customers, cheating their employees, or stealing from taxpayers. The primary moral duties of those who run companies are to obey the law, and to ensure that their employees do too.

Good behaviour may spring from other self-interested motives. For instance, in the United States various laws and court rulings encourage managers to tell employees how to behave ethically and to see that they do so. In addition, it has become more embarrassing to be caught doing something unethical. Non-governmental organisations fight hard for members and money these days; and they gain good publicity from harrying a company caught doing something questionable. As Shell and Nike can ruefully attest, being blitzed by NGOs is bad for staff morale, brand strength and the management self-confidence.

More fundamentally, a reputation for ethical behaviour may be a competitive advantage. A firm such as Hewlett Packard would argue that it treats employees, suppliers and customers well because to do so attracts good staff, ensures good service and enhances the value of its brands. Trust is valuable - and will grow more so in an electronic world, where buyers and sellers may be geographically far apart.

Such arguments allow companies to say that they are combining virtue with the pursuit of shareholder value. But what happens when virtue and value clash? Many executives would argue that corporate decisions are rarely black or white.

Say a mining company has a joint venture with a state-owned enterprise in a developing country, which does not care about western safety or environmental standards. Does it pull out, knowing that it might be replaced by another company with fewer scruples, or stay put and try to change things?

Yet every executive, every corporate board, at some point faces a decision that does not quite pass the smell test. A drug company offers health officials from developing countries lavish entertainment as an inducement to buy its drugs. A bank tries to coax people on modest incomes to borrow money to pay for holidays. An internet company sells information gleaned about its customers' surfing habits without their consent. In each case, the company's managers can reasonably argue that they are pursuing the interests of shareholders, and not breaking the law. Is this wrong?

The question makes it clear why corporate ethics is such a tangle. It is hard to think of companies as moral entities, on a par with human beings. A company has, as someone once said, "No soul to damn, no backside to kick". It may have legal obligations that apply to it as an organisation; but it cannot do good or bad without action by the individuals who work for it and own it. In some companies, the corporate culture may be so powerful that it appears to infuse the whole business with a sense of moral values; in others, anything goes. But, while the corporate culture may make it easier or harder for people to behave well, it does not mean that the company has an independent moral existence.

Indeed, ethical codes - the real sort, rather than the kind consultants are paid to concoct - are simply too complex and subtle to be applied to companies. This is not merely because moral values are hard to agree upon: who knows what is "fair pay", or whether pension schemes should treat same-sex couples as though they were married? It is also because companies cannot love their neighbours, or forgive those that hate them, or even act altruistically. These basic moral tasks are human, not corporate.

Where, then, does that leave the individual manager, torn between his corporate responsibility to shareholders and his conscience?

The moral manager applies two tests to any difficult decision. First, how would this look if it were to appear on the front page of a newspaper? And second, will he still be able to look himself in the mirror tomorrow morning without a twinge?

Because companies cannot ask the second question, it is the one that ultimately determines what corporate ethics means.

 Frances Cairncross is on the staff of the Economist

fields.headline: Dilemma for moneybags Brown
fields.standfirst: Treasury surplus needs good home
fields.trailText: If there is such a thing as an embarrassment of riches, then Gordon Brown has it. Once again the chancellor's cautious forecasts for the public sector finances have been surpassed. Instead of having £11bn left in the kitty at the end of the financial year, as he predicted in last month's budget, he has a bumper £15bn. If it were anyone but Gordon, the question would be how quickly can he spend it.
fields.body:
If there is such a thing as an embarrassment of riches, then Gordon Brown has it. Once again the chancellor's cautious forecasts for the public sector finances have been surpassed. Instead of having £11bn left in the kitty at the end of the financial year, as he predicted in last month's budget, he has a bumper £15bn. If it were anyone but Gordon, the question would be how quickly can he spend it.

However, we are in safe hands with Mr Brown. Having already pledged to use his £20bn windfall from the auction of new generation mobile phone licenses for paying down debt, Mr Brown is likely to be similarly hair-shirted about locking his latest bonus.

Above all the Treasury fears repeating the mistakes made by the previous government in the late 80s when it mistook a temporary surplus in the government's finances as a result of an unheathily booming economy, for a structural shift out of deficit. This time, however, most commentators agree that improvement in the fiscal position is real.

Mr Brown's team faces a dilemma. At this stage in the economic cycle, the chancellor cannot spend either the mobile phone windfall or run down his structural surplus without provoking the Bank of England into offsetting the boost to demand with higher borrowing costs.

But the sight of the Treasury revelling in loads of money does not fit well alongside the shabby state of Britain's public services. After decades of underinvestment - in everything from roads to public transport to schools and hospitals - even increases likely to be unveiled in this summer's second comprehensive spending review will not repair the tattered fabric of the public sector.

The one-off bonus of the mobile phone windfall should not be squandered on tax cuts or spending at the expense of higher interest rates. What is needed is some creative thinking about long-term investment ideas which will not immediately flood the economy with cash and force the Bank to retaliate with higher borrowing costs.

The £20bn is a serious amount of money. How to spend it deserves some serious consideration.

Top dogs

The latest set of figures by Caps, the fund performance measuring firm, are an intriguing read. For one thing, name and brand awareness, the speak of the market executives counts for little.

Fuji-Lord Abbett and Orbitex are not household names, but they vie for the top two slots with a return of close to 15% return during the first three months of the year. Languishing at the other end of the much-watched league table are better known firms such as Abbey Life, Britannic, Standard Life and more tellingly Phillips & Drew and Prudential, all of which produced negative returns for their investors.

True, it was a difficult period for many of the so-called "pooled mixed with property funds" with the median return for the sector at minus 0.4%, the slowest start to an investment year since 1994.

To be fair, this is better than the minus 3.4% return of the FTSE All Share index - often used as a benchmark by the major pension fund trustees - during the three month period. But it might be a source of alarm for the trustees, who make the crucial decision about which of the fund management firms should be entrusted with their precious assets, before the recent stock market rout which occurred outside the period of this latest table.

The list makes slightly better reading for the giant Mercury Asset Management, which is creeping back up the honours list, as is Schroders which last quarter got to within a whisker of its 10-year ranking of 16th.

About 65 funds are included in the rankings which show that it is the smallest funds which have produced the best returns. Nine out of the top 10 are investing less than £200m, peanuts in comparison with the £5bn or so the likes of Mercury has to handle. Orbitex, second last quarter but first over the past 12 months, claims to manage just £1m while Fuji, first last quarter, has £67m. For these funds, the telling time could come if the pension fund consultants start to recommend their funds because, as the old names found out to their peril five years ago, this is when the performance is hard to maintain.

Name calling

The embarrassing leak of a stock exchange memo, outlining how blame for a possible collapse in merger discussions with Deutsche Börse might be off-loaded on to the Germans has revived memories of a competition to find a name for the earlier plan to create a simple alliance between the two.

Two years ago when talks first got going, staff at the bourse in Frankfurt were offered the chance to win a weekend in London if they managed to think up the winning name. Likewise, staff in London were offered the chance to win a weekend in Frankfurt. And yes... no one in London bothered to enter the competition.

fields.headline: Starting with a whimper
fields.trailText: English cricket usually descends into farce at some point during the season. But rarely can it have happened as early as mid-April. Chris Lewis is one thing. Starting the Benson & Hedges Cup 25 days after the vernal equinox, the official end of winter, is quite another. Haven't the ECB heard of April showers? Sometimes you wonder.
fields.body:
English cricket usually descends into farce at some point during the season. But rarely can it have happened as early as mid-April. Chris Lewis is one thing. Starting the Benson & Hedges Cup 25 days after the vernal equinox, the official end of winter, is quite another. Haven't the ECB heard of April showers? Sometimes you wonder.

The B&H passed away unmourned at the end of the 1998 season, but was reincarnated last summer as the spurious knockout B&H Super Cup. The members, however, missed their zonal matches, it was said. So back it came. Unfortunately it was not accompanied by clear thinking. The expanded international programme (seven Tests, 10 one-dayers) was always going to mean that the B&H had to be squeezed in at the start of the season - and in one of the wettest months of the year.

The upshot has been predictable. Of the 31 games scheduled up to the start of today, 15 have entered the No Result column. In the South Division, which currently resembles a morgue, only four matches out of 11 have had any play, and Middlesex are yet to emerge from the pavilion at all. Just six sides batting first have been able to make it to 50 overs - either because rain shortened the match, or turned the greentops so green that batting became a lottery (no-one has scored more than Mike Atherton's 81* for Lancashire against Notts). Only four teams have got to 200, while four more have been skittled for double figures: in the game at Trent Bridge, Derbyshire bowled out Notts for 94 in 33.3 overs, before knocking off the runs in just 11.4 - that's a short-changing match total of 45.1 overs. But the killer stat is that a grand total of 1473.5 overs (48% of the possible maximum) have been lost to the weather.

The solution is simple. Abolish the B&H (but do it properly this time) and start the season later. The first round of Championship matches begins on April 26. That's still not ideal, but it's more sensible than this year's starting date of April 7 (when the universities began their ritual humiliation). Better to have no cricket at all than a series of half-hearted ten-over slogs. Someone clearly disagrees.

The non-stop rain has made it hard to work out who's on fire and who isn't (although rumour has it Phil Tufnell has been in top form curled up in the corner of the Lord's dressing-room). Lancashire newcomer Sourav Ganguly (2-0-7-3 v Durham) has so far found it easier to take wickets than score runs. But then so have most seamers who have landed it outside off stump. James Averis had figures of 7.4-2-8-4 for Gloucestershire against Warwickshire, Jason Ratcliffe took 3-15 for Surrey against Sussex (97 all out), and Kabir Ali chipped in with 4-29 on debut for Worcestershire v Glamorgan. If nothing else, the B&H is a great leveller.

What Shane Warne makes of it all is anyone's guess. The biggest overseas signing since Brian Lara turned out for Warwickshire in 1994, he found himself outperformed on his Hampshire debut (10-0-44-0) by a 40-year-old seamer (the redoubtable Peter Hartley: 3-38) and a fellow spinner (Shaun Udal: 2-27). But no-one really cared too much that Ronnie Irani dumped him for six or that Stephen Peters reverse-swept him for four. They were too excited by his mere presence for that.

Warne is one thing county cricket definitely does need.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

The biggest overseas signing since Brian Lara turned out for Warwickshire in 1994, he found himself outperformed on his Hampshire debut (10-0-44-0) by a 40-year-old seamer (the redoubtable Peter Hartley: 3-38) and a fellow spinner (Shaun Udal: 2-27). But no-one really cared too much that Ronnie Irani dumped him for six or that Stephen Peters reverse-swept him for four. They were too excited by his mere presence for that. Warne is one thing county cricket definitely does need. Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: Police defend investigation of Telford deaths

fields.headline: Police defend investigation of Telford deaths
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Detectives yesterday dismissed claims by a forensic expert that they had failed to examine properly the scene where a black man was found hanged in Telford, Shropshire.
fields.body:
Detectives yesterday dismissed claims by a forensic expert that they had failed to examine properly the scene where a black man was found hanged in Telford, Shropshire.

Detective Superintendent Mel Shore, of West Mercia police, told a news conference that officers had taken advice on forensic issues from both their own force and the Metropolitan police.

He was responding to charges made in a Channel 4 Dispatches programme last night about the first investigations into the deaths of Errol McGowan, who was found hanging by an electric flex from a doorknob in July last year, and his nephew Jason McGowan, found hanging from railings in Telford on New Year's Day.

Police decided the deaths were both suicides but, after a campaign by the McGowan family, they reopened the case as an investigation into supicious deaths.

Paul Millen, a former head of scientific support with Surrey police, carried out an assessment of the scene at the house where Errol McGowan died for Dispatches.

He concluded that police, knowing he had been subjected to racial harassment and death threats, should have made an immediate, detailed examination of the house.

Commenting on an apparent lack of investigation about the flex and the absence of signs of a fingerprint inspection on a door, Mr Millen said: "Quite honestly at this moment in time, I am embarrassed to be here, to see, given the allegations that had been made by the family, given the time involved, that this hasn't been done."

He added: "The first officers appear to have made an assumption that this was a suicide. The scene instead, perhaps, should have been dealt with as the scene of a suspicious death."

Mr Shore said that the police had this week removed two doors and an ironing board from the house as part of a long-standing plan dating from the re-opening of the case in February.

"This happened on July 2 last year," Mr Shore added. "It was important if we commission forensic reviews, that we have to consider them as a whole. We have had several reviews.

"If we had gone very quickly, we may well have acted on one of the reviews, only to find that other things should have been done.

"That house [where Errol McGowan was found] is also someone's home and we wanted to carry it out in one go with the minimum of inconvenience."

He added that the investigation was going well and that his team of detectives had examined 240 racial incidents in the area over three years to check for links with the deaths of Errol and Jason. Officers had spoken to 1,000 people since an appeal for information two weeks ago.

Noel McGowan, Jason McGowan's cousin, said that he was pleased with the way the investigation was progressing.

Mr Shore renewed his appeal for the occupants of three vehicles - a dark coloured, old shaped Rover 200, a light coloured Mark 2 Volkswagen Golf, and a red or burgundy Vauxhall Astra - seen in or around Holyhead Road in Telford on the night of Jason McGowan's death to contact the police.

fields.headline: An A-Z of asylum seekers
fields.standfirst:
Here we offer a handy guide which provides all you need to know about refugees, deportations and xenophobia

Refugees: special report
The issues explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: A is for asylum seeker. Individuals who claim to be refugees who are waiting for a decision from the Home Office (HO) on their case.
fields.body:
A is for asylum seeker. Individuals who claim to be refugees who are waiting for a decision from the Home Office (HO) on their case.

B is for bogus. A word banned two years ago by former immigration minister, Mike O'Brien, for being pejorative. It prejudged applications when put before the phrase "asylum seeker". "Abusive" now used instead.

C is for Campsfield House, near Oxford, the largest immigration detention centre. It is run by Group 4 and has been the scene of hunger strikes and disturbances. About 1,000 asylum seekers are detained because there is evidence they will abscond or because they face imminent removal. About half are held in Haslar and Rochester jails.

D is for deportations. More than 7,400 failed asylum seekers were removed or departed voluntarily in the year to June 1999. An unknown number left without telling the HO. Those who are deported are not allowed to return while the order is in force. Those removed rather than deported (such as illegal entrants) may come back if they satisfy the immigration rules.

E is for "exceptional leave to remain". This is granted someone who does not qualify as a refugee but has genuine humanitarian reasons for staying in the UK. About 11% of applicants were given ELR last year.

F is for "failed asylum seeker". This is the official term for someone whose application has been rejected after an initial decision and after appeal.

G is for the 1951 Geneva Convention on refugees to which the UK is signatory; it guarantees the right to asylum. It obliges states to consider all applications for asylum by people claiming to be fleeing from persecution. It provides that lawfully resident refugees should enjoy treatment at least as favourable as that given the indigenous population.

I is for "illegal immigrant". This generic term describes those who are in the UK without authority, for example in breach of a deportation order or by evading immigration control or by deceiving officials on arrival. The HO refuses to estimate the number of illegal immigrants on grounds that it is impossible to know how many are here. If they did they would take enforcement action against them. But see migration.

J is for Lord Justice Simon Brown, the appeal court judge who ruled illegal Peter Lilley's 1996 "uncompromisingly draconian" attempt to remove all welfare benefits from asylum seekers on the grounds that it "contemplates a life so destitute that to my mind no civilised nation can tolerate it". He ruled that under the 1948 National Assistance Act there was a duty to provide care to and accommodation for asylum seekers.

K is for the 3,000 Kosovans who now face removal over the next two months as their 12-month temporary permission to remain runs out.

L is for lorry drivers who now face a £2,000 fine for each illegal entrant discovered travelling in the back of their vehicles.

M is for migration. In 1997 the total inflow of people intending to stay in the UK for one year or more was 285,000. The outflow leaving to live abroad was 225,000, a net increase of 60,000.

N is for the national asylum support service which started work on April 3. It is responsible for the programme of dispersal and support for asylum seekers while their claims are decided. It makes asylum seekers a "no-choice" offer of accommodation and has sent asylum seekers to Glasgow, Liverpool, Newcastle, Sheffield and Manchester.

O is for overstayer, someone who remains in the UK beyond the permitted time. The HO recognises some may have overstayed without realising it; they will lose their right to appeal against removal from October.

P is for pre-entry controls which prevent passengers with no claim to enter the UK from travelling in the first place. They include the use of visas to stop those who are not entitled or do not have the necessary documents getting on the plane. Airlines are now routinely fined if they take passengers without proper papers. Airline liaison officers now work abroad to prevent such passengers coming.

Q is for the queue of asylum seekers waiting for a decision on their case. The backlog stands at 103,000. There is an average wait of 13 months - as a result of the complete breakdown on asylum casework in December 1998 when the bungled introduction of a new computer project reduced the number of decisions to just 800 a month. At that time the backlog stood at 64,000. The asylum process has only just managed to recover with 10,000 decisions being made last month. A special exercise is under way to clear the backlog of people who have been waiting since before 1996.

R is for refugee. This is someone recognised to have a well-founded fear of persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or holding a political opinion. Some 37% of applicants were recognised as full refugees in 1999.

S is for the safe third country rule, under which about 10% of asylum seekers find their claims rejected without any consideration of their individual case. This applies where they passed through another country deemed to be safe en route.

T is for the trend in asylum applications. The record 71,000 asylum applications last year was triggered by the crisis in Kosovo but numbers also surged to record levels in 1993 when Bosnia exploded. It is impossible to predict what next year's overall figures bring as it depends on complex "push" and "pull factors" including the state of the world.

U is for unaccompanied children. Last year there were a total of 3,349 new asylum applications from children and young people under 18.

V is for vouchers which are now being issued to 40% of all asylum seekers instead of benefits. Shops are forbidden from giving cash as change.

W is for the white list of countries from which the HO assumes that asylum applications are unfounded. The list has included Bulgaria, Cyprus, Ghana, Poland, Romania, Ethiopia, India, Kenya, Pakistan and Tanzania. It is to be scrapped in October.

X is for xenophobia. The Oxford English Dictionary describes it as "deep antipathy towards foreigners".

Y is for Yugoslavia, the break-up of which has led to the biggest European crisis in asylum in the past 10 years.

Z is for Zimbabwe, which has 20,000 people who have the right to flee to Britain without the need to go through this asylum system, because they have or had a relative who was born in Britain.

· Alan Travis is the Guardian's home affairs editor.

fields.headline: Playboy losses warning bares all
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Playboy, the adult entertainment media group, warned that first-quarter operating losses would be higher than expected yesterday because of its online investments.
fields.body:
Playboy, the adult entertainment media group, warned that first-quarter operating losses would be higher than expected yesterday because of its online investments.

Shares in the company fell in the morning in New York yesterday, close to a year low and more than half the $36 (£23) they were trading at a year ago.

In January, when the company revealed details of its plans to spin off Playboy.com into a separately traded company, the shares traded at $26. The profits warning comes just before the expected launch of an investor roadshow for Playboy.com in London.

The company said it expected to report an operating loss for its online business of about $5.7m for the quarter to the end of March, compared with $2m last year.

Analysts were forecasting an annual operating loss of between $6m-$9m before yesterday's profit warning and were expected to downgrade their estimates following the announcement.

Christie Hefner, Playboy's chief executive, said: "The increased investments signal our desire to move quickly to take advantage of Playboy.com's many growth opportunities as we continue to prepare for the company's planned initial public offering."

She found some support from Robert Routh, an analyst at Ladenburg Thalman who has been bullish on the company for some time. Mr Routh said he thought the increased investments were a positive step for the online business.

Playboy, which is one of the first traditional media companies to spin off its internet division, also said revenues from its online operations were expected to grow to about $5.8m from $2.2m in the quarter.

The website, based on the same concept as the magazine, attracted 19m unique visits in February. Yesterday's announcement also said the company's offline earnings before interest, tax and depreciation would increase from a year ago.

webTitle: Rip it up and start again

fields.headline: Rip it up and start again
fields.standfirst: You've bought it, now make it yours. Fashion editor  Laura Craik explains how to customise your clothes
fields.trailText: In a recent issue of American Vogue, a London stylist was talking about how she had just bought a Gucci bag, at considerable personal expense, only to get home, reach for the phone and "commission a new handle" to go with it. The bamboo one it came with didn't meet her high standards of taste. Cue much laughter and eyeball rolling about fashion folk.
fields.body:
In a recent issue of American Vogue, a London stylist was talking about how she had just bought a Gucci bag, at considerable personal expense, only to get home, reach for the phone and "commission a new handle" to go with it. The bamboo one it came with didn't meet her high standards of taste. Cue much laughter and eyeball rolling about fashion folk.

But for spring, this particularly British eccentricity is here to stay. It might seem an odd idea: spending good money on something new, only to attack it with scissors, pen or needle and thread the minute you get home. But in an era in which everyone's got the same Gucci bag/Earl jeans/Jack Purcells, it's hard to stand out. Customising your clothes is the best way to make them truly your own. In today's booming economy, having money isn't enough to ensure you look different from the crowd. Everyone can afford the odd label nowadays and they usually go for the same one.

"I got into it by accident," says Meni, a demon customiser working under the label VS. Meni likes to take vintage sweats and Ts, and shorten an arm, add a lace trim or sprinkle on glitter. "I started making stuff to wear myself, but when people began complimenting me, I thought I'd go into business." VS hopes to be stocked in London's The Pineal Eye, which already sells customised clothes by Noki.

Old sweats tend to take on a hefty price tag once they've had a few sequins attached, so we suggest customising clothes yourself. And if the idea fills you with trepidation, or you're an anally retentive type ("Scribble on my shirt? No, no, I couldn't possibly"), hot-foot it down to Top Shop, which sells ready customised garments. Choose from knitwear with velvet trims, embroidered jean skirts and denim jackets with sequined panels: no two are the same. Levi's flagship store on Regent Street also offers a customisation service: pop down with your jeans and they'll embroider them with a pattern of your choice.

fields.headline: Nad's
fields.trailText: You may not have heard of it, but this is the hair remover that may prove Australia's most enduring style legacy. Newly arrived in the UK, Nad's is the invention of Sydney mother Sue Ismiel. Clearly a more dedicated mother than most, she didn't just hand over the razor when daughter Nadine got distressed about her body hair. Instead Sue went into the kitchen and blended her own hair remover. It took over a year to find the right mix of honey, molasses, lemon, fructose and vinegar, but five years on, Nad's (named after the now silky-smooth Nadine) is Australia's bestselling personal care product, with a turnover of $7m.

You may not have heard of it, but this is the hair remover that may prove Australia's most enduring style legacy. Newly arrived in the UK, Nad's is the invention of Sydney mother Sue Ismiel. Clearly a more dedicated mother than most, she didn't just hand over the razor when daughter Nadine got distressed about her body hair. Instead Sue went into the kitchen and blended her own hair remover. It took over a year to find the right mix of honey, molasses, lemon, fructose and vinegar, but five years on, Nad's (named after the now silky-smooth Nadine) is Australia's bestselling personal care product, with a turnover of $7m.

So what's so revolutionary about Nad's? In essence, it's like a home waxing or sugaring kit: you smooth it on, then rip off the hairs with a cotton strip. As anyone who has ever wrestled with a microwaved pot of goo knows, DIY efforts can be very messy indeed, but Nad's melts with your own body heat, eliminating all that faffing around with ovens and hot water (not to mention the unpleasant sensation of too-hot wax on tender skin). And it's water soluble, so you can splash off any excess and (bargain alert!) wash and re-use the strips. Nad's costs £29.95, mail order 0870 789 8010.

webTitle: Cook seeks Mozambique help over Zimbabwe

fields.headline: Cook seeks Mozambique help over Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, today asked president Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique to act as a go-between with Zimbabwe's Robert Mugabe to end the tensions over land rights in the country.
fields.body:
Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, today asked president Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique to act as a go-between with Zimbabwe's Robert Mugabe to end the tensions over land rights in the country.

Mr Cook, who is in Nepal, spoke to Mr Chissano by telephone and asked him to add his voice to those of other African leaders, who are discussing the growing political crisis at a regional summit meeting in Victoria Falls, Zimbabwe.

"I hope that president Chissano and his colleagues, when they meet president Mugabe, will warn him that what he is doing is not just damaging Zimbabwe but also threatens investment, standing and stability of countries around it," Mr Cook said.

Meanwhile, mobs of army veterans kept up their campaign of violence against white-owned farms overnight.

Sources in the besieged white farming community said pro-government forces harassed and intimidated farm workers around Marondera and Wedza, east of Harare. They reported a similar campaign around Arcturus, 20 miles north of the capital Harare, where two farm compounds were reported to have been burnt yesterday.

The violence has continued despite a call yesterday by War Veterans Association leader Chenjerai Hunzvi for a stop to hostilities. He said the occupations would continue without hampering the work of the farmers. At least four people - two white farmers, a policeman and a pregnant woman - have died as a result of the government-sponsored occupation of white farms.

The escalating crisis is on the agenda of today's regional summit meeting in Victoria falls to discuss the war in the Democratic Republic of Congo, which has sucked in Zimbabwe and dragged down its economy. Joining Zimbabwe president Robert Mugabe, will be president Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, president Sam Nujoma of Namibia, president Paul Kagame of Rwanda, president Yoweri Museveni of Uganda and Mr Chissano.

Morgan Tsvangirai, leader of the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), which poses the biggest challenge to Mr Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF in parliamentary elections due in May, called on the summit leaders to put pressure on Mr Mugabe to resolve the crisis in Zimbabwe. "I hope that they will utilise the... meeting in Victoria Falls to put pressure on president Mugabe, [and tell him] that he is pursuing a suicidal path," Mr Tsvangirai said.

Much is expected of South Africa, although Mr Mbeki has maintained a deafening silence on Zimbabwe's turmoil. The outside world sees Mr Mbeki as the one person that Mr Mugabe will listen to as South Africa has the economic and political clout to influence the Zimbabwean leader. Mr Mbeki is expected to focus on Britain's obligation to support land redistribution, so as not to antagonise Mr Mugabe.

The problem lies in the term of that assistance. Harare insists Britain must compensate white farmers for land confiscated by the government. fields.headline: 14 charged over Leeds violence
fields.trailText: Fourteen people are to appear in court following disturbances at last night's Uefa Cup clash between Leeds United and Galatasaray, police said today.
fields.body:
Fourteen people are to appear in court following disturbances at last night's Uefa Cup clash between Leeds United and Galatasaray, police said today.

The men will appear before Leeds magistrates on May 4 charged with a variety of offences including threatening behaviour, violence and drunkenness.

Six people arrested for public order offences, including two Turkish men, were released without charge. Three others, arrested for criminal damage and the theft of a car, may be charged later.

The arrests followed a £100,000 security operation at Elland Road involving 350 police officers, some of whom were drafted in from neighbouring forces.

A coach carrying Galatasaray officials had a brick thrown one of its windows and there were also attacks on police and TV crews before the game, which ended in a 2-2 draw. Disturbances at a number of Leeds pubs were also reported.

Tensions had been running high following the murders of Leeds fans Christopher Loftus, 35, and father-of-two Kevin Speight, 40, who were stabbed to death before the first leg in Istanbul two weeks before.

West Yorkshire assistant chief constable Paul Garvin, the officer in charge of the security operation, was disappointed with the arrests but pleased the match passed without major incident.

"Tensions were obviously running high but I'm pleased that the outcome was no worse than a normal high security game.

"There was a small outbreak of disorder prior to the game involving known troublemakers but that was soon quelled - their actions were little different to those on most match days.

"Our main objective was public safety and we have achieved that. There were no reports of serious injuries at the event.

"I would like to pay tribute to our officers for their professional planning and handling of the event, to Leeds United for the way they handled a difficult situation and to the people of Leeds for keeping their cool."

One man suffered a suspected heart attack shortly before kick-off and died later in hospital.

The Galatasaray team beat Leeds 4-2 on aggregate to become the first Turkish club to qualify for a European final, and now face Arsenal.

webTitle: Russia sends mixed signals on nuclear weapons

fields.headline: Russia sends mixed signals on nuclear weapons
fields.trailText: Russia today sent mixed messages on nuclear weapons as its state parliament ratified the comprehensive test ban treaty while its national security council adopted a new more aggressive strategy.
fields.body:
Russia today sent mixed messages on nuclear weapons as its state parliament ratified the comprehensive test ban treaty while its national security council adopted a new more aggressive strategy.

The new military doctrine adopted by Russia's top security officials is intended to replace a 1993 version. In one of its key points, the updated strategy holds that Moscow can no longer ward off a mass conventional attack without using nuclear weapons. Vladimir Putin, Russia's president-elect, has defended the new doctrine as a response to changes in the strategic landscape, including Nato's bombing campaign against Yugoslavia and tensions in central Asian states.

The document states that "the Russian federation envisages the possibility of using all forces and means at its disposal, including nuclear weapons, where all other means to settle the crisis have been exhausted or have proven ineffective". Western officials have expressed concern at the lowering of the Russian nuclear threshold. But Sergei Ivanov, secretary of the security council, insisted the new doctrine was essentially defensive in character.

In a more reassuring move to the west, the Russian state parliament ratified the comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty, exactly one week after approving the stalled Start 2 treaty on reducing strategic nuclear warheads with the US. Britain welcomed Russian ratification of the test ban treaty, which came on the eve of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty review conference that begins in New York on Monday.

Foreign minister Peter Hain called on other nations to do the same after the Russian state parliament voted for ratification by 298 to 74. "I warmly welcome the vote today by the Russian Duma to ratify the comprehensive test ban treaty," he said. "This is a big step towards our goal of this crucial treaty's entry into force as soon as possible. Three of the five declared nuclear weapon states have now ratified the treaty. We hope the US and China will now do likewise. Early signature of the Treaty by India and Pakistan would also be a major step forward."

But Russia's Communists and their leftist allies criticised approving the test ban treaty when other states are still dragging their feet. Washington has signed the test ban accord but president Bill Clinton failed last October to persuade the senate to ratify it.

"Lately, there has been a deliberate movement aimed at depriving Russia of its status as a nuclear power," Communist MP Ivan Nikitchuk told the Duma. Another senior parliamentarian, Nikolai Kharitonov, said Russia was acting too hastily in clearing its backlog of arms treaties.

"We are seriously concerned that in the last couple of weeks there has been a kind of ratification race in this country while the president has not yet taken office and the government has still not been formed," Mr Kharitonov said.

But Mr Putin's representative in the Duma, Alexander Kotenkov, dismissed the Communists' concerns. "If we decide to end the moratorium we can still go ahead with tests. The treaty comes into effect only after all parties have ratified it," he said. Communist deputy Alexander Shabanov said he thought Mr Putin's push to ratify both Start-2 and the test ban treaty was linked to his efforts to divert attention from Russia's military campaign in Chechnya.

webTitle: Chinese find writing from 4,800 years ago

fields.headline: Chinese find writing from 4,800 years ago
fields.trailText: Archaeologists in east China have confirmed that inscriptions on 4,800-year-old pottery are the earliest Chinese writing ever discovered.
fields.body:
Archaeologists in east China have confirmed that inscriptions on 4,800-year-old pottery are the earliest Chinese writing ever discovered.

The inscriptions were found on decorated pottery wine vessels unearthed in Juxian, a county in Shandong province once inhabited by the Taihao, a tribe that worshipped gods of wine and land, the official Xinhua News Agency said.

It did not say whether outside experts had been consulted on the find.

From more than 20 drawings, seven Chinese characters, including words for "south", "ordinary", and "enjoy" have been deciphered, Xinhua said.

"This pushes back the history of the Chinese script by some 2,000 years," Wang Shuming, a researcher at the Shandong Institute of Relics and Archaeology, said.

Chinese archaeologists and historians have been under pressure from the government to prove that China has more than 5,000 years of continuous history.

fields.headline: Easter
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about Easter on the net
fields.trailText: 1. Today, Good Friday, is the day the majority of Christians mark the crucifixion of Jesus Christ.
fields.body:
1. Today, Good Friday, is the day the majority of Christians mark the crucifixion of Jesus Christ.

2. The Gospels tell the story of how Jesus, put into a tomb on Friday, rose from the dead on Sunday, the first day of Easter.

3. Modern-day Easter, however, is a blending of two traditions: one Judeo-Christian and the other Pagan. The latter, almost certainly the earliest, comes from a fertility cult celebrating the return of the spring goddess from the nether regions of winter to the light of day.

4. Hence the new life that breaks out of Easter eggs and the Easter bunnies, which are presumably at it like rabbits.

5. Easter, according to Anglo-Saxon priest the Venerable Bede, comes from the name of the Old English goddess Eostre.

6. Other languages derive their name from the Greek and Latin Pascha, which in turn comes from Pesah - Hebrew for Passover, a Jewish festival at the same time of year.

7. In the Catholic world, Easter and the preceeding Holy Week (powerfully marked in Spain's Semana santa) are celebrated with more religious fervour. They come at the end of Lent, a period of self-denial following the excesses of carnival

8. On Easter Sunday, 1772, Admiral Roggeveen set foot on Easter Island - the most isolated inhabited place in the world.

9. And on April 10 1998 - Easter fell earlier that year - Northern Ireland politicians concluded multi-party talks with the Good Friday Agreement.

10. Uncertain of which way you should swing your Easter? Combine the best of both worlds with these Easter cards from satirical magazine The Onion.

fields.headline: The Guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15
fields.body:
Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

Books for Cooks, 4 Blenheim Crescent, London W11. Tel: 020-7221 1992.

London's most civilised bookshop. The books are in the front and the food is at the back. Feed the soul, the imagination and the body, all at the same time. The kitchen is tiny, and the dining room not much larger. However, given the pedigree and the place, it would be surprising if the cooking didn't pack a serious punch, and so it does. Modern Brit, Euro-Brit, call it what you like; under the likeable control of Heidi Lascelles, it's long on flavour with plenty of finesse. The atmosphere has a touch of the amateur, in the best sense of the word. Lunch is three courses for £10.

Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Casa Santana, 44 Golborne Road, London W10. Tel: 020-8968 8764.

This Portuguese watering hole is a serious provider of serious soups - be it the classic rib-sticker caldo verde (cabbage soup), sopa de peixe (fish soup) or canja de galina (chicken soup) - at rock bottom prices. Portuguese cooking is high on flavour and short on finesse. When there's grilling to be done - chicken, octopus, fish - they do so with brio. That other Portuguese passion, salt cod, gets lumped together with onion, shredded fried potato and scrambled egg, which is as robust and filling as the line-up suggests. A magnet, not surprisingly, to homesick Portuguese, who are a friendly lot.

Cheat's kitchen

The best burger in the world

1 packet Knorr French onion soup
1.5kg ground beef
1 good dollop Heinz tomato ketchup

1 Mix soup powder, beef and ketchup thoroughly.

2 Shape into burgers as fat as you like them.

3 Grill or fry for 3-5 mins on each side, depending on a) how thick the burgers are, and b) how well cooked you like them. (Serves five to six.)

J Lee, London
 If you have a tip for the Cheat's kitchen, please send it to The Guzzler, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

Food on the net

www.cucinadirect.co.uk

For people who love to cook, so the site says, but don't expect to fill the larder here; the food section sticks to herb bundles, Valrhona chocolate and other such essentials. What they do do is stylish cookware in which to whip up and display your culinary efforts.

Pros: Good-quality stuff, from knives to make chefs drool, through gorgeous copper pans, right down to tea towels and oven gloves. Request a brochure to peruse offline.

Cons: Recycled it may be, but why so much packaging?

Delivery: Recent delays should now be smoothed out. Expect your parcel within seven days.

Charges: £3.95 per delivery.

On the menu: white pudding

As opposed to black pudding? Not quite opposed to. It's a pudding in its own right. Or sausage, rather.

A pudding as sausage? Sometimes called hog's pudding.

Hang on. I'm getting confused. This pudding is in fact a sausage. Sausage-shaped.

What's in it? I thought you'd never ask. Pork, groats, dried fruit (optional) and seasonings. Has a kind of mottled whitish look to it and sometimes comes in a horseshoe shape.

So no pig's blood? No pig's blood.

No other nasties? None.

How to cook? It is customary to poach it in simmering water, but try baking, grilling or frying as you would your basic banger.

fields.headline: Farm victim's family rejects 'intimidation' claim
fields.standfirst:
21 April: Jury 'intimidated'
20 April: Life for farmer
20 April: Bleak world of lone farmer
fields.trailText: The uncle of the teenager shot dead by farmer Tony Martin today dismissed claims that anybody connected with his family had intimidated jurors as "absolute rubbish".
fields.body:
The uncle of the teenager shot dead by farmer Tony Martin today dismissed claims that anybody connected with his family had intimidated jurors as "absolute rubbish".

Martin, 55, was jailed for life at Norwich crown court on Wednesday after being found guilty of murdering 16-year-old Fred Barras, a market trader from a Gypsy travelling family based in Newark, Nottinghamshire.

But yesterday it was claimed a juror in the case made allegations during a radio phone-in which could lead to the conviction being thrown out.

Mr Barras's uncle, Tony Joines, today denied any members of the young market trader's family had attempted to threaten jurors and rejected reports that the family felt Martin should not have been sentenced to life.

Asked by the Today programme if there was any truth in claims of intimidation, he said: "I find that basically absolute rubbish. How could anybody intimidate them? There was only his mother and his two sisters there, and his dad. How could they intimidate that juror? I don't believe it."

He said he had never heard anyone connected to the family discussing any plan to intimidate jurors.

Mr Joines also said that when his mother-in-law had said to reporters that Martin should not be in prison for life, she had meant that he should not spend the rest of his life in jail. The family felt that the 10-15 years that Martin would probably serve was appropriate to his crime, he said.

The conviction of the 55-year-old could be quashed and a re-trial ordered if the claims of jury tampering are proved by court officials after an investigation.

Martin's solicitor Nick Makin, who has appealed for anyone who knew of intimidation or harassment of jurors to come forward, said his inquiries about jury tampering were not solely based on the anonymous call made to a breakfast DJ at a Norfolk radio station yesterday.

His firm had asked the crown prosecution service to investigate and was also in touch with lawyers from Norwich-based Radio Broadland for a transcript of the conversation, which was not broadcast.

The anonymous caller is understood to have indicated she was one of 10 jurors who voted to convict Martin of murder and to have told the presenter: "This is a decision I am going to have to live with for the rest of my life."

Later Broadland 102FM issued a transcript of what presenter Rob Chandler said on air.

Mr Chandler, who received the telephone call at 7.45am during a phone-in about the Martin trial, said: "During that song we have just spoken to one of the jurors and they do not wish to be named or come on air but we can report some of the things this person said.

"I think the most powerful thing that this person said was that the last eight days had changed their life. This person now actually feels frightened to leave their house having heard some of the things they heard. They never actually wanted to be on the jury in the first place but did not have any choice over it.

"The most poignant thing that I think they said was that in Tony Martin's situation they would have done the same thing and paid the consequences."

A spokeswoman for Broadland 102FM said the station had taken the decision to release the details in order to clarify the situation.

"We want to clarify what was said because we feel that it has been misreported in some respects and want to set the record straight."

She added: "I have read the transcript of what the alleged juror actually said and what was reported on air and at no point was the word intimidation or pressure or nobbled mentioned at all."

The spokeswoman said the tape recording of what the alleged juror said was in a safe place and would be handed over to police if requested.

The Martin case was conducted under high security and jurors were given numbers so their names would not be revealed in open court. The judge told the jurors that if they were approached last weekend about the case, they should immediately dial 999. The court also heard that a £60,000 price had been put on Martin's head.

fields.headline: This murder was justified
fields.trailText:
When are we going to realise that burglary is not a property crime (Life for farmer who shot burglar, April 20)? It is a crime against people and is the worst thing you can do to someone without physically attacking them. It ruins lives, particularly in the case of elderly people and those who live alone. In this proper context, the actions of Tony Martin do not seem so unreasonable or excessive. It was not his property he was defending, but his right to security and peace of mind, without which our lives are worthless. What other protection is there for those in his position? They are on their own. Do not be surprised when someone goes too far.
Tony Wilcox
Northwich, Cheshire

In this proper context, the actions of Tony Martin do not seem so unreasonable or excessive. It was not his property he was defending, but his right to security and peace of mind, without which our lives are worthless. What other protection is there for those in his position? They are on their own. Do not be surprised when someone goes too far.
Tony Wilcox
Northwich, Cheshire

 One hopes the jury can sleep sound in their beds with clear consciences after finding a man protecting his home, property and life guilty of murder. Their verdict was yet further evidence that there is no justice in Britain. As for the comments of Norfolk chief crown prose cutor Peter Tidey ("Action such as taken by Tony Martin can never be tolerated in a civilised society") and the family of criminal Fred Barrass ("a loveable rogue"), they just beggar belief.
Bradley Roberts
Grimsby, Lincs

 I regard the conviction as both right and justified. What signal would it have sent out if he had been acquitted: that anybody can take the law into their own hands? The last thing this country needs is to go down the route of America, where people are largely responsible for their own security. Do we want mob rule and vigilante groups? We pay taxes to fund the police force and however slow they may or may not react to burglaries, it is their job to deal with crime not the public's. It is all too easy to take the populist Daily Mail view of "he got what he deserved" (the victim), but in this case it is the farmer who got what he deserved, however wrong the actions of the victim were.
Tim Harvey
Northwich, Cheshire

 Your story (Farmer jailed for life for murder of teenage intruder, Guardian Unlimited) shocks and amazes me. If a man may not defend his home against invasion, has he any rights at all? Here in Texas, the law recognises a man's fundamental right to defend his home and his property and to have arms for that purpose. If this incident had occurred in Texas, a bleeding-heart liberal prosecutor might have referred Tony Martin's case to a grand jury, but Martin would never have been indicted, much less convicted. In most of the rural counties of Texas, the sheriff would have congratulated Martin on his marksmanship.

If a man may not defend his property, presumably he must surrender it to anyone who dares to break into his home. Must the homeowner assist the housebreaker in finding goods the latter wishes to steal? Must the homeowner give a housebreaker a warranty on the goods stolen? If the housebreaker wishes to commit sodomy on the homeowner, or his wife, or his child, or his dog, must the homeowner submit meekly? One can only suspect that, in Britain, the answer to all of these questions is yes.
Michael W Johnson
Houston, Texas, USA
reddogmike1@excite.com

 To expect a householder to act in a moderate, restrained way in these circumstances is totally unreasonable. He or she may be extremely frightened, physically weak, and might well have just one advantage over the intruders - surprise. The law should demand that those venturing on to someone else's property intent on theft do so at their own risk.
Lance Green
Newport Upon Usk
lkgzzz@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Murder case jury 'intimidated'
fields.standfirst: Police investigate claims that jurors who convicted farmer of shooting burglar had been 'nobbled'
fields.trailText: Claims that the jury in the Tony Martin murder trial returned a guilty verdict because they felt intimidated were referred to police and the Lord Chancellor's Department yesterday.
fields.body:
Claims that the jury in the Tony Martin murder trial returned a guilty verdict because they felt intimidated were referred to police and the Lord Chancellor's Department yesterday.

The dramatic turn of events came when a woman phoned a local Norfolk radio station claiming to have been one of the six men and six women who found the farmer guilty of the murder of teenager Fred Barras. The woman, who did not go on air, said that the decision she had made would remain with her for the rest of her life.

Last night it was still unclear whether the caller to Radio Broadland 102 was a genuine member of the jury or someone adding to the hype surrounding the controversial trial. Martin was sentenced to life for the killing of Barras, 16, a market trader from a Gypsy travelling family based in Newark, Nottinghamshire, after a late-night incident when the teenager tried to burgle the farmer's home last summer.

Michael Ballinger, Martin's solicitor, said: "We are certainly concerned about the jury being nobbled. There was something that happened during the trial. We are certainly concerned about jury intimidation and we will be investigating this matter immediately. I would appeal to any juror who felt intimidated to make their concern known to the appropriate authority, in this case Norwich crown court."

The Martin case was conducted under high security and jurors were given numbers so their names would not be revealed in open court. The judge told the jurors that if they were approached last weekend about the case, they should immediately dial 999. The court also heard that a £60,000 price had been put on Martin's head.

Peter Tidey, the chief crown prosecutor for Norfolk, said: "I'm aware that there was one incident during the trial at which there was communication between the judge and the jury. Precisely what that was about I have no knowledge of at all. If there's a complaint that an offence has been committed then the constabulary is going to have to investigate."

The case has provoked an angry reaction from those who believe that Martin should have been entitled to shoot at a burglar in his own home.

Norman Brennan, director of Victims of Crime Trust, said the farmer's conviction was another example of how the justice system could make criminals out of crime victims.

People in the farmer's local village of Emneth were shocked at the verdict and said there was a very real fear of crime in the area.

Ann Fullwood, who moved to Emneth from Watford last December, said: "The thefts round here are terrible. You cannot leave your lawnmower out. There is a large travelling community here and I hate to feel this way towards them because we are leftwing but cars and lorries are stolen. We have been surprised at the crime level, its just so senseless."

Another resident, who did not want to be named, said: "I have got a lot of these travellers near me and I have had a lot of burglaries. I am very sorry that the farmer has been treated in this way. Like many other people, I could have been in the same situation. If I had a gun I might have fired off a warning shot and my aim is hopeless. I might have had a similar mistake."

Anthony Bosanquet of the Country Landowners Association said: "The very remoteness of rural communities and the isolation of individual homes makes them easy prey for burglars. Effective policing cannot be carried out from a distant, urban police station. Extra resources must be given to rural areas."

Norfolk's acting chief constable, John Bligh, said his was the lowest police/population ratio in the country and had "suffered a traditional paucity of funding". But he said rural areas still had considerably lower crime than urban areas.

fields.headline: United sign £19m van Nistelrooy
fields.trailText: Manchester United made clear their determination to bounce back from their Champions League disappointment by breaking the British transfer record last night to sign Ruud van Nistelrooy in a £19million transfer from PSV Eindhoven.
fields.body:
Manchester United made clear their determination to bounce back from their Champions League disappointment by breaking the British transfer record last night to sign Ruud van Nistelrooy in a £19million transfer from PSV Eindhoven.

Twenty-four hours after United were knocked out of Europe by Real Madrid, they agreed personal terms on a five-year deal with the highly rated van Nistelrooy. The 23-year-old Dutch international striker will complete transfer formalities when he flies to Manchester next week for a medical.

PSV president Harry van Raay said: "Sir Alex Ferguson is a very lucky man. We hate to lose Ruud and I was determined we would not give him away like a gift to United.

"But the player had made his mind up he was going to play in Manchester. He will certainly be a star in the European Championships this summer," he said.

The Dutchman is believed to have agreed terms of around £42,000 a week - around £8,000 a week less than United skipper Roy Keane.

The £19m fee eclipses the £12.6m United paid Aston Villa for Dwight Yorke in August 1998 and the previous British record transfer of £15m, which Newcastle paid Blackburn for Alan Shearer in 1996.

After Arsenal and Chelsea had made the early running in the bidding for van Nistelrooy's signature, United sent a high-powered delegation to Eindhoven two weeks ago.

Dutch defender Jaap Stam, who cost United a then club record £10.75m from PSV in June 1998, was instrumental in the move.

He gave United manager Sir Alex Ferguson a glowing report on van Nistelrooy and encouraged the striker, who has averaged a goal a game for PSV this season, to come to Old Trafford.

Arsenal stars Dennis Bergkamp and Marc Overmars had told him about the Gunners, but Stam entertained van Nistelrooy in Manchester to tell him more about the club and English football.

The arrival of van Nistelrooy, who has scored one goal in 10 appearances for Holland, means United have spent £42.6m on their five front-line strikers.

The move looks likely to hasten the departure of Teddy Sheringham from Old Trafford. Questions will also be asked about the future of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, who has long been coveted by Everton and Tottenham, while Leeds manager David O'Leary is reportedly keen to sign him as well.

webTitle: English football fans clash with police home and abroad

fields.headline: English football fans clash with police home and abroad
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited: Match reports and comment
fields.trailText: English fans clashed with police last night, marring the Uefa                                                                 Cup semi-finals involving Leeds United and Arsenal. Tension                                                                 was high in Yorkshire following the murder of two Leeds fans                                                                 in Turkey a fortnight ago before the first leg of the tie.
fields.byline: Martin Wainwright and Russell Thomas in Lens
fields.body:
English fans clashed with police last night, marring the Uefa Cup semi-finals involving Leeds United and Arsenal. Tension was high in Yorkshire following the murder of two Leeds fans in Turkey a fortnight ago before the first leg of the tie.

Fifteen people were arrested amid angry scenes outside Leeds' Elland Road ground as rioters threw a missile through the window of one of the coaches carrying executives of the Turkish club and journalists. Leeds fans also attacked mounted police and turned on TV crews. Among those detained were two Turkish supporters, who were arrested inside the ground for their own safety, West Yorkshire police said.

The brief but vicious fighting saw several Leeds fans mimic a knife being drawn across their throats, and four BBC TV reporters cornered against a fence and attacked before police waded in to rescue them. A Turkish TV crew was also attacked, but there were no serious injuries.

Chants from hundreds of fans of "We are Leeds" turned to "Scum", as some men made the threatening gesture of slashing the throat, allegedly after a Turk on one of the buses made an obscene sign. The throat-cutting gesture was similar to that made by Turkish fans towards United supporters in Istanbul two weeks ago.

In a separate incident in the city centre, an Asian man was taken to the city's general infirmary after being attacked by a gang outside a pub. Police reinforcements in riot gear were mobilised to cope with disappointed fans leaving the highly charged game.

In France, hundreds of Arsenal fans with match tickets were understood to have been locked out of the game with Lens, sparking trouble between Arsenal supporters and police as they milled round the stadium attempting to get in. Between 15 and 20 Arsenal supporters are believed to have been injured in the clashes.

A statement issued by Arsenal after the match said: "An incident occurred before the match involving Arsenal supporters who had difficulty gaining access to the stadium. Consequently a number of supporters were injured. However, none is believed to be serious or life-threatening."

Officials at the Felix Bollaert stadium blamed widespread forgeries for the problems.

Arsenal went through to the final after a 3-1 aggregate win over Lens and will play Galatasaray, who beat Leeds 4-2 on aggregate, in Copenhagen on May 17.

Arsenal's managing director, Ken Friar, promised a tight security operation when the north London club meet the Turkish champions.

He said: "We will be treating it as a high-profile fixture. Tomorrow we will send seven or eight people to Uefa's meeting in Copenhagen, including our club secretary, David Miles, and our local chief of police.

"Also there will be representatives of the Football Association and the police, who are highly experienced in planning these events.

"In the main our supporters, who have travelled all over Europe with us, have been impeccably behaved and we don't envisage anything other than that in Copenhagen."

In France, hundreds of Arsenal fans with match tickets were understood to have been locked out of the game with Lens, sparking trouble between Arsenal supporters and police as they milled round the stadium attempting to get in. Between 15 and 20 Arsenal supporters are believed to have been injured in the clashes. A statement issued by Arsenal after the match said: "An incident occurred before the match involving Arsenal supporters who had difficulty gaining access to the stadium. Consequently a number of supporters were injured. However, none is believed to be serious or life-threatening." Officials at the Felix Bollaert stadium blamed widespread forgeries for the problems. Arsenal went through to the final after a 3-1 aggregate win over Lens and will play Galatasaray, who beat Leeds 4-2 on aggregate, in Copenhagen on May 17. Arsenal's managing director, Ken Friar, promised a tight security operation when the north London club meet the Turkish champions. He said: "We will be treating it as a high-profile fixture. Tomorrow we will send seven or eight people to Uefa's meeting in Copenhagen, including our club secretary, David Miles, and our local chief of police. "Also there will be representatives of the Football Association and the police, who are highly experienced in planning these events. "In the main our supporters, who have travelled all over Europe with us, have been impeccably behaved and we don't envisage anything other than that in Copenhagen."
