fields.headline: Testing times
fields.standfirst: A cause for concern, but not for panicEducation Unlimited
fields.trailText: New hothouse pressures introduced into schools are pushing children - and teachers - towards suicide, according to delegates to the first teacher conference of the Easter season. The conference coincided with the inquest on a 12-year-old boy who was said to have hanged himself after an art teacher had suggested he had the "attention of a goldfish". More relevantly, Childline, the telephone advice service, received 783 calls last year from children worried about examinations. Two teachers who recently committed suicide were said by their colleagues to have been put under stress by Ofsted school inspections.
fields.body:
New hothouse pressures introduced into schools are pushing children - and teachers - towards suicide, according to delegates to the first teacher conference of the Easter season. The conference coincided with the inquest on a 12-year-old boy who was said to have hanged himself after an art teacher had suggested he had the "attention of a goldfish". More relevantly, Childline, the telephone advice service, received 783 calls last year from children worried about examinations. Two teachers who recently committed suicide were said by their colleagues to have been put under stress by Ofsted school inspections.

Teachers are right to be concerned about the emotional welfare of children - and of their colleagues. But the figures should be put into perspective. The 783 calls to Childline have to be set against the 2m children taking standard assessment tests (Sats) at seven, 11 and 14 every year. Moreover, half the calls came from 16-year-old pupils taking GCSE. No one is suggesting the 650,000 taking this exam should be excused the exercise.

But true to the tradition of such annual conferences, some delegates forgot all about perspective. Dire warnings were issued about the UK following a road that had led to huge suicide numbers in Japan. Again, the facts do not back up the allegations. There has been no dramatic increase in suicides among children under 14 - there were some 35 suicides or undetermined deaths in 1997, compared to 38 in 1987. Similarly, two suicides in a workforce of 500,000 is sad but not something which should cause undue alarm.

Estelle Morris, the schools standards minister, took exactly the right line, reminding delegates of the immense pressure put on secondary school pupils who cannot read or write. The reasons why Sats - and Ofsted - were introduced was because of the need to improve the monitoring of pupils and schools. Tests at seven allow an early diagnosis of problems which children may be facing; tests at 11 provide policymakers with a clear guide to how successful primary schools are performing. Standards have recently begun to rise after previously falling disastrously behind our continental competitors. The four key stage tests should remain in place, but ministers need to warn schools about taking up the voluntary tests for eight, nine and 10-year-olds now on offer. That would be to indulge in the worst form of test-mania.

webTitle: Teacher's agony at pupil's abuse lie

fields.headline: Teacher's agony at pupil's abuse lie
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A senior maths teacher broke down in tears at his union's annual conference yesterday as he told how his career of 22 years was nearly broken by false accusations of physical violence from a pupil aged 12.
fields.body:
A senior maths teacher broke down in tears at his union's annual conference yesterday as he told how his career of 22 years was nearly broken by false accusations of physical violence from a pupil aged 12.

Adrian Wells, head of maths at Penglais school in Aberystwyth, Ceredigion, said he endured three months of "agony and isolation" before a child protection panel decided that the boy's allegations had no substance.

Mr Wells, 44, said he was fortunate not to be suspended during an investigation over most of last autumn term.

The headteacher looked into the allegations before police inquiries started and was aware of the boy's previous unfounded complaints against other staff members. The teacher said that in spite of this he had felt guilty about the case and powerless to influence the outcome. He became withdrawn and lost confidence in his ability to maintain discipline.

"The boy openly bragged of his action and continues to retain a defiant manner. No action was taken against him," said Mr Wells. "I don't want revenge, but I am interested in ensuring that adults in the education service should have protection and rights," he told the Association of Teachers and Lecturers' conference in Belfast.

Mr Wells got a standing ovation for his courage in disclosing his case, and delegates supported a motion demanding "greater safeguards for teachers and other education professionals who are the subject of malicious or unfounded complaints".

Martin Pilkington, the association's head of legal services, said there were 120 allegations of child abuse against its members last year, of which 90% were found to have no substance. Accused teachers were not allowed representation before child protection panels, and schools usually found it safer to suspend them pending the outcome of inquiries.

Peter Smith, the association's general secretary, said: "It is easier to suspend the teacher than the child. We appreciate the importance of safeguarding children. Nobody wants teachers to have a licence to use children as punchbags. The question is whether the pendulum has swung too far."

The government should re-examine the 1989 Children Act to give social services departments and local education authorities an alternative to treating all teachers as guilty until proven innocent, he said.

Mr Wells, who is married with three children, said later that his accuser was not one of his regular pupils at the comprehensive.

He had reprimanded the boy during a lunch break last October. The boy came into his lesson intent on disruption. Later the boy alleged that the teacher punched him, and the parents made a formal complaint to police of physical assault.

Sylvia Mason, a delegate from north Wales, told the conference of an unnamed teacher who was suspended for six months after allegations from a 14-year-old who later withdrew the charges.

"The boy now walks around his school as if nothing had happened - and nothing did happen to him. But the teacher is a broken man."

Ray Butler, north Tyneside branch secretary, said he had been falsely accused of assaulting a child. Police dropped charges when the boy said his bruises were "yellow and brown" 10 hours after the incident. Doctors said it would have taken 40 hours for the bruising to turn that colour.

But Mike Taylor, the NSPCC director of child protection, cautioned ministers against adopting the association's recommendations.

"Most child abuse goes unreported. The danger is that this will discourage children from voicing their fears. All accusations of abuse should be taken seriously, with an independent investigation."

webTitle: Why Rushdie wasn't welcome in New York

fields.headline: Why Rushdie wasn't welcome in New York
fields.standfirst: Michael Ellison tells how Manhattan's literary elite froze out the Booker-winning author
fields.trailText: New Yorkers pride themselves on the welcome they extend to outsiders, even if they often find it hard to tolerate each other. This should hardly be surprising in a city of immigrants where everyone comes from somewhere else: where just under a third of the 7.3m population was born abroad, and where in the neighbourhood of Woodside, Queens, there are people from 49 countries speaking 34 different languages.
fields.body:
New Yorkers pride themselves on the welcome they extend to outsiders, even if they often find it hard to tolerate each other. This should hardly be surprising in a city of immigrants where everyone comes from somewhere else: where just under a third of the 7.3m population was born abroad, and where in the neighbourhood of Woodside, Queens, there are people from 49 countries speaking 34 different languages.

Salman Rushdie, winner of the Booker Prize, the Booker of Bookers, the English Speaking Union Literary Award, the James Tait Black Memorial Prize, the Arts Council Bursary Award, the Prix du Meilleur Livre Etranger, the Kurt Tucholsky Prize, a Whitbread Prize and a "worst of 1999" People magazine mention is not likely to have much use for Queens.

No, Manhattan is the place for him, with its bars and stars, mavens and havens. The problem is that Manhattan, or at least that part of it represented by the media and literary elite that is his natural home, has decided that this is one immigrant they can do without.

The New York Observer, required reading for this slender sector of the community, reports that Rushdie might have to look outside Manhattan for a billet.

"Three months ago he was looking at a condo downtown and they told him 'You are not welcome here, we'd have to change our security system," one publishing source was said to have told the weekly. "I mean, can you imagine hearing that Salman Rushdie is moving into your building?"

A literary agent had her dinner of beef-cheek ravioli at Babbo ruined by his presence. "I was so pissed to be in the restaurant with him," she said. "We don't want to die because of his fatwa. It's so passive-aggressive toward people in Manhattan. We have enough trouble here."

When Rushdie first appeared in front of the lens with Padma Lakshmi, his new girlfriend, his presence at movie premieres and hot night spots was reported without innuendo. So what if he was a distinguished artist of a certain age with a beautiful 29-year-old former topless model and bikini-clad TV host on his arm? Donald Trump has practically sustained his property empire by careful deployment of female companions. And anyway, Padma is a published writer herself, even if her work, Easy Exotic: A Model's Low-Fat Recipes From Around The World, has more to do with wonderful pictures than magical realism.

New Yorkers, though, have a keen sense of the presumptuous. The charge laid most consistently against Hillary Clinton is that she has no right to expect to win a seat in the Senate by running in a state with which she has no previous connection. Tina Brown's outsider status did not help either when she made changes at the venerable New Yorker magazine.

Rushdie has taken it upon himself in syndicated columns to hand down judgment on the great American issues of the day. Without discharging any particularly fresh insight, he tackles the case of Amadou Diallo and the four New York police officers who were cleared of killing him despite firing 41 bullets at the unarmed, innocent street-trader.

"The tragedy of the United States is that a nation that sees itself as leading the world toward a global future in which the American values of freedom and justice will be available for everyone fails so frequently and so badly to guarantee that freedom and that justice for so many people within its own frontiers," he admonished the people among whom he apparently wants to live.

And he makes common cause with the most famous shipwreck survivor since Robinson Crusoe. "Elian Gonzalez has become a political football and - take the word of someone who knows what it's like - the first consequence of becoming a football is that you cease to be thought of as a living, feeling human being."

The death sentence imposed in 1989 when Islamic fundamentalists took exception to The Satanic Verses was lifted 18 months ago, though that does not free Rushdie from the fear of attack by freelance extremists. Nor, apparently, does it free Manhattan's literati of the fear of having their dinner interrupted by the apocalypse.

"None of us think it's going to be a lone gunman's bullet. It's going to be the World Trade Centre all over again," the paper quotes yet another literary agent as saying, apparently unaware that British restaurants remained open throughout the entire 10 years of the fatwa.

It was never necessary during that time to be a subscriber to the London Review of Books to work out where the threatened writer might be: if there was a book awards dinner, chances were Rushdie would be there.

fields.headline: Normal Girl by Molly Jong-Fast
fields.standfirst: (Sceptre, £10) digested in the style of the original
fields.trailText: Rich daughter of even richer New York socialite takes drugs, goes into rehab, stops taking drugs, writes book about rich daughter of even richer socialite who takes a lot of drugs, goes into rehab and stops taking drugs.
fields.body:
You really can't find a decent cab driver in New York these days. I mean, there I am, the out-of-it-not-really-It girl trying to snort some coke in the back seat, when the cab veers to the left and dumps my stash all over my suede boots. I guess that makes them even more expensive.

I'm on my way to my fifth funeral this summer, but the first one for someone I killed. Yeah, that surprised you, didn't it. I murdered my boyfriend, Jeff, but I haven't told anyone. The temple's full. There's the Upper East Side crowd, the Upper West Side crowd, the Eurotrash and the media wannabes. And then there's me, 19-year old Miranda Woke, the girl who might have murdered her boyfriend (did I mention that before?). And all I'm thinking is that I could really do with another bump of coke.

Ah, there's Janice. She's a stick-thin ex-model. She's stick-thin 'cos she's a junky; she hardly has a vein left in her body and she's started to eye up her neck. She's also my best friend. Or as close to best friends as junkies get. Not that I'm a junkie. Sure I do a load of coke, dope, Valium and vodka martinis but I don't do heroin. Janice passes me a syringe in the bathroom. OK. So I do do the odd bit of junk now and again. So what?

God, I do wish Brett would get out of my life. Brett's the ex that just won't accept he's an ex. "Hi," he says, "I've been thinking about you a lot."

"Well don't strain that brain," I reply, because even though I'm always out of it, I'm pretty cool and sassy with a one-liner for every occasion.

Oh, shit. I've just remembered Jeff's dead. I think I murdered him by shooting him up with an air bubble. Did I mention that before? I need some more drugs. I'm off to party with Janice.

My mum's a rich socialite who had her tucks done in Mexico. She pretty much ignores me. My dad's very rich and is on his fifth wife, a girl three years older than me. He invites me out when he's in town, but then he stands me up.

I've just OD'd really badly, but now I've come round I need some more coke, pills, booze, anything. "You need help," Brett and my mum say. "Here's an airline ticket to Minnesota."

I spend a week in detox at Hazelford. That's something of a record and makes me pretty cool. There's a lot of losers in rehab; oddly, I feel like I'm in the right place.

I also meet an old friend of Jeff's. "I think I murdered him," I confess.

"Well you didn't," she says kindly. "He OD'd." That clears that one up, then.

"But he did have AIDS, though."

I won't bore you with the rest of rehab. The details get lost in translation. My mum said she wanted me to stay with her when I got out, but she was in Europe when I returned. I ignore Janice and decide I quite like Brett really. Now I just pig out on food, read lots of Fay Weldon and go to AA meetings, and from time to time I worry that I've got Aids. It's great to be back in the real world.

And if you really are pressed - the digested read, digested:

webTitle: BSE 'to die out in seven years'

fields.headline: BSE 'to die out in seven years'
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: The BSE epidemic in Britain is expected to die out by the year 2007, according to an independent assessment of the spread of the disease by Swiss scientists.
fields.byline: James Meikle and Paul Webster  in Paris
fields.body:
The BSE epidemic in Britain is expected to die out by the year 2007, according to an independent assessment of the spread of the disease by Swiss scientists.

Their predictions support the government's assertion of a steadily decreasing trend, assuming that a ban on feeding the most risky parts of cattle or sheep back to cows is being rigorously observed.

Researchers at the Institute of Animal Neurology at Bern University and the Swiss Federal Veterinary Office suggest there may only be isolated cases of BSE after 2007, 21 years after the disease was first identified and possibly more than three decades after it began on an unnoticed small scale.

The estimates do not take into account the unproven theory that cows may have given the disease to their calves but the unpublished work, reported by the EU's scientific steering committee, offers a real prospect of Britain emerging from the crisis. Hundreds of suspect BSE cases are still being slaughtered - 2,250 cases were confirmed in Britain last year. The total of confirmed BSE deaths among cattle - 176,600 - dwarfs other countries, including Ireland at 466, Portugal 371 and Switzerland 356.

EU scientists have accepted that Britain was entitled to lift its beef-on-the-bone ban but are likely to insist many anti-BSE controls remain in place. They and the commissioner responsible for BSE, David Byrne, want more countries, even those currently without BSE, to adopt similar measures because of the risks to consumers through imported food. In Britain 55 people have died from the human form of BSE, variant CJD, and another 12 are thought to be fatally ill.

Meanwhile in France, where entire herds are slaughtered if BSE is found, there is mounting concern over the possible length of the BSE problems, which started in 1991. The recently established food safety agency, which provided the information which convinced Paris to maintain its ban on British beef exports, believes the disease will not be eradicated in France before 2010.

One person has died from variant CJD and there are two other suspect cases. So far 94 cattle have been confirmed as BSE-related deaths.

Although the feeding of cattle with bone waste has been banned in France for six years, feed can still be given to pigs and poultry, raising the possibility of careless handling as a source of infection. But the agriculture minister, Jean Glavany, says a third way other than feed and cow to calf transmission may be the cause. So far, scientists have ruled out this possibility and health inspectors are concentrating on possible malpractice over feed.

In Britain 55 people have died from the human form of BSE, variant CJD, and another 12 are thought to be fatally ill. Meanwhile in France, where entire herds are slaughtered if BSE is found, there is mounting concern over the possible length of the BSE problems, which started in 1991. The recently established food safety agency, which provided the information which convinced Paris to maintain its ban on British beef exports, believes the disease will not be eradicated in France before 2010. One person has died from variant CJD and there are two other suspect cases. So far 94 cattle have been confirmed as BSE-related deaths. Although the feeding of cattle with bone waste has been banned in France for six years, feed can still be given to pigs and poultry, raising the possibility of careless handling as a source of infection. But the agriculture minister, Jean Glavany, says a third way other than feed and cow to calf transmission may be the cause. So far, scientists have ruled out this possibility and health inspectors are concentrating on possible malpractice over feed.

fields.headline: President 'realises he is beaten'
fields.standfirst:
Opposition: Democracy at risk as crisis deepens, says MDC chief

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The two white farmers killed by government supporters were targeted because they were members of the opposition, not because of their colour, the leader of the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) said yesterday.
fields.body:
The two white farmers killed by government supporters were targeted because they were members of the opposition, not because of their colour, the leader of the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) said yesterday.

"Their killing had nothing to do with race. It is all to do with intimidating the opposition and subduing the nation. The government realises they have lost the elections," said Morgan Tsvangirai.

"David Stevens and Martin Olds were killed because they were members of our party just as surely as Tichaona Chiminya and Talent Mabika were killed because they were MDC members.

"Mugabe has lost the support of the majority of Zimbabweans and so he is resorting to violent intimidation. It is state-sponsored violence."

Mr Tsvangirai offered to meet Mr Mugabe to try to resolve Zimbabwe's crisis. "I am prepared to sit down with Mr Mugabe to help solve the crisis, so long as he is committed to peace and an end to violence. He must not incite violence in the country. Mugabe recently said 'beat up the opposition but don't kill them'. That's an outrageous statement for a head of state to make."

Returning from an overseas tour of South Africa, Britain and the United States, Mr Tsvangirai said the situation in Zimbabwe had deteriorated in the two weeks he was gone. "The unfolding crisis, the deaths, the intimidation are threatening democracy in our country."

He said the central intelligence organisation (CIO) was behind the firebomb that killed Chiminya and Mabika. The much-feared CIO, which operates from Mr Mugabe's office, is a shadowy domestic intelligence network. Its web of undercover agents has been blamed for numerous beatings, killings and disappearances.

The MDC says nine of its members have been killed in recent weeks and scores more injured and hospitalised.

"The deaths of our MDC cadres will only spur us further to fight harder. No threats, no intimidation will deter us. They cannot intimidate into submission," said Mr Tsvangirai, who was beaten unconscious by a gang identified as Zanu-PF members in December 1998. "We are determined to withstand the pressure, the atrocities. We are not retreating."

He dismissed the government's charges that the MDC was plotting treason. "That is nonsense. We are not carrying out any military training. We are committed to legality. We are following the democratic route. Zimbabwe needs a democratic change of government that is why we need elections in a free and fair environment," he said.

With regard to the violence across the country in which white-owned farms have been burned and black MDC supporters have been beaten and threatened, Mr Tsvangirai said it was part of Mr Mugabe's strategy.

"Mugabe is trying to create a situation of lawlessness and ungovernability in order to be able to declare a state of emergency and postpone elections," he said. "But Mugabe has backed himself into a corner. To not carry out elections is unsustainable. The route to elections is irreversible, and he knows it."

He said pressure, both from within Zimbabwe and from the international community, would demand that elections be held. The intimidation and violence made it impossible to hold free and fair elections, but the MDC would contest the elections under any cir cumstances. "We are not going to give Mugabe that chance by boycotting the elections, that is what he would like."

Mr Tsvangirai said he spoke with political and business leaders in South Africa and everyone was concerned at Zimbabwe's troubles. "What is happening in Zimbabwe is sowing the seeds of regional instability and the South Africans realise that. South Africa will not be spared if Zimbabwe fails."

He said he hoped the South African president, Thabo Mbeki, would try to influence Mr Mugabe when they meet at Victoria Falls today.

Mr Tsvangirai does not want Britain to impose sanctions on the Mugabe government. "Sanctions is just what Mugabe wants so that he can point to an outside enemy. I told Robin Cook to make money available for land resettlement, on the conditions that: one, elections are held; two, there is an end to violence; and three, there is a return to rule of law."

In the US, Mr Tsvangirai said he had urged that monitors be sent to observe the elections in Zimbabwe.

fields.headline: British multi-millionaire bankrolls Mugabe party
fields.standfirst: Paymaster: Nicholas Hoogstraten says leader does a good jobZimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The old Marxist Robert Mugabe may be losing friends around the world at an alarming rate but he still has one unusual and influential capitalist supporter in Uckfield, East Sussex.
fields.body:
The old Marxist Robert Mugabe may be losing friends around the world at an alarming rate but he still has one unusual and influential capitalist supporter in Uckfield, East Sussex.

Nicholas Hoogstraten, 54, the controversial property multi-millionaire who regards ramblers as the scum of the earth and his tenants and women with even more contempt, has emerged as a long-standing financial backer of Zimbabwe's ruling Zanu-PF.

Mr Hoogstraten, who is building a £30m Renaissance-style palace with a mausoleum to preserve his remains, confirmed yesterday that he had funded Mr Mugabe and his party since the early 1960s when he acquired land in the country. He now owns nine farms covering 1m acres and a huge cattle company but, he says, only one of his nominee managers is white.

In an interview with the Guardian, Mr Hoogstraten is in no doubt where Zimbabwe's current problems stem from. Using his characteristically forceful language, he said: "This has all been stirred up by white disenfranchised trash who still think it's Rhodesia. I have some good white friends in Zimbabwe but those Rhodies, as we call them, are disgusting people. They want to ruin the country. They treat the blacks worse than blacks are treated in America. I've had no problem with indigenising my properties."

Mr Hoogstraten revealed that he continues to provide funds for Zanu-PF candidates. Over the years, he said, he must have contributed hundreds of thousands of pounds.

His money, and his friendship with Mr Mugabe, he believes, will ensure that his properties are not the subject of attacks by the war veterans.

A millionaire by the time he was 20, Mr Hoogstraten first bought some parcels of land for £40,000 in 1963. On a visit to the then Southern Rhodesia he met Tiny Rowland of Lonhro. They agreed that it made sense to back the emerging black nationalist groups, with Rowland siding with Joshua Nkomo and Mr Hoogstraten backing Mr Mugabe. Accurately he predicted that Mr Mugabe would come out on top as the leader of the biggest tribe, but like a canny businessman he did a bit of betting on both sides.

"I gave Zanu-PF five thousand here and five thousand there, a lot of money in those days. I also used to pay for Nkomo's hotel bills when he was in London but I stopped that when his side brought down a civilian airliner."

He later fell out with Rowland. In 1998 he explained that he had sold his 5% stake in Lonhro "because it's a ragbag of investments run by a bunch of incompetents".

In 10 days he flies to Harare. "It's a decent civilised ex-colonial country," he said. "It's a paradise compared with places like Nigeria.

"Mugabe has done a tremendous job keeping the country together and I'm appalled and disgusted at the way the media has treated him."

He dismisses reports of government corruption with a shrug. "It's no more than 10%. In Nigeria it's 90%. I used to own the tin mines there until I flooded them in the early 1980s."

Ever since he began his business career with a valuable stamp collection from his father, Mr Hoogstraten has courted controversy. He now owns large chunks of freehold in Brighton and homes in Cannes, Monte Carlo, Maryland and Florida. In a recent interview he described women as "chattels", and admitted to having a mistress in each of his houses. He also has an extensive collection of memorabilia from the slave trade.

Mr Hoogstraten's unconventional approach to business was demonstrated in the mid-1960s when he fell out with his partner, threw a grenade at his house, and ended up in prison. He made it into the Guinness Book of Records by having the highest disclosed UK personal tax demand in 1981: £5.3m.

More recently he was locked in combat with the Ramblers Association after he blocked a footpath across his estate. The "great unwashed", as he called them, won.

fields.headline: What Zimbabwe's papers say
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: • Financial Gazette
fields.body:
 Financial Gazette

If I were President Robert Mugabe:

I would abolish the word Comrade;

I would immediately withdraw Zimbabwean troops from the Congo;

I would use my law degree to stop lawlessness; and I would stop the "government process" of printing money since this is the main cause of inflation.

I would also use my degree in economics to stop scaring investors away through unwarranted racial attacks.

And through my broadcasting company ZBC, I would give an actual date for elections and promise the electorate that the elections will be free and fair and whoever wins will smoothly take over in the house.

I would also assure the people that Tobaiwa Mudede is not going to rig elections to help Mugabe win.
Pasval Mukuwerere, Editor

 Zimbabwe Mirror

The real land grabbing of the white settler colonial era has bequeathed a situation wherein about 4,000 white farmers own 12m hectares - more than 50% of Zimbabwe's prime agricultural land - while about 2m black peasants occupy 16m hectares, "often in drought-prone regions", acknowledges a BBC reporter; and the fact that this "land question" was glossed over at Lancaster House 20 years ago, with neither the EU, Britain nor any significant factor in the northern hemisphere making the kind of noises that would be expected of champions of "democracy" and "justice", about this historical and socio-economic obscenity.

Yes, it is a complete picture only if the observer is also able to see, behind the white faces that face the TV camera, the many angry ex-combatants and landless peasants who now wish to capitalise on a rare opportunity to have the historical injustice rectified. For all those who believe that the land question should have been resolved at independence in 1980, it is no longer possible for anyone to use the issue as merely a vote-catching gimmick. It is equally disgraceful for any black Zimbabwean to suggest that the land issue is not contentious, if only because two decades of post-independence have caused the obvious amnesia on the part of those few blacks who have benefited most from the "fruits of independence".

webTitle: 'Go back? It's not worth your life'

fields.headline: 'Go back? It's not worth your life'
fields.standfirst: White exodus: Fear wrenches farmers from their homes, their land, their livelihoodsZimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: When the time came the decision was easy. After three hours of hearing over the two-way radio how his neighbour was being beaten to death by squatters, Gordon Griffiths knew he had to leave. He had already sent his wife and two small children 50 miles away to the relative safety of Zimbabwe's second city, Buluwayo. When his brother-in-law finally went next door on Tuesday to find Michael Olds dead, it was his turn.
fields.body:
When the time came the decision was easy. After three hours of hearing over the two-way radio how his neighbour was being beaten to death by squatters, Gordon Griffiths knew he had to leave. He had already sent his wife and two small children 50 miles away to the relative safety of Zimbabwe's second city, Buluwayo. When his brother-in-law finally went next door on Tuesday to find Michael Olds dead, it was his turn.

"It wasn't completely unexpected," he says. "They had warned us that we might be targeted and so we had been preparing ourselves for a couple of weeks. But while we thought we might have to leave we never thought something like this would happen.

"After the murder that was it. We all just stood there listening to what was happening on the radio from the surveillance plane but were told the situation was too dangerous for us to go in."

Choosing what to take with them was straightforward. "You just bring the things that are not replaceable," Mr Griffiths, 52, says. "Things like the sofa and the television you can buy again. But it's things like videos of the kids, family photographs and furniture that we had made especially or which has been with us for generations that you will never be able to get again."

So he packed the few heirlooms his wife had not been able to take with her, gave instructions to his black farm labourers and, along with most of the other white farming families in the province of Nyamandlovhu, he made for the city.

His is just one of the hundreds of migrations that have taken place since the weekend as rural white communities evacuate their farms. White flight fuelled by fear that in the wave of violence that has engulfed Zimbabwe in recent weeks they might be next.

First they coordinate their departure with their neighbours over the two-way radio to make sure nobody who wants to go is left behind; then they throw their belongings into their trucks and race away. They leave the labourers to till the soil.

The exodus has been particularly intense in Matabeleland and Macheke, areas which have each seen one white farmer killed. But each day the conflict spreads, sending more farmers running.

Jennifer and Mark Stobbart have a tobacco farm just outside the capital, Harare. This year saw one of their best crops. Yesterday they saw it burnt down by squatters. "We could go back," they say. "But whatever it's all worth it's just not worth your life."

Another white couple, who refused to be identified, have left their farm near Harare. Their most treasured possessions were their passports - they are heading to Britain. "What are we supposed to do?" asks one. "Sit here terrified all the time thinking, every time I hear a car, is that them coming? Are we just going to stay here and be slaughtered?"

The current crisis has engendered fear but also created a spirit of camaraderie among white Zimbabweans, with town dwellers who are away for Easter leaving their keys with neighbours to pass on to evacuees.

"I have family in Buluwayo," says Mr Griffiths. "I think everybody would know someone in town and all of the people here have opened their doors to us.

"Of course it hurts to leave your farm, your home, your livelihood. But the alternative could be so much worse. The situation at the moment is so out of control that it is just not worth risking your life for your land."

Mr Griffiths says he has been here before. During the "bush war", when whites fought to maintain minority rule and blacks were not permitted to own land, the farms had been under siege. But those, he says, were very different times. "Then we had a police force we could count on and an army that we could rely on. We could protect ourselves then, but now there is no support."

On Wednesday he returned briefly to leave further orders for his black workers and check that everything was alright. He went in a convoy of eight other farmers with a plane hovering overhead to watch for possible attacks.

"It's crazy when you think that there's a fuel shortage, but you just can't take chances at the moment. I was very frightened to go back but I didn't think I had any choice. You can't keep on telling the labourers what to do over the phone. You just can't run a farm like that."

President Mugabe's pledge on Wednesday that farmers can return to their homes for good made no impact on him. "When I do go back it won't be because of a politician's promise but when it really is safe. One of my labourers said he had heard that if I do go back I will certainly be killed.

"It is impossible to predict when it will be. We will definitely stay here until Easter is over and then wait and see how things are. It is very, very frustrating. We want to go home. But for now we're just going to have to wait it out," he says.

fields.headline: Chechen president calls ceasefire
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: The Chechen president, Aslan Maskhadov, announced a ceasefire in the war with Russia yesterday and said he was ready for unconditional negotiations on a settlement of the bitter six-month conflict.
fields.body:
The Chechen president, Aslan Maskhadov, announced a ceasefire in the war with Russia yesterday and said he was ready for unconditional negotiations on a settlement of the bitter six-month conflict.

After weeks of speculation about indirect bargaining with President Vladimir Putin, the statement was the strongest signal yet that the search for a peace deal is on.

In an interview in today's edition of the Moscow newspaper Kommersant, Mr Maskhadov says his truce order has already resulted in a lull in the fighting, and that he has instructed his forces to release all their Russian captives and anyone being held hostage.

The Kremlin, pouring reinforcements into the rebel territory, crowed at what it characterised as a Chechen surrender.

"The current initiative, if it really takes place, shows the deep demoralisation in the ranks of the Chechen fighters," said the government's Chechnya spokesman, Sergei Yastrzhembsky.

After months of calling the democratically elected Mr Maskhadov an illegitimate leader and war criminal, Moscow recently opened channels of communications with him and said publicly that he could be pardoned for any alleged crimes.

One of the main reasons it has previously refused to negotiate with him is the prevailing view that he does not control the warlords running parts of Chechnya and that he could not deliver a peace deal. That suspicion persists, and it is not clear if the ceasefire will be observed by guerrilla leaders radicalised by the brutal war fought by Mr Putin's forces.

Mr Maskhadov insisted that he was commander in chief of the Chechen forces and that "practically all Chechen armed units are under centralised direction and definitely subordinate to me".

But he conceded that his writ did not run throughout Chechnya.

webTitle: UN tribunal told of Bosnian rape camp horrors

fields.headline: UN tribunal told of Bosnian rape camp horrors
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Her identity reduced for the second time in her young life, witness number 78 delivered heartbreaking testimony at the international war crimes tribunal in the Hague yesterday.
fields.body:
Her identity reduced for the second time in her young life, witness number 78 delivered heartbreaking testimony at the international war crimes tribunal in the Hague yesterday.

The young Bosnian woman's evidence, delivered in short painful sentences from behind a screen, is part of a trial which could overturn centuries of legal precedent by elevating rape and sexual enslavement from violations of the customs of war to the most serious war crimes category of all - crimes against humanity.

The outcome of the trial of eight Bosnian Serbs accused of running rape camps in the Bosnian town of Foca in the summer of 1992 will have implications for war crimes trials in Kosovo, Rwanda and East Timor, and for the remaining survivors of the 200,000 "comfort women" enslaved by Japanese forces during the second world war.

But the release this week of two Bosnian Serb war crimes suspects, Miroslav Tadic and Simo Zaric, for being "too long" in pre-trial detention, poses a threat to the hearing, legal experts in the Hague said yesterday.

Only three of the eight accused of running rape camps are in court: Dragoljub Kunarac, 39, a paramilitary leader; Radomir Kovac, 39, a military police commander; and Zoran Vukovic, a paramilitary.

Two of the others are dead - one killed by French peacekeeping troops while trying to escape arrest - and three remain at large.

The tribunal's indictment says Foca was surrounded and overrun by Serbian government and Bosnian Serb paramilitary forces in April 1992.

The Bosnian Serb forces then rounded up the majority Muslim population, separating the men, women and children. The women and children were detained in houses, flats, a sports hall and a secondary school, which were used as military brothels.

The indictment says witness 95 and "HB" were taken by Serb soldiers to the town's stadium. "There a large group of soldiers, among them Montenegrins and soldiers from Serbia, stood waiting. That night, countless soldiers gang-raped witness 95 and HB on the benches in the stadium."

Paul Risley, spokesman for the UN's chief prosecutor at the tribunal, Carla Del Ponte, said many of the victims were children, some as young as 12.

Although the witnesses are screened from the public, they face the court officials and the accused standing in the dock.

"It takes a lot of courage to testify, especially with something such as rape," Mr Risley said. "But the rights of the accused are the rights to see [the witness]."

Yesterday witness 78 told the court that she had hidden at her parents' house until August that year. Her father was repeatedly asked by the paramilitaries where she was.

Serb soldiers then announced that the Muslim and Croat population would be deported by bus in August. She went with her parents, hoping to leave the town. But her weeks of hiding were in vain.

They separated her from her father and mother, she said, and told her that she had to "testify" to a Serb commander. She was taken to a house used by some of the irregulars to rape women, and was herself immediately raped by two or three soldiers. She could not recall how many - "I was in a state of shock".

The prosecution asked: "What did they do specifically?" There was a pause before she replied: "They destroyed everything in me."

Heather Ryan, an observer at the Hague from the Washington legal group Coalition for International Justice, and an expert in witness protection, said the release of the two Bosnian Serb suspects was worrying, because witnesses might not turn up or could be intimidated as a consequence.

"There have been cases of intimidation of witnesses," she said.

The indictment says that one suspect, Dragan Gagovic, threateded witness 48 after he had raped her that he would "find her in five different countries if she told anyone that he had raped her".

Ms Del Ponte, was quick to criticise the release, saying in a statement: "The prosecutor is concerned that the provisional release of these accused will have a very negative impact on the victims and witnesses in this case."

The two, Miroslav Tadic and Simo Zaric, handed themselves over in 1998. But Ms Del Ponte said that if they did not turn themselves in again, they would never be handed over by the authorities in the Serb half of Bosnia, where war crimes suspects are largely regarded as heroes. The court would probably have to ask Nato peacekeeping troops to arrest them.

Last week Ms Del Ponte once again pressed Nato and the west to snatch the Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic, his army commander, General Ratko Mladic, and President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia. All are wanted by the court on war crimes charges.

A Sarajevo weekly, Slobodna Bosna, reported yesterday that Mr Karadzic hides with about 80 bodyguards at Celebici, a village near Foca. If there are rumours of a Nato raid he moves to a Bosnian Serb army barracks near Visegrad. His wife and children visit twice a month. His right hand man, Momcilo Krajisnik, was arrested last month.

Gen Mladic has been seen at football matches in Belgrade, and Mr Milosevic is trying hard to win back international respectability.

webTitle: Mugabe gangs torch homes of farm workers

fields.headline: Mugabe gangs torch homes of farm workers
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Gangs of attackers torched the homes of farmworkers yesterday, despite promises by the leader of Zimbabwe's squatters' movement of an end to hostilities.
fields.body:
Gangs of attackers torched the homes of farmworkers yesterday, despite promises by the leader of Zimbabwe's squatters' movement of an end to hostilities.

Smoke covered the Arcturus area, 30 miles north of Harare, as nearly 1,000 homes were razed by men who identified themselves as war veterans. Other farmers reported that their workers were beaten and intimidated by supporters of President Robert Mugabe.

The main target was Alan Windrum's tomato-growing farm in Arcturus. More than 100 armed men broke down doors, looted homes and threw in burning straw to set them alight. The farmworkers and their families had fled, so the attackers beat their dogs and goats to death with clubs. The scene was recorded by a lone APTV cameraman.

"This was the headquarters of the [opposition] Movement for Democratic Change and was causing us a lot of problems," said David Mashandu, leading the attackers. Many appeared to be teenagers, too young to have fought in the war against Rhodesian minority rule that ended in 1979.

Yesterday's violence was in contrast to the promises of peace made by Mr Mugabe and his ally, the war veterans' leader Chenjerai "Hitler" Hunzvi, who pledged that the attacks would stop. Hundreds of white farming families have now abandoned their homes in southern Matabeleland as well as the Marondera and Wedza areas.

The Zimbabwe Independent newspaper yesterday claimed that the farm invasions were directed by Zimbabwe National Army officers deployed to coordinate Zanu-PF supporters and war veterans. The ZNA "commanders" are providing supplies to the ex-combatants, who have occupied 1,000 white-owned farms.

Later today President Mugabe will meet the South African president, Thabo Mbeki, the Rwandan president, Paul Kagame, and the Ugandan president, Yoweri Museveni, at Victoria Falls to discuss the Congo civil war. The conference will also consider the crisis in Zimbabwe.

webTitle: Scathing verdict on MoD over floods row

fields.headline: Scathing verdict on MoD over floods row
fields.standfirst: Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: MPs are to deliver a damning verdict on the Ministry of Defence for its half-hearted response to the Mozambique floods that claimed hundreds of lives.
fields.body:
MPs are to deliver a damning verdict on the Ministry of Defence for its half-hearted response to the Mozambique floods that claimed hundreds of lives.

The international development committee, which has a majority of Labour MPs, will heavily criticise the MoD in a report to be published after the Easter parliamentary recess.

A leak to the Guardian reveals the MPs will condemn the MoD for its initial prohibitive costing for the supply of four Puma helicopters to help rescue flood victims. The report will also criticise the department's lack of flexibility when first asked to intervene.

The MPs are particularly scathing about the fact that the MoD estimated it would have to send 100 people to keep the four helicopters airborne. The MPs saw that as overmanning on a grand scale.

They also express scepticism about the initial cost of the operation, put at £2.4m by the MoD. Within days, in the face of public criticism, this had been cut back to £1.2m.

The report recommends that in future operations dealing with emergencies should not be conducted on an ad hoc basis.

The MPs, who took evidence from the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, the international development secretary, Clare Short, and United Nations officials, completed their report on Wednesday after two days of discussion.

A source close to the committee said: "Hoon said it was a Rolls-Royce package. You don't want a Rolls-Royce package in a situation like that. You want something done quickly.

"When people see something like Mozambique, they do not want the MoD talking about how much they are going to charge and including the cost of taking 100 people."

The source added: "It is an understatement to say Geoff Hoon will not be pleased with this report." In the inter-departmental battle between the MoD and Ms Short, the report unequivocally comes out on the side of Ms Short.

When the Mozambique flooding was at its height, with nightly television pictures of victims being plucked from trees, there was a huge behind-the-scenes row. Ms Short balked at the initial high cost put forward by the MoD and hired helicopters locally. In the days that followed, she was at loggerheads with the defence minster John Spellar over costs.

The source said: "The Department for International Development comes out of it extremely well. They did more than anyone else, and did it early and better."

As well as criticising the MoD, the report expresses extreme dissatisfaction with the performance of the UN office for the co-ordination of humanitarian affairs (Ocha).

The report suggests that Ocha should have co-ordinated the operation better, rather than leaving it to countries such as Britain to scrabble around trying to find helicopters. It also criticises the office for not considering the possibility of further rainfall.

The MPs question why Britain and Ocha could not have access to Nato resources. The MoD had to pay £500,000 to hire an Anatov plane to transport the helicopters and their equipment to Africa. The MPs show surprise that there was no Nato plane available for the task.

The row between the MoD and DfID began on Saturday, February 26, when DfID first contacted the MoD about the floods.

On February 28, Mr Spellar asked officials to draw up contingency plans. The following day, Ms Short's department was told the cost would be £2.4m. This was subsequently scaled down, along with the number of personnel to accompany the helicopters.

The MoD helicopters did not leave Britain until March 2 and began operation on March 6.

The report clears the MoD of accusations that the delay cost lives. The report will say that Ms Short, by hiring helicopters locally, ensured the British government's reaction was quick.

The MPs will ask Mr Hoon to respond to their findings.

fields.headline: Motorola rescues Hyundai plant
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
www.motorola.com
www.hyundai.com
fields.trailText: Motorola, the US electronics group, is investing £1.3bn in Scotland to increase its capacity to make chips for the booming mobile phone industry.
fields.body:
Motorola, the US electronics group, is investing £1.3bn in Scotland to increase its capacity to make chips for the booming mobile phone industry.

The group has bought the mothballed Hyundai semiconductor plant at Dunfermline and plans to employ about 1,350 people there within five years.

Motorola's new investment, its biggest in Europe, will only create 700 new jobs. It is planning to close its semiconductor plant at South Queensferry, near Edinburgh, and transfer its 650 strong workforce to the Dunfermline plant.

Motorola is already Scotland's largest manufacturing employer, with a total of 6,500 people at its semiconductor plants at South Queensferry and East Kilbride and its mobile phone handset operation at Easter Inch. But Hyundai's abandoned plans for Dunfermline involved a £2.4bn two phase development which would have created 2,000 jobs.

The Hyundai project, announced in 1996, was halted in 1998 after the first phase was built and equipped but before production started.

The South Korean company called off the project because of the financial crisis at home and the collapse in the market for dram chips which the plant was intended to make.

Hyundai never received promised government grants because no new jobs were created. Motorola, however, is expected to receive several million pounds in selective regional assistance.

Negotiations to secure the Motorola plant for Scotland have been going on for about a year. Scottish Enterprise, the regional development agency, became aware that the US group was planning a new European facility when it was exploring the possibility of having a contract semiconductor foundry built north of the border.

Scotland is believed to have fought off competition for the Motorola investment from alternative sites in Italy, France and Germany.

Motorola said the Dunfermline plant would make semiconductors based on eight inch wafers and using deep sub-micron technology for the rapidly growing mobile communications business.

Bill Walker, the senior Motorola vice president who announced the investment, said the new facility would help the company meet not only strong market demand but also anticipated future demand.

Motorola said the Dunfermline's semiconductors would incorporate its DigitalDNA technology which enables customers "to create smart products and new business opportunities in the networking and computing, wireless communica tions, transportation, and imaging and entertainment markets".

Robert Crawford, Scottish Enterprise's chief executive, said: "Motorola has already made an enormous contribu tion to the Scottish economy and I am delighted that this project will create more high quality employment opportunities. It is an enormous testament to the skills and quality of our workforce.

"Scotland needs to ensure that it has a strong foothold in this dynamic industry."

He added that the original investment made by Scottish Enterprise in the Dunfermline site and the surrounding infrastructure had also paid off. "One of Motorola's key requirements was to get this project off the ground as quickly as possible. The fact that we had a facility ready and waiting, with scope for expansion, was a major advantage."

Christine May, the Fife council leader, said the investment would have a strong effect on the local economy which in recent years had suffered significant job losses in defence related work.

fields.headline: Microsoft victors split over penalty
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
The future of Microsoft: special report
www.microsoft.com
fields.trailText: Lawyers for the US government and the 19 US states that brought the historic anti-monopoly case against Microsoft are trying to reach agreement over how to punish the company.
fields.body:
Lawyers for the US government and the 19 US states that brought the historic anti-monopoly case against Microsoft are trying to reach agreement over how to punish the company.

The US justice department is due to submit its preferred remedy to Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson next week. The government case was largely vindicated earlier this month when Judge Jackson ruled that Microsoft broke the law by abusing its stranglehold over the world's computer systems. However, there are understood to be strong differences of opinion between the 19 states and the justice department over penalties.

However, the extent of their reported differences is expected to make an agreement difficult to reach over the coming days.

webTitle: Marconi buys foothold in network services

fields.headline: Marconi buys foothold in network services
fields.standfirst:
£570m MSI deal brings in 'top flight' professionals

E-finance: special report
www.marconi.com
www.msi-world.com
fields.trailText: Marconi, the internet and telecoms group, is splashing out up to £570m on MSI, an international software and wireless consultancy. It wants to gain a foothold in the business of building networks to support the UK's much anticipated third generation mobile telephone system.
fields.body:
Marconi, the internet and telecoms group, is splashing out up to £570m on MSI, an international software and wireless consultancy. It wants to gain a foothold in the business of building networks to support the UK's much anticipated third generation mobile telephone system.

The acquisition is the first in six months for Marconi, which was transformed last year with the disposal of its defence interests to BAe and the name change from GEC.

It will pay £196m in cash for MSI and £195m in Marconi shares. A further £66m of options and warrants is likely to be rolled over into new Marconi options but this may grow by another £113m if certain performance targets are met.

Staff are expected to increase sales by $1.4bn over the next three years for the additional payment of £113m options to be made.

"I am confident the sales synergies we realise will be multiples of MSI's current revenues," said Marconi's chief executive Lord Simpson. "MSI takes Marconi further up the value chain in network services and wireless and, equally importantly, brings a team of top flight telecom professionals who are dedicated to providing high level software solutions to their clients." MSI had revenues of £58.8m in 1999.

Lord Simpson said Marconi was developing technology in Italy which it hoped would be used in the roll-out of networks for the five third generation mobile phone licences.

However, some analysts were sceptical yesterday that Marconi would be successful in winning a contract for one of the licences because it has no presence in mobile telephony and it would also be up against big manufacturers such as Nokia, Motorola and Ericsson.

Marconi was originally in the running to buy one of the third generation mobile phone licences as part of the Sonera and Virgin consortium, which withdrew after the price became too expensive.

Lord Simpson said Marconi would also look at building third generation networks in other European countries.

Analysts were favourable about the MSI acquisition. James Heal at Commerzbank said: "I don't think they have overpaid for the deal. All you need is a contract to roll out one of those third generation licences and you've clinched the benefits and synergies for the deal."

Marconi is expected to report a 2000 pre-tax profit near to £650m and Lord Simpson said the company's trading was "fine. I've got nothing to worry about."

However, analysts are concerned about the integration of Marconi's US acquisition of Fore Systems made last year, which propelled it into the ranks of big equipment suppliers to internet companies.

The company also quit its defence interests which it sold to BAe Systems.

fields.headline: Gloomy Trimble attacks 'stubborn' IRA
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, last night described the IRA's traditional Easter message as deeply depressing, and said it had undermined the current push to signal a return to devolution.
fields.body:
David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, last night described the IRA's traditional Easter message as deeply depressing, and said it had undermined the current push to signal a return to devolution.

Mr Trimble said the IRA had made it clear in its statement that the late offer it delivered on arms decommissioning two months ago had no substance. The IRA message will be read at rallies around Ireland on Sunday to mark the 1916 Easter Rising.

His comments came shortly after Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern, his Irish counterpart, met at Downing Street to discuss how to revive the flagging Good Friday agreement. While work behind the scenes will continue, the big push is now expected to come the week after next.

Mr Ahern, who also had discussions with Mr Blair in Dublin on Tuesday, was confident that they could make progress. But he said selling a proposed blueprint to Ulster Unionists and Sinn Fein would be difficult. He agreed there was little to derive from the IRA statement. But the comments are designed for the IRA's supporters, rather than for negotiations.

The Ulster Volunteer Force, on ceasefire for five years, also accused republicans of acting in bad faith. It feels the IRA has deliberately continued to instill fear and mistrust among unionists.

The IRA's initiative on weapons, made as Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, was suspending the executive two months ago, referred to movement on weapons in the context of the removal of the causes of conflict. It was withdrawn after direct rule was reimposed.

The IRA's statement yesterday spelled out for the first time what was meant by the removal of the causes of conflict. It defined it as "British involvement in Irish affairs, partition and the injustices which flow from that".

Mr Trimble said: "An offer to decommission in the context of the removal of the British presence and the creation of a united Ireland is not on offer. The IRA has made it clear that nothing of substance was offered on February 11 when the institutions were suspended.

"The IRA has vindicated the secretary of state's decision. Through its stubborn refusal to commit itself to peace by word and deed, it has put off the day when Northern Ireland politicians administer Northern Ireland affairs."

Mr Trimble is likely to come under pressure early next month to accept a compromise that will contain no guarantees on decommissioning. The governments are instead keen to secure an IRA commitment that there will be no return to violence. They are increasingly convinced that decommissioning is the wrong test with which to gauge republicans' long-term intentions and that it should be redefined to represent less of an obstacle to progress. One senior figure said: "But republicans have to say more, do more and commit more to unionists. It is about creating confidence."

The IRA is understood to acknowledge it has to offer something, but is adamant that there will be no statement explicitly stating its war is over. It also wants the institutions restored before it makes any move. But Mr Trimble would find it hard to sell such a deal to his sceptical party.

webTitle: 'We can't have them going around in rags'

fields.headline: 'We can't have them going around in rags'
fields.standfirst:
Budget pressures led Whitehall to draw up plans for a Scandinavian-style monarchy in the 1960s

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Whitehall drew up a secret plan for a Scandinavian-style monarchy when the royal family was pressing Harold Wilson's Labour government for a massive inflation-proofed increase in the annual civil list, according to recently released prime minister's office papers.
fields.body:
Whitehall drew up a secret plan for a Scandinavian-style monarchy when the royal family was pressing Harold Wilson's Labour government for a massive inflation-proofed increase in the annual civil list, according to recently released prime minister's office papers.

When the plan, drawn up by Sir William Armstrong, then permanent secretary at the Treasury and the future head of the civil service, was presented to Wilson he was told the scope for further economy in the royal finances was strictly limited unless more radical solutions were looked at.

The plan involved the Queen and her immediate family moving out of Buckingham Palace, which would become a historical monument open to the public as well as being used for ceremonial occasions. The large staff - the Queen herself was later to question the number of footmen - were to be reduced to a small core to run the royal office and provide food and drink as part of "government hospitality" at official functions.

Sir William proposed that the Queen should move to a purely private house, financed entirely from her own private means. She would have to pay the whole costs of running the house, including the wages of the private servants. "No doubt considerable style would be maintained," the Treasury's most senior civil servant predicted in his secret memorandum.

Struggle

This radical option is among the further detail in the official Downing Street file on the secret discussions about the civil list between 1965 and 1969 which was transferred to the public record office earlier this month. It shows that what the historian Ben Pimlott has called the "civil list crisis" went on for far longer - four years - than previously thought and that Whitehall considered far more radical options than was known about at the time.

The long struggle between Palace and Downing Street over money only became public when the Duke of Edinburgh, in his inimitable off-the-cuff way, told a 1969 NBC Meet the Press television interview in Washington: "We are in the red," and as the official record puts it "very jocularly" added "we might have to move out of our house next year".

As the Downing Street file puts it: "After Bill Heseltine [the Buckingham Palace chief public relations officer] had writhed in horror at these comments, there was discussion locally as to whether this part of the interview could be deleted; but since there were too many ordinary press people present it was decided not to do so." In fact the state papers make clear that Prince Philip was unaware of the delicate negotiations that had been going on or that his eviction from the palace had been seriously considered.

The duke, who added in the TV interview that they had been forced to sell a small yacht and expected that he would have to give up polo, caused consternation back in London where Wilson was forced into giving a Commons statement. The prime minister told MPs that discussions had been going on with the palace for a year over revising the civil list. The royal family had been in the red since 1962 and the civil list reserves would be exhausted by the end of 1970. He proposed that all parties agree that legislation for a new civil list was needed after the next general election.

Economies

But the papers show that the "discussions" had been going on ever since November 1965 and the royal family were pressing for the civil list payment to be increased from £475,000 to £785,000. They were also seeking an annual adjustment for rising costs and prices at a time when the Labour government was struggling to impose a prices and incomes policy on the rest of the country.

The Treasury reported that the tax-free annuities received by the Duke of Edinburgh (£40,000), the Queen Mother (£70,000), Princess Margaret (£15,000) and the Duke of Gloucester (£35,000) had been fixed in 1952 or earlier. "The palace have told us that the annuitants are finding it very difficult to make ends meet and we are looking into possible reliefs." At one point in the negotiations Roy Jenkins, the chancellor, said he could not see why they could not dip into the "royal fortune itself; or perhaps the royal family's bankers could be asked to help out with a loan" to tide them over until the new civil list.

The palace had undertaken two inquiries into possible efficiencies, one by the Treasury and one by the industrialist Sir Charles Smallpeice. A secret report by Sir William Armstrong in January 1966 said that further economies would only be possible with a "drastic reorganisation of the Queen's way of life of a kind which, I understand, the palace are not prepared to contemplate". Wilson responded by saying that it was "not practical politics to try to come to grips with the problem of the civil list so long as a substantial amount remained in the royal trustees account [the civil list reserve]."

Instead the three most senior civil servants in Whitehall, the cabinet secretary, Burke Trend, and the two joint permanent secretaries at the Treasury, Sir William Armstrong and Sir Laurence Helsby, drew up a detailed secret memorandum on the royal finances. It is in this memorandum that Armstrong said they could consider transferring the expenses of the royal mews (the upkeep of the carriages and horses, fodder and so on) to the taxpayer but the scope for economy must be strictly limited unless more radical ways "in which the net cost of the monarchy to the exchequer might be reduced".

He said that as long as the monarch and royal family continued to live in a palace (or palaces) that was at once a private house, an office and a centre for state occasions, with a household of employees who were in part personal servants of the royal family and in part servants of the state, then only small efficiency savings could be found.

Sir William said it was impossible to say how much could be saved by this option, as it had not been examined with the palace, but it would involve the virtual abolition of the Buckingham Palace resident staff and a cut in domestic staff. "The main point is it is difficult to see how a substantial saving could be made in any other way." He adds that this "Scandinavian-style" reform also had the virtue that it would remove the need to trouble parliament again during the Queen's reign.

Radical

He also proposed a second radical option of asking the Queen to surrender the whole of her revenues from the Duchy of Lancaster merged with the crown estate. The Queen still considers these annual revenues, which amounted to £5m in 1998, as her private income.

The Treasury did, however, succeed in getting the palace to agree that Prince Charles should surrender 50% rather than the 40% initially proposed from his annual revenues from the Duchy of Cornwall on the grounds that £133,000 a year was "rather a lot for a young man".

In the event Wilson did not go down the Scandinavian route and he eventually helped the Queen receive a generous settlement. The general Labour party attitude of the time was summed up by the veteran Labour MP Emanuel Shinwell, who said: "They probably find the going a bit hard. We can't have them going around in rags."

How Whitehall saw 'a quite different set-up at the palace'

"It is possible, however, to conceive of a quite different set-up at the palace, which for convenience might be called a Scandinavian-style monarchy. The idea would be that the monarch and the immediate royal family would live in a purely private house, financed entirely from the monarch's private means, including the grant to the privy purse. No doubt considerable style would be maintained, but the monarch would be wholly responsible for the purchase, maintenance and running of this establishment, the staff would be private servants, and their pay, pensions and other terms of service would be entirely a matter for the monarch.

"Buckingham Palace would cease to be a private house. Instead part of it would be a royal office and the remainder would be both a historical monument to which the public would be admitted and a site for ceremonial occasions, such as state banquets, investitures, receptions, garden parties, etc. It would be maintained entirely, inside and out, by the state from votes [taxpayers]; the staff would be limited to officials who were needed to help the monarch as head of state; and when food and drink were required for ceremonial occasions they would be provided by government hospitality, as is done already for functions in Lancaster House, and elsewhere."

webTitle: Lordships embark on a frisson impossible

fields.headline: Lordships embark on a frisson impossible
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: I arrived in the House of Lords to hear Lord Waddington denounce the visit of the despotic Putin.
fields.body:
I arrived in the House of Lords to hear Lord Waddington denounce the visit of the despotic Putin.

"What sort of ethical foreign policy is it that we bomb the living daylights out of a country which can't bomb us back [Serbia], and court a country which can?" he inquired.

Baroness Scotland, a Foreign Office minister, bridled at this. "I recall the frisson that went round this house when we said that there was no option but to take military action," she said.

She meant, I suppose, that their lordships were terribly excited about the idea, rather as if all their vibrating pagers had gone off at once, or they had learned that toasted crumpets were back on the tearoom menu. But it seems a peculiar policy, foreign affairs by tingle, sending young men off to die in a frisson impossible.

Moments later the peers began debating the Freedom of Information Act, or freedom from information bill, as one Tory called it. With almost no exceptions, they hated it.

Lord Falconer, a close friend of Tony Blair, launched the second reading. He thought it was a terrific bill. He pointed out that part I, clause 1, paragraph 1, subsection (a), said that anyone who wanted information from any public body had the right to be told if they had the info to hand, and if they did, to be told what it was.

Unfortunately after these five stirring lines, it is downhill all the way. It turns out that there are more loopholes in the bill than in a macrame mainsail.

Not that Lord Falconer was deterred. He pointed proudly to clause 76: "Nothing in this act is to be taken to limit the powers of a public authority to disclose information held by it."

This is as if the tax code declared: "Nothing in this act shall prevent anyone paying every penny he owes in tax, if he feels like it." Such a clause might make that possible, but only a fool would imagine it could make it likely.

The exemptions go on forever. We will not be allowed to learn anything that might affect the "capability, effectiveness or security" of the defence forces, or might prejudice "relations between the UK and any other state", or might harm "the effective conduct of public affairs", a phrase that could mean absolutely anything at all.

It turns out that there is an information commissioner, who can order the material to be handed over anyway. But a senior minister can overturn that order. When? Not any old time, oh dear me, no. Only if disclosure might have "effects adverse to the public interest".

Which translates, one suspects, as "if I say so". Putting it another way, the public has a right to all information, unless it might, conceivably, just possibly, in any way, shape or form, be inconvenient for a politician or, heaven forbid, a civil servant.

Listening to Lord Falconer, and the various attacks made on the bill, I thought that it would be simpler if they cut the verbiage and said anyone could have any information they wanted, just as soon as they had trained a troupe of gerbils to perform the finale from Riverdance.

Lord Mackay was as rude about the bill as any Tory could be, since his party's contribution to freedom of information is on a par with Cannon and Ball's contribution to world comedy.

But Lord McNally, a Liberal Democrat, was able to let rip. A real bill, he said, would not be an "anoraks' charter, of interest only to Guardian leader writers", but to the public as a whole.

The way things were, Sir Humphrey had won. "And we'll be hearing from Sir Humphrey later."

So we did, and nobody was remotely surprised when Lord Armstrong of Spycatcher - sorry, Illminster - turned out to be the only backbench supporter this sorry bill could claim.

fields.headline: Slovak leader held
fields.standfirst: Former prime minister charged with abuse of power
fields.trailText: Vladimir Meciar, the controversial former prime minister of Slovakia, was arrested yesterday and charged with abuse of power and fraud during his period in office in the 1990s.
fields.body:
Vladimir Meciar, the controversial former prime minister of Slovakia, was arrested yesterday and charged with abuse of power and fraud during his period in office in the 1990s.

Police commandos surrounded his villa at Trencianske Teplice in central Slovakia just after dawn. After reading the fraud charges over a loudhailer, the police asked him to leave the building. When he refused, they blew open the door, and took him away.

For the past month he has refused police demands to answer questions in an investigation into the 1995 kidnapping of Michal Kovac Jr, the son of his arch-rival Michal Kovac, who was president of Slovakia between 1993 and 1998.

Mr Meciar was taken to the capital, Bratislava, and charged with abuse of power and the illegal payment of bonuses to his ministers, amounting to more than $300,000 (£190,000).

He was also fined for refusing to answer police questions.

The charges did not relate to the kidnapping.

By noon he was released, to the cheers of supporters who had gathered outside the police station.

A former boxer turned lawyer, Mr Meciar emerged from the 1989 Velvet Revolution which overthrew the Communist authorities. He founded his Movement for a Democratic Slovakia (HZDS) from one wing of Public Against Violence. He led Slovakia to its independence in 1993.

HZDS officials yesterday accused the current government, led by Mikulas Dzurinda, of state terrorism and vowed to hold public protests. The HZDS, which leads in the opinion polls with more than 25%, is pushing for an early election. The government survived an opposition vote of no confidence a week ago.

Mr Meciar dominated Slovak politics for most of the 1990s, winning consecutive terms in office before being narrowly defeated by a coalition of four centre parties in 1998.

His years of power were marred by growing international condemnation and isolation, and a series of scandals which peaked with the kidnapping affair.

On August 31 1995 Michal Kovac Jr was found bruised and dazed in the back of his car just across the Austrian border.

He said he had been attacked by masked men on his way to work, beaten up, and forced to drink a bottle of whisky. Mr Kovac was arrested by the Austrian police, as he was wanted for fraud, which he claims was an attempt to frame him.

At his trial in Austria in 1996, an agent of the Slovak Secret Service, Oszkar Fegyveres, who claimed he had taken part in the kidnapping, gave evidence in Mr Kovac's defence, and the judge ruled that Mr Kovac was "kidnapped to Austria against his will", and set him free.

A subsequent police in vestigation in Slovakia ended when a key witness, a former policeman called Robert Remias, died when his car exploded in April 1996. At the same time, another police official, Peter Vacok, accused the government of blocking the investigation.

The current government has always accused Mr Meciar and his secret service chief, Ivan Lexa, of ordering the kidnapping to embarrass President Kovac.

In March 1998 Mr Meciar ordered an amnesty for all those responsible for the kidnapping, but the case was reopened when the opposition won power.

Mr Lexa was later detained but released on bail. No date has been given for the trial of Mr Meciar and Mr Lexa.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Civilians killed
fields.body:
Civilians killed

Iraq said yesterday that US and British warplanes enforcing the no-fly zones had killed 295 people and injured 860 since December 1998.

An air force spokesman told a weekly briefing that most of the casualties were civilians.

Iraq does not recognise the no-fly zones set up after the 1991 Gulf war to protect Shi'ite Muslims in the south and Kurds in the north.
AP, Baghdad

Workers to stay

Skilled foreign workers welcomed to Germany to make good a shortage of information technology skills will be allowed to stay longer than originally planned, the labour ministry said yesterday.

A spokesman for the labour minister confirmed reports that the workers, mainly from India and eastern Europe, would be allowed to stay for five years rather than the three years originally planned.
Reuters, Berlin

Gorilla signs out

Michael, one of only two gorillas said to have learned human language, has died. The 27-year-old knew about 500 gestures in sign language and "had a great facility with communication and was a talented artist", his trainer said.
AP, Woodside, California
