webTitle: Nevada tele.com woos Stentor in £45m deal

fields.headline: Nevada tele.com woos Stentor in £45m deal
fields.trailText: Nevada tele.com, a joint venture of Energis and Viridian, intends to expand to the Republic of Ireland after confirming yesterday that it was in talks with Irish rival Stentor that could lead to a £45.8m takeover.
fields.body:
Nevada tele.com, a joint venture of Energis and Viridian, intends to expand to the Republic of Ireland after confirming yesterday that it was in talks with Irish rival Stentor that could lead to a £45.8m takeover.

The likely takeover has already been given the green light by Stentor's major shareholder, the Co-operation Retirement Benefit Fund, which would hold about 84% of the company if convertible preference shares and warrants were exercised.

The offer would value Stentor at about 37p a share and 481p apiece for convertible preferred shares.

Stentor shares rose 7p to 36p, while Energis surged 161p to £29.12. Viridian was up just 1p to 720p.

Energis and Viridian will provide the funding for the takeover.

Nevada tele.com, which delivers data and internet services, operates in the Northern Ireland market and built its own metropolitan network in Belfast serving business and government customers and interconnects with NTL, BT and Energis.

Irene Cackett, managing director of Nevada tele.com, declined to comment on whether it would build its own network to service Dublin.

"I think I'll reserve my judgment on that, there are a number of things going on in the Dublin market," she said. "This deal does give us a chance to go south very quickly."

The large number of international corporates which have call centres and manufacturing plants based in Ireland will be attractive to Nevada tele.com, and in some cases the group might be able to gain leverage off Energis's own relationships with such corporates elsewhere in Europe.

The Irish market is one of the hottest investments in Europe because of its low corporate taxes and massive technology investment.

Ms Cackett believes Nevada tele.com could become a significant player serving the Irish business market in voice, internet, data and e-commerce, competing against Eircom and the BT-owned Esat because those two companies have been distracted by their other telecoms markets of fixed-line residential and mobile.

The consolidation in the Irish telecoms market was sparked off in January when BT bought Esat for $2.5bn (£1.6bn).

webTitle: Unigate merger with Dairy Crest upset by rival bid

fields.headline: Unigate merger with Dairy Crest upset by rival bid
fields.trailText: An all-out battle for control of the Unigate cheese and milk business broke out yesterday when Scottish milk group Robert Wiseman slapped down a £225m bid, upsetting a £202m merger plan Unigate had already agreed with rival Dairy Crest.
fields.body:
An all-out battle for control of the Unigate cheese and milk business broke out yesterday when Scottish milk group Robert Wiseman slapped down a £225m bid, upsetting a £202m merger plan Unigate had already agreed with rival Dairy Crest.

Just hours later Dairy Crest bounced back with a £235m offer.

The Wiseman bid of £125m cash was a substantial pre mium to the £102m all-share bid originally proposed by Dairy Crest. The original value of the Dairy Crest offer, when it was made in February, was £120m, but Dairy Crest's share price has since dwindled, taking the value of its bid down with it. Both companies were also assuming £100m of debt owed by the Unigate cheese and milk business.

But yesterday Dairy Crest came back with a choice for shareholders - its original all-share bid or £135m in cash, or a mixture of the two. The Wiseman bid had been expected and the group was last night urging Unigate shareholders to take no action. The group is considered likely to come back with a yet higher offer.

Unigate advised its shareholders to take no action - an about-turn for the company, which last week posted a circular to its shareholders proposing a vote to approve the Dairy Crest deal.

The Unigate business under the hammer includes the St Ivel and Shape brands, which in turn include the labels Utterly Butterly, Golden Churn and Vitalite.

Dairy Crest's range includes Country Life butter, Clover, Frijj and Yoplait Petit Filous and Frubes yoghurt tubes. If the merger with Dairy Crest goes ahead it will make the enlarged company number one or two in every dairy food sector.

Robert Wiseman, on the other hand, is a bulk supplier of milk to supermarkets. The company, based in East Kilbride, is run by brothers Alan and Robert Wiseman, who are chairman and managing director and who control just over 50% of the £70m business.

It is Britain's fourth largest milk processor. The bid for Unigate means it is attempting to take over a group three times larger than its own, current operation.

A spokesman for Wiseman said its offer would mean fewer job cuts. "Both Unigate and Dairy Crest are strong in the south", he said, "and their merger is based on cost savings, which means job cuts and closures. Wiseman, on the other hand, is strong in the north. It is a perfect geographical fit."

He said there was little overlap in the customers of Wiseman and Unigate. The Scottish group's biggest customers are Asda, Safeway and Morrisons, while Unigate's biggest buyers are Waitrose, Sainsbury and Marks & Spencer.

fields.headline: Leaked memo exposes British anxieties
fields.trailText: Intransigent Germans were to be contrasted with a flexible, compromising London, if the stock exchange had failed to clinch a merger with its Frankfurt rival.
fields.body:
Intransigent Germans were to be contrasted with a flexible, compromising London, if the stock exchange had failed to clinch a merger with its Frankfurt rival.

In a leak of a proposed strategy document - said to have been rejected by officials - the stock exchange was to issue "statesmanlike" expressions of regret but confidence in the future if the merger talks collapsed.

Embarrassing as the leak might be, last night the memo was not expected to derail the delicate talks about a possible merger between London and Germany.

The memo, described by public relations experts as a normal part of planning for significant announcements, also set out concerns about tackling the media even if the merger did succeed.

The anxiety, it appeared, was that a cynical press would regard any deal as a victory for Frankfurt, with the Germans winning or even taking over the London Stock Exchange itself. In that instance, the exchange planned to highlight London's role as a financial centre and define the agreement as a "watershed moment".

"We have come a long way," the draft memo said, pointing to the plans to demutualise after 200 years and the recent introduction of new trading systems.

In reality, the exchange was at pains yesterday to explain that agreement about a merger has yet to be clinched. The unwelcome publicity surrounding the memo follows a difficult period for the exchange, which was unable to open until 3.30pm on the last day of the financial year because of computer problems.

While the memo appears to have been a first attempt at producing a strategy, some of its concerns might shed some light on the nature of the talks. It mentions "intransigence of Germans over regulation" while raising questions about the possible ownership structure of any merged entity.

fields.headline: £4bn boost for pre-election tax giveaway
fields.trailText: Whitehall underspending and buoyant tax revenues have boosted the Treasury's coffers by an extra £4bn in the financial year just ended, leaving the chancellor plenty of room for pre-election tax cuts, official figures showed yesterday.
fields.body:
Whitehall underspending and buoyant tax revenues have boosted the Treasury's coffers by an extra £4bn in the financial year just ended, leaving the chancellor plenty of room for pre-election tax cuts, official figures showed yesterday.

Spending outstripped revenues by £1.4bn in March, the last month of the financial year, but this did not stop the public sector from chalking up a £15bn net surplus for the year as a whole - £4bn more than the chancellor predicted in last month's Budget. "Money seems to stick to this government," said Jonathan Loynes, UK economist at HSBC markets. "Once again they've been a bit cautious with their Budget figures. They are going to have a £3bn-£4bn better starting point for next year which means that, other things being equal, Mr Brown will be able to stand up in a year's time and give that much away."

Government departments underspent their budgets by £3.9bn, while tax receipts were £1.3bn higher than in the Budget forecast.

But some analysts warned that if departments carried out the planned spending in the next financial year there would be a substantial loosening of the fiscal stance which could prompt the Bank of England to rein back the economy with higher borrowing costs.

"If £3bn of public spending is carried forward, the fiscal stance will now ease by a substantial 1.2% of GDP in 2000-01," warned David Walton, UK economist at Goldman Sachs. "Public spending could grow by as much as 6.5% in real terms between 1999-00 and 2000-01, further complicating the task of the monetary policy committee."

The robust health of the public finances will exacerbate the problems facing pension funds which must hold a minimum proportion of blue chip government debt in their investment portfolios. As the government's finances have moved into surplus, the supply of long-dated government borrowing has dried up, forcing up prices.

Analysts said the Treasury target of issuing £12bn worth of ten-year gilts next year was out of reach.

webTitle: The jury's out for the prime minister

fields.headline: The jury's out for the prime minister
fields.trailText: For a moment Tony Blair must have thought he had been handed the greatest PR stunt of his career.
fields.body:
For a moment Tony Blair must have thought he had been handed the greatest PR stunt of his career.

As the prime minister tucked into his breakfast yesterday a formal summons popped through the letterbox demanding that one Anthony C Blair, of 11 Downing Street, present himself for jury service at Southwark crown court.

What a chance, he probably muttered to himself over his cornflakes, to demonstrate at first hand the core Blair belief of being "tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime".

As images of a stern prime minister marching up the court steps flashed in front of Mr Blair's eyes, reality struck home, no doubt with the help of his wife Cherie, who sits as a part-time judge. His status as an MP and a barrister means that the prime minister is a member of a select group, including the insane and the clergy, who are barred from jury service.

When the prime minister broke the news to Alastair Campbell of how close he had been to a public relations triumph, his spokesman decided that all was not lost. Why not release the letter to the press to show what an ordinary guy Tony is? He may have a grand residence in Downing Street, but as far as the court service computer is concerned he is just a random name on the electoral roll.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Antisoma drops £20m placing
Volatile market conditions have scuppered a placing of shares by Antisoma, the drug development company, which was intended to raise up to £20m.
fields.body:
Antisoma drops £20m placing
Volatile market conditions have scuppered a placing of shares by Antisoma, the drug development company, which was intended to raise up to £20m.

Antisoma's chief executive, Glyn Edwards, last night confirmed the fundraising had been cancelled, blaming last week's plunge in shares on the US market Nasdaq. "We'll consider coming back to the market early next year."

A spin-out from the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, Antisoma specialises in cancer therapies. The company has a drug for ovarian cancer in phase three clinical trials. Its shares fell 3p to 188p.

Ashtead £320m bet on Rentokil
Industrial plant hire firm Ashtead Group is buying Rentokil Initial's BET USA unit for £320m.

Ashtead chairman Peter Lewis said he had been discussing the takeover with Rentokil, Britain's second-biggest support services firm behind Hays, since last August. He also said the deal would mean that from now on two-thirds of Ashtead's revenues would come from the US, adding that BET USA would generate more cash for the group. Rentokil shares were trading near flat in the morning session and it has underperformed its sector by 21.5% this year.

BBC looks for property partner
The BBC kicked off its search for a private sector partner yesterday to help revamp its £500m property portfolio in what is likely to be one of many commercial deals under director general Greg Dyke.

As part of its plans to tighten its belt and focus more on programme making, the BBC launched a tender for a property partner to manage and develop its vast estate in a deal that could top £1bn.

The BBC - which spends £173m or 6% of its budget each year on its estate - plans to spruce up and streamline its portfolio which spans 522 properties, covering 7.5m sq ft.

No relief yet for internet stocks
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter's internet analyst Mary Meeker said the market is closer to a bottom than a top for the leaders in the internet sector.

Meeker said there are some compelling internet stock values. However, she added that she estimates more than half the companies in the sector will never truly recover and the sector, as a whole, perhaps has not yet seen a bottom.

The companies expected to come out in front are those with: leading market share, compelling operating models, strong cash positions, sufficient liquidity, sustainable growth, significant international opportunities, significant wireless and broadband opportunities, and strong management teams.

Deutsche spares Breuer
Rolf Breuer, chief executive of Deutsche Bank, survived yesterday's meeting of the bank's board despite speculation that he would lose his job as a penalty for collapse of the merger with Dresdner.

Mr Breuer was said by fellow board member Gerhard Renner said Mr Breuer to have persuaded the board to let him keep his job after explaining the events which led to the breakdown of the much-heralded deal. Bernhard Walter, his counterpart at Dresdner, has already fallen on his sword.

fields.headline: Blair denounces London's 'showbiz' candidate
fields.standfirst:
Race for mayor PM praises '24 hours a day' Dobson and warns Livingstone's tube plans could mean up to £6bn debt millstoneThe London mayor: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair returned to the mayoral fray yesterday with another highly personal attack on Ken Livingstone as the "showbiz" candidate whose disastrous policies would land London's taxpayers with "a millstone of debt" and its motorists with £5 a day congestion charges.
fields.body:
Tony Blair returned to the mayoral fray yesterday with another highly personal attack on Ken Livingstone as the "showbiz" candidate whose disastrous policies would land London's taxpayers with "a millstone of debt" and its motorists with £5 a day congestion charges.

At the same time he sought to portray Frank Dobson, the man who narrowly won the Labour nomination, as someone who would "roll up his sleeves to get the job done" by dint of hard work and practical policy solutions to the problems facing the capital - notably the cash-starved tube.

"Frank is not a media candidate. He is not a showbiz candidate but he is a 24 hours a day candidate. The guy will work night and day for this city. He has never changed in the 20 years I have known him," Mr Blair said at his second appearance at Mr Dobson's side during the current campaign.

Mr Dobson insisted that Londoners were beginning to recognise "the nightmare that would be a Livingstone mayor". He added: "Strip away the chat show talk, the gesture politics and the smarming up to every group he meets and you see what Londoners increasingly are seeing - that the emperor has no clothes."

Though Mr Livingstone's 20-page manifesto is cautious about his earlier plan to impose immediate congestion charges on cars entering London - an important income source for transport improvments - Mr Blair did not hesitate to revive it as being a £5 a day tax on motorists.

Mr Livingstone's plans to finance tube reconstruction via bond issues - rather than John Prescott's plans for public private partnership - were also condemned by Mr Blair at Labour HQ in Millbank as potentially costing £6bn in cost overruns.

With the fight to become what could be the first of many elected executive mayors in Britain - on the US or European model - now entering its last two weeks, Mr Blair's crude, if heartfelt, attack was seen by rival campaigns as proof of Downing Street's desperation.

Steve Norris, the Tory candidate who hopes to come through the middle and win against the odds, said Labour was rattled after he was attacked by Mr Blair as well. Under the Tories London would get "debt and privatisation", he predicted.

"They recognise that this is now a two-horse race between me and Ken Livingstone ... this can be the only explanation for the prime minister taking his eye off the ball to visit the bedside of Frank Dobson's ailing campaign," Mr Norris countered.

Dobsonites see it as a sign that the prime minister believes Mr Livingstone can still be beaten by loyalty and organisation, provided he gets what leftwing loyalist, Dennis Skinner, calls "a fair crack of the whip" from the media. The Bolsover MP also made a ferocious attack on his old NEC ally, Mr Livingstone this week, calling him an egotist and a liar.

The former GLC leader responded to Mr Blair's attack by saying that he has produced a detailed policy manifesto - a recipe for confrontation with Whitehall, says the Dobson camp - whereas "Frank, with the election only two weeks away, is the only candidate with no manifesto".

Far from talking policy, as he he claims to be doing, the Dobson campaign "is spending most of his time attacking me. Labour's campaign is currently a manifesto-free zone," the Brent East MP declared in a statement. The Dobson manifesto is due shortly.

Mr Livingstone declined a BBC News 24/Radio 5 Live plan to join other candidates to grill each other live on air. He would accept their questions, but not question them because it would descend into "point scoring and mud slinging", he predicted.

The Lib Dem candidate, Susan Kramer, who is close behind Mr Dobson and Mr Norris on 12% according to last week's local poll, said Mr Dobson had still not explained how he will finance the tube.

fields.headline: Spycatcher peer backs secrecy code
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: The government's freedom of information bill won the active support of a single peer when it faced a barrage of renewed criticism during its second reading in the upper house yesterday.
fields.body:
The government's freedom of information bill won the active support of a single peer when it faced a barrage of renewed criticism during its second reading in the upper house yesterday.

Support came from the former cabinet secretary, Lord Armstrong of Ilminister, the Whitehall official who travelled to Australia to try and supress the MI6 memoir, Spycatcher, and famously admitted in court that he had been "economical with the truth".

Though the Lords gave the bill an unopposed second reading, peers in all main parties renewed criticisms made by MPs.

The minister in charge, Lord Falconer, promised "a fair hearing" to any amendments which improveed the bill, much as Jack Straw made conciliatory retreats in the Commons. "We believe that we have got the balance about right," Lord Falconer told peers as he commended the home secretary's "broad consensus". Lord Armstrong's rare intervention took the shape of broad support for greater openness in British public life, combined with a mandarin's warning that advice given to ministers by officials like himself - a crucial point of controversy in the bill - must be protected from disclosure.

"I do not believe that those processes can be conducted in a goldfish bowl," he told fellow peers. It was impractical to try and divide official advice between that which could be disclosed and that which could not, Lord Armstrong insisted. He also backed protection for traditional collective cabinet responsibility.

Labour, Liberal Democrat and Tory peers promised to probe key weaknesses in the bill at committee stage. But Lord Armstrong warned that "it will always be possible for governments to find means by which they can avoid the disclosure of information which they really do not want or think it right to disclose without technically failing to comply with the legislation".

The search for evasive techniques would mean that information could be recorded improperly, passed by word of mouth or on the "backs of envelopes", he said.

webTitle: Russia to return looted art, but not to Germany

fields.headline: Russia to return looted art, but not to Germany
fields.standfirst: Law change announced as Moscow agrees 'exceptional' swap with Berlin of drawings for section of Amber RoomRussia: special report
fields.trailText: Russia is to lift its blanket ban on returning thousands of precious works of art looted at the end of the second world war, in an overture by President Vladimir Putin's administration towards the west.
fields.body:
Russia is to lift its blanket ban on returning thousands of precious works of art looted at the end of the second world war, in an overture by President Vladimir Putin's administration towards the west.

But while the bill, expected to be passed by the Russian parliament next week, will please the country's wartime allies and help to overcome years of rancour over the "trophy art" controversy, it will leave Germany angry at being exempted from the list of potential beneficiaries.

Since the cold war ended a decade ago, Russia and Germany have been at loggerheads over the rightful ownership of the huge collections of art and cultural objects looted first by the Germans across Nazi-occupied Europe and then removed by the Red Army when the Russians sacked eastern Germany at the end of the war.

The basements of museums and galleries across Russia today remain stuffed with the booty - estimated by German officials at more than 1m works of art and 2m books and other objects taken from Germany at the end of the war. The lower house in Moscow, the Duma, is expected to amend the trophy art legislation next week, making it possible for works of art held by Russia to be returned to their owners abroad, provided they were not among the "aggressor states" of axis powers.

Effectively the complex legal measures mean that items looted by the Nazis and then seized by the Soviet Union will qualify for restitution. Moscow insists that the German loot rightfully belongs to Russia as small compensation for the destruction wrought on the country by the Nazis. Berlin argues that Russia is in breach of international law in keeping the treasure.

But despite the continuing ban on returning war booty to Germany, Russia and Germany are next week to trade 101 drawings and paintings for a fragment of the legendary 18th century Amber Room which disappeared from a St Petersburg palace in 1945.

The pictures, currently under guard at the German embassy in Moscow, include works by Albrecht Dürer and Toulouse Lautrec originally in the collection of the Bremen Kunsthalle in northern Germany. In a pioneering move, the Social Democratic mayor of Bremen, Henning Scherf, and Germany's arts minister, Michael Naumann, are to be given the pictures at a ceremony in Moscow next week, the first time since the war that Moscow has handed over war loot to Germany.

In return the Russians will receive a commode and one of four mosaic panels that once graced the fabulous Amber Room at the imperial summer palace in Tsarskoye Selo, outside St Petersburg.

The mosaic is the first fragment of the room to have surfaced since the war, despite constant treasure hunts for the mystery masterpiece during the last 50 years. The mosaic emerged in Bremen three years ago in the possession of an old-age pensioner whose father apparently stole it in 1945.

Built at the beginning of the 18th century in what was east Prussia and is now the Russian enclave of Kaliningrad, the Amber Room, a study entirely clad in highly carved honey-coloured amber, was a present to Peter the Great of Russia from King Friedrich Wilhelm I of Prussia to seal the two monarchs' pact against Sweden.

The Russian ruler's daughter, Elizabeth, had the amber cladding installed at the Catherine Palace at Tsarskoye Selo, where it remained for almost two centuries until the Nazis dismantled it in 1943 and returned it to Königsberg.

When the Red Army seized the enclave in 1945, Hitler had the chamber stripped and the amber packed into crates. It then disappeared without trace until the mosaic surfaced in 1997. Intriguingly, the Amber Room has never been found, baffling experts and fortune-seekers and spawning countless treasure hunts and false alarms.

The Germans are returning the mosaic and the chest of drawers next week in the hope that the gesture will hasten the return of hundreds of thousands of books, coins and paintings looted from Nazi Germany, including an original Gutenberg bible, and the fabled Schliemann collection of gold from ancient Troy.

The Russians say they are making an exception in returning the 101 pictures to Bremen because they were stolen by an individual and not removed by Stalin's official teams of art-robbers.

The changes to the law should end a decade of confrontation between the Kremlin and the parliament about trophy art, and are the latest evidence that President-elect Putin is in for a much easier ride with the Duma than was his predecessor, Boris Yeltsin.

For years, the Duma defied Mr Yeltsin's attempts to be more conciliatory on the war loot, causing Mr Yeltsin to go to the constitutional court last summer to have the art treasures law amended.

Mr Putin is to visit Germany on June 15-16 for his first meeting with the chancellor, Gerhard Schröder.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: London shares closed a dull pre-Easter session on a firm note despite a mixed showing in New York at the opening bell and fears - following strong UK data - that a rise in British interest rates in the near future is almost inevitable.
fields.body:
London shares closed a dull pre-Easter session on a firm note despite a mixed showing in New York at the opening bell and fears - following strong UK data - that a rise in British interest rates in the near future is almost inevitable.

The FTSE 100 index ended the day 56.3 points higher at 6,241.2, compared with an early-day low of 6,134.4.

The broader FTSE indices were also in positive territory, with only the Techmark bucking the trend, down 23.58 to 3,538.73 on the back of continued Nasdaq uncertainty.

Volume was an uninspiring 1.162bn shares, with trading tailing off late in the day as traders and fund managers headed off early for the long weekend.

Strong gains from soon-to- merge drug groups Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham provided blue chips with their biggest boost, as encouraging first quarter results from both helped the Footsie reverse its initial decline. Glaxo added 56p to £19.58, SmithKline was up 28p at 879.5p, after strong sales growth from both groups.

BAT was a late winner, up 32 at 346p, boosted by late buying, thought to be by US traders, ahead of the holiday weekend.

Elsewhere, "quality" media and telecoms stocks attracted some fresh interest. Reuters stood out, up 67p at £11.25, continuing to be supported by solid first quarter results and helped by a new internet delivery system.

BSkyB gained 120p to £16.10, Energis rose 161p to £29.12, United News and Media added 25p to 791p and Colt Telecom ran 199p higher to £28.09.

Deutsche Bank "buy" advice lent support to WPP Group, 62p higher at 938p, ahead of full-year results next week. The broker expects WPP to highlight the benefits of strong global advertising markets coupled with growth in the non-advertising businesses, plus recovery in the Far East and Latin America.

Royal Bank of Scotland added 22p to 976.5p as the same broker had some nice things to say on the Scottish bank's move to upgrade its estimate of savings and revenue enhancements from the NatWest merger. Bank of Scotland joined in the fun, up 29p at 664p, boosted by "outperform" advice from Lehman Brothers, while Lloyds TSB added 21p to 661.5p as Credit Lyonnais Securities upgraded its ratings recommendation to "buy" from "add".

Rentokil Initial remained firm, up 14p to 174.5p after announcing plans to sell its US plant hire business to second liner Ashtead Group for £320m.

BSkyB gained 120p to £16.10, Energis rose 161p to £29.12, United News and Media added 25p to 791p and Colt Telecom ran 199p higher to £28.09. Deutsche Bank "buy" advice lent support to WPP Group, 62p higher at 938p, ahead of full-year results next week. The broker expects WPP to highlight the benefits of strong global advertising markets coupled with growth in the non-advertising businesses, plus recovery in the Far East and Latin America. Royal Bank of Scotland added 22p to 976.5p as the same broker had some nice things to say on the Scottish bank's move to upgrade its estimate of savings and revenue enhancements from the NatWest merger. Bank of Scotland joined in the fun, up 29p at 664p, boosted by "outperform" advice from Lehman Brothers, while Lloyds TSB added 21p to 661.5p as Credit Lyonnais Securities upgraded its ratings recommendation to "buy" from "add". fields.headline: Taking care of business
fields.standfirst: Queen's Awards: From lava lamps to chemical warfare agent detection systems...
fields.trailText: Firms making products ranging from buses to lava lamps are among those today granted the Queen's Award for Enterprise 2000.
fields.body:
Firms making products ranging from buses to lava lamps are among those today granted the Queen's Award for Enterprise 2000.

The Queen announced 77 awards for international trade, 32 for innovation and seven for environmental achievement. There are more awards this year in the innovation and environmental achievement categories but fewer for international trade.

Among the 116 successful companies are well-known brand names such as Jaguar, which has picked up an international trade award for the sixth time, and Marks & Spencer's womenswear group - which won an innovation award for its Secret Support vest and bodysuit liner.

Other winners include Glasgow-based Traditional Weatherwear, which specialises in mackintoshes and exports them to Europe, the United States and the Far East.

Another fashion retailer in the awards line-up is George J Cox of Wellingborough, Northamptonshire, which manufactures footwear.

The company's biggest line is its retro-style creeper, of which it sells more than 50,000 pairs a year to Japan.

One of the companies to be given an innovation award is Marconi Applied Technologies' safety and security group based in Chelmsford, Essex, which makes thermal imaging cameras used by emergency and rescue services.

Graseby Dynamics of Watford has won an award for the first time. It manufactures chemical warfare agent detection systems, and its exports have increased fourfold during the past three years.

Optare Group of Leeds has been given an innovation award for its Solo low-floor bus, which allows elderly passengers and mothers with pushchairs to get aboard the vehicle more easily.

A company which has developed a breast pump to help working mothers has won awards for both innovation and trade.

The pump - which is made by the baby products division of the Cannon Avent Group, in Glemsford, Suffolk - is designed to help mothers combine breast and bottle feeding by expressing milk, allowing babies to benefit from breast milk for longer.

London-based Mathmos - which makes objects for the home including the lava lamp - has won its second international trade award.

One of the organisations to receive an environmental award is Strattons Hotel in Swaffham, Norfolk, which has reduced its energy consumption by 19%.

The hotel has introduced a range of energy efficiency projects - including collecting rainwater in an old underground tank.

Another is Tesco Distribution, which has been given the award jointly with the Paxton Division of McKechnie Components for developing a reusable transport packaging system which means vehicles have to make fewer journeys.

Successful organisations are entitled to fly the award flag and display the emblem on their letterheads, the goods they produce and articles used by employees.

This year there is a new award emblem, designed by students Christine Munch and Kjerstin Keller from Robert Gordon University in Aberdeen, who won a national redesign competition. A Queen's Awards office spokesman said: "We are delighted with the new emblem. It is simple and elegant and will quickly become an easily recognised symbol of the prestige which a Queen's Award confers."

fields.headline: Broker buttresses Wickes defence
fields.trailText: Wickes, the DIY group which is the subject of a hostile 375p-a-share bid from privately owned rival Focus Do It All, received support in its campaign to stay independent yesterday. The broker Collins Stewart attacked the FDIA proposal as "opportunism, not realism".
fields.body:
Wickes, the DIY group which is the subject of a hostile 375p-a-share bid from privately owned rival Focus Do It All, received support in its campaign to stay independent yesterday. The broker Collins Stewart attacked the FDIA proposal as "opportunism, not realism".

Wickes is the number three player in the huge and growing DIY market, which is led by B&Q with Homebase in second place.

FDIA's rationale is that Wickes cannot survive on its own and an enlarged group would be a credible third force, able to muster improved buying power and marketing muscle - and able to compete more vigorously with the market leaders.

Wickes's boss, Bill Grimsey, is not impressed. In his official defence document he labelled the FDIA offer "ludicrously low". The shares are changing hands at 405p.

Collins Stewart joined the growing band of City DIY-watchers who reckon the bid, which was at a 39% premium to Wickes' share price when it was tabled, is far too low. Collins Stewart describes Wickes as "a cash cow and a tactical asset" and urges shareholders to hold out for more. It even suggests that investors not in the stock should climb aboard because the downside risk is limited.

Wickes, it says, has a robust balance sheet and even after the group's current £150m renewal programme it will retain positive cash balances. When the programme is complete in 2001, "the group will be highly cash generative and will have the flexibility provided by substantial free cash flow".

On that basis Collins Stewart reckons that 2002 earnings should be the basis of any valuation of Wickes. The current bid, the brokerage calculates, is just 6.5 times its 2002 forecast and it should be nearer 10 times.

The brokers also reckon a rival bid might be forthcoming, perhaps from the US or a continental European operator.

Several analysts have suggested a £5-a-share bid is more appropriate, but Collins Stewart reckons a more accurate valuation of the business is 598p a share.

FDIA is fighting a losing battle with its paltry 375p suggestion.

webTitle: Straw asked to allow Shipman inquests

fields.headline: Straw asked to allow Shipman inquests
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: A coroner has written to Jack Straw, the home secretary, seeking permission to open inquests into the deaths of 23 women who could be victims of the serial killer Harold Shipman.
fields.body:
A coroner has written to Jack Straw, the home secretary, seeking permission to open inquests into the deaths of 23 women who could be victims of the serial killer Harold Shipman.

John Pollard, the south Manchester coroner, said he was unable to proceed without Mr Straw's approval because the bodies had all been cremated.

Shipman, a former GP from Mottram, near Hyde, Greater Manchester, was convicted in January of murdering 15 of his women patients with lethal injections of diamorphine.

After the trial ended at Preston crown court, the crown prosecution service decided not to proceed with criminal charges against Shipman relating to the 23 patients because he could not be guaranteed a fair hearing.

Mr Pollard will also reopen the inquests into the deaths of Sarah Ashworth, Alice Kitchen and Elizabeth Mellor, which were adjourned at the end of 1998 pending further investigation.

He is now satisfied that there will be no criminal proceedings following from the deaths of the three women and the in quests will be held as soon as possible.

Shipman, who is in Frankland prison, Co Durham, will be informed of the inquests by the coroner and notified of his right to attend the hearings.

Mr Pollard has also decided that in all the other deaths which he investigated that there is either no evidence or insufficient evidence to justify him asking Mr Straw to make exhumation orders.

Greater Manchester police investigated a total of 150 deaths of Shipman's former patients.

"I have taken this course of action based upon the evidence which is presently before me and particularly based upon the fact that it is my understanding that the families and relatives of the deceased are anxious for the evidence relating to their deaths to be heard and tested by way of inquest," Mr Pollard said.

"I would take this opportunity to reiterate that any coroner's inquest is a court of inquiry and not one of determining blame or liability, be that either criminal or civil."

He said there would be a considerable amount of work involved in the investigation and inquests.

The families of some of the 23 women named by Mr Pollard welcomed his letter.

Sue McAlpine, whose mother Irene Heathcote is one of the suspected victims, said: "There are an awful lot of questions surrounding this that need to be answered. Due to the fact that the inquiry is going to be held in private, the only way I can get these answers is through an inquest." Helen Blackwell, whose mother Bertha Moss died in Shipman's surgery, said: "It's a crumb of comfort. We should have had some individual attention a while ago. But we still want to know how he was allowed to go on for such a long time. We don't want any cover-ups."

An independent inquiry, headed by Lord Laming of Tewin, will begin hearing evidence in private in Manchester at the end of next month.

The 23 possible victims are: Dorothy Andrew, Irene Berry, Edith Grady, Edith Brock, Elsie Cheetham, Erla Copeland, Lillian Cullen, Valerie Cuthbert, Elsie Dean, Joan Dean, Doris Earls, Elsie Hannible, Irene Heathcote, Hilda Hibbert, Bertha Moss, Nellie Mullen, Gladys Saunders, Mabel Shawcross, Marjorie Waller, Mary Walls, Ada Warburton, Amy Whitehead and Joyce Woodhead.

webTitle: British oil worker endures 239th day as hostage in Colombia

fields.headline: British oil worker endures 239th day as hostage in Colombia
fields.trailText: Alistair Taylor was driving along the road between the city of Yopal and Moricha Morichal in Colombia's oil-rich Casanare region when the kidnap gang struck.
fields.body:
Alistair Taylor was driving along the road between the city of Yopal and Moricha Morichal in Colombia's oil-rich Casanare region when the kidnap gang struck.

Three yellow taxis surrounded the Scottish oil worker's four-wheel drive and forced it to a standstill. Firing warning shots into the air, the gang bundled him into the boot of one of the taxis.

Mr Taylor, from Inverurie in Aberdeenshire, is now spending his 239th day in the hands of the group of Marxist rebels.

According to Jose Escobar, Colombia's anti-kidnapping tsar, the 44-year-old is being held by a gang of rebel gunmen belonging to a small faction within the national liberation army, the ELN. The group issued a photograph after the ambush showing Mr Taylor alive and well, and his family was able to deliver letters and a detective novel to him for Christmas through the International Red Cross.

A long, long week ago

I can still remember how the market used to make me smile

What I'd do when I had the chance

Is get myself a cash advance

And add another tech stock to the pile...

With every speech that he delivered

Bad news on the rate front

Still I'd take one more punt

I can't remember if I cried

When I heard about the CPI

I lost my fortune and my pride

The day the Nasdaq died...

Now I'm gettin' calls for margin

'Cause my cash account's dry

It's just two weeks from a new all-time high

And now we're right back where we were in July

We're right back where we were in July...

QCOM at 150 or above?

'Cos George Gilder told you so

Now do you believe in Home Depot?

Can Wal-Mart save your portfolio?

Well, I know that you were leveraged too

So you can't just take a long-term view

Your broker shut you down

No more margin could be found...

I never worried on the whole way up

Buying dot.coms from the back of a pickup truck

But Friday I ran out of luck

It was the day the Naaaasdaq died...

I started singin'

Bye, bye to my piece of the pie

Now I'm gettin' calls for margin

'Cause my cash account's dry

It's just two weeks from a new all-time high

webTitle: Kidnaps for ransom reach worldwide high

fields.headline: Kidnaps for ransom reach worldwide high
fields.standfirst: Political unrest and poverty are key factors in the rise of abductions, says insurer, and Latin America is singled out as riskiest region
fields.trailText: Kidnapping for ransom reached a record high across the world last year, with Latin America by far the most dangerous region, according to a survey released by a specialist insurer. There were 1,789 known kidnappings in 1999, with 92% occurring in just 10 countries. Latin America accounted for more than three-quarters of the total.
fields.body:
Kidnapping for ransom reached a record high across the world last year, with Latin America by far the most dangerous region, according to a survey released by a specialist insurer. There were 1,789 known kidnappings in 1999, with 92% occurring in just 10 countries. Latin America accounted for more than three-quarters of the total.

In Colombia, where Marxist guerrilla groups use kidnapping as a means of funding their war with the government, there were 972 abductions, accounting for 70% of the total.

Rob Davies, a special risks underwriter at the insurance group Hiscox, which carried out the survey, said political unrest, lawlessness and poverty were key reasons for the rise in kidnappings over the past decade. "The total number of kidnappings is likely to be considerably higher, because many incidents, particularly in developing countries, go unreported and are dealt with privately. We advise anyone travelling to or working in the 'at risk' countries to exercise due caution."

The Foreign Office advice is more clear cut. "Whatever business you are in, and whatever you do, we suggest that people follow our advice. And if that advice is don't go to a particular country, then don't go.

"In places like Chechnya, for example, we won't risk sending our own people there, so there is very little we can do to help you."

The Foreign Office sets in motion a well-rehearsed set of procedures when a British national is kidnapped abroad. The first step is to contact the government of the country concerned and insist that no action is taken that could harm the hostage's safety, a request that was ignored with disastrous results by the Yemeni government in December 1998, when three British tourists and one Australian were killed in a shoot-out between security forces and a gang of Islamic militant kidnappers.

British policy remains never to give in to ransom demands, but the Foreign Office admits it has no control over the actions of people and companies with abduction insurance.

Diplomats are understood to be worried that the rise in demand for kidnap insurance may be exacerbating the problem, as many kidnap gangs expect employees of multinational companies to be covered.

But it is not just businessmen and women who are at risk. At least three Premiership clubs are reported to be paying premiums at Lloyd's brokers for abduction and ransom cover when their teams play abroad. Manchester United's trip to Brazil to play in the inaugural World Club Championships was considered a particularly high-risk trip.

South American players and their families have long been the target of kidnap gangs. Romario, the Brazilian star, almost dropped out of the 1994 World Cup in the US after kidnappers seized his father and demanded a £4m ransom. The gang later released him unharmed.

In Colombia footballers have even managed to find themselves on the wrong side of the law in kidnap cases. The national team's former goalkeeper, Rene Higuita, spent six months in jail after being accused of acting as an intermediary in the kidnap of the daughter of a drug baron, Carlos Molina, by another drug baron, Pablo Escobar.

The number of kidnap and ransom policies underwritten at Lloyd's has more than doubled in the past 10 years. It is understood that Hiscox pays out for about 30 kidnappings a year, but the group refuses to release details about people for whom it has paid to be released or those it insures.

A spokeswoman for the company said: "If it becomes common knowledge that a person has kidnap insurance then they are much more likely to become a target."

Hot spots for danger

1 Colombia - 972

2 Mexico - 402

3 Former Soviet Union - 105

4 Brazil - 51

5 Philippines - 39

6 Nigeria - 24

7 India - 17

8 Ecuador - 12

9 Venezuela - 12

10 South Africa - 10

webTitle: Byers to name new investor in West Midlands

fields.headline: Byers to name new investor in West Midlands
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Ministers are to increase state aid for the West Midlands and unveil the identity of a new overseas investor in the region, after conceding last night that the break-up of Rover would create devastation.
fields.body:
Ministers are to increase state aid for the West Midlands and unveil the identity of a new overseas investor in the region, after conceding last night that the break-up of Rover would create devastation.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, is preparing to augment a £129m rescue package for the region after a government appointed taskforce warned that more money would be needed to offset huge job losses. He also hopes to announce shortly expansion plans by an overseas manufacturer that will create hundreds of new jobs.

Mr Byers will present the multimillion pound investment as a vote of confidence in the West Midlands, but will acknowledgesmuch more needs to be done to offset up to 19,000 redundancies.

Alex Stephenson, chairman of the task force set up by Mr Byers following the decision by BMW to sell Birmingham's giant Longbridge car plant, yesterday conceded that the sale would have a "significant, even severe" impact on the local economy. The government fears the job cuts could cost it seats in the West Midlands at the election.

BMW intends to retain 2,000 workers making gearboxes and engines, but a leaked taskforce report concedes as many as 19,000 jobs will go at Longbridge, among suppliers, and in the wider economy.

Mr Stephenson refused to confirm the figure as he warned BMW's plan to ditch Longbridge posed major problems for the area. "That does mean a lot of jobs, but I am not prepared to put a figure on it," said Mr Stephenson. The leaked document stating as many as 19,000 jobs will go is to be presented next week to Mr Byers.

Mr Stephenson maintained the region still had a bright manufacturing outlook, although not necessarily centred on car production. The taskforce study says extra cash will be needed on top of the £129m to save the region from an economic catastrophe. "As we focus on the longer term regeneration activities additional funding will be sought," says the report.

A series of short-term measures already agreed will retrain workers facing redundancy and help firms find new markets. Economists accept most car workers face bleak prospects and are unlikely to find other well-paid jobs in motor manufacturing. BMW made clear that it would keep a couple of thousand of Longbridge's 9,000-strong workforce as it attempted to counter bad publicity. A spokesman for BMW in Germany said: "We have maintained all along that the 2,000 staff at the Midland Powertrain would be retained."

Yet BMW's favoured plan is to sell on Longbridge to venture capitalists Alchemy, which has said it would concentrate on building MG sports cars and admitted many jobs would go.

A rival bid by the Phoenix consortium, headed by a former Rover chief, would save more jobs, but the German-owned motor giant appears to want a quick deal with Alchemy.

Mr Byers hopes to make public the identity of the new investor next week - it is believed already to have an operation in the region. He faces a series of industrial problems including potentially heavy job losses in shipbuilding and steel. Earlier this week he announced a £100m deal to postpone pit closures. Yesterday he promised the government's "fullest consideration" to bids by Govan shipyard for a defence contract.

fields.headline: Refugees return to Kosovo
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Almost exactly a year after arriving in Yorkshire from the wreckage of Kosovo, nearly 70 refugees returned home yesterday on a flight to Pristina.
fields.body:
Almost exactly a year after arriving in Yorkshire from the wreckage of Kosovo, nearly 70 refugees returned home yesterday on a flight to Pristina.

Families packed up slightly bulkier belongings than the threadbare holdalls and plastic bags with which they arrived last April from the mud of Stenkovac 1 camp in Macedonia.

Most had been staying at converted elderly people's homes and schools in Leeds, which was the first British city to accept refugees from Kosovo. Liz Westmoreland, regional coordinator of the emergency relief effort, said: "People in this area gave an amazingly warm welcome to these evacuees from Kosovo and we are all delighted that they can now go home and start to rebuild their lives. They are are very grateful that so many people have shown them such goodwill."

Other Kosovans will remain in Britain while their home areas are considered unsafe. The UN High Commissioner for Refugees advises against the return of Kosovo Albanian refugees to Serb-dominated parts of the province.

fields.headline: Women's team goes professional
fields.trailText: They will train five times a week, aspire to winning the Premiership, and be expected to show the same commitment to the game as the likes of Karl-Heinz Riedle and Bjarne Goldbaek, Fulham football club's star players.
fields.body:
They will train five times a week, aspire to winning the Premiership, and be expected to show the same commitment to the game as the likes of Karl-Heinz Riedle and Bjarne Goldbaek, Fulham football club's star players.

But the new signings, announced yesterday at the ambitious west London club, have one clause in their contracts that sets them apart: the right to maternity leave. These players are women, and, as of next season, they will form the nation's first professional women's football team, with fixtures every Sunday.

The seven signed so far to Fulham Ladies include one mother, Norwegian international midfielder Margunn Haugenes, who takes her 11-month-old daughter, Camilla, to all the matches. But the club will not penalise any of the squad, who will number 16 by the time the season starts in July, if they become pregnant.

"You'll get maternity leave as you would in a normal 9 to 5 job," explained Ronnie Gibbons, 20, the side's captain. "You won't be able to play at all, but you'll be given time off and then be expected to come back a month after the birth."

The right wing-back, who has played for Fulham girls since the age of 13, added that she felt "very proud" to captain the first professional womens' side, and described it as a gain for feminism.

"It has given women in general a boost, and shown our worth is recognised. When I was a girl, all the people I looked up to were men - but, hopefully, now there will be some good female role models."

The desire to strike a blow for equality may not have been uppermost for Mohamed Al Fayed, the club's multi-millionaire chairman, when he decided the amateur side should turn professional after attending the Women's World Cup in the United States last year. There matches drew crowds of almost 100,000, and alerted him to the possible popularity of the women's game.

"I realised the tremendous potential of women's football," he explained, as he surveyed his recruits at Fulham's ground, Craven Cottage. "It is my hope that Fulham FC can play a part in building opportunities for women to play professional football in this country and enhance its profile.

"I want the club, not just the men's but also the women's, to be the best in the country, and I will put in enough money so this will happen."

The Harrods owner has revolutionised the once ailing club, which has risen from the third to the first division since he bought it for £10m in 1997 and channelled £50m into it. But it is unlikely such payouts as the £2m for Chris Coleman to leave Blackburn Rovers, or the £1.1m for West Brom's Paul Peschisolido will find their way to the women.

"The sums just aren't comparable," admitted Gary Mulchaey, the women's manager. "After all, there isn't the incentive: women's teams won't turn professional in America until next year, and bar a semi-professional league in Italy, women aren't being paid in Europe."

Kelly Simmons, the Football Association's women's games coordinator, said the FA's intention of creating a professional women's league within three years was now a possibility.

"With the tremendous growth in interest in terms of people coming into the womens' game, that's a realistic target - and this has really helped. We hope other professional men's clubs will follow Fulham's example."

fields.headline: Lockerbie TV trial appeal fails
fields.standfirst:
The future of the BBC: special report
Lockerbie: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC has lost an appeal to televise the Dutch trial of the two Libyans accused of causing the Lockerbie tragedy.
fields.body:
The BBC has lost an appeal to televise the Dutch trial of the two Libyans accused of causing the Lockerbie tragedy.

Judges at the high court in Edinburgh rejected the corporation's argument that special CCTV footage of the court sessions, which will be transmitted in private viewings for relatives of the victims at remote sites in Britain and the US, meant the trial was effectively being televised anyway.

A spokesman for the BBC, which was backed by eight other broadcasters in its attempt, said yesterday it was disappointed but had been granted leave to appeal to the Privy Council on Tuesday.

"We are obviously very disappointed at the judgment," he said.

"We thought it was a unique case and we want to see that justice is seen to be done. We believe this was a way of doing that, but we have asked for leave to appeal."

A PanAm aeroplane exploded over the Scottish town in Lockerbie in December 1988, killing 270 people.

Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed Al Megrahi, 47, and Al Ali Kalifa Fhimah, 43, deny conspiracy, murder and a breach of the 1982 Aviation Security Act over the disaster.

The trial, which will be held under the auspices of Scottish law, is due to start at Camp Zeist in Holland on May 3.

webTitle: Prescott hits back on air traffic plans

fields.headline: Prescott hits back on air traffic plans
fields.standfirst: More about the privatisation of air traffic control
fields.trailText: John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, yesterday hit back at his critics in the Labour party who are threatening to block the government's plans to part-privatise Britain's air traffic control service (Nats) - and net the Treasury £600m.
fields.body:
John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, yesterday hit back at his critics in the Labour party who are threatening to block the government's plans to part-privatise Britain's air traffic control service (Nats) - and net the Treasury £600m.

In a letter sent to all Labour MPs as they headed for their 10-day Easter recess, the deputy prime minister and transport supremo rejected the critics' claims that air safety would be jeopardised by his proposals because they would inject private sector profit motives into Nats management.

Mr Prescott, who is fighting a series of policy battles across the wide front of his mega-ministry's policies, is convinced that he is right in his partnership strategy for Nats, re-building the London Underground and the Channel tunnel rail link.

To rub in his point, Mr Prescott published a list of British airports - and aircraft movements - run by Nats and other air traffic control systems run by private or municipal concerns without creating safety problems.

It showed that most passengers - 138.9m against 22.7m - went through Nats-run airports, the major players such as Heathrow. However, the majority of overall aircraft movements - 1.9m against 1.6m - went through non-Nats airports, from Alderney in the Channel Islands to Lerwick in the Shetlands.

"Nats already bids with commercial companies for commercial contracts which involve an element of profit. Presumably opponents of the Nats public-private partnership are not suggesting that British airports covered by commercial air traffic control services are less safe," Mr Prescott wrote to all 419 Labour MPs.

In his draft reply Mr Prescott used similar words, hoping to throw the committee's own harsh phrases back at them. Only when it was realised that the intended irony might misfire was the draft rewritten.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Eroica (Radio 4, 9.0pm) is the Friday night play. Beethoven's intimations of his deafness, the growing pressures of fame and his troubled relationship with his mistress, Josephine, are tempting subject matter for a playwright. Unfortunately, Ludwig has to convey being hard of hearing by saying "what?" a lot and thumping away at the pianoforte. Meanwhile, brother Casper chides Ludwig for wasting his time on composing, while Josephine's busybody mother, who can hardly get her son-in-law buried before planning a more brilliant match, is also fun.

fields.headline: Crucifixion images
fields.standfirst: Artist exhibits fruits of Good Friday ritual
fields.trailText: This morning the artist Maggi Hambling will go to her studio, chain-smoke her way through a few pages of the Bible and create an image of the crucifixion.
fields.body:
This morning the artist Maggi Hambling will go to her studio, chain-smoke her way through a few pages of the Bible and create an image of the crucifixion.

Each Good Friday for 14 years Hambling has followed this curious ritual, using accounts of the Passion culled from the gospels for inspiration.

Last year she used a power tool to file the head of Christ out of plywood, touching it up here and there with paint and gold leaf. The result looks like a kind of B&Q Turin shroud.

Hambling became fascinated by the death of Christ when she was a student. This Easter, art galleries are thick with scenes of Calvary. The National Gallery is staging a vast Seeing Salvation show, and Damien Hirst is showing a crucifixion scene of a type - his Christ is a skeleton with ping-pong ball eyes - at the new White Cube 2 in Hoxton, east London.

Eighteen of Hambling's images are on show at Gainsborough's House in Sudbury, Suffolk. They include the first in her series, Head of Christ 1986, her early Blue Christ, and what remains of two canvasses of Christ and the devil, painted using a model who looked remarkably like the comedian Frankie Howerd. Hambling destroyed both works, keeping only the devil's crotch and one of Christ's hands.

Hugh Belsey, curator of Gainsborough's House, said Hambling would not describe herself as a Christian but "she has beliefs which this work explores". She prefers to think of herself as a humanist who believes in something larger than humanity. The exhibition runs until May 21.

fields.headline: Crunch time
fields.standfirst: The screech of metal... the roar of chainsaws... Philippa Forrester in leather trousers.  Jim White  explains why men, women, children (and even spotty adolescents) can't get enough of Robot Wars
fields.trailText: Radio enthusiasts with long memories will recall that Friday night used to be known as music night. Not any more. Thanks to the hugely successful Robot Wars, the eve of the weekend has become something considerably darker. Now, for a regular audience of four million, Friday night is sadists' night.
fields.body:
Radio enthusiasts with long memories will recall that Friday night used to be known as music night. Not any more. Thanks to the hugely successful Robot Wars, the eve of the weekend has become something considerably darker. Now, for a regular audience of four million, Friday night is sadists' night.

And tonight for the grand final (6pm, BBC2) it is anticipated that double the regular number of devotees of destruction will hunker down in front of the television to enjoy the exquisite pleasure of seeing a few pieces of scrap iron powered by lawnmower engines torched to a frazzle, chain-sawed into oblivion and otherwise steaming, cranking and wheezing their way into the nearest skip. For true aficionados of robot warfare, it is a satisfaction substantially increased by the sight of the creators of the humiliated pieces of machinery being obliged to witness the destruction of their work, their faces a rictus of good-sportsmanship, wearing thin smiles which fail to disguise their pain at the monumental waste of time.

Oddly, research suggests that the demographics of the huge audience of BBC2's most-watched show take in virtually every strata of society. It is not just adolescent boys spending a rare few minutes away from their joysticks. Small children love it, grown men can't get enough, women watch in droves. Ah, the unspeakable joy of watching nerds suffer.

The brilliance of Robot Wars is that it has the feel of a show that has been waiting to happen for ever. In essence, it is gladiatorial combat to the death, using the only performers whose televised demise is deemed acceptable in these civilised times: machines. The idea, apparently, came when a television executive saw a robot battle at an American trade fair. In a text-book example of selling coals back to Newcastle, Mentorn, the producers of the show, are currently locked in lucrative negotiations to flog the format to the US networks. What with that, the 30,000-strong fan club, the website that receives four million hits a month and the cheery bonus of knocking Chris Evans' self-indulgent TFI Friday (screened at the same time on Channel 4) off the ratings barometer, this is clearly a programme doing something right.

As every fan will tell you, the reason for the show's success is that there is much more to it than simply watching robots crunching each other, or being mashed by the infinitely superior house robots called things like Sir Killalot or Dead Metal. Everything about it is a joy, everything charged with nuance. As the commentator, for instance, Jonathan Pearce's breathless hyperbole is perfect. The presenter Craig Charles, with his surly swagger and Red Dwarf cult background, brings a touch of malevolence to the role so much more satisfying than the superior sneer of the original host, Jeremy Clarkson.

And then there is Philippa Forrester.

I saw a pub comedian this week launch into a ten-minute routine of unrepeatable lasciviousness about Philippa Forrester. Which, since everyone in his audience seemed both to know who she was and to agree with his sentiments, must count as a measure of national prominence. Forrester's role in the programme is to act as pit reporter. She swishes through a side studio decorated to look like a garage, where she gently patronises the competitors as they conduct a final fiddle with their nuts. Importantly, to undertake this task she is kitted out in spray-on leather trousers and a spaghetti-strapped top. She is, very clearly, fragrant.

And this is the final, delicious cruelty of the programme. Forrester looks like a woman who has never in her life turned right on entering an aeroplane. Dirt has clearly never dared spend more than a nano-second under her fingernails. The chances of her ever entertaining the idea of actually dating one of the boffin grease monkeys with whom she flirts are about as high as Frank Dobson's are of becoming mayor. Yet many of them appear to think that game is very definitely on. How wrong they are.

This sadistic taunting technique was developed in another BBC2 robot spin-off recently, when Ulrika Jonsson was recruited to interview the nerds. The fun was watching how long, in close proximity to her contours, the beardy spods could maintain their air of academic concentration with their glasses steamed up. But while Ulrika struggled with the autocue, Forrester clearly knows what she is talking about. Which makes the competitors even more deliciously confused.

And if you don't believe me, join the gathering throng and watch her in action in tonight's grand final. It might be about machines, but the utter, gut-twisting frustration on display will be entirely human.

fields.headline: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: We're delighted to see the revivalist trend of 60s and 70s pop culture memorabilia continue. Forget Randall & Hopkirk and even Charlie's Angels. The latest bit of kitsch to be revived is Badjelly the Witch by Spike Milligan.
fields.body:
We're delighted to see the revivalist trend of 60s and 70s pop culture memorabilia continue. Forget Randall & Hopkirk and even Charlie's Angels. The latest bit of kitsch to be revived is Badjelly the Witch by Spike Milligan.

The story was first published in 1973 and originally written for Spike's own kids. And until now it's survived as so many battered copies of spine-broken books in the attics of all children of the 70s. But Ragdoll - those lovely people who make the Teletubbies and much else besides - are set to animate the tale, bringing to the screen the eponymous hag, the "nice" children Tim and Rose and a raft of unlikely other types. Remember Mud-wiggle the worm and Jim the Giant Eagle? Well you soon will.

Looking further back, there's a wealth of neglected children's nonsense which could be exploited - sorry, revived - for the 21st century. It seems only natural to suggest that, just as the entire oeuvre of Samuel Beckett is being filmed, the works of Edward Lear should come up for a TV makeover too. Now there's character. "Far and few, far and few, Are the lands where the Jumblies live; Their heads are green, and their hands are blue, And they went to sea in a sieve." Stop-frame animation, anyone?

Talking of makeovers, it seems that BBC2's makeover shows need a dose of their own medicine. BBC2 controller Jane Root has suggested that overhauling the tried and tested (some might say tired and tested) format of home improvement TV is the way to give this particular genre a lick of new paint.

So, Home Front is unlikely to reappear on BBC2 in future, while its spin-off Inside Out is more likely to stay, having achieved a more "documentary" feel to its tales of new lick and spittery.

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

fields.headline: Body specimens linked to Nazis
fields.trailText: Dissected parts of the bodies of executed prisoners of the Nazi regime have been kept since the war as anatomical specimens at the University of Vienna medical faculty, according to a report today in the Lancet medical journal.
fields.body:
Dissected parts of the bodies of executed prisoners of the Nazi regime have been kept since the war as anatomical specimens at the University of Vienna medical faculty, according to a report today in the Lancet medical journal.

The body parts may also have featured in the paintings that make up the famous anatomical atlas by the enthusiastic Nazi sympathiser Eduard Pernkopf, once rector of the university, the report says.

The report is written by Daniella Angetter, a member of the commission that began investigating the origins of the specimens in a number of Viennese institutions in 1997 after disquiet was expressed by American medical professors and Yad Vashem, the Holocaust Martyrs and Heroes Remembrance Authority.

The commission found that bodies had routinely been used for anatomical study since 1404. "Hence Nazi anatomical practices were easily 'legalised', and based on a decree of February 18, 1939, all bodies of executed prisoners were sent to the department of anatomy of the nearest university, for research and teaching purposes.

"These bodies were used in dissection courses for students, as well as for the preparation of specimens for lectures, anatomical collections and the illustrations for Pernkopf's anatomical atlas."

The incomplete records obtained by the commission show that 1,377 bodies of citizens executed in the Nazi period, including eight of Jewish origin, were passed to the anatomy department. Much of the faculty's anatomical collection was destroyed in the bombing, but several departments acknowledged having specimens that had been or might have been taken from Nazi victims. "The department of histology and embryology was found to have 98 specimens fixed in formaldehyde, which, according to their labelling, had definitely originated from people executed at the Vienna assize court," says the report.

The department of neurology had specimens given to it by Heinrich Gross, the former Nazi doctor charged with experimenting on brains of child patients and murdering at least nine of them. He was released last month as unfit to stand trial due to dementia.

Gross worked in Am Speigelgrund, the psychiatric hospital where children with mental and physical disabilities suffered "euthanasia" under the Nazis. The commission "discovered wartime connections between the department of anatomy at the University of Vienna and Am Spiegelgrund," says the article. The specimens Gross gave to the neurology department dated back to 1942-44 and were from children murdered at the hospital. They were handed to the judicial authorities.

Other remains found included bones and the skull of Wilheim Zehner, an Austrian general who was either murdered by the Gestapo or killed himself when they came to arrest him in April 1938.

All body parts will be buried in a grave of honour by the City of Vienna, the report says.

The commission could not substantiate the suspicion that some models for illustrations in Pernkopf's work, still widely consulted, were Jewish concentration camp victims.

fields.headline: Deaths mock Columbine memorial
fields.standfirst:
Pensioners gunned down as nervous US marks the first anniversary of its biggest school massacre

Gun violence in the US: special report
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of people in Colorado brought their communities to a sombre halt yesterday as they led the US in a national day of commemoration on the first anniversary of the Columbine school massacre.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of people in Colorado brought their communities to a sombre halt yesterday as they led the US in a national day of commemoration on the first anniversary of the Columbine school massacre.

The secondary school in the Denver suburb of Littleton, where two students shot and killed 12 schoolmates and a teacher and wounded 23 others before turning their guns on themselves, was closed for the day in memory of the massacre, the worst school shooting in US history.

Survivors, relatives and community leaders asked the media to stay away from the area during a series of private events to mark the anniversary. Several streets were closed by barricades, against which local people placed flowers, messages and teddy bears in memory of those who died in the massacre.

The governor of Colorado, Bill Owens, led a service of remembrance at the state capitol building in Denver, beginning with a state-wide minute of silence at 11.21am, the moment at which Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold began the attack, which still resonates through American society.

"I think Columbine will be with us for ever," he said earlier. As though to underline his point, the anniversary was littered with reminders that the Columbine killings and the national argument about gun violence which they have generated remain unresolved.

The parents of one Columbine victim, Daniel Rohrborough, marked the eve of the anniversary by bringing a case against Jefferson county police alleging that their son was killed by a shot fired by a police officer rather than the earlier bullet in the leg fired by Harris and Klebold. The police deny the accusation.

Several other US schools decided to close as a precaution after reported threats of violence to mark the anniversary. One was Hinkley high school in Aurora, 20 miles from Columbine. Schools in some parts of Wisconsin and another in New Hampshire shut their doors for the day after rumours of possible violence spread among students.

A high school in Alameda, California, decided to stay open after three students were arrested following the discovery of "hit-lists" naming 105 students who would be killed on April 20.

With schools throughout the US on alert, it fell to a retirement community in Peoria, Arizona, to become the scene of the latest random shooting spree, when a 61-year-old man burst into a meeting of residents, killing two elderly people and wounding three.

"He just came in, stood in the rear of the room and started firing," a witness said after Richard Glassel was arrested for opening fire on the residents with a rifle and handguns. Mr Glassel was reported to be angry about a decision to trim back the bushes around his home.

The previous day a retired man in Michigan opened fire on his neighbours, killing two, during a meeting which was called to attempt to resolve complaints about his use of bad language to fellow residents of his tower block.

While gun-related deaths in schools have fallen by 40% in the last two years, and general gun crime has fallen steadily for most of the last 10 years, the number of Americans shot dead remains exceptionally high by international standards. Columbine has probably done more than any other incident to prompt debate in the US and abroad about America's gun culture.

Both presidential candidates used the anniversary to speak about gun violence in schools. Vice-President Al Gore, who went to Columbine after the shooting, called for stricter gun control, while George W Bush urged parents and schools to concentrate on values, culture and character.

President Bill Clinton called on congress to mark the anniversary by passing a gun control bill. But no one in Washington, including Mr Clinton, expects one to be passed this year, not least because any radical measure would fall foul of the 2nd amendment, which guarantees the right to bear arms.

The pressure on congress is likely to increase during the build-up to the Million Mom March in Washington on May 14, when hundreds of thousands of people are expected to rally in support of "sensible" gun control.

Meanwhile the National Rifle Association is broadcasting a video which warns against "global forces working to destroy the right that makes American freedom the purest on the planet".

It says: "Third world dictatorships are plotting, through the United Nations, to eliminate your 2nd amendment."

The US is one of the few countries throught to have more guns than people.

Year of multiple murders shocked America

April 20, 1999: Two school students kill 12 fellow pupils and a teacher, and then themselves, at Columbine high school, in Littleton, near Denver, Colorado

May 20: A student shoots six schoolmates in a school in Conyers, Georgia, exactly a month after Columbine

July 13: Seven people shot dead in a domestic killing in Atlanta

August 10: A gunman goes on the rampage in a Jewish day-care centre in California, shooting dead a postal worker and wounding five adults and three children

September 15: A man kills seven and wounds seven others in a church in Fort Worth, Texas, before turning the gun on himself

November 2: Seven people killed in a Xerox Corporation office shooting in Honolulu

December 5: Five women shot dead in a Baltimore house

December 31: A hotel employee kills four co-workers and a motorist in a shooting spree in Tampa, Florida

March 22, 2000: A man shoots four in a Houston church before killing himself

April 18: Two people shot by fellow resident of tower block for the retired in Michigan

April 19: A man kills two and injures three at a retirement village near Peoria, Arizona
