Several streets were closed by barricades, against which local people placed flowers, messages and teddy bears in memory of those who died in the massacre. The governor of Colorado, Bill Owens, led a service of remembrance at the state capitol building in Denver, beginning with a state-wide minute of silence at 11.21am, the moment at which Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold began the attack, which still resonates through American society. "I think Columbine will be with us for ever," he said earlier. As though to underline his point, the anniversary was littered with reminders that the Columbine killings and the national argument about gun violence which they have generated remain unresolved. The parents of one Columbine victim, Daniel Rohrborough, marked the eve of the anniversary by bringing a case against Jefferson county police alleging that their son was killed by a shot fired by a police officer rather than the earlier bullet in the leg fired by Harris and Klebold. The police deny the accusation. Several other US schools decided to close as a precaution after reported threats of violence to mark the anniversary. One was Hinkley high school in Aurora, 20 miles from Columbine. Schools in some parts of Wisconsin and another in New Hampshire shut their doors for the day after rumours of possible violence spread among students. A high school in Alameda, California, decided to stay open after three students were arrested following the discovery of "hit-lists" naming 105 students who would be killed on April 20. With schools throughout the US on alert, it fell to a retirement community in Peoria, Arizona, to become the scene of the latest random shooting spree, when a 61-year-old man burst into a meeting of residents, killing two elderly people and wounding three. "He just came in, stood in the rear of the room and started firing," a witness said after Richard Glassel was arrested for opening fire on the residents with a rifle and handguns. Mr Glassel was reported to be angry about a decision to trim back the bushes around his home. The previous day a retired man in Michigan opened fire on his neighbours, killing two, during a meeting which was called to attempt to resolve complaints about his use of bad language to fellow residents of his tower block. While gun-related deaths in schools have fallen by 40% in the last two years, and general gun crime has fallen steadily for most of the last 10 years, the number of Americans shot dead remains exceptionally high by international standards. Columbine has probably done more than any other incident to prompt debate in the US and abroad about America's gun culture. Both presidential candidates used the anniversary to speak about gun violence in schools. Vice-President Al Gore, who went to Columbine after the shooting, called for stricter gun control, while George W Bush urged parents and schools to concentrate on values, culture and character. President Bill Clinton called on congress to mark the anniversary by passing a gun control bill. But no one in Washington, including Mr Clinton, expects one to be passed this year, not least because any radical measure would fall foul of the 2nd amendment, which guarantees the right to bear arms. The pressure on congress is likely to increase during the build-up to the Million Mom March in Washington on May 14, when hundreds of thousands of people are expected to rally in support of "sensible" gun control. Meanwhile the National Rifle Association is broadcasting a video which warns against "global forces working to destroy the right that makes American freedom the purest on the planet". It says: "Third world dictatorships are plotting, through the United Nations, to eliminate your 2nd amendment." The US is one of the few countries throught to have more guns than people. Year of multiple murders shocked America April 20, 1999: Two school students kill 12 fellow pupils and a teacher, and then themselves, at Columbine high school, in Littleton, near Denver, Colorado May 20: A student shoots six schoolmates in a school in Conyers, Georgia, exactly a month after Columbine July 13: Seven people shot dead in a domestic killing in Atlanta August 10: A gunman goes on the rampage in a Jewish day-care centre in California, shooting dead a postal worker and wounding five adults and three children September 15: A man kills seven and wounds seven others in a church in Fort Worth, Texas, before turning the gun on himself November 2: Seven people killed in a Xerox Corporation office shooting in Honolulu December 5: Five women shot dead in a Baltimore house December 31: A hotel employee kills four co-workers and a motorist in a shooting spree in Tampa, Florida March 22, 2000: A man shoots four in a Houston church before killing himself April 18: Two people shot by fellow resident of tower block for the retired in Michigan April 19: A man kills two and injures three at a retirement village near Peoria, Arizona

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Second arrest in arson case
fields.body:
Second arrest in arson case

A woman, 38, was arrested yesterday over the deaths of a couple in Normanton, West Yorkshire 12 days ago.

Jane Pemberton, 23, and James Murphy, 28, died of smoke inhalation after petrol was poured through their letterbox. Police also arrested a 36-year-old man on Wednesday.

Message in a bottle returns

A message in a bottle thrown into the sea in south Devon has turned up on the tiny island of Sentosa in Singapore.

Sam Mote, 11, of Newton Abbot, threw a cola bottle into the sea last August and the message was sent back to him by a holidaymaker.

Woman faces 'ecstasy' trial

A woman was charged yesterday after a baby swallowed what is thought to be an ecstasy tablet.

The 21-year-old woman from Edinburgh was arrested after the one-year-old was taken ill earlier this month.

Flood warnings for the south

Flood warnings were issued across the south of England yesterday.

A month's rain fell in just over two weeks in Hampshire and the Isle of Wight. Further downpours were forecast for the weekend.

'Lord of the Manor' for sale

A collection of ancient titles, giving their bearers the right to be known as Lord of the Manor, is being sold at auction.

Thirteen Welsh titles from Glamorgan, Anglesey, Monmouth and Bangor are expected to fetch between £5,000 and £25,000 each.

webTitle: Ministers to act on drug pricescam

fields.headline: Ministers to act on drug pricescam
fields.standfirst:
'Manipulation, hoarding and collusion' costs NHS £200m
The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The government plans to impose a ceiling on the price it will pay for the most commonly prescribed NHS medicines, to close down a scam that has cost the health service £200m, it said yesterday.
fields.body:
The government plans to impose a ceiling on the price it will pay for the most commonly prescribed NHS medicines, to close down a scam that has cost the health service £200m, it said yesterday.

The prices of generic drugs - commonly used medicines that have become cheap because they are out of patent - have soared by 45% over 15 months, causing havoc with the budgets of GPs who are urged by government to prescribe generics rather than branded medicines wherever possible.

Manufacturers and suppliers have claimed that shortages and new packaging costs have pushed up prices, but the House of Commons health select committee in December blamed the problems on "manipulation, hoarding and collusion".

Speculators within the industry were stockpiling drugs and holding them back to create an artificial shortage, said the report. Drugs in short supply are placed on what is known as category D, which forces the Department of Health to pay the price the drug company demands. In January 1999, there were about 30 drugs in category D. The number rose to 190 by last November but has now dropped back to 53.

Yesterday the junior health minister Lord Hunt announced a government crackdown to end what has been called a speculator's charter. The present system "appears to have offered opportunities for speculation and the hoarding of certain drugs," he said, although he was unable to give examples of malpractice. An inquiry into loopholes in the system, announced on the day of the select committee report, and an Office of Fair Trading investigation are still continuing.

The department yesterday for the first time listed the price the NHS would pay for each of the contentious drugs. Thyroxine, for example, for thyroid disorders has gone up from 21p to £1.62 for a pack of 28. The NHS will now pay no more than 27p. Bendrofluazide tablets for lowering blood pressure went up from 15p to over £1, but will now be pegged at 15p. Other drugs affected include warfarin, codeine, diazepam, hydrocortisone, pethidine and tamoxifen.

The minister told the House of Commons that category D itself would be abolished, after discussions with the generics industry.

The government's tough line will lead to speculation that it might be prepared to take on the rest of the drugs industry. Prices for expensive modern drugs - the branded medicines still in patent - are much higher and are regulated by a voluntary agreement called the pharmaceutical price regulation scheme (PPRS). This agreement, negotiated every five years, stipulates the total amount the NHS will reimburse each company for its drugs. Most western countries agree a price per drug, and some think the UK system is dated and due for an overhaul.

"The notion of price-fixing has not been part of the UK system before and maybe this heralds a change in the government strategy if the present PPRS scheme is withdrawn," said Joe Collier, the professor of medicines policy at St George's School of Medicine in south London and adviser to the select committee's generics inquiry.

The British Medical Association said the government move was very good news. "Last year GPs were faced with soaring increases in the cost of generic drugs. We don't want to be in that position again," said George Rae, chairman of the BMA's GP prescribing sub-committee.

webTitle: MPs plan to ease baby problems at Commons

fields.headline: MPs plan to ease baby problems at Commons
fields.trailText: Parents who work in or visit Parliament may gain new facilities for changing or breast feeding their babies under proposals to be put forward by a team of women MPs.
fields.body:
Parents who work in or visit Parliament may gain new facilities for changing or breast feeding their babies under proposals to be put forward by a team of women MPs.

A seven-strong committee, led by equal opportunities minister Margaret Hodge together with women's minister Tessa Jowell and public health minister Yvette Cooper, will also consider the question of maternity leave for MPs.

The issue of family facilities was raised again earlier this month when the Speaker, Betty Boothroyd, ruled that breastfeeding was barred in most parts of the palace of Westminster. The Labour MP for Swindon, Julia Drown, had sought permission to feed her son Harvey during Commons committee sittings, but was told that - under rules forbidding the consumption of refreshment in committees or the Commons public gallery - breastfeeding was banned in both areas.

Members of the public have to use lavatories in the Commons to feed or change babies, while MPs have been allowd use of the family room, which some say is inappropriate.

webTitle: Portillo ally warns of election danger

fields.headline: Portillo ally warns of election danger
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo's closest ally yesterday launched a scathing attack on William Hague, labelling him as a weak leader who had failed to inspire confidence among Tory MPs and party workers.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo's closest ally yesterday launched a scathing attack on William Hague, labelling him as a weak leader who had failed to inspire confidence among Tory MPs and party workers.

The former minister Eric Forth made clear that he had given up any hope of winning the general election when he warned that polling day was now "perilously close".

Mr Forth, a key member of the Portillo inner circle, accused Mr Hague of failing to help the party recover from the "very traumatic" last election. "We have lost all our self-confidence and are constantly looking over our shoulders at our own shadow," he told BBC2's Despatch Box programme. "We are getting perilously close to an election and we have not got that political self-confidence to go for firm positions that we can relate to and that people can relate to."

Mr Forth even criticised the Tory leader's performance in the Commons, one area where he is generally believed to have performed well. Mr Forth said Mr Hague "had a bad day" on Wednesday when his attack on government running costs was undermined by the prime minister pointing out that the Tories had benefited from a threefold increase in public funding.

Mr Forth insisted that Mr Portillo wanted to remain a loyal member of the shadow cabinet. But asked whether the shadow chancellor might consider a leadership bid after the election, he replied: "Whatever." His attack on Mr Hague was brushed off by the Tory leadership. One source said: "This is not the first time that a backbencher has apparently criticised the leadership. William is consistently setting out firm positions on a variety of issues."

fields.headline: The muddle ground of politics
fields.standfirst:
Whatever the Tory leader's message is, it is hard to decipher

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Whatever the Tory leader's message is, it is hard to decipher
fields.body:
I have been trying to buy an anthology of William Hague's speeches as part of my Easter reading. The receptionist at Conservative Central Office seemed unsure whether such a publication existed. When I phoned a bookshop, the woman at the other end of the line laughed as I made my request. My fleeting inquiries were no joke. I was genuinely keen to obtain a compilation of his big speeches. They would tell a revealing story, even if William Hague - In His Own Words would never quite make the bestsellers' list, nor grip a Good Friday traveller at an overcrowded airport.

The story would convey one of the more startling u-turns in recent political history. The William Hague who made his speech this week on locking up asylum seekers, is a million miles from the one who embarked on his tortuous journey as Conservative leader in 1997. Some have commented on his early visit to the Notting Hill carnival, his first attempt to suggest that the narrow-minded Conservative party (which had nearly been wiped out in the election) was about to become a broader church. But it is in his first party conference speech as leader in October 1997 when he became more explicit. The Conservative party, he declared would be an inclusive, socially tolerant party. The word "inclusive" was repeated several times.

At around this period, there were other symbolic gestures towards this more inclusive style. The single currency was ruled out "for the foreseeable future", a formula which kept even Ken Clarke contented. Hague's early policy reversals all suggested a move to the centre ground. The party, for example, became more pluralist.

At the same time, and he deserved more credit for this, he modernised his party. It was, he said in another of his early speeches, time to "move on". And how. Neil Kinnock, who spent nine arduous years trying to persuade Labour to move on, must have viewed the spectacle with particular envy. At the click of his fingers, Hague democratised his party. Those ageing Conservative activists have a big say in policy nowadays and, of course for the first time ever, will cast their votes to elect their next leader.

Opposition parties cannot be judged by the practical implementation of their policies. Policies are therefore adopted for their symbolic value. In his early phase, Hague's actions symbolised a move towards a modern centrist party. Fast forward to his speech this week on asylum seekers. It goes without saying that the speech smacked of political desperation. Inclusiveness has been replaced by a crude exclusiveness that embraces the party's language on every issue from Europe to race. How and why has such a dramatic change come about? The first sign that Hague was moving rightwards came shortly after that 1997 conference speech when he greatly hardened his stance on the single currency.

Unfortunately Hague's early efforts at political re-positioning did not seem to work. That is the real factor behind the change. Political leaders need a quick fix these days. Patience among supporters is in short supply. For reasons I have never fully understood, Hague was mocked for visiting Notting Hill. The baseball cap, which also symbolised a youthful inclusiveness, became a joke. For Hague it was soon time to "move on" from his original attempts to "move on".

His "British way" came next, but went away again almost immediately as nobody knew what it meant. Before long we had the full-blooded "commonsense revolution" with its "tax guarantee". I suspect Hague feels more comfortable with these rightwing symbols than he did with his early attempts at inclusiveness. The give-away is the tax guarantee, launched with a flourish in his Blackpool speech last October.

Hague was in the Treasury when Norman Lamont was forced to increase taxes. He was at the Department of Social Security when he watched Peter Lilley struggle to contain the welfare budget. He is better placed than any politician in parliament to know that a cut in the tax burden cannot be guaranteed under any circumstance. In other words he knows he will not have to implement such a guarantee. Instead it may, just, expose the chancellor's use of stealth taxes and appeal to enough voters to ensure that Hague has another stint as leader of the opposition.

But the final twist to Hague - In His Own Words is more subtle than that. Recent speeches show that while it proclaims the Thatcherite commonsense revolution the party also supports high public spending on the NHS, education, the Home Office and defence. Soon I predict it will back big increases in government spending on transport. The party of deregulation has also become a supporter of the minimum wage.

That is the final twist in the story - there is no story, but a blurred muddle. If publishers invite Hague to compile an anthology of his speeches, he would be wise to politely decline.

 Steve Richards is political editor of the New Statesman

fields.headline: Iran's supreme leader attacks press
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: Iran's supreme leader yesterday blamed an escalating national crisis upon US attempts to penetrate the Islamic republic and Iranian journalists whom he accused of trying to undermine the state.
fields.body:
Iran's supreme leader yesterday blamed an escalating national crisis upon US attempts to penetrate the Islamic republic and Iranian journalists whom he accused of trying to undermine the state.

In his second hardline speech in under a week, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei attacked a recent gesture by Washington to end Iran's isolation. And he accused Iranian journalists in the booming reformist press of aiding the enemy.

"There is a double threat that consists of direct penetration by America as well as the new wave of globalisation," the leader told thousands of young Iranians, some of whom were bussed to a Tehran prayer hall to hear him speak.

On Monday the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, delivered the clearest statement to date on the US desire to end 20 years of hostility with Iran. The overture, welcomed in reformist circles, was criticised by hardliners.

Though conservatives favour reconciliation for the economic gain it would bring, they want to deprive the moderate president, Mohammed Khatami, of any credit for a rapprochement which would be popular among Iranians. On the domestic front, conservatives in the courts have cracked down on reformist journalists. A veteran of Iran's progressive press, Mashallah Shamsolvaezin, who has run four newspapers, was imprisoned last week for "insulting Islamic values". He was given a 30-month sentence.

Another prominent journalist, Akbar Ganji, who wrote attacks against the conservative establishment, was declared an apostate last week by a hardline cleric.

Adding to the instability, the guardian council, a body of conservative clerics and jurists, have been chipping away at the reformers' victory in February's parliamentary election by annulling reformist gains in about 10 constituencies. Protests and violent outbursts against the council have erupted in some towns where poll results were nullified.

Under pressure from growing criticism, conservative clerics and hardline extremists have formed an unspoken alliance to combat the reformist onslaught.

The elite revolutionary guards this week issued a warning that they would not remain passive while the Islamic system was threatened.

webTitle: Taiwan, China and the US: that infernal triangle

fields.headline: Taiwan, China and the US: that infernal triangle
fields.standfirst:
Changes in Taipei's government may force a break with the past

Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: Changes in Taipei's government may force a break with the past
fields.body:
Yang Chin-hsin photographed the Taiwan countryside while working for American agricultural advisors in the 50s. His pictures, recently displayed at the History Museum in Taipei, reveal Taiwan before the era of transistors, let alone micro-chips. They show a landscape of remote villages, where travelling dentists pulled teeth in the streets, and adults and children alike sat entranced before storytellers. This was a country hardly touched as yet by the mainlanders who had taken it over a few years before, most of whom were still down in Taipei, itself not much more than a provincial Japanese town.

It may seem a vanished world in today's factory-dotted Taiwan. But the children in those pictures are still only middle aged, and their attitudes have moulded the ideas of the next generation, now young adults. To these people, particularly those in the more rural south of the island who voted for him in landslide proportions, the election of Chen Shui-bian as president this spring represents a victory and an affirmation. Taiwan had already had a native Taiwanese president in Lee Teng-hui, Chen's predecessor, but Lee was with the Kuomintang (KMT), the mainland party which had dominated the island politically since Chiang Kai-shek took Taiwan over in 1945. Chen Shui-bian, on the other hand, is a Taiwanese leading the mainly Taiwanese Democratic Progressive party, heir to dissident movements that had resisted the KMT monopoly of power at a time when that could lead to prison or worse. The party's objective of independence has been judiciously diluted, but no one doubts that the DPP's guiding principle remains "Taiwan first". When Chen is inaugurated next month, the Taiwanese, colonial subjects of the Japanese and then, under the KMT, denied full political rights until democracy began to take hold a decade or so ago, will finally come into their own.

Beijing got exactly the result it did not want in this contest, and may have contributed to it by the threats made during the campaign. Since the election China has been relatively restrained, except in its splenetic fury over the suggestion by Annette Lu, Taiwan's new vice-president, that the People's Republic and Taiwan are only "distant relations". As for Chen Shui-bian, Beijing has said that it will watch what he does and listen to what he says, but that there can be no negotiations on such matters as a direct commercial relationship or direct transport links unless he accepts the principle of one China.

This Chen will not do and thus there is an impasse which, in theory, could last as long as he is in power. At present Taiwan's trade and investment links with China have to dog-leg through Hong Kong, at considerable profit to the former British territory, and it looks as though that will continue. The ludicrous situation in which Taiwan, whose businessmen own perhaps 40,000 factories in China, cannot officially deal with Beijing, will continue.

There has been the usual speculation about the chances of military action. But Chairman Mao's rule - "Never fight a battle unless you are sure you can win it" - is imprinted in the minds of the Chinese leadership. Whatever they say, or hint, they know that China does not now have the capacity to stage a successful invasion of Taiwan and that an attempt which ended in failure would be a political as well as military disaster of global proportions. The curve of China's growing might will eventually take it to the point - perhaps 10 years from now - where it does have that capacity. As that crossover gets closer the pressure on Taiwan to accept China's view that the island is a wayward province that must return to the fold, will certainly increase. Yet it will still be diffuse, for even a successful invasion of Taiwan could do terrible damage to China's relations with the rest of the world.

On the surface, the military moves and counter moves of Beijing, Washington and Taipei concern the real possibility of conflict. But the recurrent dramas arising from Taiwan's efforts to procure advanced weapons from the United States are just as much to do with China's efforts to show Taiwan that it is increasingly isolated, and that the United States can be intimidated. The American decision this week, to sell Taiwan a few of the weapons systems it has requested while withholding others, is typical of this nuanced game, which has been going on for years now. The nature of American politics in the last phase of Clinton's presidency, however, mean that this minor victory for Beijing could have unhappy consequences for the Chinese. Anger in Congress over Taiwan being allegedly left in the lurch could just conceivably lead to the defeat of the China trade bill in the House of Representatives, or even to passage in the Senate of a bill already approved by the House which mandates closer US military cooperation with Taiwan.

But what probably matters more than any outside development is that, as a result of the election, the island's political system is in flux. Chen's victory was the result of a falling-out between a leader and his heir apparent worthy of a Shakespeare play, one which cost them the throne. No one knows quite why President Lee Teng-hui fell out with James Soong, who at one time looked certain to be his successor. But their differences led to Lee endorsing another politician, the uncharismatic Lien Chan, as the KMT candidate to follow him in office, and to Soong standing as an independent. Without that split, the KMT would still hold the presidency, which explains why furious KMT supporters called for, and got, Lee's resignation as chairman of the party after the election. Chen will thus govern in a society where the majority did not vote for him. He also faces a legislature in which his party is outnumbered. A difficult exercise in cohabitation lies ahead.

The DPP has no experience of government and Chen has had to pick a KMT man to lead his cabinet. But that suggests both that the party will not pursue in office as vigorous an attack on corruption as it promised during the campaign, and that it wants to send a soft signal to Beijing. If so, that will not please some party supporters. Nor will trimming to the needs of big business, because the DPP has a particular following among workers and unionists. Chen himself has uneasy relations with some of the party's founding figures, who regard him as a man come late to the struggle. If the DPP is in for a rough ride, the same is true of the KMT, saddled with a leader who came third but shows no sign of stepping down, and facing the task of proving to the populace that, in spite of its huge commercial holdings and its vast network of patronage, it is ready to part company with the corrupt ways of the past.

Then there is the enigma represented by James Soong's new People First party. Will it become a permanent fixture, or wither away? Democracy is entering a volatile period in Taiwan, with uncertain consequences at home and abroad.

fields.headline: Top Chinese faces execution
fields.trailText: Beijing stepped up its campaign against corruption yesterday by expelling a senior communist leader, who may become the highest ranking cadre ever to be shot for embezzlement.
fields.body:
Beijing stepped up its campaign against corruption yesterday by expelling a senior communist leader, who may become the highest ranking cadre ever to be shot for embezzlement.

A terse report from the Xinhua news agency said Cheng Kejie, 66, had been stripped of his position as a vice-chairman of the national people's congress standing committee and expelled from the party, "because of corruption charges".

Mr Cheng is believed to have taken 40m yuan (about £3m) in bribes and siphoned state funds into a company owned by his mistress, Li Ping.

Hong Kong newspapers said he sold quotas for chemical fertiliser, edible oil and other products in short supply to Li's company, and ordered the railways ministry to consign it 32 hectares (80 acres) of land for building a car park.

At least 500,000 yuan in bribes were allegedly payment for promoting subordinates.

Mr Cheng is reported to have been under house arrest since last summer, and a blind eye is often turned to such cases of corruption in China. So yesterday's sudden decision to conclude the investigation and publicly expel him is seen as being intended to intensify the anti-corruption crusade which President Jiang Zemin has repeatedly called a "matter of life and death" for the Communist party.

When Hu-Changqing, a former vice-governor of Guangxi province, was shot for embezzlement last month, the prime minister, Zhu Rongji, proudly declared that only in China could so many corrupt officials be executed.

But corruption investigations continue to be hampered by politics, and senior officials often escape execution.

webTitle: Dinosaur heart a shock to evolution

fields.headline: Dinosaur heart a shock to evolution
fields.trailText: For the first time, scientists have unearthed a fossilised dinosaur complete with its heart - a discovery that could help overturn a centuries-old image of a cold-blooded, reptilian Jurassic Park.
fields.body:
For the first time, scientists have unearthed a fossilised dinosaur complete with its heart - a discovery that could help overturn a centuries-old image of a cold-blooded, reptilian Jurassic Park.

Scans of rock occupying the thescelosaurus's chest cavity show a heart adapted to pumping warm, oxygen-rich blood. The discovery, announced today in the US journal Science, reopens the debate about the dinosaur's place in evolution.

"Not only does this specimen have a heart, but computer-enhanced images of its chest strongly suggest it is a four-chambered, double-pump heart with a single systemic aorta, more like the heart of a mammal or a bird than a reptile," said Dale Russell, of North Carolina State University. "This challenges some of our most fundamental theories of how dinosaurs evolved."

The thescelosaurus was 13ft from nose to tail with a body the size of a pony. Its 66-million-year-old fossil was found in 1993 in South Dakota by a collector, Michael Hammer. Part of the extremities and the left-hand side had been eroded away by rainfall; in another six months, the rest might have been washed away.

Bones may fossilise, but the soft tissue of a carcass is hardly ever preserved - the bones are picked clean by scavengers, or the flesh decays. But Mr Hammer decided that the stone enclosed within the ribs could be important and, most unusually, did not chip the bones free. He took the sandstone block to Dale Russell at the North Carolina museum of natural sciences.

Mr Hammer, Dr Russell and others then asked Paul Fisher, director of the university's veterinary school, to look at computerised tomography scans of the block. They found, a little distorted over 66m years, a"ferruginous concretion" the size of a grapefruit in the sandstone. That was the first clue: iron suggested blood and haemoglobin. Using software to turn two-dimensional images into a 3D shape, they identified a heart with two ventricles, and two atria that may have collapsed when the creature died.

fields.headline: A song of sixpence
fields.standfirst: Why are we so timid about the monarchy?The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Scotland and Wales are granted a measure of independence; hereditary peers are being removed from the Lords; London is about to elect an executive mayor, a pattern other great cities will follow. Even when we allow for promises not so far kept, like a referendum on the electoral system, this is a record of radical change in the constitution which few governments can have bettered. But one great bastion remains, in theory at least, unassailable. The monarchy is as safe in Tony Blair's hands as it always was in those of his predecessors.
fields.body:
Scotland and Wales are granted a measure of independence; hereditary peers are being removed from the Lords; London is about to elect an executive mayor, a pattern other great cities will follow. Even when we allow for promises not so far kept, like a referendum on the electoral system, this is a record of radical change in the constitution which few governments can have bettered. But one great bastion remains, in theory at least, unassailable. The monarchy is as safe in Tony Blair's hands as it always was in those of his predecessors.

Or so we thought. But there now emerges from the Public Record Office a batch of documents which tell a different tale. It begins in 1965, just a year after Labour returned to power under Harold Wilson. The Queen, it appears, has, like her counterpart in the nursery rhyme, been busy in her counting house counting out her money, and she fears - or at least her advisers fear - it is not enough. The arrangements made when she succeeded her father 13 years earlier have left her scrimping. More generous treatment is called for, the palace believes, through the traditional system where the government proposes, a select committee reports, and legislation is framed, to keep the coffers replenished.

But even kindly prime minister Wilson is troubled by that. The economy is askew. The public have been asked to tighten their belts, then forced to do so by a prices and incomes policy. Devaluation having done for Chancellor Callaghan, the public finances have come into the hands of the dangerous radical, Austerity Jenkins. He cannot see now why the Queen should not turn to the royal bankers to help. The result is a document written by one of two permanent secretaries at the Treasury, Sir William Armstrong, which bluntly suggests that the key to putting the royal income in order is not the series of index-linked handouts which the palace has set its heart on. Sir William examines a radically different option: a slimmed-down monarchy, Scandinavian style, with Buckingham Palace becoming a state-financed royal HQ while the family lives more modestly, at its own expense, down the road. There is also the delicate question of other royal revenues, outside the usual equation: the whopping sums available from the revenues of the duchies of Cornwall and Lancaster. Indeed, the entire Lancaster revenues might be surrendered and merged with the Crown Estate.

All these thoughts, needless to say, are kept safely under the carpet. Wilson procrastinates until he reaches the point where he can decently propose to the leaders of other parties that select committee hearings should take place after the coming election (not before, when if word got out, the nation might rise in horror at such an assault on its queen). What we have here is what we usually get when such matters are being discussed: a search for some kind of reform paddling about underneath, but nothing but smooth timidity on the surface. More than 30 years on, we know more than we did about royal money, and the palace has made concessions on the civil list, and various events, especially the death of Diana, have dragged the monarchy further into the open. Yet the Armstrong formula looks radical even now. There still seems to be an acceptance at the top of all parties that these matters are somehow indecent in terms of public debate. How good it would be to hear a government which prides itself on its radical approach to the constitution declaring that the future of the monarchy is now a legitimate subject for public consideration.

Do not bank on it, though.

webTitle: Nurse sues over threats by killer anaesthetist

fields.headline: Nurse sues over threats by killer anaesthetist
fields.trailText: The hospital that employed the consultant Thomas Shanks, given a life sentence for murder, is being sued by a nurse who claims he threatened her with violence.
fields.body:
The hospital that employed the consultant Thomas Shanks, given a life sentence for murder, is being sued by a nurse who claims he threatened her with violence.

Erica Bujanski, 39, who works in intensive care at Pontefract general hospital, West Yorkshire, claims that the doctor, a former SAS man, "went berserk" at her shortly before he used an AK-47 automatic rifle to kill another nurse.

Shanks, 49, an anaesthetist, was convicted on Wednesday at Sheffield crown court of murdering his former partner Vicky Fletcher, 21, in a frenzy of jealousy after she had left him for another man.

Ms Bujanski is claiming damages for stress and ill health which led to 18 months off work after Shanks allegedly screamed abuse and threat ened her when she intervened in a row between him and another doctor while she treated a seriously ill patient.

She said yesterday: "I was absolutely terrified because he kept coming after me. His neck veins were pumping and I thought he was going to hit me.

"He had absolutely lost control. Then another doctor grabbed him and pulled him away."

Ms Bujanski said that Shanks had persecuted her continually after the incident, which happened nine months before he turned a looted Iraqi Kalashnikov, smuggled home from the Gulf war, on Ms Fletcher, last May.

David Collins, nursing director at the Pinderfields and Pontefract hospitals NHS trust, said that the trust could not comment on Ms Bujanski's claim for legal reasons.

fields.headline: 63% unaware of big phone switch
fields.trailText: Most people are unaware of the shake-up in phone numbers which is taking place tomorrow, according to telephone companies.
fields.body:
Most people are unaware of the shake-up in phone numbers which is taking place tomorrow, according to telephone companies.

Figures released by the Big Number - a consortium of Britain's 40 phone companies overseeing the move - show that despite a £20m advertising campaign, 63% of the people affected will not know their correct number.

While most subscribers were aware that their area code would change, few realised that one or more digits would have to be added to the rest of their number.

Other research by Number Master, a technology group, showed that, although having out up with three number alterations in 10 years, 70% of London businesses were unaware when the latest changes take effect.

David Hands, a spokesman for the Federation of Small Businesses, said: "Five years ago when there was a similar change, Oftel [the telephone industry watchdog] told us businesses would not have to change their numbers again during their lifetime.

"I think a lot of people have been confused by the new change, and the message has not been communicated well enough."

The overhaul will create 400m numbers, and is needed because of an explosion in communications equipment such as mobile phones, pagers and the internet.

Dialling codes and telephone numbers will be updated for six British regions: London, Portsmouth, Southampton, Coventry, Cardiff and Northern Ireland - a total of 11.5m lines.

Millions more people will need to reprogramme mobile phone memories; businesses will have to spend an estimated £2bn on reprinting stationery and other materials.

Local calls, which do not require an area code, will change at 1am tomorrow when callers using an old number will hear a recorded message advising them of the change.

However, old and new national numbers, which require an area code, will run in tandem until August 5 when a similar recorded message will be used.

Oftel plans to overhaul mobile and pager telephone numbers on April 28, 2001.

Ringing the changes

The regions below will have area codes altered and extra digits placed at the front of existing numbers.

Northern Ireland numbers will be totally restructured and the public is advised to call freephone 0808 2242000 for details of changes.

Inner London

From (0171) to (020) 7

Outer London

From (0181) to (020) 8

Portsmouth

From (01705) to (023) 92

Southampton

From (01703) to (023) 80

Coventry

From (01203) to (024) 76

Cardiff

From (01222) to (029) 20

Dialling codes and telephone numbers will be updated for six British regions: London, Portsmouth, Southampton, Coventry, Cardiff and Northern Ireland - a total of 11.5m lines. Millions more people will need to reprogramme mobile phone memories; businesses will have to spend an estimated £2bn on reprinting stationery and other materials. webTitle: Police given names in Dando case

fields.headline: Police given names in Dando case
fields.standfirst: More on the Jill Dando case
fields.trailText: Police hunting the killer of Jill Dando have received more than 300 calls, some 36 of which they described as "very interesting", following a fresh appeal for information.
fields.body:
Police hunting the killer of Jill Dando have received more than 300 calls, some 36 of which they described as "very interesting", following a fresh appeal for information.

Detective Chief Inspector Hamish Campbell, who has led the murder hunt that is costing the police £40,000 a week, had personally appealed for information on loners and people who might have been obsessed with guns or with Ms Dando, as well as people who could have been in Fulham, west London, on the day of the television presenter's murder. "People are ringing in with that sort of information - very precise," Mr Campbell said. "A lot of names - two names have been mentioned twice - and that is the sort of information we need. [There are] some new individuals' names linking directly to Jill Dando in previous relationships, and that is what we are looking for."

The appeal by Ms Dando's former colleagues and police on the BBC Crimewatch programme came almost a year after she was shot dead at point-blank range outside her home.

The Crimewatch presenter Nick Ross said 183 calls had been made to the BBC studio, with 36 calls being prioritised as "very interesting indeed". At least another 100 calls were received by the incident room in Kensington, west London. Mr Ross added that many people had called in with theories on why Ms Dando was murdered. However, he said, the police had been investigating for nearly a year and needed facts, not theories.

The programme focused on a man who had been seen loitering near Ms Dando's home on the day of her murder, and on two previous Mondays and a Wednesday.

fields.headline: Gregynog passion play
fields.trailText: Christ will be crucified this afternoon beside the dying daffodils and budding rhododendrons in the grounds of a Victorian manor house in the empty centre of Wales.
fields.body:
Christ will be crucified this afternoon beside the dying daffodils and budding rhododendrons in the grounds of a Victorian manor house in the empty centre of Wales.

Having ridden across a manicured lawn on a donkey called April, been greeted by waving crowds and betrayed by Judas, Jesus will be scourged and led to a low hill by an ancient wood where two pot-bellied thieves wait to share his agony.

Roman soldiers will haul him up on to the cross with the aid of a rope and brute strength. This should prove to be the highlight of the drama for the audiences who will gather this Easter for four performances of the passion play at Gregynog, six miles from Newtown, Powys.

For the cast, this is a dangerous moment. Christ, played by James Burke Dunsmore (the only professional in a company of more than 80), has to put his trust in his colleagues. "You have to be careful about safety, and at the same time make it look like torment," he said.

At the dress rehearsal things did not go well, partly because the Roman army was short of men because a couple of legionaries were sheltering somewhere from the bitter wind.

But it was not as cold as at the first production in 1998, when after 90 minutes the director called off the show, fearing that Jesus would get hypothermia.

Ruth Davies, the producer said: "Participation has nothing to do with what they believe or don't believe. The passion story inspires love in everyone, and that is what makes the group. We are trying to live the story rather than talk academically about it."

Director Peter Richards added: "The show binds them together, and for me it's very rare to deal with 80 actors who don't have a trace of ego between them."

Penry Thomas, 72, who plays Third Pharisee and Joseph of Aramathea, said: "I was very doubtful at first. But I've found this awe-inspiring.

"When I saw those crosses for the first time I could have cried. And after the trial scene, I had to tell Caiphas he was so good I could have hit him."

fields.headline: The power struggle
fields.standfirst:
Whites say the issue is the plight of white farmers at the hands of a black mob. They would, wouldn't they?

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Whites say the issue is the plight of white farmers at the hands of a black mob. They would, wouldn't they?
fields.body:
One of the more pernicious effects of white supremacy is its ability to filter all experience through the apex of its own ego, to the detriment of everything else around it - including, ultimately, itself. Thus history is skewed, priorities misplaced and perspective polluted. So the story of the civil rights movement in America became a battle between integration (what white Southerners feared) and segregation (which they sought to preserve), rather than a battle to democratise and modernise the most powerful nation in the world.

The story of slavery and colonialism is similarly relegated to, at best, an unfortunate episode from less enlightened times, and at worst a civilising force, rather than the theft of land and labour that impoverished an entire continent and enriched a few individuals. And so the recent events in Zimbabwe are depicted as the plight of white farmers at the hands of black mobs, rather than the cynical attempt to undermine democracy by an embattled president desperate to retain power.

The situation here is highly emotive. Two white women have been raped; two white men have been killed. No decent human being can condone this. The use of violence, terror and misogyny as a political tool is abhorrent and cannot be excused, mitigated or explained away by any reasonable person who professes to believe in democracy or humanism. No Zimbabwean should have their national credentials questioned or undermined as a result of their race or ethnicity. If it was wrong for Norman Tebbit to do it in Britain then it is wrong for Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe to do it here.

Now for some context. White Zimbabweans comprise less than half a percent of the total population. The fact that they are small in number does not, in itself, mean that their condition should not be the focus of attention - you can often tell a great deal from a country by the way in which it treats minorities. But there have been six murders of black Zimbabweans in the last two weeks of political violence, one of a pregnant woman, and one alleged rape. Although they account for three quarters of the deaths so far they have not received even a scintilla of the media attention.

Focusing on the plight of white farmers and their families, events in Zimbabwe are a white supremacist's dream. Proof, in one simple narrative, that black people are unable to govern themselves, that white women are at the prey of black men and that Africa is full of basket cases who bring their destitution on themselves. Only then do the graphic accounts of rape, pictures of white women clutching her children as black men toyi-toyi (protest dance) a few yards away on the other side of her fence and references to "uncivilised mobs" slot into place.

Yet if you take all of these deaths - black and white - into account you can begin to understand the motivation for this apparently senseless violence. Only then does it become clear that these murders are not random, but logical; not racial, but political.

Zimbabwe is one month away from elections for which a date has not yet been set. For the past 20 years the country has been ruled by one party (Zanu-PF) - and one president: Mugabe. Now the opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), is gaining ground while Zanu-PF and Mugabe are haemorrhaging credibility. They are not, as some have suggested, devoid of political legitimacy. If there were an election tomorrow Zanu-PF would still be the largest party. But they would no longer, effectively, be the only party. That prospect has worried them sufficiently to attack their opponents.

The killings that have taken place have been, essentially, political. All of the murders bar one were committed against members of the MDC (the other was a black policeman whom Zanu-PF supporters thought was a member of MDC because he had a new bike). Mugabe has whipped up tensions and created a climate of intimidation that could allow him to either postpone the elections, cancel them, or hold them under a state of emergency which would effectively strip them of any pretence of being free or fair.

Moreover, what was once a fundamentally sound economy is now in tatters. Inflation, interest rates and unemployment are all high. The price of two litres of milk has risen by 136% in the past year. Queues of up to three hours for petrol are not unheard of. Mugabe and his government have nobody to blame for this but themselves. And since they are not likely to do that in a hurry they have drawn on an age-old British tradition - they look for someone to scapegoat and then play the race card.

But, unlike the victimisation of asylum seekers in Britain at present, this is not a straight fight between the powerful and the powerless. White Zimbabweans may be a tiny minority but they own the vast majority of good land. And they did not come by it honestly. They acquired it in much the same way as the war veterans have sought to regain it - under a bloody campaign of organised, armed theft. Two wrongs may not make a right; but it is not feasible to right a wrong in the present while ignoring wrongdoing in the past.

So while it is possible to sympathise with the individual suffering of white farmers, it is difficult to take their collective spasm of moral indignation at the current state of affairs seriously. Almost all Zimbabweans, including many whites, believe that for the country to progress there has to be substantial land reform. The MDC say after the economy it is the second most important issue in the forthcoming election. The question is not whether, but how the government goes about it.

The farmers' complaints about the demise of democracy are also hard to stomach. These are the people - not all but most - who fought tooth and nail to maintain white minority rule and only surrendered at gunpoint. Mugabe could do with a good lecture on democracy and the rule of law. But he can be forgiven for not taking it from white farmers. It was they who imprisoned him when he was fighting for precisely that. Their conversion to democracy is a relatively recent one. Most support the MDC not because it directly represents their interests but because, according the old dictum, at times of crisis the enemy of my enemy is my friend.

Similarly it is difficult to fathom with what authority the international community makes its high-minded pronouncements. If Mugabe is a wicked tyrant now then he was no less so a few months ago when the British government tried to defend supplying him with arms to fight the unpopular war in the Congo. Objections to Mugabe's terror is well-founded; but given the scant interest world leaders have shown for human rights violations in Chechnya it is neither consistent nor principled.

What is taking place in Zimbabwe is not so much a campaign against whites as a struggle for democracy and human rights. Thanks to Mugabe the issue has been refracted over an unseemly scramble for land in which no one can rightfully claim the moral high ground.

 gary.younge@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Keep them down
fields.standfirst: Higher interest rates must harm industryThe issue explained: Setting Britain's interest rates
fields.trailText: A fresh increase in interest rates looks likely after the news of a 6.1% rise in average earnings in the year to February. This is way above the 4.5% that the Bank of England regards as consistent with its inflation target of 2.5%. Worse, it comes when the IMF and the independent National Institute believe the Budget's loosening of fiscal policy will raise City expectations that rates must rise. Even so, the Bank should think carefully before raising rates further. The earnings figures - compiled on a quarterly basis - still contain two months of inflated city bonuses and end-of-year overtime working. Given that higher rates induce an even more overvalued pound - thereby intensifying the unacceptable squeeze on industry - the Bank should wait to see whether earnings will come off the boil.
fields.body:
A fresh increase in interest rates looks likely after the news of a 6.1% rise in average earnings in the year to February. This is way above the 4.5% that the Bank of England regards as consistent with its inflation target of 2.5%. Worse, it comes when the IMF and the independent National Institute believe the Budget's loosening of fiscal policy will raise City expectations that rates must rise. Even so, the Bank should think carefully before raising rates further. The earnings figures - compiled on a quarterly basis - still contain two months of inflated city bonuses and end-of-year overtime working. Given that higher rates induce an even more overvalued pound - thereby intensifying the unacceptable squeeze on industry - the Bank should wait to see whether earnings will come off the boil.

The Bank should also remind itself that its statutory duty is not to keep earnings down, but to keep the underlying rate of inflation at 2.5%. At the moment underlying inflation is only 2%. Technical factors may push it up next month - but there could also be downward pressures if oil prices fall. The chancellor would have made the Bank's job easier if he had tightened fiscal policy more than he did. But, given that practically everyone applauds the extra health spending, that would have meant higher taxes when the Treasury was wallowing in a £15bn surplus, even before counting the £19bn windfall profits from the auction of radio spectrum.

Gordon Brown is planning to use that money to reduce the national debt. But there is another use for it: selling sterling to bring down the value of the pound. Intervention to prevent a currency falling is usually a mug's job. But intervening to prevent it rising could be not only successful but profitable. The more Mr Brown spends "upstream" on intervention, the less he will have to spend "downstream" on bailing out Rover, farming, the coal industry and all the other victims of the overvalued pound.

fields.headline: Bunker mentality in the classroom
fields.trailText: What hope is there for consistency and order in the classroom when disruptive pupils are allowed to return without so much as a punishment (Teachers plan to sue over disruptive pupils, April 20)? With most heads now taking their 30 pieces of silver to push the problems back into the classroom from the safety of their administrative bunkers, and on to the fragile shoulders of an increasingly isolated and disparaged workforce, there is little hope.
fields.body:
What hope is there for consistency and order in the classroom when disruptive pupils are allowed to return without so much as a punishment (Teachers plan to sue over disruptive pupils, April 20)? With most heads now taking their 30 pieces of silver to push the problems back into the classroom from the safety of their administrative bunkers, and on to the fragile shoulders of an increasingly isolated and disparaged workforce, there is little hope.

I despair for the vast majority of children who have come to school keen and eager to learn, only to find the promise of a bright future blighted by a minority, whose presence in the classroom is only there to to cosmeticise the statistics and make less work for the police. The futures of so many children are being blighted for political expediency, unless they have parents who have followed the Blairs in using religious schools to secure a better education for their offspring. Would that children could sue for educational opportunities lost, there would be a tidal wave of litigation.
Andrew Waruszynski
Milton Keynes
waruszynski.fsnet.co.uk

 When asked about the teacher who had committed suicide following an Ofsted inspection, education minister Estelle Morris said two astonishing things. First, that inspections were important and we should not go back to the days "when nobody knew what was going on in schools". The notion that the inspectors and education officers did not know what was going on in the schools is outrageous. They knew the schools and the teachers very well. They knew their strengths and weaknesses; intervened when necessary and - how different from now - provided not only inspection but support. They identified the needs of schools and individual teachers and set up programmes of staff development to address them.

Second, that we are all accountable and life today was full of stress and we had to learn to live with it. It is nothing new for teachers to be under pressure. It can be quite productive in producing an adrenaline flow, as long as the teacher is in control and can manage. Stress occurs when extraneous forces impinge on the teacher in ways over which the teacher has no control.
Bob Gough
Walton-on-Thames, Surrey

fields.headline: Mugabe's first victims
fields.trailText: It is with much anger that I read the reports on Zimbabwe in the British press (Crisis in Zimbabwe, April 20).The west is only discovering now that Robert Mugabe is a delusional megalomaniac, yet people from the Matabeleland region of Zimbabwe have known this for the past 18 or so years.
fields.body:
It is with much anger that I read the reports on Zimbabwe in the British press (Crisis in Zimbabwe, April 20).The west is only discovering now that Robert Mugabe is a delusional megalomaniac, yet people from the Matabeleland region of Zimbabwe have known this for the past 18 or so years.

When Zimbabwe gained independence in 1980, I was only six years old and did not understand what the excitement was all about. I do remember a year or so later when troops from Mugabe's 6th brigade broke into our property, beat my father and left him for dead. His only crime was that he was Ndebele.

The press seems intent on highlighting the deaths of two white farmers. What about the tens of thousands of Ndebele people killed by this man? He certainly is turning this matter into a race issue and you seem to be playing the game right along with him. Mugabe does not like opposition of any kind, whether it is from black people or white people. The white farmers are not the only people who are bearing the brunt of Mugabe's iron fist; anyone opposing his rule is. The land issue in Zimbabwe can be likened to the asylum issue in England, it is an emotive one.

Before any election, Mugabe and his sycophants go to the countryside, preaching to the rural people that it is the fault of the white farmers that they are unable to put food on the table. The so called "war veterans" we see on the television, in any case, are too young to have fought in any war, let alone the war of independence. It does not take a rocket scientist to figure out that these are young men who have been hoodwinked by Zanu PF to cause anarchy in a country that once prided itself on being one of the most peaceful in Africa. And it is not only the white farmers who have been branded enemies of the state: I seem to recall Mugabe once using the same phrase in reference to my people, the Ndebeles.

When Zimbabwe gained independence in 1980, I was only six years old and did not understand what the excitement was all about. I do remember a year or so later when troops from Mugabe's 6th brigade broke into our property, beat my father and left him for dead. His only crime was that he was Ndebele. The press seems intent on highlighting the deaths of two white farmers. What about the tens of thousands of Ndebele people killed by this man? He certainly is turning this matter into a race issue and you seem to be playing the game right along with him. Mugabe does not like opposition of any kind, whether it is from black people or white people. The white farmers are not the only people who are bearing the brunt of Mugabe's iron fist; anyone opposing his rule is. The land issue in Zimbabwe can be likened to the asylum issue in England, it is an emotive one. Before any election, Mugabe and his sycophants go to the countryside, preaching to the rural people that it is the fault of the white farmers that they are unable to put food on the table. The so called "war veterans" we see on the television, in any case, are too young to have fought in any war, let alone the war of independence. It does not take a rocket scientist to figure out that these are young men who have been hoodwinked by Zanu PF to cause anarchy in a country that once prided itself on being one of the most peaceful in Africa. And it is not only the white farmers who have been branded enemies of the state: I seem to recall Mugabe once using the same phrase in reference to my people, the Ndebeles. Name and address supplied

fields.headline: Flights of fancy
fields.trailText:
You allege that the RAF is opposed to the government's plans for a partial privatisation of the National Air Traffic Control System (Prescott fails to quell air traffic rebellion, April 20); this is not the case. The RAF has been closely involved in developing the concept of a public-private partnership for the NATS, so that we can ensure the successful joint and integrated working arrangements between military controllers and NATS will continue.
Air Commodore DA Walker
Ministry of Defence

 Catriona Graham (Letters, April 20) scorns women MPs who want to breastfeed in the Commons on the grounds that airline pilots and surgeons don't breastfeed on the job. But pilots and surgeons would have a legal right to six months maternity leave. Women MPs have none.
Harriet Harman MP

 Perhaps the reason the M4 bus lane is empty (Letters, April 20) is because the buses have actually managed to arrive at their destinations.
Dr Eleanor Scott
Portsmouth
Eleanor.Scott@btinternet.com

 Leeds United chairman Peter Ridsdale placed whole-page adverts in daily newspapers requesting calm prior to his team's match against Galatasaray. He does not appear to have placed one in the Guardian. Does he believe it would have been money wasted, since he considers Guardian readers to be calm, rational and beyond reproach? Or does he think that readers are complete hooligans who would not heed his exhortations to behave?
Toby Wood
Peterborough
TobyWood@compuserve.com

Warwick

fields.headline: Ya Ya rah rah
fields.trailText:
What a nasty little story (Write Stuff, Orange shortlist place for book panned by critics, April 19). Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood by Rebecca Wells has received nothing but praise since publication here and in the US and now, quite rightly, it has the accolade of being shortlisted for the Orange Prize. This cheap and hurtful story must have been calculated to ruin the author's delight at some good news.
Jeremy Trevathan
Macmillan Publisher

fields.trailText: Tree Naked, a Gilbert and George panel painting, should have been dated 1991 in a story on Britart, page 13, April 14. Through a slip the two artists were mentioned as having recently been lured away from the Lisson Gallery, rather than from the Anthony D'Offay Gallery.

Tree Naked, a Gilbert and George panel painting, should have been dated 1991 in a story on Britart, page 13, April 14. Through a slip the two artists were mentioned as having recently been lured away from the Lisson Gallery, rather than from the Anthony D'Offay Gallery.

An article on the late Yehudi Menuhin's link with a Guildford school, page 2, Guardian Education, April 18, slightly misspelled the local area. It should have referred to Stoughton Grange junior school. Quoting a BBC documentary due to be aired tomorrow, the piece incorrectly said that Stoughton was "the roughest area of Guildford".

One of Isambard Brunel's 19th-century ships, the Great Eastern, mentioned in a piece about Bristol, Page 9, Travel, April 18, was built not in that city's docks but at a yard on London's Isle of Dogs.

A story headlined Clubbers gassed in Lisbon attack, page 12, April 17, referred to an earlier attack on a club in the northern Portuguese town of Amarante, near Oporto. But that incident occurred three years ago, not 13, and there were about 30 people in the Mea Culpa club at the time, not hundreds. The victims were lined up against a wall, not in the middle of the room, while petrol was poured on the dance floor.

fields.headline: Refugees from the system
fields.trailText:
Mark Leonard has a go at the Conservatives for ignoring Britain's tradition of offering sanctuary to the persecuted, such as the Huguenots (Comment, April 18). Had he read William Hague's speech, he would have found a specific mention of the Huguenots. Genuine refugees are suffering under the asylum regime. I have come across cases in my constituency of people who have experienced terrible traumas and find themselves elbowed aside by those who have been rehearsed in how to exploit the system. Mr Leonard has every right to disagree with us, but please attack us on the basis of what we're actually saying.
Daniel Hannan MEP

 I arrived here in 1959 from Mozambique, where, as a Portuguese settler, I had been imprisoned for rebelling against Salazar's colonial regime. I became a journalist, being now the oldest-serving outside contributor of the BBC Portuguese service for Africa. In contrast with fellow exiles working for Radio Moscow, the Voice of America, Radio Prague, Deutsche Welle and other similar international services, I enjoyed a remarkable freedom of movement and expression. If you compare Britain with most countries, it stands out as one of the best. For the sake of civilisation, keep it that way.
Antonio de Figueirado
London

 David Leigh (Thank You, England, April 19) omits the acceptance by our fathers and grandfathers of the widespread corruption of immigration functionaries. Thank goodness we can trust them today not to make covert financial demands in return for granting entry to refugees!
Elkan Allan
London

fields.headline: Wrong spin
fields.trailText: Graham Norman (Letters, April 15) is wrong that only a right-arm bowler can deliver a googly. The Chinaman (really the left-armer's leg break) is only the equivalent of the googly in that it turns "in" to the right-handed batsman. The true googly, whether bowled by a right or left-arm bowler, is a wrist spinner delivered out of the back of the hand so that it turns "the wrong way", hopefully, deceiving the batsman.
fields.body:
Graham Norman (Letters, April 15) is wrong that only a right-arm bowler can deliver a googly. The Chinaman (really the left-armer's leg break) is only the equivalent of the googly in that it turns "in" to the right-handed batsman. The true googly, whether bowled by a right or left-arm bowler, is a wrist spinner delivered out of the back of the hand so that it turns "the wrong way", hopefully, deceiving the batsman.

The ball turning away is more difficult for a batsman; thus some right-arm bowlers choose the more difficult and inaccurate wrist spin and use the even more difficult and inaccurate googly as a surprise ball. The left-armer's natural, accurate finger spin comes as a leg break to the right-handed batsman and there is little reason for him to resort to wrist spin. George Kitchin
Penrith, Cumbria

fields.headline: David Spanier
fields.standfirst: Diplomatic journalist with a passion for poker
fields.trailText: David Spanier, who has died of a stroke aged 67, combined a distinguished career as a foreign and diplomatic correspondent for the Times - and later for Independent Radio News - with a passion for gambling in general, and poker in particular. Few things gave him more pleasure than the column he wrote about poker for the Independent, and playing the game was even better than writing about it.
fields.body:
David Spanier, who has died of a stroke aged 67, combined a distinguished career as a foreign and diplomatic correspondent for the Times - and later for Independent Radio News - with a passion for gambling in general, and poker in particular. Few things gave him more pleasure than the column he wrote about poker for the Independent, and playing the game was even better than writing about it.

Spanier hid an exceedingly sharp mind behind horn-rimmed spectacles and a jaunty, self-deprecating and friendly manner. His first book, Europe Our Europe, was an account of the negotiations for Britain's entry into the European Common Market, and he had just finished a memoir, The Hand I Played, when he died - appropriately enough at the casino where he was gambling. In between, he wrote six books about games and gambling.

The son of a stockjobber, Spanier grew up among a prosperous liberal Jewish family in Hampstead, north London. He was educated at Charterhouse and, after national service in the army, which he loathed, went up to Trinity College, Cambridge, where he studied under FR Leavis and played a little unserious cricket.

His poker, on the other hand, was, from the start, deadly serious. He joked about how in one game he came close to losing his allowance for the whole term; at the time, it can hardly have been very funny.

Spanier always wanted to go into journalism. While still at Cambridge, he acquired some work experience with the Yorkshire Post, and it was there that he started work after completing his degree. In 1957, he moved to the Times, where he was to remain for the next 25 years, fielding, in a debonair manner, teasing from more earnest colleagues about his nocturnal gambling exploits. In the brown linoleum drabness of the home newsroom, he was an elegant figure, sometimes with a flower in his buttonhole.

After four years, he transferred to the foreign department as commonwealth correspondent, and he remained an international expert, except for a brief interval as assistant city editor. Some friends believe he was disappointed not to become deputy city editor, with the possibility of preferment to the top job - but if that was so, he kept his feelings to himself. He was, in general, a tolerant and self-possessed man, whose favourite way of making a point was with dry wit.

Spanier worked as the Europe economics specialist, then in Brussels and in Washington, and the Association of European Journalists voted him European Journalist of the Year in 1971. In Brussels, he was famous for having once asked a question at a press conference in Flemish (not a language he knew well). He described himself as a good European, but his worldly-wise intelligence and his preference for reporting, as opposed to advocacy, kept him a sceptical one. In 1974, when he became the Times diplomatic correspondent, he surprised the Foreign Office by refusing the individual briefing that had been the newspaper's prerogative since time immemorial.

Unlike many of his colleagues, Spanier did not leave immediately after the Murdoch takeover of the Times. But, in early 1982, he took a job as diplomatic correspondent of LBC radio and Independent Radio News. Later, he focused more on writing about the things that amused him - above all, games and gambling. In Total Poker (1977), he had explored the similarities between poker and diplomacy; in 1987, in Easy Money, he delved into the psychology of the gambler.

Spanier became chess correspondent of the short-lived newspaper Today, and then of the Daily Telegraph. In 1998, his poker columns from the Independent were collected as The Little Book Of Poker. To the end of his life, he gambled heavily, regularly - and, on the whole, successfully. He had a gaming room installed in his home, where he sometimes played poker all night with fellow devotees, among them Anthony Holden and Al Alvarez.

It was at the Times that Spanier met the distinguished fashion journalist Suzy Menkes, and they married in 1969. Their marriage was exceptionally loving and strong, and David did a great deal to make Suzy's career flourish. They had three sons, Gideon, Joshua and Samson, as well as a daughter, Jessica, who died in infancy. David's choice of the names reflected his deep pride in being Jewish, though he was not especially religious.

He is survived by his wife and sons.

fields.headline: Carmen Dillon
fields.standfirst: Oscar-winning art director setting the scene for great British films
fields.trailText: The art director Carmen Dillon, who has died aged 91, was fortunate to have gained her experience in the 1940s and early 1950s, when most films were shot in a studio and when British cinema made some attempt to equal Hollywood in spectacle. In 1948, in recognition of her design of Laurence Olivier's Hamlet, she became the first woman ever to win an Oscar for set decoration, an award that had been called "interior decoration" until the previous year.
fields.body:
The art director Carmen Dillon, who has died aged 91, was fortunate to have gained her experience in the 1940s and early 1950s, when most films were shot in a studio and when British cinema made some attempt to equal Hollywood in spectacle. In 1948, in recognition of her design of Laurence Olivier's Hamlet, she became the first woman ever to win an Oscar for set decoration, an award that had been called "interior decoration" until the previous year.

Dillon was also one of the very few woman art directors and designers around until the 1960s, when more and more entered the field. Like many of the best art directors, her work often determined the mood and atmosphere of a film, as well as the visual quality. Although Roger Furse was credited with the art direction on Hamlet, it was mainly Dillon who realised the predominantly sombre sets - the sinuous, maze-like corridors and misty-edged brutal battlements of Elsinore. She always felt that her architectural background was a prerequisite of her success.

Carmen Dillon was born in Cricklewood, north-west London, the youngest of six children. One of her sisters, Una, founded the Dillon's bookshops. She had a strict Catholic upbringing, but her parents - her father was a businessman, her mother a teacher - encouraged her in her desire to become an architect.

Her interest in the cinema was aroused when she met several art directors, including Vincent Korda and Alfred Junge, while studying in London at the Architectural Association. She liked, what she called, "the arty side" of films. She began in the industry working on "rotten little old films, but very exciting and great fun to do - with as little as £100 spent on sets." She remembered that she was requested not to wear slacks on the set, and once overheard someone say, "That bloody Carmen Dillon is keeping a man out of a job."

One of her first big jobs was as assistant to Ralph Brinton on The Mikado (1938), the first film made at Pinewood in Technicolor. But when Brinton was called-up during the Munich crisis, Dillon took over a great deal of the art direction, until Paul Sheriff replaced him.

She then worked as assistant art director on a number of Anthony Asquith films, including French Without Tears (1939) and Quiet Wedding (1940), eventually becoming the art director on Asquith's The Demi-Paradise (1943), a wartime propaganda film for which she created the "typical" English village into which Soviet engineer Laurence Olivier could be warmly welcomed.

A year later, she and Paul Sheriff were experimenting with flattened perspectives, painted backdrops derived from medieval paintings, and stylised landscapes for Olivier's Henry V, effectively contrasting them with location shooting. Dillon worked with Olivier again on Hamlet, Richard III (1955) and The Prince And The Showgirl (1957). Further films under Asquith's direction were The Browning Version (1951) and The Importance Of Being Earnest (1952), for which Dillon created an elegant and witty Edwardian style.

As the quality of British films deteriorated in the mid-1950s, and more and more movies were shot on location, the challenges for an art director like Carmen Dillon, whose preference was for period pieces and studio design, were diminished. "Above all, I wanted to create an illusion of reality," she once remarked.

She designed a few Doctor films, and a couple of the Carry On series, as well as a number of other run-of-the-mill British comedies, until rescued artistically by Joseph Losey, who employed her on Accident (1967) and The Go-Between (1971). In these two keen analyses of the British class structure, Dillon's simplicity of style has been credited with having toned down Losey's baroque excesses.

She continued to work throughout the 1970s, notably on Lady Caroline Lamb (1972), The Omen (1976) and Julia (1977), for which she was now called production designer. She also designed the sets for several stage plays, including Anyone For Denis? at the Whitehall theatre, London. But film remained her true love. "I think I'm not a good stage designer," she once commented. "When I have designed for stage, it has been rather carefully realistic."

Carmen Dillon, who never married - believing that her work was a "wholetime" job - lived for many years with her two unmarried sisters in a large Edwardian flat off Kensington high street, west London. She spent the last decade of her life in a nursing home, having outlived her siblings.
