She designed a few Doctor films, and a couple of the Carry On series, as well as a number of other run-of-the-mill British comedies, until rescued artistically by Joseph Losey, who employed her on Accident (1967) and The Go-Between (1971). In these two keen analyses of the British class structure, Dillon's simplicity of style has been credited with having toned down Losey's baroque excesses. She continued to work throughout the 1970s, notably on Lady Caroline Lamb (1972), The Omen (1976) and Julia (1977), for which she was now called production designer. She also designed the sets for several stage plays, including Anyone For Denis? at the Whitehall theatre, London. But film remained her true love. "I think I'm not a good stage designer," she once commented. "When I have designed for stage, it has been rather carefully realistic." Carmen Dillon, who never married - believing that her work was a "wholetime" job - lived for many years with her two unmarried sisters in a large Edwardian flat off Kensington high street, west London. She spent the last decade of her life in a nursing home, having outlived her siblings.  Carmen Dillon, art director, born October 25 1908; died April 12 2000

webTitle: Brazil's landless to spoil big day

fields.headline: Brazil's landless to spoil big day
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of Brazil's rural workers will be hoping to obstruct the country's 500th anniversary celebrations tomorrow to culminate a week in which they stepped up an aggressive programme of land invasions.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of Brazil's rural workers will be hoping to obstruct the country's 500th anniversary celebrations tomorrow to culminate a week in which they stepped up an aggressive programme of land invasions.

More than 100 private farms have been invaded since Monday by peasant families who are protesting against the unfair distribution of land in Latin America's largest country, the Landless Movement of Rural Workers (MST) said.

The MST had planned to invade 500 properties by the week's end, saying that the number symbolically represents five centuries of rural exploitation. "We are doing this as a counterpoint to the official celebrations," said a spokesman, Nilton Viana. "We want to show that Brazil is not just the beautiful country portrayed by the elite, but has serious social problems."

Brazil's long-planned commemoration of the day in 1500 when the Portuguese navigator Pedro Alvares Cabral first spotted the Brazilian coastline is threatening to turn into a public relations disaster, as it has focussed the protests of the country's down-trodden minorities, who say that there is little to celebrate.

This week's invasions were largely by the 74,000 families who were living under plastic sheeting in roadside camps, Mr Viana said.

Brazil's president, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, is taking extra precautions to ensure that the expected 40,000-strong protest, consisting mainly of landless Brazilians, does not end in pitched battles with the police. "The 500th birthday party is not an invitation to a wake," he said.

The president's fears are not unfounded. Four years ago police killed 19 landless protesters in a case which attracted widespread international condemnation.

In the 16 years since its formation, the MST has successfully gained land for 250,000 families by squatting on land and refusing to leave until title is granted.

While the ministry for agrarian development puts the number of invasions at a third of the MST's claims, both sides agree that Brazil's land distribution - one of the most unfair in the world - is in need of reform. The richest 20% of the people hold 90% of the land, while the poorest 40% own 1%.

"We need to intensify our actions to speed up the pace of reform," said Mr Viana. As well as the farm occupations, members of the MST this week invaded regional head offices of the government's land reform institutes and took employees hostage.

fields.headline: Tourists die in S Africa
fields.trailText: Two Danish tourists on a golfing holiday were shot dead near Sun City, one of South Africa's major tourism destinations, police said yesterday.
fields.body:
Two Danish tourists on a golfing holiday were shot dead near Sun City, one of South Africa's major tourism destinations, police said yesterday.

The two men, aged 33 and 37, had stopped their car on the road between Sun City and nearby Pilanesberg game park, a police spokesman said. The victims' names were not released.

The shots were fired from a light delivery van and both men died instantly, the spokesman said.

Police had no suspects or firm motive for the attack. They said that nothing appeared to be stolen. About 20,000 people are murdered in South Africa each year.

webTitle: Rebel allies escalate civil war in Sudan

fields.headline: Rebel allies escalate civil war in Sudan
fields.standfirst: Islamist regime faces fresh insurrection as guerrilla groups join forces for offensive
fields.trailText: The ground at Makit is torn up by the treads of two T-54 tanks. There was a pitched battle here a few hours ago, but soldiers are nowhere in sight now. Government troops penetrated guerrilla-held positions for several hours, but left when the rebels attacked their unprotected rear. It was the kind of cat-and-mouse encounter that typifies Sudan's fast-spreading revolt.
fields.body:
The ground at Makit is torn up by the treads of two T-54 tanks. There was a pitched battle here a few hours ago, but soldiers are nowhere in sight now. Government troops penetrated guerrilla-held positions for several hours, but left when the rebels attacked their unprotected rear. It was the kind of cat-and-mouse encounter that typifies Sudan's fast-spreading revolt.

At the same time as the fighting here, opposition forces captured the town of Hameshkoreb, 60 miles to the north-west, in a stunning show of force that seemed to catch Khartoum off-guard.

Sudan's barren north-eastern corner, bounded on one side by Eritrea and on the other by the Red Sea, is the newest battlefront in the country's civil war, which was once confined to the south.

Because of this area's strategic importance - threatening the country's vital road and rail links to the coast, its new oil pipeline and other key economic installations - the outcome of this protracted war may eventually be decided here.

Heavy fighting

Both sides are gearing up for heavy fighting during the coming months, while they manoeuvre for political leverage in competing peace initiatives.

The government's goal is to push the rebels across the border into Eritrea and then seal the frontier. Opposition forces are hoping to carve out an enclave from which to launch attacks throughout the north. A tour of their mountain bases suggests that they will be hard to dislodge.

The rebels are building a network of camouflaged supply depots, training facilities and military camps in a warren of volcanic hills where the government's superior armour and aircraft are ineffective. They also have mobile units of their own, using captured military vehicles and converted pick-up trucks.

This is changing a regional contest between north and south into a national revolt that could threaten the Islamist regime that seized power here in 1989.

Intermittent civil war has wracked Sudan almost from the moment it gained its independence from Britain and Egypt in 1956. Much of its southern third is now under the control of the Sudan People's Liberation Movement (SPLM), which also holds pockets of territory in central and eastern Sudan, in the Nuba mountains and the Inghessina hills.

But in the north-east, the SPLM is one of seven opposition armies. The others run the political gamut: from the traditional Islamic sect-based movements shouldered aside by the ruling National Islamic Front to the Communist party and a new group led by disaffected military officers, the Sudan Alliance Forces.

Until recently, these disparate forces managed little more than sporadic ambushes and small surprise attacks, often fleeing east into Eritrea when pursued. Today, they are fighting for the first time under a single command. Their increased effectiveness is readily apparent.

This was accomplished after two events which, at first, appeared to be setbacks. Last year, as a result of Eritrea's border war with Ethiopia, relations between Asmara and Khartoum thawed. As a result, the National Democratic Alliance - a coalition of Sudanese opposition groups - were ordered to close their bases in Eritrea and move into Sudan.

This led rebel leaders to agree to combine their forces in one division under a unified command structure. The SPLM augmented these forces by redeploying almost 8,000 soldiers from the south to what they call the "eastern front".

Also, in March the largest northern group in the NDA coalition, the Umma party of the ousted former prime minister Sadiq al-Mahdi, left the coalition, saying that they would challenge the Islamist government of General Omar al-Bashir from within.

Many here view the defection as a blessing after years of internal wrangling that paralysed the NDA. A spurt of armed actions have doubled the size of "liberated" territory in the last six weeks alone.

Now, what started as a conflict between the Arabised, Islamic north and the non-Muslim African south is becoming a fight between a fundamentalist Islamic movement at the centre and a diverse alliance challenging it from the periphery.

Famine toll

Up to 2m people have died from war- and famine-related causes since the fighting resumed in 1983 after a decade-long truce. What is at stake is the country's identity: whether it is to be strictly Arab-Islamic or loosely multi-ethnic and secular - and whether it can exist as one or the other within a single national boundary.

The potential for the fighting to spill over into a wider regional conflict has triggered a flurry of diplomatic activity. Two initiatives - one promoted by Libya and Egypt, the other by members of the East Africa-based Intergovernmental Authority for Development - are on the table. Neither one has reached the stage of serious negotiations.

The SPLM leader, John Garang, is calling for the consolidation of the two initiatives. So far, the government has declined to do so, preferring to deal with the opposition parties one at a time.

Under these circumstances, it is likely that fighting will intensify in one of the worst drought-affected areas of Sudan. Many civilians are trekking to refugee camps in Eritrea, which are taking the place of the opposition military bases dismantled just months ago.

Dan Connell is the author of Against All Odds: A Chronicle of the Eritrean Revolution (Red Sea Press, 1997). He is currently working on The Road to New Sudan (Red Sea Press, 2001).

Five decades of conflict

1956 Sudan gains independence under an Arab-dominated, northern regime; north-south civil war breaks out

1972 War ends under an agreement brokered by Ethiopia that grants cultural freedom and political autonomy to southern Sudan

1983 Autonomy is rescinded and Islamic law is imposed throughout the country; army units in the south mutiny, form the Sudan People's Liberation Movement (SPLM)

1989 On the eve of a new peace agreement, the army seizes power on behalf of the National Islamic Front, which escalates the war and the campaign to push Islamic and Arabic influence onto the Christian and animist African south

1995 The SPLM joins northern opposition groups in the National Democratic Alliance (NDA), calling for separation of religion and the state and self-determination for the south; the war spreads northward

1999 The former prime minister Sadiq al-Mahdi breaks with the opposition to resume dialogue with the regime; the NDA forms a unified command for its seven remaining armies and escalates the war in the north-east; competing peace initiatives promoted by East African states and by Libya and Egypt fail to halt the fighting

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Richard Adams
fields.trailText: Richard Adams
fields.body:
 More bad tidings for News International. Not only does owner Rupert Murdoch have cancer (and I'm sure Diary readers will join me in wishing the old devil well), but morale seems to have plummeted, with staff complaining of a lack of leadership, clarity, direction and so on. According to a memo leaked to the Diary, from the managing director of News Networks (Mr Murdoch's internet business arm), staff were told: "We have not been successful in evangelising the company's vision of the future, inspiring you, telling it like it is or providing direction when it's crazy around here." Crazy, indeed. "Additionally, we are not seen as being part of the industry's network of influential leaders or 'walking the talk'." (the phrase "walking the talk" comes of course from the popular expression: "She can talk the walk, but can she walk the talk?"). The survey also found that "only a small minority of News employees believes that there is an incentive system that rewards them for company successes". Er, in English, I think that they feel underpaid.

 Perhaps it is no wonder they are underpaid at News International, if this week's effort by Rachel Campbell-Johnston on the Times is anything to go by. Rachel rather let the side down on Wednesday, with her article in the Times arts section. "Built at the end of the 17th century by a wealthy relation of Peter the Great," wrote Rachel, "the Church of the Intercession is the only intact example of 17th-century Moscow baroque to have survived the ransacking of Napoleonic invaders," and dubbing it "a jewel of the baroque." How odd, then, that just eight days earlier, this appeared in the Guardian by Ian Traynor in Moscow: "Built in 1693 by a wealthy uncle of Peter the Great, the church... is a jewel of the Moscow baroque... the sole 17th-century church to have survived intact the ravages wrought through the centuries by Napoleon." Really, Rachel, you can do better. Just change a few words, add in more adjectives and no one will be any wiser.

 After the Diary revealed that protesters and journalists are ranked as high as Russia and China as threats by the Atomic Weapons Establishment at Aldermaston, Bruce Kent sends us a new "restricted" memo, for the wearers of nuclear protection suits. "Procedure for Urination and Defecation in the Arctic," it is headed. I won't go into details, but procedures for urination include 22 separate steps. Defecation gets 31 individual motions, the highlight of which is step 17: "Defecate in normal manner."

 News of an important breakthrough: British scientists have perfected the Vulcan "mind-meld" technique as seen on Star Trek. The mind-meld - which allows two brains to be merged into one - was first tested by Labour MPs during the mayoral nomination (when MPs sent out identical letters supporting Dobbo). Now the technique has been adopted by senior figures. A letter from Caroline Adams on No10 Downing Street letterhead to Tim Sawyer, a Radio 4 journalist who complained about the mayoral stitch-up, is an almost word-for-word repeat of letters sent out by party general secretary Margaret McDonagh. "Your voice is important to us," writes Caroline/ Margaret. It's the personal touches that make such a difference, don't you think?

 First there was the Oooh You Amaze Me! T-shirt (just £7.50, order yours today!), and now readers can visit the official website. Today sees the launch of www.ooohyouamazeme.com, a parody of Dobbo's latest official site. His campaign team was forced to relaunch the first site after a prankster created a near identical one. The updated Oooh You Amaze Me! © website includes a rip-off of a speech by Mr Tony Blair: "I have known Frank Dobson for almost 20 years. I know he will do pretty much anything I ask him to: Frank will even stand up to the government if I tell him."

webTitle: Malaysian state swaps tourism for morality

fields.headline: Malaysian state swaps tourism for morality
fields.trailText: Men and women in this palm-fringed, east coast Malaysian state are no longer allowed to stand in the same queues at supermarkets, even if they're married to one another. The idea is to prevent men witnessing women purchasing "personal items", according to a senior member of the state's new Islamic government.
fields.body:
Men and women in this palm-fringed, east coast Malaysian state are no longer allowed to stand in the same queues at supermarkets, even if they're married to one another. The idea is to prevent men witnessing women purchasing "personal items", according to a senior member of the state's new Islamic government.

Signboards now segregate male and female customers at cash tills and there are plans to separate other danger spots, such as unisex hair salons, where "free mixing" of the sexes might take place.

"I have been chosen to protect the rights of women against exploitation," says Awang bin Jusoh, the avuncular representative of the new Islamic government of Terengganu, whose job it is to tour public places in need of segregation.

He has been politely persuading supermarkets and department stores to provide new uniforms for their female Muslim staff: a headscarf that covers the hair and neck, a shirt buttoned to the collar and long trousers.

"We are not making them wear the full Islamic robes from head to toe, that would be rather extreme. We are being quite moderate in that sense," explains Mr Awang, who says he is not forcing anyone to make the changes.

Shop managers, though, say they have been left in little doubt that they must comply, despite the expense and inconvenience, if they want to continue to enjoy the cooperation of the state government.

Terengganu's Muslims, who make up 95% of the state's population, have yet to voice any objection to the new Islamic policies. The majority of Muslim women here already wear headscarves, and even Haja Zahliyha binte Loung, a member of the prime minister Mahathir Mohammad's United Malays National Organisation party - the state's opposition - agrees that "Muslim women must wear headscarves".

"We should not expose any part of the body, even if it's just one strand of hair," she says.

Since the federal Islamic opposition party, the Parti Islam Se-Malaysia (PAS), gained control of two states in north-eastern Malaysia in last year's elections, its crusade against immorality has shocked many liberal Malaysians in the capital, Kuala Lumpur. They fear that the hardline Islamic party, which is rapidly gaining support, will undermine the image of Malaysia as a progressive Muslim country where different races and religions coexist in harmony.

Although PAS has made efforts not to alienate the state's non-Muslim residents, Chinese businesses affected by the new drive towards Islamic fundamentalism are furious; Jeffrey Tham, who runs the Banana Karaoke Lounge, faces financial ruin after a life's hard work. PAS has said that only two establishments in the state capital, Kuala Terengganu, will be allowed to serve alcohol - the rest will be closed.

"We are now sitting like a dead duck waiting for them to shoot us down," says Mr Tham, who is operating without a valid licence. "I don't think we'll last until the end of this year," adds.

There appears to be valid concern that severely limiting the sale of alcohol will damage the state's burgeoning tourist industry. The chief minister, Abdul Hadi Awang, says that foreign tourists who visit the state's beach resorts must be sensitive to local culture or steps will have to be taken to keep them in line.

The shifting attitudes have been enough to prompt one French couple to cut short their holiday in Terengganu because the atmosphere is already so off-putting. "We had the feeling that people are looking at us, and especially my wife because she has no headscarf," says Edgar Mirrer, who says he is astonished by the attitude of the people.

They fear that the hardline Islamic party, which is rapidly gaining support, will undermine the image of Malaysia as a progressive Muslim country where different races and religions coexist in harmony. Although PAS has made efforts not to alienate the state's non-Muslim residents, Chinese businesses affected by the new drive towards Islamic fundamentalism are furious; Jeffrey Tham, who runs the Banana Karaoke Lounge, faces financial ruin after a life's hard work. PAS has said that only two establishments in the state capital, Kuala Terengganu, will be allowed to serve alcohol - the rest will be closed. "We are now sitting like a dead duck waiting for them to shoot us down," says Mr Tham, who is operating without a valid licence. "I don't think we'll last until the end of this year," adds. There appears to be valid concern that severely limiting the sale of alcohol will damage the state's burgeoning tourist industry. The chief minister, Abdul Hadi Awang, says that foreign tourists who visit the state's beach resorts must be sensitive to local culture or steps will have to be taken to keep them in line. The shifting attitudes have been enough to prompt one French couple to cut short their holiday in Terengganu because the atmosphere is already so off-putting. "We had the feeling that people are looking at us, and especially my wife because she has no headscarf," says Edgar Mirrer, who says he is astonished by the attitude of the people.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText:
Galaxy Quest: 20th Anniversary - The Journey Continues
8pm, Sci-Fi
fields.body:
Galaxy Quest: 20th Anniversary - The Journey Continues
8pm, Sci-Fi

The spoof documentary seems to have come into its own as a promotional tool, after The Blair Witch Project's convincing primer last year, and this effort should help drum up some talk about the forthcoming sci-fi spoof, starring Tim Allen, Sigourney Weaver and an alien-headed Alan Rickman. The TV has-beens mix bitterness and fondness as they reminisce over their career-destroying involvement with the Star Trek-style series of the title.

The Railway Children
(Lionel Jeffries, 1972)
4.30pm, Carlton Cinema

This enchanting, old-fashioned adventure out of an E Nesbit story is possibly the best children's film ever. Three Edwardian children (Jenny Agutter, Sally Thomsett, Gary Warren) are reduced to living with Mother (Dinah Sheridan) in a small Yorkshire cottage when Father is jailed for espionage; their summer's adventures revolve around the local railway station and dour-but-lovable stationmaster Perks (Bernard Cribbins).

Out Of Sight
(Steven Soderbergh, 1998)
8pm, Sky Premier

This hip-and-witty thriller brought indie star Soderbergh storming into the mainstream. Scriptwriter Scott Frank, who also did Get Shorty, plots an intricate path through Elmore Leonard's twisty novel, and hangs on to the master's snappy dialogue. Meanwhile George Clooney's bank robber and Jennifer Lopez's federal marshal fizz with odd-couple chemistry; Ving Rhames is dead cool as Clooney's partner in crime.

The Hit
(Stephen Frears, 1984)
10pm, FilmFour

A classy Brit gangster film. Two hitmen - a crunchy combination of John Hurt as Braddock and Tim Roth's Myron - are in Spain to kill Terence Stamp's Willie Parker: the grass whose singing sent a gang of hoods down a decade before. It's the perfect Stamp role: part cockney hardnut, part zen philosopher.

webTitle: Mexican cowboy bucks the status quo

fields.headline: Mexican cowboy bucks the status quo
fields.standfirst: July's presidential election could finally herald an end to the PRI party's 71-year grip on power
fields.trailText: A former Coca-Cola executive with a cowboy style, a Jesuit education and a populist message is posing one of the most serious challenges ever to the Institutional Revolutionary party's (PRI) 71-year-old monopoly of the Mexican presidency.
fields.body:
A former Coca-Cola executive with a cowboy style, a Jesuit education and a populist message is posing one of the most serious challenges ever to the Institutional Revolutionary party's (PRI) 71-year-old monopoly of the Mexican presidency.

"We're not thumb-sucking kids anymore, we're grown-ups now and we can kick out the PRI," Vicente Fox, 57, bellows at a village rally high in the lush-but-poverty-stricken eastern Sierra Madre.

The PRI has held the presidency without interruption since it was founded in 1929, winning the six-yearly elections with the support of entrenched networks of cronyism, patronage and, in the past when those failed, fraud. In recent years, the government has felt obliged to invite international electoral observers and few expect fraud this time around, but the party machinery remains formidable.

"The PRI always wins," says Mercedes Hernandez, a domestic servant in Mexico City. Ms Hernandez will vote for the challenger this time because she believes that tackling widespread poverty and the country's high levels of common and organised crime requires a change of regime.

As the July 2 presidential election approaches, the Fox campaign has taken off. Most opinion polls show him just a few points behind the PRI candidate, Francisco Labastida, and far ahead of the other main opposition candidate, the left-leaning Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, who many Mexicans believe had the presidency snatched from him by electoral fraud in 1988.

"The horse that catches up is the horse that wins," says Mr Fox as he campaigns in a bus painted with his bear-like figure raising a hand in a V-for-victory sign.

The Fox campaign intentionally spurns the traditional solemnity and circumlocutions of doing politics in Mexico, inundating the media with ads that reduce the message to one two-letter word - Ya - meaning enough, or now, or at last.

The new tact has seen the candidate leaning out of his campaign bus window whistling at passers-by and peppering his speeches with popular slang.

"Faced with the challenge of wresting power from a party in government for 70 years, we knew we needed a strategy so different it could throw the competition off balance," Mr Fox says, adding that heading Coca-Cola in Mexico provided an invaluable understanding of promotional techniques.

And he is natural communicator, giving each audience an easy-listening version of their concerns as he strides across provincial city platforms with the relaxed pose of a crooner when needed, or addresses a bankers' conference with the confidence of a successful businessman.

He appeals to the poor in a language they understand: "I am going to govern for the 40m Mexicans whose fate has been to dance with the ugliest girl," he told a rally in an impoverished rural town.

He can appeal to women voters: "The wonderful women of Mexico deserve total respect and the opportunity to fulfil themselves," he proclaimed at another gathering where the female vote was considered key.

And he has developed a rapport with the international media: "I believe that development should be directed by the state in harmony with the market, and that is why I am opening up the third way," he explains to a British reporter, echoing Blairisms.

Mr Fox's pragmatic populism has angered more dogmatic members of his rightwing National Action party, but with the smell of victory growing stronger, few are complaining.

The PRI, meanwhile, plays with a similarly amorphous ideology that glorifies the Mexican revolution while also supporting the global free market.

In the past few years the party has reinvented itself as the "new PRI", loosening its grip to allow other parties to win local elections and parlia mentary power, as well as democratising candidate selection within its ranks. But while the PRI modernisation helped the greying Mr Labastida begin the campaign with a massive head start, his lacklustre performance so far appears to have favoured the colourful Mr Fox.

The PRI campaign team says Mr Labastida's small-scale events thus far are intentional, designed to emphasise his sensitive side, but they promise that mass events closer to polling day will prove the party's organisation is as strong as ever.

"The campaign of that yellow-faced shorty Labastida is sinking. It can't even float," Mr Fox tells some well-dressed and carefully coiffed women who stand on their chairs and whoop with delight in his home state of Guanajuato.

But for all their enthusiasm, it is hard for many to believe that it is possible to oust the PRI from the presidency and end the world's oldest regime.

A rural teacher, Jose de Jesus Martinez, says: "It is very difficult to pull up a tree that has such deep roots. It is very difficult for Fox to win."

fields.headline: The long goodbye
fields.trailText: "Rickeee!" The word drills through the eardrum and runs around the cavaties of the brain like a cornered rat. It's the most famous mating call on TV. Ian Beale from EastEnders was once asked on Night Fever (Channel 5, so you won't have seen it) what Bianca used to say. He raised his arms, counted "One, two, three!" and, like one woman, the whole audience shrieked "Rickeee!"
fields.body:
"Rickeee!" The word drills through the eardrum and runs around the cavaties of the brain like a cornered rat. It's the most famous mating call on TV. Ian Beale from EastEnders was once asked on Night Fever (Channel 5, so you won't have seen it) what Bianca used to say. He raised his arms, counted "One, two, three!" and, like one woman, the whole audience shrieked "Rickeee!"

Bianca and Ricky were married in EastEnders (BBC1). Ever since Bianca left to go into full-time ear-piercing, Ricky's looked like a lost dog waiting for a whistle. He's served 12 years in the soap, man and boy, most of them with his head under a car bonnet and his ears ringing. He's leaving, apparently, to become a pop star and, God knows, why not?

His last appearance was an EastEnders special, one of those dark-night-of-the-soul episodes with only two characters, helplessly horns-locked. It was very effective, the more so as the whole thing was written as a metaphor.

After a fraught stint at the Queen Vic unblocking toilets, Ricky snapped like a Twiglet, drove off in a stolen car (only Ricky could have managed to steal a stolen car) and crashed. Now read on.

Phil, the square's resident bad egg, retrieved the battered lad from the cop shop. In the peculiarly desolate setting of a service station at night, Ricky (Sid Owen) explained why he felt he must go and Phil (Steve McFadden) argued against it. Unspoken but implicit was the reality of an actor leaving the security and cosiness of a soap to take a leap in the dark.

Phil: "This is stupid. What are you gonna do? Where are you gonna go?"

Ricky: "Anywhere. Somewhere away from you."

Phil: "What's it gonna getcha, Ricky? There's not some magical land aht there. Look, that's all there is!" (The motorway traffic screamed like a knife across the throat). "Miles and miles of strangers. No one's gonna know yer. No one's gonna care about yer. You should be back at 'ome in the Square."

Ricky said, with admirable candour, that the Square made his skin crawl. Shouting shrilly, "I'm well shot of you! I'm well shot of all of you!" he knocked hot coffee over the only bit of Phil not upholstered in black hide like a rhino and stormed off down a long, lonely walkway. It was brightly lit but every window showed the night outside.

Seeing Ricky's little face was cold and hard like a salad egg, Phil gave him a thumbnail sketch of what would happen if he left. "It's really going to 'it the fan. Pat'll find out and she'll dump Roy. Frank'll go spare. He'll go mad at Mum and he'll walk out. And what about Lisa? If she gets wind of it, she'll be straight out the door."

Strangely, this description of a very average day in Albert Square, with people going mad in alphabetical order, appeared to sway Ricky. He hesitated. "If I go back, I'll never leave." This may well be true. Before every soap star is the spectre of Ken Barlow, who joined Coronation Street 40 years ago and is serving a life sentence. Ricky said weakly: "I just need some peace" and, enclosing him in a Mafia hug, Phil said: "And you're going to get it. I promise you."

Clever or what! Hands up those who thought Phil was going to kill him! You all feel pretty silly now, don't you?

Ricky, in fact, hitched a lift with a lorry driver heading for Calais. As far as I know he has no passport, so I suppose he will claim asylum. And what Frenchman, when he's described the catering in Kaff's Caff, would have the heart to refuse him?

It was written by Simon Ashdown and directed by Richard Dale with devotion, as if it were a real play. And wasn't it?

Futurescope (C4) was a gripping little thriller, the first of three, set in the near-future when pirate TV can hack into a global audience. The pirate is, unfortunately, a close relation of Dave Spart, who can talk without pausing for breath on globalisation, democratisation, biotechnology and rich bastards. Your natural instinct to switch over to snooker is tempered by the fact that he and his accomplice, a social work lecturer, have kidnapped the head of a pharmaceutical company and put him on trial on TV for avarice, arrogance, inhumanity and being a rich bastard ("Press red for death, green for life"). The interactive audience enthusiastically vote for death. I would have thought this implausible if it weren't Good Friday.

"Good news! The rain's getting warmer." - John Kettley, weatherman on Radio 4.

fields.headline: National round-up
fields.trailText: Best 'on the wagon for good'
fields.body:
Best 'on the wagon for good'

The former Manchester United football star, George Best, last night pledged never to drink again.

In an interview screened on TV, he insisted he had finally faced up to his alcoholism.

He also revealed that he hoped to start a family with his wife, Alex, 27, and to live to approach 100 like his grandmother.

Best, 53, released from hospital last week after suffering liver failure, described how his life became a nightmare battle against alcohol. He told ITV's Tonight programme: "I should be dead. But I'm not and now I'm not going anywhere."

The ex-Northern Ireland international, still in huge demand as a celebrity at functions, also detailed an endless round of liquid lunches and drink-sodden evening engagements.

And he revealed how he drank to cheer himself up when he felt low and drank just as much when he felt in a good mood. "Drink has no respect for who you are. It's as bad as taking heroin or whatever else people take. Now I don't think about how much longer I can drink, because I'm not going to."

Speaking of his hopes for the future with Alex despite a series of bust-ups during their eight years together, he said: "It's nice to think that I've personally been given a new start and with a bit of luck, a couple of kids, we could get back to a little bit of normality."

Man jailed for stabbing smoker wife

A former smoker repeatedly stabbed his wife with a kitchen knife because she refused to give up cigarettes.

Robert Plumb, 56, was jailed for four years at Manchester crown court for the attack on his wife, Glenys, 51. He had pleaded guilty to wounding with intent.

The court heard that the couple, from Littleborough, Greater Manchester, who had been married for 30 years, had made a pact to give up smoking. But Plumb slashed his wife across the neck and throat when he found she had been unable to quit. Her hands were also cut as she tried to fight him off.

The attack ended when their daughter, Kirsty, 16, hit her father over the head with a bottle and dialled 999.

Judge Jonathan Geake told Plumb: "The reason for this attack was that you had given up smoking and she did not feel able to do so, despite promises.

"In the course of the struggle on that terrible, terrible day, you admitted you slashed at your wife repeatedly.

"She was trying to struggle, she was fighting for her life with her hands. The use of knives in situations matrimonial or otherwise cannot be tolerated."

After the hearing, Mrs Plumb, who still smokes 20 cigarettes a day, said: "I'm afraid I like smoking, and no one can make me give up.

"Bob used to smoke like a trooper but then became a born-again non-smoker who thought I should just fall into line with him."

She said he had made her swear on their daughter's life to give up smoking.

"He may have left me for dead, but whatever he's done I've still no plans to give up smoking."
Helen Carter

Greek tomb holds wrong Philip

Archaeologists deliver a blow to Greek pride today in a report in Science. The tomb of Philip II of Macedon - father of Alexander the Great - discovered at Vergina in 1977 did not contain King Philip.

The body, grave goods, sword and armour belonged to Alexander's half-brother, Philip III Arrhidaeus, writes the archaeologist Antonis Bartsiokas.

In 1977 researchers discovered a tomb at Vergina containing magnificent relics and cremated skeletons, one with apparent injuries consistent with descriptions of King Philip, who subdued Athens and Thebes and hired Aristotle to tutor Alexander.

The artefacts have since been dated at 317 BC, a generation after Philip II's assassination in 336 BC. And now Dr Bartsiokas reports that apparent evidence of eye injury was either natural or damage after death. "King Philip II suffered severe injuries, but there is no skeletal evidence of injuries to the male occupant of Royal Tomb II."
Tim Radford

fields.headline: No: 1620
fields.standfirst: Genghis Khan
fields.body:
Age: 833.

Catchphrase: "I am the punishment of God!"

Ancestry: His line of descent is traced back, by Mongol believers, to the mythical union of a grey wolf and a white doe.

Offspring: Kublai Khan, founder of the Chinese Yuan dynasty.

And Chaka Khan? You're getting confused.

All these Khans... His real name was Temujin. Genghis Khan - which means "universal leader" - was the warrior king of the largest land empire in history, with a penchant for casseroling his enemies.

The product of a traumatic youth? I'll say. Dad murdered by the Tartars, wife kidnapped by a rival Mongol tribe, house burnt.

Did Genghis get his own back? Most certainly. He duly conquered and enslaved the Tartars, exploiting their warfaring skill and tangy fish sauces in his bloodthirsty invasion of central Asia and China.

The fiend! Not any more. Tartar historians are now defending the empire their ancestors built under Genghis's charge.

On what grounds? While Mongol rule "was not all paradise", admits academic Mirkasyn Usmanov, "that doesn't mean Russian history books should paint it all black".

Decapitation saving money on haircuts, that sort of thing? Not exactly. We're talking the introduction of paper money, the first population census, the emergence of Moscow as Russia's capital.

So will the Russians concur? Unlikely. They want no truck with a warmongering leader who brutally repressed a weak, would-be independent state.

Thank goodness that doesn't happen these days. Quite.

Thought to have said: "All who surrender will be spared; whoever does not surrender but opposes with struggle and dissension, shall be annihilated."

Thought to have said (revised): "I know. I'll develop a more efficient postal system and encourage Russian art."

fields.headline: Jung hearts run free
fields.standfirst: The story of the making of 70s cult classic Steppenwolf is as weird and decadent as the film. Jenny Fabian was there
fields.trailText: The story of the making of 70s cult classic Steppenwolf is as weird and decadent as the film. Jenny Fabian was there
fields.body:
The strange, claustrophobic lighting; the decadent world of Weimar clubland; weird pre-Lynch images... watching the early 1970s movie adaptation of Steppenwolf you get the feeling of peering down a tunnel into a shadowy past. Now simply a neglected film, Steppenwolf was perhaps too philosophical, too gothic for its time.

"There's no production like pre-production." The tall, dark man flashed a smile and a diamond glittered in his teeth. It was 1970, I'd just been introduced to Melvin Abner Fishman. He'd told me he was producing a film of Hermann Hesse's book Steppenwolf, and I was impressed.

The chaos within the Steppenwolf's soul was something we beaded people identified with as we tried to break free from accepted conventions. Already three years into pre-production hustle, Fishman was staying at the Ritz and working the room service hard. Weird bits of gossip about interesting movie people issued from his mouth like Hollywood Babylon. He was into Jung and alchemy and told me you are judged on the quality of your magic. Flitting in and out of my life for the next few years, he kept me informed of the grinding process of making such a metaphysical movie.

First published in 1927, Steppenwolf had become cult reading in the mid-60s, handed out by Timothy Leary with tabs of LSD. The words "The price of admittance your mind" as condition of entry to The Magic Theatre had acid-heads nodding wisely. Pablo the musician with his sweet-smelling cigarettes and unheard-of suggestions was a familiar figure on the scene. All our curiosity about the unconscious seemed to be summed up by Hesse. "It will be the first Jungian film," Fishman said. "All we need is for someone to walk round deep in thought."

Although Fishman was very much the auteur of the Steppenwolf project, he needed a co-producer to keep him grounded. Richard Herland, with his blonde college-boy looks, was an ideal counterpart to Fishman's visionary freestyle. Herland was a straight, Fishman took a lot of acid.

Herland found himself having to pull Fishman back from some of his wilder conversational gambits as they touted for money. "Fishman was far too brilliant, he could take people much further than they were willing to go. He would be on one of those riffs where he had almost convinced some guy to do business, then he would flip it in such a way that the guy couldn't go to that cosmic level, in the sense of balance sheets, profit and loss statements."

The Steppenwolf universe seemed to be in constant flux. The group of the same name bawled "Born to be Wild" at us. Fishman and Herland were doing the rounds of Hollywood, trying to get their project off the ground. Fishman had offered Antonioni $1 million - an unheard-of amount in those days - to direct the film. This had brought Carlo Ponti sniffing around, because he had Antonioni under exclusive contract.

Their relationship was at a stand-off after the Zabriskie Point flop. It got as far as a kind of surreal casting discussion, Ponti suggesting Walter Matthau for the role of Harry Haller, tormented hero; Fishman telling Ponti he'd been thinking of Jack Lemmon, while, in the kitchen, Sophia Loren was cooking spaghetti as she nursed little Carlo. Antonioni announced the book was unfilmable.

Meanwhile, James Coburn had approached Herland, waving contracts, trying to rope Fishman out of the deal. Behind their backs, MGM was trying to poach Steppenwolf scriptwriter Fred Haines, whose screenplay for Ulysses had just received an Oscar nomination. Herland bumped into Marlon Brando buying a copy of Steppenwolf in a Beverly Hills bookstore. John Frankenheimer, hot from The Manchurian Candidate and Birdman of Alcatraz, was another power player who wanted complete control. Herland came to realise all these deals would have been Faustian. No big studio would risk such an eclectic project without destroying the spirit of the book.

While Fishman dropped acid with Leary, Herland would be courting studio executives on Dean Martin's tennis court. Turning up with a financier's lawyer at Fishman's Beverly Hills shack, Herland found him sitting naked and Buddha-like on the lawn with the sprinklers full on. He was sampling some psylocibin he was planning to initiate Herland with. "You don't feel the wet," he told them gleefully.

Nevertheless, it was Fishman who had built up the invaluable relationship with the Hesse family, which, after an 18-month charm offensive, had enabled the negotiation of a tricky clause in Hesse's will previously prohibiting the sale of film rights to his work.

At one point, Fishman and Herland found themselves in competition with Conrad Rooks, the rich Avon cosmetics junkie kid, looking to take the next step after his self-reflecting film Chappaqua, featuring William Burroughs and Allen Ginsberg. I came across Rooks in 1968 in the basement all-night restaurant in The Royal Garden hotel, which was a good place to recover from Saturday night's Unlimited Freak Out. Four years later and he was holding court to members of the Hesse family on his oversized yacht in Cannes harbour. But Rooks, with fortunes at his disposal, was too stoned to remember which book he was after except that it began with S. He ended up with Siddhartha.

Herland and Fishman had no such financial resources. Herland, with some minor film production deals already under his belt, managed to cobble together the $150,000 needed for the rights, and decamped the team from the big-time bullshit of Hollywood to Basle, Switzerland, the home of LSD, and, coincidentally, where Steppenwolf was written.

A production team of eight moved into a house, supported by Herland as he desperately juggled finances to keep the show alive. Fishman announced he was going to make the movie anyway. "We know Haines wrote the script, now we want to be sure he's read it." For three days with a handheld camera, he filmed Haines, wearing Hesse's dressing gown, reading the screenplay beneath a 150-watt lightbulb with a couple of pictures of Hesse in the background. Three hours of film with one image. "Once you've accepted that he's not going to move, you can make your own movie," Fishman said. "The other film will be the Mickey Mouse version."

Zig-zagging their way across Europe, touting their project, Herland was starting to feel the pressure of Fishman's obsession. Driving through the Black Forest to meet Dr Bender at the Institute of Parapsychological Studies in order to consult the mythological runes, Herland was overcome with intense paranoia. "I saw Melvin in the same black light as the night when he gave me the magic mushroom. I felt I had somehow lost my grip on the reality I had pieced together for 34 years and was powerless to avoid floating off into a terrifying world of crazies. I had given my mind to Melvin."

Finally, Herland came up with a financier, Peter Sprague, a man born into the American industrial aristocracy who liked to think he had a radical image. Timothy Leary, on the run from prison, turned up at the Hesse-Jung Summer Institute, and Fishman had the notion of screen-testing him for the part of Harry Haller. They introduced him to Sprague, who liked him, but Leary blew it by dropping two Sunshine tabs on Sprague, who had a bad trip and had to be cooled out with a handful of valium and a copy of the Financial Times. He called Leary "that perverter of mankind".

Finally, after seven years, shooting began. Haines took the director's chair, stoked up on the Ritalin which had come gift-wrapped. "We're film fans," said the head of one of the many pharmaceutical companies based in Basle. "We're drug fans," Fishman replied. The cast was a formidable European roll-call: Max von Sydow as tortured Haller; Dominique Sanda, a favourite of Bertolucci and Visconti, the androgynous Hermine; and Pierre Clementi, in his first role since Belle de Jour and two years' incarceration on a dope charge, as Pablo, "exotic demi-god of love". None was a native English speaker. The early special effects have a magic long since lost in the onslaught of computer animation. See Pablo pick up a hologram of Hermine and crumple her up like paper.

Behind the scenes there was trouble among the producers. Herland ran off with the cutting copy and refused to part with it until Sprague paid up, but this meant finally relinquishing any further control he and Fishman might have had. What followed became a marketing disaster. Eighty prints were struck but the colours were wrong, and Sanda's brilliant blue eyes became brown. It adds strangely to the film's other-worldly quality.

By now, Fishman, who had suffered a minor heart attack after taking a Christmas speedball, swung between desperate hope and total despair. His fantasy was in the can, but he'd lost control of it. No one knew quite how broke he was. Two years later, still with Herland, still trying to get their film back from Sprague, who had stuck it away on a shelf somewhere, it was fade-out for Fishman. He had another heart attack, this time fatal, and died with 20 Swiss francs in his pocket, no dream left to dream.

 Steppenwolf will be screened at London's Riverside Studios on Thursday.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: The Blair Witch Project | The Last Broadcast | The Iron Giant | Runaway Bride
fields.trailText: The Blair Witch Project | The Last Broadcast | The Iron Giant | Runaway Bride
fields.body:
The Blair Witch Project
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Fox Cert 15
****

The Last Broadcast Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Metrodome Cert 18
**

The famous one and the other one. Both feature US youngsters going into the woods to investigate gruesome, legendary mysteries and failing to return. Both have enough handheld camerawork to make you feel slightly sick, though this effect is minimised on the small screen. Both cost about $25,000. You'll know which one has made well over $100m.

Each has a mystery, but the third one is whether Blair Witch was influenced by Last Broadcast. BWP has a simpler story, a more skilful use of its non-budget and a memorable performance by Heather Donahue, whose heartfelt apology speech has been much parodied. She starts out professional and a little domineering ("We'll all look back on this and laugh heartily. Believe me."), and it's her descent into panic that gives the film its fright quotient.

I found it surprisingly unscary but it's certainly unsettling and has its remarkable moments, such as when a babe in arms tries to cover the mouth of her mother as if to stop her telling the Blair Witch story. Plus its twig people induce the odd shiver. The Blair Witch DVD has plenty of extras for obsessives, including the remarkable 42-minute documentary which helped the film take off in the US. The care and thoroughness of this fake doc on a fake doc (woodcuts, ancient documents and many interviews) is extraordinary.

The Last Broadcast, completed earlier, has the Jersey devils as its demons, and a cable TV show (Fact or Fiction), whose team decide to boost ratings by hiring a psychic to find the site. Bad things ensue ("Are you a psychic or a psycho?") and a murder investigation makes this more like a traditional documentary. Not bad, but not memorable.

The Iron Giant
Retail (£14.99) and DVD (£15.99)
Warner Cert U
****

Witty and delightful cartoon based on Ted Hughes's story, which uses elements from ET, King Kong, Frankenstein and The Snowman but weaves them together in a wholly original way. Hogarth is a frisky kid who discovers a mysterious metal monster, and, knowing adults will mess things up a treat because that's what adults do, decides to keep the giant to himself, with his friend, a designer-stubbled artist who lives in a junkyard.

With a secret serviceman on the trail of the colossus, the story combines humour, suspense and some terrific set pieces, such as the tidal wave when IG jumps into a pond where Hogarth is swimming. Where traditional kids' cartoons spoil things with insipid songs, The Iron Giant gives you the Coasters' wonderful Searchin' - it's set in the 50s. Director and co-writer Brad Bird is executive producer of The Simpsons and voices include John Mahoney and Jennifer Aniston. Unbeatable family Easter viewing, and worth a look for the child-free, too.

Runaway Bride
Rental and DVD (£15.99)
Warner Cert 18
**

A Julia Roberts rom-com, so you'll already know whether you're interested. As usual, there's more rom than com, but it has more laughs than most recent Roberts vehicles, thanks to a witty script. (When Roberts, who works in a hardware store, flees a wedding, the local paper headline is: Hardware honey goes nuts and bolts).

On the downside, the plot is ludicrous, even for this sort of light, screwball mood: nobody's actions make any sense except as a plot device. The concept here is get the stars we have loved back with the director of their hit (Roberts and Richard Gere, Pretty Woman, Garry Marshall). The same idea recently brought us You've Got Mail and, again, William Hill's is not taking bets on you guessing the ending. Night-owl Oz fans will be amused to find the much-married Keller (Chris Meloni) cast as Roberts's current bridegroom-to-be.

fields.headline: No bridge over troubled Water
fields.standfirst: Director Deepa Mehta caused a storm with her last film, Fire. Her next, Water, has caused a lawsuit, a fatwa and death threats
fields.trailText: Director Deepa Mehta caused a storm with her last film, Fire. Her next, Water, has caused a lawsuit, a fatwa and death threats
fields.body:
The Canadian film-maker Deepa Mehta is used to controversy. When her 1996 film, Fire, opened in India, Hindu mobs set light to cinemas where it was being screened. Undeterred, she returned last year to make Water, which concludes her trilogy after Earth. But six months on, the project is in tatters and Mehta is back in Canada, demoralised and upset.

Mehta, who was driven out of the holy city of Varanasi by angry Hindu mobs, finds herself at the centre of another row - this time over plagiarism. Sunil Gangopadhyay, a Bengali writer has accused her of lifting large passages from his novel and incorporating them into her script for Water.

Mehta has denied the allegations and last month she fired off a writ demanding damages. "There is no similarity of plot, storyline, characters, time-span, settings, language or dialogue," the writ declares. Given the tortuous nature of India's legal system, the case may drag on for years.

Mehta, who was born in India but emigrated to Toronto in 1973, admits she has been "inspired" by Mr Gangopadhyay's epic historic novel, Those Days. But she denies behaving unethically. "What is really tragic is that the film still hasn't been made," she says.

Gangopadhyay says he had been reluctant to speak out against Mehta but felt compelled to do so after reading her script. "The two main characters were literally lifted from my novel. There were several scenes and dialogues taken almost verbatim as well. If she had asked my permission originally, I would have given it gladly," he says.

The film deals with three women and their search for freedom. Gangopadhyay complains that two characters have been plucked directly from Those Days. "The descriptions are exactly the same in Deepa's script. Same characters. She keeps on contradicting herself," he adds.

Mehta says her film draws inspiration from several literary sources. "There are 17 characters in my film, compared to 218 in his novel," she storms. She is adamant the line between inspiration and plagiarism has not been crossed. Her lawyer, Chander Lall, meanwhile, accuses her critics of being "gung-ho". "Deepa is very determined. Her reputation is at stake. She is not a plagiarist. She is happy to postpone or abandon the film if need be."

The film is little further forward than when Mehta arrived in India six months ago. Four days before shooting began "the shit hit the fan". Rumour had spread among local Hindu activists that her script depicted the city's pious widows as prostitutes and denigrated Hindu religion - a charge she denies.

Following protests, the Indian prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, intervened to allow filming to continue. Mehta agreed to minor cuts to her script. A young Hindu activist rowed into the Ganges and threatened to kill himself if the film was made. The director was "hounded out" of Varanasi on the grounds that her safety could not be guaranteed. Hindu gangs celebrated by toppling part of her set into the Ganges. "You will never make Water," one local journalist told her at a press conference.

Taking her two lead actresses with her, Nandita Das and Shabana Azmi, both of whom had shaved their hair off in keeping with their role as traditional Hindu widows, Mehta moved to West Bengal at the invitation of the chief minister, Jyoti Basu. Some 1,500 Calcutta prostitutes, who identified with the sexually exploited widows in Mehta's film, then staged a rally in support. Such is India's confusing multiplicity.

Azmi, meanwhile, is also in trouble with fundamentalists. The Muslim actress, who appears next month in a new play at the National Theatre, is the subject of a fatwa from Islamic clerics. They are unhappy that she has shaved off all her hair.

Azmi makes her debut on the British stage in The Waiting Room, by Tanika Gupta. Until the plagiarism row is settled Mehta is unlikely to return to India to start work again on her film. "It feels like a Kafka nightmare," she says.

Fire, the first part of her trilogy, raised hackles on the subcontinent because it depicted two sisters-in-law drifting towards a lesbian romance. While some western critics liked it, others dismissed it as a feminist tract. Earth, the first part of the trilogy, also dealt with a difficult theme - the trauma caused by the partition of India and Pakistan.

It is a sad irony that Mehta is now at odds with India's secular intellectuals, who supported her in the face of religious hostility and obscurantist threats. Because they were once her friends, their critiques of her work are more wounding, and more subtle. Aruna Chakravati, the translator of Those Days, yesterday said the novel showed a society moving towards "a progressive and enlightened view of the world". But Deepa Mehta's Water merely depicted "stagnancy", she said stingingly.

The saga says much about how difficult it is to make a serious film in India these days, and how the prevailing national mood has become shriller, more bombastic; and less tolerant.

"What is so scary is that people are reinterpreting what the rules are regarding culture," Mehta says. "If I could just say one thing to those who oppose my work, it would be: 'Lighten up guys'."

 Earth is released today.

webTitle: There was this priest and a rabbi...

fields.headline: There was this priest and a rabbi...
fields.trailText: There was this priest and a rabbi...
fields.body:
There's an old Hollywood legend I'm very fond of. It involves two real people - novelist William Faulkner and fellow southerner, drinker and screenwriter Nunnally Johnson - but that's no guarantee of its veracity.

In the late 1930s, Faulkner had to rely on the tender mercies of various satanic studio heads. When he landed at MGM Darryl F Zanuck ordered him to report to Johnson's office to discuss a new movie. Johnson was then a success and Faulkner was not, but they were both proud sons of Dixie, so Johnson's welcome was warm, and coloured by the kind of chivalric courtliness, long obsolete outside the Deep South, which one associates with pillared plantation houses and mint juleps at sundown.

Faulkner, who was well versed in such rituals of hospitality, responded in kind by producing from his jacket pocket a pint of bourbon - the primary social lubricant of the old Confederacy. He started picking at the heavy lead foil around the cork but only managed to cut his finger open. When he found he couldn't open the bottle and hold the bleeding finger in his mouth, Faulkner dropped to his knees and removed his hat, which he used as a bowl to catch the blood while he continued to labour with the bottle (which was more important in Faulkner's scheme of things than any injury up to and including a severed head).

After much undignified struggling, and with blood now staining his trousers, shirt and tie, the future Nobel prize-winner rose again to his full height and emptied half the bottle down his famously capacious throat. "How's about a drink, sir?" he said to his host, whereupon Johnson took the remaining half-pint and necked it all, in a manner most unlike a gentleman.

And that was the last anyone saw of the pair for nearly three weeks when, as legend has it, they were tracked down by MGM detectives and found holed up in an Okie camp halfway across the country, boozing it up in the most indescribable squalor. The two fallen gentlemen were dusted down, hosed off, sobered up and once again chained to their studio desks.

Since this is, of course, a lovingly embellished legend, it's OK to add one's own embellishments. I've always enjoyed trying to imagine what happened to them in that three-week period. I like to think their marathon alcoholic odyssey included at least one sojourn on a chain-gang, much whoring in Mexican bordellos, the loss of all their drinking-funds at the cock fights in Tijuana, and a romantic interlude involving twin female lion-tamers, preferably with insanely jealous carnival-freak boyfriends.

This story has been much on my mind since I saw Keeping the Faith, the indescribably witless directorial debut of actor Ed Norton. This alleged comedy about two best friends, a rabbi (Ben Stiller) and a Catholic priest (Norton), who both fall in love with their childhood friend Jenna Elfman, is so very terrible that I found myself watching it with clenched teeth, frequently casting about the stalls in search of expensive things to break and small children to strangle.

One day Ed Norton was being given his directorial head and the next thing he knew, he'd woken up to find himself the star of Keeping the Faith. Forget lion-tamers and Okie camps - this must have been like waking up with a corpse in the bed and a tidemark of bloodstains up the wall to well above eye-level. How did it come to this?

Keeping the Faith - which must have been, oh, at least the fourth script in Norton's pile - seems to come from a long-gone era in American ethnic comedy when people still cared about the church and the synagogue. Back then you had Pat O'Brien or Bing Crosby as the genial, piano- playing, Chesterfield-smoking sky pilot, or, worse, the ferociously devout Loretta Young ("Attila the Nun" to her enemies) clad in a habit designed to emphasise her splendid breasts and promote all manner of licentiousness. This was the ornate and hypocritical era that began to fade once that Nazi-loving old villain Pius XII took his last one-way ride on the down escalator.

And while Norton is setting fire to his vestments and sticking his burnt bum in the font, Stiller is accessing the almost obsolete strain of humour of the 50s Jewish resort nightclubs in the Catskills and the Pochanos where his parents, Jerry Stiller and Anne Meara, paid their early comic dues. The script reheats old chestnuts such as the rabbi who faints at his first bris and is always fighting off the horny widows in his congregation.

Stiller and Norton, both talented actors in the right vehicle, have no idea how to present friendship on-screen - they look as though they loathe each other - and their chemistry is non-existent. Elfman's a game gal, and a fine comedian, but she, too, is cast adrift by Norton's atrocious, directionless direction, which makes one yearn for the sure and steady directorial hand of (ha!) Emilio Estevez or Kevin Costner.

It's amazing how enduring this kind of thing is, though. Not the humour per se, but its ability to attract a 1953 audience at the dawn of the 21st century. My good friend Kevin (a Catholic raised in the shadow of Pius XII) makes an annual pilgrimage to Las Vegas each February to hook up with his college friends from back east for a long weekend of unspeakable degeneracy, reckless gambling, avant-garde alcohol abuse, and God knows what else.

This year they all paid $60 to see Jerry Lewis at one of his packed-out nightclub appearances. "We went with one intention - to laugh at him, not with him," said Kevin afterwards. Jerry was about as contemporary as Keeping the Faith, heavy on jokes about Japanese transistors that were old before the fall of Saigon. Sample joke: "A Chinaman takes five chopsticks and drops them on a trashcan lid. Pying! Dong! Wap! Bing! And that's how these guys name their kids!"

The oldsters in the packed club just ate this shit up, slanty-eye jokes and everything. They're the sector of the audience that helped Keeping the Faith rise to the number three spot this week. The youngsters, meanwhile, were laughing at the sheer suburban awfulness of it all. Perhaps I should have gone to the new Sandra Bullock movie instead. It can't have been any worse.

fields.headline: Tracks of my Frears
fields.standfirst: Nick Hornby's London novel about an obsessive music fanatic has become a movie set in Chicago. Stuart Husband gets the lowdown from its director, the very English Stephen Frears, man of many genres.
fields.trailText: Nick Hornby's London novel about an obsessive music fanatic has become a movie set in Chicago. Stuart Husband gets the lowdown from its director, the very English Stephen Frears, man of many genres.
fields.body:
"I think, as time goes on, I'm getting more and more English," Stephen Frears announces, as he contemplates his antipasti in a Notting Hill trattoria, just down the road from his home. "I wouldn't know what to do in Hollywood. This is where I live."

It's just the kind of mission statement you might expect from a director who's turned the filmic spotlight on the complexities of domestic class and culture, whether set among the thrusting Thatcherite immigrant entrepreneurs of 1985's My Beautiful Laundrette - the movie which brought him to international attention - or mavericks clawing and scheming their way out of the working-class ghetto, both in his Joe Orton biopic Prick Up Your Ears, and his adaptations of Roddy Doyle's The Snapper and The Van.

Hang on, though - wasn't this also the man who made one of the definitive American road movies in The Grifters, meticulously anatomised the court machinations of 18th-century France in Dangerous Liaisons, and, most recently, helmed the finest Sam Peckinpah western the man himself never made, complete with cattle drives and dusty rodeos, last year's The Hi-Lo Country?

We should at least be back on familiar terrain with Frears's latest movie, High Fidelity, an adaptation of Nick Hornby's best-selling novel about a manic-depressive, north London second-hand record shop owner who consoles himself through serial break-ups with obsessive Top 5 list-making. Somewhere in development hell, however, John Cusack acquired the rights to the book, assembled his Grosse Pointe Blank writing team, and shifted the location from London to Chicago, with Cusack himself - not the first face that would spring to mind when contemplating the doleful character of Rob - in the leading role.

It turns out to be these two factors that attracted Frears to the project. "I'd read the book," he says, "and though I found it enjoyable, it didn't really chime with me; it's not about my generation. But I liked the idea of John doing it; he's been a friend since we did The Grifters. And while I was as sceptical as anyone about the change of setting, it finally appealed to me, because it made it less parochial; it stops it being about England."

"That's sort of the problem with English films, isn't it?" he asks, warming to his theme. "England is all they're ever about, and if they're not, they're even worse. This country is just not a very interesting subject. It's terribly limited."

It sounds contradictory - an English film director who feels intensely English, who's ambiguous at best when it comes to making films about England because he doesn't find England interesting. But then, Frears himself cuts a rather contrary figure. A youthful-looking 58, his bushy black hair greying above the ears, he resembles a rumpled, trendy don. He is, in fact, a visiting tutor at the National Film School in Beaconsfield, and his soft-spoken manner can change from avuncular bonhomie to icy patrician disdain with quicksilver speed.

For instance, when I venture a remark that 70% of High Fidelity appears to be delivered straight-to-camera by Cusack, he's indignant: "That's stupid, a wild exaggeration. It's nothing like that, you don't know what you're talking about. It's more like 7%."

The next minute, he's asking my opinion on which of the new breed of British film directors has "got it" (for the record, the only one he really rates is Kevin Allen, who made Twin Town and The Big Tease - "he seems a very clever boy").

In some ways, he's the embodiment of the establishment that came of age in the late 60s and early 70s - he abandoned his Cambridge law degree to work as assistant director to Karel Reisz on 1966's Morgan - A Suitable Case For Treatment, and repeatedly refers, luvvie-like, to "Lindsay" (Anderson), "Ridley" (Scott), "Ken" (Loach), "Les" (Blair), or "Mike" (Newell and Leigh). However, he also portrays himself simply as a workaday movie-maker who's generally been lucky with his projects (though he passed on Thelma & Louise), despite the fact Cusack puts him "in the front rank" of directors working today.

"It doesn't feel like that from where I stand," he shrugs. "It's not that there are 15 offers sitting around and people begging me to do them. There's generally one thing that captures my imagination and, like a spoilt child, I'll go off and do it, whether it's set in Dublin or Illinois."

But not, perhaps, Notting Hill. Despite living in the area for 20 years with painter Anne Rothenstein and their three sons and daughter, Frears hasn't seen the film of the same name, "except occasional bits over people's shoulders on planes", and looks blank when I mention the legendary Blue Door.

"I'm not really interested in it," he claims. "That's what I mean about English films - they're generally so cosy. I think what we've done with High Fidelity is kept the spirit of the book but universalised the story. There are differences - the character of Rob probably has more sexual confidence, but that's partly a function of setting it in the States, where they seem less neurotic about that kind of thing, and partly because it wouldn't be too convincing having John being that gauche - but Nick Hornby told me he's very pleased with it."

Given the variety of his output, what exactly constitutes "A Stephen Frears Film"? Some critics have compared him to Howard Hawks; like that Hollywood eminence, Frears is a director who, from his debut with Gumshoe in 1972, has transcended genres and settings by focusing on the human drama at the heart of a story. "Hawks, eh?" says Frears. "Well, I was brought up to film what was in front of me, to concentrate on the people at hand, rather than go on some interior journey or get into elaborate framings or effects. I don't think in terms of high concepts."

Perhaps this explains his facility to coax sterling, often career-best performances from his actors: one thinks of Anjelica Houston's murderous rage in The Grifters or Glenn Close's manic method of make-up removal in Dangerous Liaisons. "I'm interested in those moments where people reveal their true natures," he says. "And I think the actors in my films are very good and I admire them. I find I say less and less to them; I'm doing as little direction as possible these days, because I tend to make things worse.

"Being on a movie set is very intimate; it's like being with your family. It's a sort of organic process; I never quite know what the thing's going to be about before I start but, on a good day, it sorts itself out and you breathe life into it. I'm not terribly analytical - I go entirely from the gut. I make sure I work with good writers like Hanif Kureishi and Alan Bennett, and have them on hand to deal with that stuff. My natural inclination is to protect the actors while we work things out. I become completely paternal," he guffaws.

For Frears, casting is the key element. One of his biggest contributions to High Fidelity, he says, was to keep Jack Black, who plays Cusack's boorish assistant, on board. "Jack's a bolter," says Frears, "and I brought him back twice because I had faith in him. Sometimes you're amazed by the stuff you get. Like Annette Bening, on the first day of The Grifters: she started doing incredible things. If you can photograph that delight, those moments of discovery, you just keep your mouth shut and get on with it."

While Frears has certainly made films in the States, he's at pains to point out that he's never "gone Hollywood". "I don't think I've ever taken a meeting in my life," he demurs. "I've yet to have a film green-lit, as it were." He's "rather disapproving" of young British directors who fashion their movies as Hollywood calling-cards. "I'm a little old-fashioned in that way. My generation was lucky; up until 1988, the idea of a British director going to Hollywood was inconceivable. It just wasn't on offer. And we didn't sit around moaning about it; it just wasn't what people expected or valued. We just got on with it."

In fact, his crab-like progress between modestly-mounted UK and US indies garnered him a reputation as an on-time, on-budget safe pair of hands; it was only when he tackled a pair of studio behemoths, 1992's Accidental Hero, starring Dustin Hoffman as a thief who helps the victims of a plane crash, and 1996's Mary Reilly, with Julia Roberts, that Frears came a cropper.

"I didn't know how you filmed a plane crash," shudders Frears. "And it's not that Dustin was difficult, but having big stars skews the movie; you have to concentrate on this enormous investment. I'm sure I could handle it now, but at the time it knocked me down like a train. In Laundrette and Liaisons, you could see where the money was going, but with Hero we had $42m to deal with, and it was flying all over the place. And I should never have done Mary Reilly. I knew that before I started. It was full of great design and photography, but it should have been a little BBC film."

These experiences brought on what he describes as "five or six very difficult years where I lost my confidence". It wasn't until he began working on The Hi-Lo Country that he got "the old feeling" back. High Fidelity, with its youthful optimism and buoyant soundtrack - could this possibly be a portrait of Frears's current state of mind? "Maybe," he confirms. "People say it's positively jaunty compared to my normal films."

However, about that perennial Aunt Sally, the renaissance of the British film industry, Frears is less sanguine. "Is there a British film industry?" he asks plaintively. "Where is it? There just seem to be a lot of independent producers leading very tough lives. I served my apprenticeship with the BBC, where you were judged by your peers, and it was rather elitist, but it was a benign hierarchy, and tempered by its beneficiaries. Everyone you can name today came out of it: Sam, Danny, Antony [Mendes, Boyle, Minghella], me. It was a real coal face of creativity, and to have ripped the heart out of that is idiotic, but the government seem unable to see that."

British film industry or no, Frears keeps right on working. He's just directed Fail-Safe, a live-broadcast remake of a 60s cold-war nuke-alert movie for CBS TV in the States, starring George Clooney and Richard Dreyfuss ("David [Hare] said, what about your heart, it was absolute madness, terrific though"), and is currently shooting a Jimmy McGovern script about "fascism, unemployment, and Catholicism," for the BBC in Liverpool. He cheerfully admits to knowing nothing about Catholicism; I wonder if he's addicted to leaps in the dark.

"What it is," he says, "is that I've no talent for making a film about my own life. I made a huge mistake with Sammy & Rosie Get Laid; I set it on the Harrow Road, in my backyard, and all my judgment went out the window. I like to make films about really different worlds, whether that might be the Pakistani community, the Irish, the aristocracy, whatever. I need distance."

As we walk back to Frears's house, we pass a washeteria called, inevitably, My Beautiful Laundrette. "They asked me for my permission," he says. "They even asked if I'd open it." And, for all his England-kills-me-I'm-just-a-glorified-techie protestations, there's just the hint of a gratified smile playing about his lips.

 High Fidelity opens on July 21.
